Sec. 2-82. - Map. 
The city clerk shall cause to be printed a map showing the boundaries of the wards. Said map shall be posted in a conspicuous place in said city clerk's office in plain view of the public. 
(Code 1980, § 2-62; Ord. No. 76-48, § 1, 11-29-1976)  
Sec. 2-83. - Annexations. 
In the event the boundaries of the city are increased by annexation, the area annexed shall become part of the ward adjoining said annexed area. In the event the annexed area adjoins two (2) or more wards, then the city council by ordinances shall designate the portion of the annexed area which is to become a part of each ward. 
(Code 1980, § 2-63; Ord. No. 76-48, § 1, 11-29-1976)  
Secs. 2-84—2-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Power of council to determine its rules of order and procedure, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-11. 
 
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 2-101. - Scope and applicability. 
The provisions of this division shall govern the conduct of meetings of the city council and shall, except for things which by their nature can have no application, also govern the meetings of any committees thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 2-71)  
Sec. 2-102. - Meetings to be public; records. 
The city council shall sit with open doors, except that closed meetings may be held as permitted by 5 ILCS 120/2 and 5 ILCS 120/2a. It shall keep a journal of its own proceedings. 
(Code 1980, § 2-72)  
Sec. 2-103. - Order of business. 
The business of all regular meetings of the city council shall be transacted in the following order: 
(1)  Roll call. 
(2)  Reading of the minutes. 
(3)  Reports of officers. 
(4)  Reports of committees. 
(5)  Acceptance of petitions and communications. 
(6)  Introduction of ordinances and resolutions. 
(7)  Special and unfinished business. 
(8)  New business. 
(9)  Adjournment. 
(Code 1980, § 2-73; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 20; Ord. No. 77-36, § 1, 9-26-1977)  
Sec. 2-104. - Approval of minutes. 
At each city council meeting, the minutes of the preceding meeting shall be approved by a majority of the aldermen present. If no objection is made to the minutes, the same shall be approved. The motion shall be, "I move to accept the minutes of the previous meeting as printed and read." 
(Code 1980, § 2-74; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 20; Ord. No. 77-36, § 1, 9-26-1977)  
Sec. 2-105. - Presiding officer. 
The presiding officer of the city council shall be the mayor or mayor pro tem, whose powers and/or duties during the council meeting shall be as follows: 
(1)  To open the meeting and call the members to order. 
(2)  To call the order of business. 
(3)  To recognize members entitled to the floor. 
(4)  To state and put to vote all questions or motions which are regularly moved or necessarily arise in the course of the proceedings and to announce the result of the vote. 
(5)  To protect the council from frivolous or dilatory action. 
(6)  To restrain the members when engaged in debate within the rules of order. 
(7)  To require the council room cleared in the event of disturbances or disorderly conduct. 
(8)  To assist in the expediting of business in every way compatible with the rights of the council. 
(9)  To preserve decorum. 
(10)  To decide all questions of order, subject to appeal to the council. 
Such powers and duties shall be in addition to all others provided by this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 2-75; Ord. of 1-20-1964, §§ 5, 9) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-14.  
Sec. 2-106. - Right of mayor to make motions or second them; debate. 
The mayor may not move or second motions. He may comment on pending matters being debated. 
(Code 1980, § 2-76; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 7)  
Sec. 2-107. - Chairman pro tem. 
The chairman of the committee on finance of the city council shall be the deputy mayor. In the absence of the chairman of the committee on finance, the most senior alderman shall act as the temporary chairman. In the absence of the chairman of the committee on finance and the most senior alderman, the city council may elect an alderman to act as a temporary chairman. The temporary chairman shall have only the powers of a presiding officer and a right to vote in his capacity as alderman on any ordinance, resolution or motion. The deputy mayor shall assist the mayor on matters as directed by the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-77; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 8; Ord. No. 81-17, § 1, 5-21-1981; Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 5-23-1985; Ord. No. 92-43, § 1, 10-8-1992; Ord. No. 11-7, § 2, 2-24-2011)  
Sec. 2-108. - Sergeant at arms. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to appoint a sergeant at arms to assist him in maintaining decorum. 
(Code 1980, § 2-78; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 9)  
Sec. 2-109. - Quorum; compelling attendance. 
A majority of the city council shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller number, however, may adjourn from time to time, and may compel the attendance of absentees, under whatever penalties, including a fine for a failure to attend, the council may prescribe by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-79; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-12.  
Sec. 2-110. - Voting. 
Every alderman present at a city council meeting shall vote except members having conflicts of interest in the question, who shall ask to and be excused from voting. Any passed or silent vote shall count with the majority. 
(Code 1980, § 2-84; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 15)  
Sec. 2-111. - Roll call vote. 
It shall be the right of any alderman to demand a roll call vote of the city council on any question or motion on the floor. No member shall comment further while a vote is being taken. 
(Code 1980, § 2-85; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 16)  
Sec. 2-112. - Voting by presiding officer. 
The mayor shall not vote in a city council meeting on any ordinance, resolution or motion except where the vote of the aldermen has resulted in a tie, or where one-half (½) of the aldermen elected have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote, or where a vote greater than a majority of the city council is required by state law to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. In each such instance specified, the mayor shall vote. Nothing in this section shall deprive an acting mayor or mayor pro tem from voting in his capacity as alderman, but he shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as acting mayor or mayor pro tem. 
(Code 1980, § 2-86) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30.  
Sec. 2-113. - Reconsideration of vote at special meetings. 
No vote of the city council shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting, unless there are present at the special meeting at least as many aldermen as were present when the vote was taken. 
(Code 1980, § 2-92; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 32) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-55.  
Sec. 2-114. - Deadline for submitting matter for consideration; agenda changes. 
(a)  No petitions, or communications, shall be acted upon by the city council at any meeting which have not been delivered to the city clerk by 12:00 noon on the Thursday preceding any regular council meeting; provided, however, that this provision may be waived by unanimous vote of the city council and provided further, that no changes shall be made on any agenda without unanimous vote of the city council. 
(b)  All ordinances and resolutions presented by the ordinance and resolution committee shall be placed on the agenda for the next council meeting. All ordinances and resolutions shall be posted in the city clerk's office after presentation by the ordinance and resolution committee prior to adoption; provided, however, that a majority vote of the council members present and voting at the meeting may waive the posting of the ordinance or resolution in the clerk's office prior to passage. A majority vote of the council members present and voting at a meeting may direct that an ordinance or resolution be placed on the agenda for that meeting. 
(Code 1970, §§ 2.221, 2.239; Code 1980, § 2-93; Ord. of 2-22-1973, § 1; Ord. of 10-24-1974, § 1; Ord. No. 77-36, § 2, 9-26-1977)  
Sec. 2-115. - Requests for street lighting. 
Any request or petition for a street light installation shall be referred to the committee on public utilities prior to any action by the full city council. The committee on public utilities shall consider said request and consult with representatives of the public utility electric company to determine whether said installation is proper. The committee shall report any action taken in regard to any street light request to the city council. 
(Code 1970, § 2.239; Code 1980, § 2-93.1; Ord. of 7-24-1975, § 1)  
Sec. 2-116. - Withdrawal of motions. 
A motion may not be withdrawn by the mover without consent of the member seconding it. 
(Code 1980, § 2-94; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 22)  
Sec. 2-117. - Stating of motions by chair. 
When a motion is made by an alderman, it shall be stated by the chair, before debate. 
(Code 1980, § 2-95; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 22)  
Sec. 2-118. - Motion for the previous question. 
When the previous question is moved in a city council meeting, and seconded and carried by a majority vote, it shall be voted upon. There shall be no further amendment or debate, but pending amendments shall be put in their order before the main question. 
(Code 1980, § 2-96; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 23)  
Sec. 2-119. - Motion to lay on the table. 
A motion to lay on the table shall preclude all amendments or debate of the subject under consideration and the subject may be resumed only upon motion of a member voting with the majority and with the consent of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members present. 
(Code 1980, § 2-97; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 24)  
Sec. 2-120. - Amendments to ordinances or resolutions generally. 
It shall be in order to amend a proposed ordinance or resolution at any time prior to the voting by the aldermen. 
(Code 1980, § 2-98; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 25)  
Sec. 2-121. - Amendments to strike out and insert. 
On an amendment before the city council to strike out and insert material in a resolution or ordinance, the paragraph to be amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken out and those to be inserted shall be read, and finally, the paragraph as it would stand if so amended shall be read. 
(Code 1980, § 2-99; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 26)  
Sec. 2-122. - Amendments to amendments. 
A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be introduced. 
(Code 1980, § 2-100; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 27)  
Sec. 2-123. - Motion to postpone. 
All motions to postpone may be amended as to time. If a motion to postpone indefinitely is carried, the principal question shall be declared lost. 
(Code 1980, § 2-101; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 28)  
Sec. 2-124. - Motion to adjourn. 
A motion to adjourn shall be in order at any time, except in the following circumstances: 
(1)  When another alderman has the floor. 
(2)  When the aldermen are voting. 
(3)  When adjournment was the last preceding motion. 
(4)  When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken. 
(Code 1980, § 2-102; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 30)  
Sec. 2-125. - Dissents and protests. 
Any member shall have the right to express an opinion or views on any ordinance or any resolution of the city council and have said opinion recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(Code 1980, § 2-103; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 18)  
Sec. 2-126. - Requests for ordinances or resolutions. 
Any council member may move that the ordinances and resolutions committee prepare an ordinance or resolution. Upon approval of such request by the council, the ordinances and resolutions committee shall prepare and submit copies of all proposed ordinances or resolutions as provided in this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-104; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 36)  
Sec. 2-127. - Conduct of aldermen generally. 
During city council meetings, the aldermen shall preserve order and decorum and shall, neither by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings. Aldermen desiring to speak shall address the chair, and upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine themselves to the question under debate and shall avoid all personalities. A council member once recognized, shall not be interrupted while speaking unless called to order by the presiding officer, unless a point of order is raised by another member or unless the speaker chooses to yield to questions from another member. All aldermen desiring to speak shall be heard. 
(Code 1980, § 2-105; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 9)  
Sec. 2-128. - Limits on debate. 
No alderman shall be allowed to speak more than once on the same question, until every other alderman desiring to speak shall have had an opportunity to do so. No alderman shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one (1) time except by consent of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-106; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 14)  
Sec. 2-129. - Seating of members. 
All aldermen shall occupy the respective seats assigned to them by the mayor, but any two (2) or more members may exchange seats by submitting their intentions in writing to the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-107; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 11)  
Sec. 2-130. - Conduct while a member is speaking. 
While an alderman is speaking to the city council, no alderman shall hold any private discourse, or pass between the speaker and the chair. 
(Code 1980, § 2-108; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 14)  
Sec. 2-131. - Personal privilege. 
An alderman shall have the right to address the city council on a question of personal privilege, but said right shall be limited to cases in which his integrity, character or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned. 
(Code 1980, § 2-109; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 17)  
Sec. 2-132. - Impugning other's motive; addressing chair when another speaking. 
When recognized by the chair, a council member shall refrain from impugning the motives of other members' argument or vote. No member shall address the chair or demand the floor while any vote is being taken. 
(Code 1980, § 2-110; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 12)  
Sec. 2-133. - Conduct of public at meetings generally. 
All members of the public attending city council meetings shall observe the same rules of propriety, decorum and good conduct applicable to aldermen. Any person making personal, impertinent, and slanderous remarks, or who becomes boisterous while addressing the council or while attending the council meetings, shall be removed from the room, by the sergeant at arms, if so directed by the presiding officer. In case the presiding officer fails to act, any council member may move to require him to enforce the rules, and by the affirmative vote of the majority present, the council shall require the presiding officer to act. 
(Code 1980, § 2-111; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 9)  
Sec. 2-134. - Conduct of public when addressing council. 
Any member of the public desiring to address the city council may be recognized by the chair, and shall state his name and address in an audible tone, and shall limit his remarks to the question under discussion. All remarks or questions shall be addressed to the presiding officer and not to an alderman. 
(Code 1980, § 2-112; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 9)  
Sec. 2-135. - Appeal from ruling of presiding officer. 
Any alderman may appeal to the city council from a ruling of the presiding officer. The member making the appeal may briefly state his reason for appealing and the presiding officer may briefly state his ruling. There shall be no debate on the appeal, and no other alderman shall participate in the discussion. If a majority of the members present vote to sustain the action of the presiding officer, the ruling of the chair shall be sustained, otherwise, it shall be overruled. 
(Code 1980, § 2-113; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 13)  
Sec. 2-136. - Applicability of Robert's Rules. 
The rules of parliamentary practice contained in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised Edition, shall govern the council in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with this article or state law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-114; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 31)  
Sec. 2-137. - Suspension of rules. 
Except where the provisions of this division are required by state law, the city council may, by a majority vote, vary the rules and procedures contained in this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-115)  
Secs. 2-138—2-160. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Committees 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Standing committees. 
(a)  The following shall be standing committees of the city council: 
(1)  Committee on finance. The finance committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: finance department, purchasing and personnel departments, personnel evaluation and council rules. 
(2)  Committee on public safety. The public safety committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: police department, fire department, civil defense and animal control. 
(3)  Committee on public works. The public works committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: building department, street and alley department, maintenance department, sewer department and public buildings, equipment and property and department for community development and department of inspectional services. 
(4)  Committee on public utilities. The public utilities committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: water department, electrical, plumbing, public lighting systems, natural gas, public telephone systems, railroads and transportation. 
(5)  Committee on health, education and welfare. The health, education and welfare committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: public health department, youth service, senior citizens, library, waterways and housing committee. 
(6)  Committee on ordinances and resolutions. The ordinances and resolutions committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: legal department, ordinances and resolutions, zoning, judiciary and public relations. 
(7)  Committee on permits and licenses. The permits and licenses committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions associated with business permits and licenses. 
(b)  The mayor shall appoint the members of the standing committees, and shall appoint the chairman thereof. Each of the committees shall consist of three (3) members. 
(c)  Each alderman shall be a member of two (2) standing committees and the chairman of one (1) standing committee. Vacancies on any committee shall be filled as herein provided for original appointments. 
(Code 1980, § 2-80; Ord. No. 77-20, § 1, 5-26-1977; Ord. No. 78-23, § 1, 6-8-1978; Ord. No. 78-45, § 1, 10-12-1978; Ord. No. 80-5, § 1, 4-10-1980; Ord. No. 81-16, § 1, 5-14-1981; Ord. No. 85-26, § 1, 7-11-1985; Ord. No. 87-3, § 1, 2-26-1987; Ord. No. 89-16, § 1, 5-11-1989; Ord. No. 11-10, § 2, 2-24-2011; Ord. No. 13-24, § 2, 6-13-2013)  
Sec. 2-162. - Special committees. 
The city council, by majority vote, may appoint special committees. Such committees shall be discharged upon the acceptance of a final report without a vote unless otherwise ordered. 
(Code 1980, § 2-81; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 35; Ord. No. 87-4, § 1, 2-26-1987)  
Sec. 2-163. - Referral of new business to committees; reports. 
All petitions, motions and communications shall be referred to the appropriate committee or committees. Whenever any referred matter shall not have been reported back to the city council by the committee to which referred, within a period of sixty (60) days, the chairman of the committee shall, at the request of any alderman, submit a report in writing to the council at its next regular meeting, giving a brief summary of the proceedings had in said committee, in relation to such referred matter. 
(Code 1980, § 2-82; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 38)  
Sec. 2-164. - Deferment of committee report. 
Upon the request of any two (2) aldermen present at a city council meeting, any report of a committee of the council shall be deferred, for final action thereon, to the next regular meeting of the council after the report is made. 
(Code 1980, § 2-83) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-35.  
Secs. 2-165—2-190. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Legislation 
 
Sec. 2-191. - Passage of certain matters. 
The passage of all ordinances for whatever purposes, and of any resolution or motion to create any liability against the city or for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, shall require the concurrence of a majority of all members then holding office on the city council, including the mayor, unless otherwise expressly provided by state law; provided that, if the council consists of an odd number of aldermen, the vote of the majority of the aldermen shall be sufficient to pass an ordinance. The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the question of the passage of the designated ordinances, resolutions or motions and recorded in the journal of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-87) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-40.  
Sec. 2-192. - Reading and passage of ordinance and resolution. 
It shall not be required prior to adoption, that an ordinance or resolution be read. A motion may be made that the following "ordinance" or the following "resolution" shall be adopted as presented. An ordinance or resolution may be read pursuant to motion adopted by a majority vote of the council members present and voting at the meeting. 
(Code 1980, § 2-87.1; Ord. No. 77-37, § 1, 9-22-1977)  
Sec. 2-193. - Adoption of ordinance at initial presentation. 
No ordinance shall be adopted at the council meeting at which it was initially presented except upon a two-thirds vote of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-88; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 37)  
Sec. 2-194. - Approval and veto of ordinances. 
All resolutions and motions which create any liability against the city, or which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, and all ordinances passed by the city council shall be deposited with the city clerk. If the mayor approves of them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves he shall return to the city council, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the city council occurring not less than five (5) days after their passage. The mayor may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, and, if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the mayor may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation. If the mayor fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(Code 1980, § 2-89) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-45.  
Sec. 2-195. - Passage over veto. 
Every resolution and motion specified in section 2-194 of this Code, and every ordinance which is returned to the city council by the mayor shall be reconsidered by the city council at its next regular meeting. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the aldermen then holding office on the city council shall agree to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the mayor's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the mayor's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal. 
(Code 1980, § 2-90) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-50.  
Sec. 2-196. - Motion for reconsideration generally. 
(a)  A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for reconsideration, having been once made and decided in the negative, shall not be renewed, nor shall a motion to reconsider be reconsidered. 
(b)  A motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by aldermen who voted on the prevailing side of the question to be reconsidered, unless otherwise provided by law; provided, however, that where a motion has received a majority vote in the affirmative, but is declared lost solely on the ground that a greater number of affirmative votes is required by statute for the passage or adoption of such motion, then in such case a motion to reconsider may be made and seconded only by those who voted in the affirmative on such question to be reconsidered. 
(Code 1980, § 2-91; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 29) 
State Law reference— Motions to reconsider, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-55.  
Secs. 2-197—2-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Plumbing inspector, § 14-501 et seq.; fire chief, deputy chief, assistant chief—generally, § 30-33; chief of police—generally, § 46-35; supervisor of records and communications, § 46-48. 
State Law reference— Powers of city with reference to employees generally, 65 ILCS 5/10-4-1. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-231. - Appointments generally. 
(a)  Except as may be otherwise provided by this Code or by state law, all officers shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(b)  Whenever under any ordinance, an officer is appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council, the name of said officer shall be submitted for appointment and confirmation to the city council not later than the last regularly scheduled council meeting in May of each year. 
(c)  In the event the mayor appoints an employee who has worked for the city in excess of three (3) years to head any department of the city or in a supervisory position not covered by any union contract, such employee shall be entitled to return to the position held with the city prior to the appointment as such department head or supervisor in the event such appointment does not receive the consent of the city council or such appointment is not renewed after the term has expired. 
(Code 1980, § 2-16; Ord. No. 78-12, § 1, 4-27-1978; Ord. No. 02-20, 5-23-2002) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5.  
Sec. 2-232. - Term of office of elected officials. 
Elected officials of the city shall serve for a four (4) year terms, according to the method provided by statute. Each elected official, having been duly elected and qualified, shall take office and begin his term at the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities held in the month of May following his election or at a properly-noticed special meeting held in the month of May prior to the first regular meeting. 
(Code 1980, § 2-16.1; Ord. No. 01-17, § 1, 4-26-2001)  
Sec. 2-233. - Commission of office; certificate of appointment. 
Whenever a person has been appointed or elected to a city office, the mayor shall issue a certificate of appointment or election, under the corporate seal, to the city clerk. All officers elected or appointed under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.), except the city clerk, aldermen and mayor shall be commissioned by warrant, under the corporate seal, signed by the city clerk and the mayor, acting mayor, or mayor pro tem. 
(Code 1980, § 2-17)  
Sec. 2-234. - Oath of office. 
(a)  Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all city officers, whether elected or appointed shall take and subscribe the following oath: 
I do solemnly swear (affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States, and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of _______ according to the best of my ability. 
(b)  This oath, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 2-18) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.  
Sec. 2-235. - Bond. 
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all municipal officers, except the aldermen, shall execute a bond with security, to be approved by the mayor and council. The bond shall be payable to the city in whatever penal sum may be directed by resolution or ordinance, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all money received by such officer, according to law and ordinances. Such bond may provide that the obligation of the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure or closing of any bank organized and operating either under the laws of the state or the United States wherein such officer has placed funds in his custody, if the bank has been approved by the city council as a depository for these funds. These bonds shall be filed with the city clerk except the bond of the clerk, which shall be filed with the city treasurer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-19) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30.  
Sec. 2-236. - Salary. 
All city officers and employees shall receive such salary as may be provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-20)  
Sec. 2-237. - Duty to surrender effects of office. 
Within five (5) days after notification and request, any person who has been an officer of the city shall deliver to his successor in office all property, books and effects in his possession, belonging to the city, or appertaining to the office he has held. Upon his refusal to do so, he shall be liable for all the damages caused thereby, and to the penalty prescribed by this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 2-21) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-35.  
Sec. 2-238. - Attendance at council meetings. 
(a)  Any officer, department head or any employee may be requested by the mayor or any alderman to attend a council meeting to discuss matters relating to the city. 
(b)  Any department head may be requested by any council member or city council committee chairman to attend a meeting of the city council committee to discuss matters relative to said person's department, and to discuss matters relative to the city; said department head must attend provided that he is advised of the meeting within a reasonable time. 
(c)  The following department heads shall submit to the city council at the first regular council meeting each month, a monthly report of all activities for the prior month: city clerk/collector, cultural center, Faith Baily Health Center director, purchasing and personnel director, police chief, fire chief, recycling director, animal control department, finance department, building department, water department, housing administration department, street and alley commissioner, community development director and youth and family services department. 
(Code 1980, § 2-23; Ord. of 1-20-1964, § 10; Ord. No. 77-15, § 1, 3-24-1977; Ord. No. 91-26, § 1, 7-11-1991)  
Sec. 2-239. - Armed forces active duty compensation and benefit differential. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Benefits includes salary, based on full-time compensation, plus benefits, including insurance coverage, pension rights, employment and promotional rights, not including overtime, or any other fringe benefit (holidays, vacation, life insurance, sick time, etc.) This compensation, minus the salary paid to the employee by the United States, shall be paid to the employee as specified in this section. 
Duration means the compensation and health benefit to be paid to, or on behalf of, the employee, which shall continue for the duration of his or her active military service. 
Employee for the purposes of this section, means a full-time employee of the city, employed at the time he or she is ordered to active duty. 
(b)  Application. This section and all of its benefits shall only apply to servicemen or women called into active duty because of a war, or peacekeeping mission as declared by the President of the United States. This section shall not apply to employees who enlist, or are on their required reserve status for summer or weekend duty. The employee shall notify the city as to his call to duty and when they anticipate departure. 
(c)  Career status. The benefits of this section may be terminated immediately upon the employee/soldier deciding to stay in the Armed Forces after his/her tour of duty is completed. 
(d)  Military service credit. Any employee of the city, past or present shall be entitled to military service credit pursuant to the rules of the IMRF, and the resolution attached to Ordinance No. 03-63. 
(e)  Pension and seniority protection. Any employee called to active duty shall be considered on "furlough" or "leave of absence" for purposes of his or her pension and seniority. Payments shall continue to be made to any pension fund during this period of "furlough" or "leave of absence." Any employee called to active duty shall be restored to his or her position without loss of seniority or to any other such position as the employee's status would have entitled the employee had the employee been continuously in the active service of the city during the period of such "furlough" or "leave of absence." 
(Ord. No. 03-63, §§ 1—4, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 10-52, § 2, 10-14-2010) 
Editor's note— The Resolution referred to in this section is not set forth herein but can be found on file in the city clerk's office.  
Sec. 2-240. - Indemnification. 
The city hereby authorizes, approves and provides for the indemnification, to the fullest extent permitted by law, and payment of legal defense costs from any and all claims, causes of action and suits of every kind and nature that is associated with the official's term in office for actions brought against an official, in either their individual or official capacity, and incurred or suffered as a result of litigation, provided, however: (1) that the actions taken by the official were on behalf of the city; (2) that the litigation or proceeding against the official was not initiated by the city or state or federal government or agency nor pertains to the defense of any criminal proceeding; or (3) that the litigation or proceeding was not initiated by the official. The city hereby further authorizes, approves and provides an official the ability to retain legal representation of their choosing when a defense is required, desirable, or has been undertaken and shall further hold the official harmless from the payment of any and all reasonable attorney fees (provided, however, that the rate to be paid by the city for such attorney fees shall be no greater than the hourly rate charged by the city attorney) and costs associated with said defense arising as a result of any litigation herein contemplated or costs incurred in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 10-9, § 2, 1-28-2010)  
Secs. 2-241—2-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 2-261. - Residency requirements. 
All officers and employees of the city shall be residents of the City of Calumet City at the time of appointment or employment and, if not, as a condition of appointment or employment, shall become a resident within the city within one (1) year of said appointment or employment. All current and new officers and employees must remain residents of the city during their appointment or employment by the city unless different residency requirements as herinafter set forth apply. These requirements shall not apply to municipal engineers, city attorneys, prosecuting attorneys, special counsel, auditors, architects, economic development coordinator or engineers of the city. Each department head, deputy director, office manager, assistant police chief or deputy fire chief and any other executive level non-union employees shall observe the same residency requirement as the rank and file of their respective departments as more fully set forth in the collective bargaining agreements for employees working in those departments. This section is enacted independent of any negotiated collective bargaining agreement and nothing contained herein is intended to delete from or create any rights relative to any existing collective bargaining agreement. 
(Code 1980, § 2-39; Ord. No. 94-56, § 1, 9-22-1994; Ord. No. 95-30, § 1, 7-13-1995; Ord. No. 11-4, § 3, 1-27-2011; Ord. No. 13-67, § 2, 12-30-2013; Ord. No. 17-13, § 2, 4-27-2017)  
Sec. 2-262. - Violations. 
Any person in violation of the provisions of section 2-261 of this Code shall be subject to suspension or termination after a hearing before the corporate authorities of the city pursuant to notice, at which time and place such person may appear and be given an opportunity to defend themselves. 
(Code 1980, § 2-40; Ord. No. 94-56, § 1, 9-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-263. - Exemptions. 
Any officer or employee, other than policemen or firemen, of the city who reside outside of the city limits at the time of adoption of Ordinance No. 94-56 shall be allowed to remain an officer or employee without being subject to the provisions of sections 2-261 and 2-262 of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 2-41; Ord. No. 94-56, § 1, 9-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-264. - Part-time employees. 
Notwithstanding any provisions of sections 2-261, 2-262 and 2-263, all part-time employees, current and new, of the city shall be residents of the city and remain residents during their employment. 
(Code 1980, § 2-42; Ord. No. 94-56, § 1, 9-22-1994)  
Secs. 2-265—2-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ETHICAL CONDUCT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, adopted May 13, 2004, amended division 3 of article IV of chapter 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former division 3, §§ 2-291—2-295, pertained to the local gift ban and was derived from Code 1980, §§ 2-43—2-47; and Ord. No. 99-32, § 1, adopted June 10, 1999. 
 
Sec. 2-291. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Campaign for effective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state or local public office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities: 
(1)  Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; 
(2)  Relating to collective bargaining; or 
(3)  That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code (5 ILCS 5/1-3). 
Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this chapter, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, compensated time includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location. 
Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
Contribution has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
Employee means a person employed by the City of Calumet City, on a full-time or part-time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
Employer means the City of Calumet City. 
Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive: 
(1)  Compensation for employment; 
(2)  Service credit towards pension benefits; and 
(3)  Health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
Officer means a person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities: 
(1)  Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; 
(2)  Relating to collective bargaining; or 
(3)  That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the State Board of Elections or a county clerk under section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the State Board of Elections or a county clerk. 
Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable voter outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 5-13-2004)  
Sec. 2-292. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time, as defined herein. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the City of Calumet City in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 
(1)  As part of that officer or employee's duties; 
(2)  As a condition of employment; or 
(3)  During any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this division. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party, or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 5-13-2004)  
Sec. 2-293. - Gift ban. 
(a)  Except as permitted by this section, no officer or employee and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipients") shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source, as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer to make a gift that violates this section. 
(b)  This section is not applicable to the following: 
(1)  Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public. 
(2)  Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or immediate family member, pays the fair market value. 
(3)  Any (i) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code or (ii) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political organization or candidate. 
(4)  Educational materials and missions. 
(5)  Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business. 
(6)  A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee. 
(7)  Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: 
a.  The history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; 
b.  Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and 
c.  Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gifts to other officers or employees or their spouses or immediate family members. 
(8)  Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or refreshments are consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared or catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means. 
(9)  Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances. 
(10)  Intra-governmental and inter-governmental gifts. For the purpose of this division, "intra-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee from another officer or employee, and "inter-governmental" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another governmental entity. 
(11)  Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death. 
(12)  Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Each of the exceptions listed in this subsection is mutually exclusive and independent of every other. 
(c)  An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this section if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered, or succeeded. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 5-13-2004)  
Sec. 2-294. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-292 may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary or a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(b)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-293 is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(c)  Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this division to the local enforcement authorities, the state's attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,500.00). 
(d)  A violation of section 2-292 shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the City of Calumet City by filing in the circuit court an information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. 
(e)  A violation of section 2-293 may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the City of Calumet City. 
(f)  In additional to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of sections 2-292 or 2-293 is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 5-13-2004)  
Secs. 2-295—2-330. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - CITY COLLECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-361. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of city collector. 
(Code 1980, § 2-139; Ord. of 2-24-1966, § 1)  
Sec. 2-362. - Clerk to serve. 
The city clerk shall hold the office of city collector. 
(Code 1980, § 2-140; Ord. of 2-24-1966, § 1) 
State Law reference— Power of city to require clerk to be collector, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-135.  
Sec. 2-363. - Bond. 
The city collector, before assuming his office, shall post a bond in an amount prescribed by the city council and with sureties approved by it. 
(Code 1980, § 2-141; Ord. of 2-24-1966, § 3) 
State Law reference— Bond, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30.  
Sec. 2-364. - Turning over of moneys. 
Not less than once per week the city collector shall turn over to the city treasurer all money collected by him from any source whatsoever, taking said treasurer's receipt therefor in duplicate and filing one of the receipts immediately with the city clerk. At that time, or on demand, the city collector shall obtain a copy of any receipts so filed from the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 2-142; Ord. of 2-24-1966, § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-120.  
Sec. 2-365. - Annual financial statement; publication. 
(a)  Between the first and tenth of April of each year, the city collector shall file with the city clerk a statement of all the money collected by him during the year, the particular warrant, special assessment or account on which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in his possession and the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all warrants which he returned to the city clerk during the preceding fiscal year. 
(b)  The city clerk shall publish said statement at least once within ten (10) days in one or more newspapers published in the city or in one or more newspapers with a general circulation within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-143; Ord. of 2-24-1966, §§ 3, 4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-125.  
Sec. 2-366. - Other duties. 
In addition to the duties prescribed hereinbefore, the city collector shall perform the following additional duties: 
(1)  Preserving all warrants returned to him. 
(2)  Keeping his books and accounts in the manner prescribed by the city council. 
(3)  Presenting all warrants, books, vouchers and papers pertaining to his office for examination at any time to the mayor, city clerk or any member or committee of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-144; Ord. of 2-24-1966, § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-120.  
Secs. 2-367—2-400. - Reserved.
