DIVISION 11. - INDEPENDENT INSPECTOR GENERAL[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-65, §§ 1—11, adopted Nov. 10, 2011, amended Div. 11 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Div. 11, §§ 2-500.1—2.500.11, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 07-58, §§ 1—11, adopted May 17, 2007; Ord. No. 07-67, §§ 1—11, adopted June 14, 2007. 
 
Sec. 2-500.1. - Inspector general establishment. 
There is hereby established an office of city government (city) to be known as the office of independent inspector general (OIIG). The independent inspector general shall head the OIIG. The organization and administration of the OIIG shall be sufficiently independent to assure that no interference or influence external to the office adversely affects the independence and objectivity of the independent inspector general. The OIIG shall include an inspector general and such deputies, assistants and other employees as may be provided in the annual appropriation ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 1, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.2. - Qualifications, appointment and term. 
(a)  The independent inspector general shall be a person who has at least one (1) of the following characteristics: 
(1)  At least ten (10) years of federal, state, or local government experience as a law enforcement officer, judge, or government attorney. 
(2)  Progressive supervisory experience in an investigative public agency similar to an inspector general's office. 
(3)  Has managed and completed complex investigations involving allegations of fraud, theft, deception, or conspiracy. 
(4)  Has demonstrated the ability to work with local, state and federal law enforcement agencies and the judiciary. 
(b)  The independent inspector general shall have a four-year degree from an accredited institution of higher learning or the equivalent law enforcement experience. 
(c)  The independent inspector general shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 2, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.3. - Purpose of office. 
The purpose of the office of independent inspector general is to detect, deter and prevent corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination or misconduct in the operations of city government. Additionally, the OIIG shall assist the city attorney and the other departments in the city as called upon by the mayor or city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 3, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.4. - Functions, authority and powers; duties. 
In addition to other powers conferred herein, the OIIG shall have the following functions, authority and powers: 
(1)  To receive and register complaints and information concerning corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination and misconduct in the operations of city government; including, but not limited to any city contract, grant, lease, license, or application or certification of eligibility for the same; all city employees, departments, bureaus, boards, agencies, agents, or independent contractors; and appointed officials, in the performance of their official duties; contractors and subcontractors providing goods and services pursuant to a city contract; and all persons and business entities seeking city contracts or certification of eligibility for city contracts. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the OIIG shall have no power or authority over, or relating to matters concerning, the corporate authorities. 
(2)  To investigate litigation filed against the city at the direction of the mayor and/or city attorney or city prosecutor. 
(3)  To promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of investigations consistent with the requirements of equal protection, due process and this division. 
(4)  To request information from and to conduct interviews under oath with city employees, officials, agents, contractors, sub-contractors, licensees, grantees or persons or businesses seeking city contracts, grants, licenses, or certification of eligibility for city contracts, for the purpose of investigation of corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement or misconduct. This includes the power to review past, present, and proposed city programs, accounts, records, contracts and transactions. 
(5)  To prepare confidential reports and make recommendations for corrective action as outlined in section 2-500.5. 
(6)  To notify the state's attorney or other appropriate law enforcement authority if the independent inspector general determines or suspects that possible criminal conduct has occurred, and to promptly tender to such authorities any evidence or information which has been obtained by the independent inspector general. In the event an investigation by the OIIG threatens to interfere with an investigation by a different county, city, state, or federal law enforcement agency, the OIIG will cooperate in all respects with such law enforcement agency. The OIIG shall acquiesce in its investigation only upon written request of another law enforcement agency. 
(7)  To serve as liaison between city government and law enforcement authorities regarding any matters which have been referred to such authorities by the independent inspector general. 
(8)  To provide quarterly reports to the mayor and members of the city council as outlined in section 2-500.7. 
(9)  To create and maintain a toll-free office of the independent inspector general hotline for the purpose of receiving citizen and employee reports of corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination and misconduct. The identity of any individual placing a call to the office of the inspector general hotline shall be kept confidential during and after the investigation of any complaint made by the caller, unless the caller consents to disclosure of his or her name or disclosure of the caller's identity is otherwise required by law. Alternatively, reports may be made anonymously. 
(10)  The independent inspector general shall be able to request such assistants, employees and personnel and establish personnel procedures as deemed necessary for the efficient and effective administration of the OIIG. The request shall be subject to budgetary approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 4, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.5. - Cooperation. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all city employees, officials, agents, contractors, sub-contractors, licensees, grantees or persons or businesses seeking city contracts, grants, licenses, or certification of eligibility for city contracts, to cooperate with the OIIG in the conduct of investigations undertaken pursuant to this division. Every city contract and every bid, proposal, application or solicitation for a city contract and every application for certification of eligibility for a city contract or program shall contain a statement that the person, individually and on behalf of the applicant, will abide by all provisions of this division. It shall be unlawful for any person subject to this section to refuse to cooperate with the independent inspector general as required by this section. The penalty for such violation shall be governed by section 2-500.11. 
(b)  All persons with whom the OIIG requests an interview are required to comply in a timely fashion. Within constitutional limitations, failure by any city employee, official, agent, contractor, sub-contractor, licensee, grantee or person or business seeking city contracts, grants, licenses, or certification of eligibility for city contracts, to cooperate with any reasonable request by the OIIG carries the threat of sanctions and/or criminal contempt proceedings, and any other penalties the city council has within its scope to assess. 
(c)  Nothing in this compliance section may be interpreted to allow the OIIG to violate any individual's constitutional rights, including the 5th Amendment right against self-incrimination. 
(d)  It is the duty of every employee, department and elected official to cooperate with the independent inspector general in any investigation or hearing. Each department's premises, equipment, personnel, books, records and papers shall be made readily available to the independent inspector general. 
(e)  The IIG may make recommendations regarding city departments to the mayor and city council. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of every employee of the city to report, directly and without undue delay, to the independent inspector general any and all information concerning conduct which they know to involve corruption, allegations of political discrimination in non-exempt positions or other criminal activity, by another city employee or official, which concerns his or her office of employment. The knowing failure of any employee to report as required above shall constitute cause for discipline up to and including termination. For purposes of this division, a report made to the inspector general hotline shall be considered a direct report. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 5, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.6. - Subpoenas. 
The independent inspector general with the advice and cooperation of the city attorney and/or city prosecutor shall be authorized to issue subpoenas to request documents or testimony related to an investigation authorized by this division. Subpoenas shall be served in the manner provided under the Rules of the Illinois Supreme Court and shall identify the person to whom the subpoena is directed and the documents or items sought, stating the date, time and place for appearance of the witness and production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena. In no event shall the date for appearance or production be less than seven (7) days after service of the subpoena. No later than the time for appearance or production requested by subpoena, the person to whom the subpoena is directed may object to the subpoena in whole or in part. The independent inspector general shall consider the grounds for the objection and may resolve the objection through negotiation. No documents or testimony may be sought from representatives of labor organizations relating to the function of representing an employee subject to investigation, or for documents or information which are privileged or confidential under state or federal law, including but not limited to documents or information maintained under the Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities Confidentiality Act. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 6, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.7. - Quarterly reports. 
No later than the fifteenth day of January, April, July and October of each year, the independent inspector general shall submit to the mayor and city council, a publicly available report, accurate as of the last day of the preceding month, indicating: 
(1)  The number and type of investigations initiated, concluded, or pending since the date of the last report. 
(2)  The number and type of investigations of the conduct (corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination or misconduct) of any city employee, appointed officials, elected officials, contractors, subcontractors, persons seeking city contracts, or persons seeking certification of eligibility for city contracts or other city programs. 
(3)  The number of and types of investigations conducted by the OIIG regarding employees under the separately elected officials. 
(4)  The number and type of recommendations made to any department heads or elected official and whether or not the recommendation was followed. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 7, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.8. - Summary reports. 
Upon conclusion of any investigation, the independent inspector general shall submit a confidential summary report to the mayor, the appropriate head of any department whose office the investigation pertains, and to the purchasing agent in the case of a sustained finding regarding a contractor, subcontractor, applicant for a contract, or person seeking certification of eligibility for a contract. If the independent inspector general has conducted any investigations regarding the office, or an employee, contractor or subcontractor the independent inspector general also shall submit the confidential summary report to the elected official. 
(1)  The report shall include the following: 
a.  A description of any complaints or other information received by the independent inspector general pertinent to the investigation. 
b.  A description of any illegal conduct, corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination, misconduct, or inefficiencies observed or discovered in the course of the investigation. 
c.  Recommendations for correction of any illegal conduct, corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination, misconduct, or inefficiencies described in the report and a timeline for corrective action. 
d.  Such other information as the independent inspector general may deem relevant to the investigation or resulting recommendations. 
(2)  The report shall not mention the name of any informant, complainant, witness, or person investigated, except in the following instances: 
a.  Where the copy of the report given to the head of any department or agency recommends disciplinary action against an employee of that agency. 
b.  Where the copy of the report given to the purchasing agent makes recommendations concerning any contractor, subcontractor, applicant for a contract, or person seeking certification of eligibility for a contract. 
c.  Where the copy of the report given to the head of a department or agency makes recommendation concerning a person seeking certification of eligibility of a program administered by the department or agency. 
d.  Where the copy given to the mayor recommends disciplinary action against the head or any employee of any executive department or agency. 
(3)  If any investigation is not concluded within one hundred eighty (180) days after its initiation, the independent inspector general shall notify the mayor and city council of the general nature of the complaint or information giving rise to the investigation and the reasons for failure to complete the investigation within one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 8, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.9. - Confidentiality. 
Investigatory files and summary reports concerning alleged corruption, fraud, waste, mismanagement, unlawful political discrimination or misconduct by any person shall be confidential. 
(1)  Summary reports shall not be divulged by the independent inspector general to any person except to the mayor and the head of any department whose office the investigation pertains, the accused, purchasing agent where applicable and to the separately elected official to whose office the investigation pertains. 
(2)  Investigatory files shall be confidential, however, said files may be divulged with the summary report to the head of any department and elected official to whose office the investigation pertains in order to effectively address matters of discipline or ethical violations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, information or evidence obtained by the independent inspector general which pertains to possible criminal activity shall be may be promptly provided to the appropriate law enforcement authorities. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 9, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.10. - Removal of independent inspector general. 
The independent inspector general may be removed prior to the expiration of his term only for cause and in accordance with the provisions of this section. The mayor shall give written notice to the city council of intent to remove the independent inspector general, stating the cause for removal. A copy of the notice shall be served upon the independent inspector general. Within ten (10) days of receipt, the independent inspector general may file with the city council a request for hearing on the cause for removal. If no such request is made within ten (10) days, the independent inspector general shall be deemed to have resigned his office as of the tenth day after receipt of notice. If a request for hearing is made, the city council shall convene a hearing on the cause for removal of the independent inspector general, at which the independent inspector general may appear and be heard. The hearing shall be convened within fourteen (14) days after the request and shall be concluded within fourteen (14) days thereafter. The hearing shall be conducted in closed session with notice given in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.). The mayor's notice of cause for removal shall constitute the charge against the independent inspector general. Removal of the independent inspector general shall require the affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the city council then holding office. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 10, 11-10-2011)  
Sec. 2-500.11. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this division for any person to: 
(1)  Retaliate against, punish, harass, threaten or penalize any other person for communicating, cooperating or assisting the independent inspector general in the performance of duties. 
(2)  Interfere, obstruct or attempt to interfere or obstruct an investigation conducted by the independent inspector general. 
(b)  In addition to all other available remedies, civil and criminal, the following penalties shall apply to violations of this division: 
(1)  Any city employee who is found to have willfully violated this division as provided in section 2-500.5 or subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including discharge. Disciplinary action shall be instituted in accordance with procedures applicable to the employee, including, but not limited to, those established by the collective bargaining agreements, employee manuals, handbooks or at-will practice of the employer. 
(2)  Any agent, independent contractor or appointed official found to have willfully violated this division as provided in section 2-500.5 or subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to removal. 
(3)  Any contractor, subcontractor, grantee, lessee or licensee under a city contract, grant, lease or license, found to have willfully violated this division as provided in section 2-500.5 or subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to termination of existing contracts, grants, leases or licenses, and/or ineligibility from consideration for future city contracts, grants, leases or licenses for a period not to exceed two (2) years. 
(4)  Any person or business entity seeking city contracts or certification of eligibility for city contracts or participation in any city program found to have willfully violated this division shall be subject to ineligibility from consideration for future city contracts, grants, leases, licenses, or programs for a period not to exceed two (2) years. 
(5)  Any person found to have willfully violated section 2-500.5 shall also be subject to a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Actions seeking the imposition of a fine shall be filed as quasi-criminal actions subject to the provisions of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 11-65, § 11, 11-10-2011)  
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-501. - Holidays for certain employees. 
(a)  The following shall be legal holidays for all employees of the city hereinafter designated: 
New Year's Day. 
Lincoln's Birthday. 
Washington's Birthday. 
Memorial Day. 
Good Friday. 
Independence Day. 
Labor Day. 
Columbus Day. 
Veterans Day. 
Thanksgiving Day. 
Friday following Thanksgiving. 
Christmas Day. 
The city council annually shall designate the date on which the city shall observe such holidays. 
(b)  The term "employee," as used herein, shall mean any person giving his full time services to the city for which payment is made in the form of wages or salaries and devotes no less than a minimum of thirty (30) hours per week. Any employee who is eligible for holiday benefits, and who is required to work on a day designated as a city holiday, shall receive straight time pay in addition to regular pay for that day. Any employee who is eligible for an unworked holiday and does not work on the holiday shall be paid his regular wages. This section shall not apply to policemen, firemen or personnel under a union contract. 
(Code 1980, § 2-24; Ord. No. 77-1, § 1, 1-27-1977; Ord. No. 78-16, § 1, 4-27-1978; Ord. No. 81-1, § 1, 1-8-1981)  
Secs. 2-502—2-520. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - VACATION AND OTHER LEAVE 
 
Sec. 2-521. - Scope. 
Except as otherwise provided, the provisions of this division shall not apply to members of the police and fire departments, nor any other departments or employees governed by a union contract whenever any state statutes or contracts are contrary or inconsistent to it. In such cases such applicable state statutes or union contracts shall govern. 
(Code 1980, § 2-31; Ord. of 10-8-1964, § 5.1)  
Sec. 2-522. - Roster. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of each head of each department to maintain a roster of employees who have taken any leave in accordance with any terms and conditions of this division. 
(b)  A copy of the roster will be delivered to the office of the city clerk on or before the tenth and twenty-fifth day of each month covering the prior payroll period. 
(Code 1980, § 2-32; Ord. of 10-8-1964, §§ 6.1, 6.2)  
Sec. 2-523. - Vacations. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this division, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
Employee: means any person giving his full-time service to the city for which payment is made in the form of wages or salaries. 
Full-time employee: means any employee who devotes his services to the city for not less than thirty (30) hours per week. 
Vacation of two (2) weeks, three (3) weeks, four (4) weeks or five (5) weeks. Vacation time respectively equivalent to the number of regularly scheduled work hours in a period of fourteen (14), twenty-one (21), twenty-eight (28) or thirty-five (35) days. 
(b)  Eligibility. An employee who completes one (1) year of continuous service with the city shall be entitled to two (2) weeks vacation each calendar year until the year in which he completes his fourth year. An employee who completes five (5) years of continuous service with the city shall be entitled to three (3) weeks vacation each calendar year until the year in which he completes his ninth year. An employee who completes ten (10) years of continuous service with the city shall be entitled to four (4) weeks vacation each calendar year thereafter. An employee who completes fifteen (15) years of continuous service with the city shall be entitled to five (5) weeks vacation each calendar year thereafter. 
(c)  Maximum amount. Five (5) weeks is the maximum paid vacation to which any city employee shall be entitled. 
(d)  Minimum period. No vacation period shall be for less than one (1) week except upon prior approval of the department head. 
(e)  Cumulation. Vacation periods shall not be cumulative and must be completed within the calendar year. 
(f)  Prior approval. No vacation shall be taken unless approved by the head of the department, except that heads of departments shall seek the approval of the mayor. 
(g)  Seniority preference. Employees shall be entitled to vacation period preference by seniority. 
(Code 1980, § 2-33; Ord. of 10-8-1964, §§ 1.1, 1.2; Ord. No. 81-32, § 1, 10-8-1981)  
Sec. 2-524. - Sick leave and funeral leave. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this section, the term employee shall mean any person giving his full-time services to the city for which payment is made in the form of wages or salaries and who devotes no less than thirty (30) hours per week to said employment. 
(b)  Eligibility. An employee must be employed one year, with a minimum of fifteen hundred (1,500) hours of service, before he is eligible for sick leave. Upon completion of the first continuous year of service an employee shall immediately be credited with twelve (12) days sick leave. 
(c)  Waiting period. Except as provided herein, there shall be a three (3) day waiting period. A three (3) day waiting period shall not be applicable if the employee is hospitalized during any part of his absence, or if the employee, upon return to work, produces a certification by a licensed physician showing that the employee had been under the care of said physician from the first day of illness or injury which rendered him unfit to work during his absence. 
(d)  Physician's certificate. An employee must present a physician's certificate if absent for more than three (3) days. 
(e)  Computation. Sick leave shall be computed on a continuous basis and shall accumulate at the rate of one eight (8) hour working day per month to a maximum of sixty (60) eight (8) hour working days. 
(f)  Reasons allowable. Sick leave pay may be granted to a city employee for: 
(1)  Absence from duty because of personal illness. 
(2)  Legal quarantine in accordance with local and state health regulations. 
(g)  Reasons not allowable. Sick leave pay will not be granted: 
(1)  While the employee is on vacation, suspension, layoff or leave of absence. 
(2)  When an employee leaves the city employment under a retirement plan. 
(3)  In case of sickness or disability directly or indirectly due to intoxication, use of stimulants or drugs or narcotics, unless prescribed by a licensed physician; nor in cases of unlawful acts, immoralities, fighting, (unless in self-defense against unprovoked assaults) nor the willful intent on the part of an employee to injure himself or another. 
(h)  Funeral leave. A maximum of five (5) days leave may be granted in case of death in the employee's immediate family or spouse's family in order to attend the funeral. Proof of death shall be presented. As used in this subsection, immediate family shall mean the husband, wife, children, stepchildren, father, mother, sister, brother, grandparent, mother-in-law or father-in-law. 
(i)  Laid off employees. An employee who is laid off from his position for reasons that are not discreditable to him, may, if reappointed within twelve (12) months, have available for his necessary use any unused sick leave existing at the time of his lay off. 
(j)  Notice. If sick, an employee shall notify his department head no later than one (1) hour after he is to begin his regular duties. 
(k)  Not a right. Sick leave shall not be considered a right which an employee may use at his discretion, but shall be allowed only in the case of injury or sickness of an employee. 
(l)  Examination and investigations. An employee shall permit a physician designated by the city to make such examination as may be necessary in order to determine the employee's condition. The city may rely upon the findings of such physician in deciding whether an employee shall be given sick-leave benefits, and any decision of the city based on its findings shall be final, or the city may make a final decision in its discretion based upon such other investigations as it may decide upon. An employee shall give correct information to the physician or to others designated by the city to make investigations concerning his sickness or disability. 
(m)  Alternative work. If an employee is unable to perform his normal duties due to a temporary sickness or disability, but in the opinion of a physician designated by the city is able to perform light work or work of a different nature, in the same department, he shall be assigned such other work whenever it is available. No sick-leave benefits shall be paid if the employee is unable to perform his regular duties and refuses to perform light work or work of a different nature, when in the opinion of a physician designated by the city he is able to do so. 
(n)  Accumulation. Officers and employees who are in the service of the city, and are eligible for sick leave, as of October 8, 1964, shall be entitled to an accumulation of sick leave days as follows: 
Years of service 	Eight-hour working days allowed 
20 and over ..... 	60 
Over 15, less than 20 ..... 	50 
Over 10, less than 15 ..... 	40 
Over 5, less than 10 ..... 	30 
Over 2, less than 5 ..... 	20 
Over 1, less than 2 ..... 	12 
 
(Code 1980, § 2-34; Ord. of 10-8-1964, §§ 2.1—2.10; Ord. No. 85-12, § 1, 3-14-1985)  
Sec. 2-525. - Injury leave. 
(a)  Defined. Injury leave as distinguished from sick leave shall mean leave allowed to an employee due to absence from duty because of an accident or injury that occurred in the line of duty and during his normal work period. 
(b)  Reports of injury. If an employee is injured in the line of duty and during his normal work period, he must report to his department head immediately no matter how slight the injury. 
(c)  Application for other benefits. An employee who is injured and unable to work shall apply for workmen's compensation, or any other compensation he is entitled to either by contract, agreement or statute. 
(d)  Payments. If a physician designated by the city certifies that an employee's injuries prevent him from working, he will be eligible to receive full regular pay for a period of three (3) months, except that members of the police and fire departments shall be eligible to receive full regular pay for a period of six (6) months arising out of a single injury or occurrence. 
(e)  Other compensation. An employee's full pay received from the city shall be subject to the deduction of any compensation as may be derived from workmen's compensation or any other compensation received as a result of employment by the city. 
(f)  Alternative work. Benefits shall not be paid if the employee is unable to perform his regular duties and refuses to perform light work or work of a different nature when in the opinion of a physician designated by the city he is able to do so. 
(g)  Extension of benefits. Benefits may be extended for not more than an additional six (6) month period by approval of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-35; Ord. of 10-8-1964, §§ 3.1—3.5)  
Sec. 2-526. - Leaves of absence—Generally. 
(a)  With pay. Leave of absence, with pay, may be granted by the mayor, with the consent of the city council, to permit an employee to attend professional meetings or conferences in the interest of the city. 
(b)  Without pay. A leave without pay, for not more than sixty (60) days, may be granted by the department head and the mayor when requested by an employee when such leave is deemed to be justified. Any requests for a leave period beyond sixty (60) days shall be submitted to the city council for approval. 
(c)  Written request. A written request for leave of absence must be submitted to the department head for his approval and forwarded to the city council where applicable. 
(Code 1980, § 2-36; Ord. of 10-8-1964, §§ 4.1—4.3)  
Sec. 2-527. - Same—Computation of fringe benefits. 
(a)  It is hereby established that all employees of the city who shall be granted leave of absence in accordance with the ordinance in such case made and provided shall be paid as follows: 
(1)  Clothing allowance. The clothing allowance provided by ordinance shall be paid on a fiscal year basis, pro rata, according to the period worked in the prior fiscal year. 
(2)  Longevity. Any person on leave of absence shall not accumulate longevity time. 
(3)  Seniority. Any person on leave of absence shall not accumulate seniority time. 
(4)  Insurance premiums. Any employee granted a leave of absence shall pay in advance their proportionate share of insurance premiums, to conform with current insurance policy provisions, to cover the period of leave of absence granted. 
(5)  Holiday and holiday pay. An employee granted a leave of absence shall not be entitled to receive holiday pay nor credited for a holiday compensatory day when such holiday occurs within the leave of absence period. 
(6)  Vacations. Any vacation that an employee is entitled to must be taken at the beginning of the leave of absence period; provided, however, that no vacation or sick leave time will accrue during the leave of absence period. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, in computing the exact date that an individual is entitled to fringe benefits, the date provided for said fringe benefits shall be fiscal year date, annual year date, or the individual anniversary year date of the employee as provided by the specific ordinance in each case. 
(Code 1980, § 2-37; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 7-12-1979)  
Sec. 2-528. - Accounting of accrued sick leave, vacation time and holidays. 
The city treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to account for accrued sick leave, vacation time and holidays for city employees, including superintendents and department heads, in accordance with federal and state requirements and regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 2-38; Ord. No. 85-14, § 1, 4-25-1985)  
Secs. 2-529—2-565. - Reserved.

The department of finance shall be composed of the elected city treasurer, a bookkeeper and such other personnel as shall from time to time be designated by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-189; Ord. of 4-30-1965, § 2)  
Sec. 2-663. - Supervisor. 
The elected city treasurer shall be supervisor of all employees in the department of finance and all such employees shall perform their duties subject to his directions. 
(Code 1980, § 2-190; Ord. of 4-30-1965, § 3)  
Sec. 2-664. - Departmental duties. 
In addition to the duties prescribed in this article, the city treasurer and all personnel in the department of finance shall perform such other duties as may be required by ordinance, all to the end that the purposes of the department of finance shall be faithfully and efficiently administered and carried out. 
(Code 1980, § 2-191; Ord. of 4-30-1965, § 5)  
Sec. 2-665. - General duties of treasurer. 
The city treasurer shall present to the city council regular reports covering the work of the finance department for which he is responsible, together with such other reports as may be required by the city council and mayor. He shall act in an advisory capacity to the council in financial matters and at the end of each fiscal year, he shall assist the council in the preparation of a budget estimate of income and expenditures of the ensuing year. 
(Code 1980, § 2-192; Ord. of 4-30-1965, § 4)  
Secs. 2-666—2-690. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Director 
 
Sec. 2-691. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of director of finance. Said director shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. The person appointed as director of finance shall possess a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university and shall be a certified public accountant. Said position may be filled on a part-time basis or by an independent contractor as needed. 
(Code 1980, § 2-201; Ord. No. 90-2, § 1, 1-25-1990)  
Sec. 2-692. - Compensation. 
Any person appointed as director of finance on a full-time basis shall receive such compensation as established from time to time by the city council. Any person appointed as director of finance on a part-time basis or as an independent contractor shall be paid an hourly rate of thirty dollars ($30.00) per hour; provided, however, that any person appointed between the effective date of this division and April 30, 1990, shall not be paid an amount of money which exceeds five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) unless approved by the city council prior to exceeding said five-thousand-dollar ($5,000.00) limit. 
(Code 1980, § 2-202; Ord. No. 90-2, § 1, 1-25-1990)  
Secs. 2-693—2-710. - Reserved.

(Code 1980, § 2-269; Ord. No. 96-40, § 1, 7-11-1996; Ord. No. 03-48, § 1, 9-10-2003; Ord. No. 07-123, § 3, 12-13-2007)

DIVISION 5. - HEALTH, YOUTH AND FAMILY SERVICES DEPARTMENT  
Subdivision I. - In General

(Code 1980, §§ 2-308, 2-315; Ord. of 10-12-1972, § 1; Ord. No. 80-31, § 1, 12-11-1980; Ord. No. 03-50, §§ 1, 3, 9-10-2003)

Subdvision II. - Commissioner of Health[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 38. 
 
Sec. 2-743. - Qualifications. 
The commissioner of health shall be a licensed physician, in good standing with the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation. 
(Ord. No. 04-72, § 2, 10-14-2004)  
Sec. 2-744. - Office created. 
There is hereby created the office of commissioner of health, an executive office of the city. He/She shall be appointed by the mayor and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-336; Ord. No. 04-72, § 1, 10-14-2004)  
Sec. 2-745. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the commissioner of health to enforce all ordinances containing provisions for the protection of public health. He shall advise the director of health, as well as the city health inspector, of issues concerning public health. 
(b)  He shall oversee all immunization programs for the residents of this city, which shall include, but not be limited to, well-baby clinics. In addition, it shall be the duty of the commissioner of health to coordinate, in conjunction with the director of health, the implementation of state mandated vaccinations to school-aged children through combined initiatives with the city public school nurses in an effort to bridge the gap between health and education. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the commissioner of health to educate the residents of this city on chronic prevalent diseases common to the community, i.e., including but not limited to hypertension, diabetes, and obesity; and he shall govern the implementation of community health initiatives including the creation of appropriate health-related support groups. 
(d)  He shall perform any other duties and functions that may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-337; Ord. No. 04-72, § 3, 10-14-2004)  
Sec. 2-746. - Reports. 
The commissioner of health shall make such reports to the city council as may be required. He shall also make recommendations for rulings, orders or ordinances respecting the public health whenever he is requested to do so, or whenever he deems it necessary or advisable. 
(Code 1980, § 2-338)  
Sec. 2-747. - Powers. 
(a)  The commissioner of health shall exercise general supervision over the health of the city with full power to make such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the rules of the state department of public health. 
(b)  He shall govern the prevention, restriction, and suppression of contagious and infectious diseases in accordance with the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations of the state department of public health. 
(Code 1980, § 2-339; Ord. No. 81-43, § 3, 12-10-1981; Ord. No. 04-72, § 4, 10-14-2004)  
Secs. 2-748—2-762. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Director of the Health Center and Youth and Family Services 
 
Sec. 2-763. - Position created; appointment. 
There is hereby created the position of director of the health center and youth and family services of the health department. Said person shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1970, § 7.1001; Code 1980, § 2-346; Ord. No. 76-13, § 1, 6-10-1976; Ord. No. 03-50, § 5, 9-10-2003)  
Sec. 2-764. - Reports. 
The director of the health center and youth and family services shall present to the city council monthly reports and mandatory quarterly reports as requested by the Illinois Law Enforcement Commission together with such other special reports as may be requested by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-312; Ord. of 10-12-1972, § 1; Ord. No. 03-50, § 4, 9-10-2003)  
Sec. 2-765. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The director of the health center and youth and family services shall have supervision over all persons under his jurisdiction. The director shall have the power to employ those qualified and necessary persons and the power to discharge said personnel. 
(b)  The director of the health center and youth and family services shall perform such duties as are necessary to the end that the purposes and policies of the mayor and city council shall be faithfully and efficiently administered and carried out in regard to those services necessary to promote the general welfare, conduct and assistance regarding the youth of the city. The director shall utilize the services and coordinate the activities of the health, youth and family services department with the police department and all public and private agencies necessary to implement a complete program regarding youth and related activities, including but not limited to drug prevention, recreation and counseling. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the director of the health center and youth and family services to be in charge and responsible for the health center and personnel employed therein. The health commissioner and the director of the health center and youth and family services shall mutually cooperate with each other for the good and welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 7.1003; Code 1980, §§ 2-311, 2-313, 2-348; Ord. of 10-12-1972 § 1; Ord. No. 76-13, § 1, 6-10-1976; Ord. No. 80-31, § 1, 2-11-1980; Ord. No. 03-50, §§ 4, 5, 7, 9-10-2003)  
Secs. 2-766—2-781. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - DEPARTMENT OF ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 2-782. - Established. 
There is hereby established the department of ethics and professional standards. 
(Ord. No. 03-51, § 1, 9-10-2003)  
Sec. 2-783. - Director. 
(a)  Appointment. The department shall be staffed by a director who shall be appointed by a mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. This director shall be a professional and not be required to reside in the City of Calumet City. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. 
(1)  The director also shall act as the ethics officer pursuant to section 2-292 of the City of Calumet City Code and as the equal employment opportunity officer. 
(2)  The director shall initiate and receive complaints of any actual or perceived violation of the appointed officials' public duties from other appointed officials or employees of the city. In addition, the director shall receive and process any complaints from residents or other interested parties who may have complaints regarding the appointed officials of Calumet City government. The director may conduct investigations concerning any matter which the director may find to possibly violate any city ordinance or state law. When the director determines that assistance may be needed in conducting investigations, or when required by law, the director shall request the assistance of other appropriate agencies or the city attorney. The director also shall have the authority to consult with all other city departments, officials and employees on matters involving ethical conduct. 
(3)  The director shall make recommendations to the mayor and city council as to further legislation and rules in regard to complaints, hearings and possible sanctions. 
(4)  The director shall be responsible for hearing any complaints regarding discrimination or harassment based on any cause, including, but not limited to, race, sex, religion or political affiliation. 
(5)  The director shall maintain a presence in the city via a phone number and office accessible to the general public. 
(c)  Compensation. The director shall be compensated in an amount to be determined by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 03-51, §§ 2—8, 9-10-2003)  
Secs. 2-784—2-798. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
[15]
Footnotes: 
 
Sec. 2-841. - Established; composition. 
There is hereby established a board of local improvements which shall consist of the mayor and all the members of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-252; Ord. of 7-10-1969, § 1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/9-2-7.  
Sec. 2-842. - Attorney.

The special assessment attorney shall receive such compensation as is provided by law, and generally paid to attorneys specializing in special assessment practice in the county. 
(Code 1980, § 2-253; Ord. of 7-10-1969, § 3)

He shall receive such compensation as is authorized by law and generally paid to engineers specializing in this type of work in the county.

Sec. 2-844. - Secretary. 
There is hereby established the position of secretary of the board of local improvements. The city clerk shall serve as secretary of the board of local improvements. It shall be the duty of the secretary to keep minutes of all of its regular and special meetings, prepare and publish notices and perform other duties as are prescribed by statute or authorized by the board of local improvements. 
(Code 1980, § 2-255; Ord. of 7-10-1969, § 5; Ord. No. 85-29, § 1, 8-22-1985)  
Sec. 2-845. - Duties. 
The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by state law or ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-256; Ord. of 7-10-1969, § 2) 
State Law reference— Duties of board generally, 65 ILCS 5/9-1-1 et seq.  
Secs. 2-846—2-880. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - FINANCE[16] 
Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-881. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of May of each year and end on the last day of April of the following year. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1; Ord. of 10-26-1961, § II) 
State Law reference— Fiscal year, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2(5).  
Sec. 2-882. - Payment of bills. 
(a)  All bills which are payable by the city, other than those for the payment of salaries established by the city council, shall be submitted to the city council for approval before payment. 
(b)  Whenever an unforeseen or emergency payment is required prior to submission to the city council for approval for payment, payment may be made provided the following terms and conditions are complied with: 
(1)  The treasurer and either the mayor, city clerk or chairman of the finance committee shall certify in writing that an unforeseen or emergency payment is required, not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per payment. 
(2)  The request for payment should be in writing signed by the department head on a form provided by the treasurer, and the payment request should be provided for in the current appropriation ordinance, and the payment request will not over-expend said appropriation. 
(3)  The payment request shall be included on the bills submitted for payment by council approval at the next regular council meeting. 
(4)  The treasurer shall determine whether all of the above conditions have been complied with prior to authorizing issuance of any check as herein provided. 
(c)  The above provisions notwithstanding, water bills payable by the city to the City of Chicago or the Hammond Water Works Department shall be paid when deemed necessary by the treasurer in order to secure prompt payment discounts prior to submission to the city council for approval before payment; however, such action of the treasurer shall be submitted to the city council for ratification and approval of his action at the next regular council meeting. 
(d)  The above provisions notwithstanding, bills payable by the city to any provider of electrical service to any city-owned or managed properties shall be paid when deemed necessary by the treasurer in order to secure prompt payment discounts prior to submission to the city council for approval before payment; however, such action of the treasurer shall be submitted to the city council for ratification and approval of his action at the next regular council meeting. 
(e)  The above provisions notwithstanding, the treasurer may authorize the payment of postage and the reimbursement of the petty cash fund prior to city council approval but shall report such action for approval and ratification at the next regular council meeting. 
(Code 1980, § 2-3; Ord. of 11-25-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 76-41, § 1, 10-28-1976; Ord. No. 12-53, § 2, 11-20-2012; Ord. No. 13-31, § 2, 6-27-2013)  
Sec. 2-883. - Competitive bidding requirements waived for asbestos removal in certain emergency situations. 
(a)  It is hereby ordained that no advertising or competitive bidding shall be required to remove the asbestos from any vacant or deteriorating structure or to demolish such structure determined to be detrimental to the life, safety and health of the citizens of the city and such determination shall be without regard to whether or not the cost thereof exceeds ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) where the condition of such structure is determined to be a threat to said life, safety and health of any person so as to create an emergency situation and the need to avoid serious hazard. 
(b)  It is hereby determined and ordained that the waiving of the bidding requirement shall only occur where there is written direction from the director of inspectional services, which indicates a requirement for immediate asbestos removal and demolition approved by the chief of the fire department or the chief of police and further, that such direction indicates in writing that appropriate notice requirements to the owner or owners of the property have been attempted and that an emergency demolition is required. 
(Code 1980, § 2-6; Ord. No. 96-55, §§ 1, 2, 8-22-1996)  
Sec. 2-884. - Special assessment unclaimed rebate fund established; use of fund. 
(a)  There is hereby established a special assessment unclaimed rebate fund for the city pursuant to the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/9-1-5—9-1-10, as amended. 
(b)  The corporate authorities by ordinance may direct the use of the money in the unclaimed rebate fund for any public purpose for which the municipality is authorized by law to expend funds. 
(Code 1980, § 26-161; Ord. No. 88-14, §§ 1, 2, 6-23-1988)  
Secs. 2-885—2-900. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ISSUANCE PROCEDURES FOR INDUSTRIAL REVENUE AND POLLUTION CONTROL REVENUE BONDS 
 
Sec. 2-901. - Definitions. 
Whenever used in this division, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
Economic development project means any building or facility or any area, industrial park or portion thereof or combination or part thereof occupied or utilized by an industrial manufacturing or business enterprise located within or partially within the municipality, including any land, interest in land, building, structure, facility, system, fixture, improvement, addition, appurtenance, machinery or equipment, or any combination thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary in connection therewith, for use by any person, provided that the existence of such economic development project will create or retain employment opportunities in or near the municipality. 
Municipality means the City of Calumet City, Cook County, Illinois. 
Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation (including public utilities), association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, state agency, or any other legal entity, or its legal representative, agent or assigns. 
Pollution means any form of environmental pollution including, but not limited to, water pollution, air pollution, land pollution, solid waste pollution, thermal pollution, radiation contamination, or noise pollution as determined by the various standards prescribed by this state, the federal government or other governmental entities and including but not limited to, anything which is considered as pollution or environmental damage in the Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.), and any amendment thereto and substitution therefor. 
Pollution control facility means any land, interest in land, building, structure, facility, system, fixture, improvement, addition, appurtenance, machinery or equipment, or any combination thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary therewith, having to do with or the end purpose of which is, reducing, controlling or preventing pollution. 
Project means any economic development project or pollution control facility or any combination thereof. 
Project costs means and includes the sum total of all reasonable or necessary costs incidental to the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, repair, alteration, improvement, equipping and extension of a project including, without limitation, the cost of studies and surveys, plans, specifications, architectural and engineering services, legal, marketing or other special services, financing, acquisition, demolition, construction, equipment and site development of new and rehabilitated buildings, rehabilitation, reconstruction, repair or remodeling of existing buildings and all other necessary or incidental expenses whether directly or indirectly related to the project, including an initial bond and interest reserve together with interest on bonds issued to finance a project to a date six (6) months subsequent to the estimated date of completion and any costs or expenses which may be included under the provisions of Section 103(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended. 
Revenue agreement includes any lease, sublease, installment or direct sales contract, service contract, take or pay contract, loan agreement or similar agreement wherein a person agrees to pay the municipality funds sufficient to provide for the prompt payment of the principal of, interest on, and redemption premium, if any, on the bonds and agrees to cause the project to be acquired, constructed or improved. 
(Code 1980, § 2-375; Ord. No. 79-18, § 1, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-902. - Legislative declaration of purpose. 
It is hereby determined and declared that the purpose of this division is to provide a financing device which will aid in financing the cost of projects in order to relieve conditions of unemployment, retain employment opportunities and encourage the increase of industry within or near the municipality, thereby reducing the evils attendant upon unemployment and to provide for the increased welfare and prosperity of the residents of the municipality; it is hereby further determined and declared to be the purpose of this division to provide a financing device which will aid in financing the cost of pollution control facilities in order to eliminate, abate or reduce the serious dangers to the public health and welfare caused by environmental pollution; and the same are hereby declared and determined to be public purposes and functions pertaining to the government and affairs of the municipality. 
(Code 1980, § 2-376; Ord. No. 79-18, § 2, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-903. - Additional powers of municipality. 
(a)  In addition to powers which it may now have, the municipality shall have the power under this division to: 
(1)  Construct, acquire by gift, purchase or lease, to reconstruct, improve, better or extend and to finance one or more projects, whether or not now or hereafter in existence, within or without the municipality or partially within or partially without the municipality, but in no event further than ten (10) miles from the territorial boundaries of the municipality, and, if desirable, to acquire by gift, purchase or lease, lands or rights in land in connection with any project; 
(2)  Issue its revenue bonds to defray in whole or in part the project costs of any project and to designate an appropriate name for such bonds; 
(3)  Rent, lease or sell any project to any person or to loan the proceeds of its revenue bonds to any person for the payment of project costs under and pursuant to a revenue agreement; 
(4)  Pledge the revenues and receipts derived from the revenue agreement to the punctual payment of bonds authorized under this division, the interest thereon, and the redemption premiums, if any; 
(5)  Mortgage such projects in favor of the holder or holders of bonds issued therefor; 
(6)  Sell and convey such project, including without limitation, the sale and conveyance thereof subject to a mortgage, if any, as provided in this division, for such price and at such time (whether prior or subsequent to the payment in full of bonds authorized under this division) as the governing body of the municipality may determine; 
(7)  Issue its bonds to refund in whole or in part, bonds theretofore issued by such municipality under authority of this division, and to extend the term of the refunding bonds beyond the term of the refunded bonds. 
(b)  Property acquired by the municipality pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be exempt from the imposition and collection of taxes thereon while owned by the municipality, but the use of such property is subject to taxation to be paid by the lessee or occupant as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-377; Ord. No. 79-18, § 3, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-904. - Authority to issue; bonds generally. 
The exercise of all powers granted by this division may be authorized, and bonds may be authorized to be issued under this division for the purposes set forth in this division, by ordinance of the governing body of the municipality which may be adopted at the same meeting at which it is introduced and shall take effect immediately upon adoption. 
The bonds shall bear interest at such rate or rates, payable at such times, may be in one or more series, may bear such date or dates, may mature at such time or times not exceeding forty (40) years from their respective dates, may be payable in such medium of payment at such place or places, may carry such registration privileges, may be subject to such terms of redemption at such premiums, may be executed in such manner, may contain such terms, covenants and conditions, and may be in such form, either coupon or registered, as such ordinance may provide or as may be subsequently determined by the governing body before the bonds are issued. The bonds may be sold at public or private sale in such manner and upon such terms as may be deemed advisable by the governing body of the municipality. Pending the preparation of the definitive bonds, interim receipts or certificates in such form and with such provisions as the governing body of the municipality may determine, may be issued to the purchaser or purchasers of bonds sold pursuant to this division. The bonds and interim receipts or certificates shall be deemed to be securities and negotiable instruments within the meaning and for all purposes of the Uniform Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1980, § 2-378; Ord. No. 79-18, § 4, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-905. - Covenants in bonds. 
Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds under this division may contain such covenants as the municipality may desire including, but not limited to, covenants as to: 
(a)  The use and disposition of the revenues and receipts from the project for which the bonds are to be issued, including the creation and maintenance of reserves; 
(b)  The issuance of other or additional bonds relating to the project or any rehabilitation, improvements, renovations, enlargements or additions thereto; 
(c)  The maintenance and repair of such project; 
(d)  The insurance to be carried thereon and the use and disposition of insurance moneys; 
(e)  The appointment of any bank or trust company within or outside the State of Illinois, having the necessary trust powers as trustee for the benefit of the bondholders, fiscal agent, paying agent, and bond registrar; 
(f)  The investment of any funds held by such trustee; and 
(g)  The terms and conditions upon which the holders of the bonds or any portion thereof or any trustees therefor, are entitled to the appointment of a receiver. 
Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds under this division may provide that the principal of and interest on any bonds issued under this division shall be secured by a mortgage or indenture of trust covering such project for which the bonds are issued and may include any improvements or extensions thereafter made. Such mortgage or indenture or trust may contain such covenants and agreements to properly safeguard the bonds as may be provided for in the ordinance authorizing such bonds and shall be executed in the manner as may be provided for in the ordinance. The provisions of this division and any such ordinance or ordinances and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall constitute a contract with the holder or holders of the bonds and continue in effect until the principal of, the interest on, and the redemption premiums, if any, on the bonds so issued have been fully paid, and the duties of the municipality and its corporate authorities and officers under this division and any such ordinance or ordinances and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall be enforceable by any bondholder by mandamus, foreclosure of any such mortgage or indenture of trust or other appropriate suit, action or proceedings in any court of competent jurisdiction, provided the ordinance or any mortgage or indenture of trust under which the bonds are issued may provide that all such remedies and rights to enforcement may be vested in a trustee for the benefit of all the bondholders. 
(Code 1980, § 2-379; Ord. No. 79-18, § 5, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-906. - Signatures of officers; validity of bonds. 
The bonds shall bear the manual or facsimile signatures of such officers of the municipality as may be designated in the ordinance authorizing such bonds and such manual or facsimile signatures shall be the valid and binding signatures of the officers of the municipality, notwithstanding that before the delivery thereof and payments therefor, any or all of the persons whose signatures appear thereon have ceased to be officers of the municipality issuing such bonds. The validity of the bonds is not dependent on nor affected by the validity or regularity of any proceedings relating to the acquisition, purchase, construction reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment or extension of the project for which the bonds are issued. The ordinance authorizing the bonds may provide that the bonds shall contain a recital that they are issued pursuant to this division, which recital shall be conclusive evidence of their validity and of the regularity of their issuance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-380; Ord. No. 79-18, § 6, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-907. - Lien of bonds. 
All bonds issued under this division have a lien upon the revenues and receipts derived from the revenue agreement entered into with respect to the project for which the bonds have been issued, and the governing body may provide in the ordinance or ordinances authorizing such bonds for the issuance of additional bonds to be equally and ratably secured by a lien upon such revenues and receipts or may provide that the lien upon such revenues and receipts is subordinate. 
(Code 1980, § 2-381; Ord. No. 79-18, § 7, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-908. - Liability for bonds. 
All bonds issued under and pursuant to this division shall be limited obligations of the municipality payable solely out of the revenues and receipts derived from the revenue agreement entered into with respect to the project for which such bonds are issued. No holder of any bonds issued under this division has the right to compel any exercise of taxing power of the municipality to pay the bonds, the interests or premium, if any, thereon, and the bonds do not constitute an indebtedness of the municipality or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provision. It shall be plainly stated on the face of each bond that it has been issued under the provisions of this division and that it does not constitute an indebtedness of the municipality or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provisions. 
(Code 1980, § 2-382; Ord. No. 79-18, § 8, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-909. - Investment of funds. 
The municipality, or any trustee or fiscal agent on behalf of the municipality, may invest any funds held by it pursuant to this division in: 
(1)  Any bonds or other obligation which as to principal and interest constitute direct obligations of or are unconditionally guaranteed by the United States of America; 
(2)  Obligations of the Federal National Mortgage Association; 
(3)  Obligations of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks; 
(4)  Obligations of federal banks for cooperatives; 
(5)  Obligations of federal land banks; 
(6)  Obligations of federal home loan banks; 
(7)  Obligations of the Federal Financing Bank; 
(8)  Time certificates of deposit of banks organized under the laws of any state of the United States and national banks which have a combined capital and surplus of at least five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); and 
(9)  Any other investments to the extent then permitted by state law. 
Any such securities may be purchased at the offering or market price thereof at the time of such purchase. 
(Code 1980, § 2-383; Ord. No. 79-18, § 9, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-910. - Exemption from construction and bidding requirements for public buildings. 
The acquisition and construction of a project shall not be subject to any requirements relating to public buildings, structures, grounds, works or improvements imposed by law or any other similar requirements which may be lawfully waived by this section and any requirement of competitive bidding or restriction imposed on the procedure for award of contracts for such purpose, or the lease, sale or other disposition of property of the municipality is not applicable to any action taken under authority of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-384; Ord. No. 79-18, § 10, 5-24-1979)  
Sec. 2-911. - Powers conferred as additional and supplemental; limitations imposed; effect. 
The powers conferred by this division are in addition and supplemental to, and the limitations imposed by this division shall not affect, the powers conferred by any law or any other ordinance. Projects may be acquired, purchased, constructed, reconstructed, improved, bettered, equipped, extended and financed, and bonds may be issued under this division for such purposes, notwithstanding that any law or any other ordinance may provide for the acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment, extension and financing of a like project, or the issuance of bonds for like purposes, and without regard to the requirements, restrictions, limitations or other provisions contained in any law or any other ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-385; Ord. No. 79-18, § 11, 5-24-1979)  
Secs. 2-912—2-940. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - CODE ENFORCEMENT[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference— Fire code prevention, § 30-161 et seq. 
State Law reference— Administrative adjudication of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-941. - Purpose. 
The stated purpose of this article is to provide for the fair and efficient enforcement of the Municipal Code of Calumet City, Illinois, other than those ordinances pertaining to vehicular standing, parking or vehicle compliance regulation (hereafter the "City Code"), as may be allowed by law and directed by ordinance, through an administrative adjudication of violations; and, establishing a schedule of fines and penalties, and authority and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties. 
(Code 1980, § 2-501; Ord. No. 99-63, § VI, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-942. - Creation. 
There is hereby established a department of the city government to be known as the ordinance enforcement department and to have the power to enforce any municipal ordinance as from time to time authorized by the city council, except for (i) any offense enforced pursuant to Article VII.5 of Chapter 17 of this Code; (ii) any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.); or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles; and, (iii) except for any reportable offense under 625 ILCS 5/6-204. The establishment of the ordinance enforcement department does not preclude the mayor and city council from using any other method or court with jurisdiction to enforce ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-503; Ord. No. 99-63, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-943. - Administrative composition. 
(a)  The ordinance enforcement department shall be composed of a hearing officer, an ordinance enforcement administrator, system coordinator/computer operator and hearing room security personnel, with the power and authority as hereinafter set forth. 
(1)  The hearing officer is authorized and directed to: 
a.  The hearing officer, prior to appointment, must be an attorney licensed to practice law for at least three (3) years in the State of Illinois. The hearing officer shall preside over all adjudicatory hearings and shall have the following powers and duties: 
1.  To administer oaths; 
2.  To hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the existence of the City Code violation; 
3.  To issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their representatives; 
4.  To preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
5.  To issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a City Code violation exists; 
6.  To impose penalties, sanctions or such other relief consistent with applicable City Code provisions and assessing costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a penalty of incarceration; and, 
7.  To review final determination of liability for an ordinance violation in accordance with the administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth. 
b.  Prior to conducting administrative adjudication proceedings under this article, the hearing officer shall have successfully completed a formal training program which includes the following: 
1.  Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings over which the hearing officer shall preside; 
2.  Orientation to each subject area of the code violations that he/she will adjudicate; 
3.  Observation of administrative hearings; and 
4.  Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuing final orders. 
(2)  The ordinance enforcement administrator is authorized and directed to: 
a.  Operate and manage the ordinance enforcement department. 
b.  Adopt, distribute and process all notices as may be required under this article or as may be reasonably required to carry out the purpose of this article. 
c.  Collect moneys paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final determination of liability. 
d.  Certify copies of final determinations of an ordinance violation adjudicated pursuant to this article, and any factual reports verifying the final determination of any violation liability which was issued in accordance with this article. 
e.  Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created. 
f.  Collect unpaid fines and penalties through private collection agencies and direct the pursuit of all post-judgment remedies available by law. 
(3)  The system coordinator/computer operator is hereby authorized and directed to operate and maintain the computer programs for the administrative adjudication system of the ordinance enforcement department hereby created, on a day-to-day basis, including but not limited to: 
a.  Input of violation notice information. 
b.  Establishing hearing dates and notice dates. 
c.  Record fine and penalty assessment and payments. 
d.  Issue payment receipts. 
e.  Issue succeeding notice of hearing dates and/or final determination of liability. 
f.  Keep accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at administrative hearings, pleas entered, judgments entered, sanctions imposed, if any, fines and penalties assessed and paid. 
(4)  All hearing room security personnel shall be qualified off-duty, full-time, part-time or auxiliary police officers who are hereby authorized and directed to: 
a.  Maintain hearing room decorum. 
b.  Have and execute authority as is granted to courtroom deputies of the circuit court. 
c.  Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required and as directed by the hearing officer or ordinance enforcement administrator. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby authorized to appoint persons to hold the positions above set forth. Other than the hearing officer, one person may hold and fulfill the requirements of one (1) or more of the above stated positions and compensation for each of the above stated positions shall be as approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-504; Ord. No. 99-63, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 01-56, 11-19-2001)  
Sec. 2-944. - Procedures. 
The system of administrative adjudication of any ordinance violation authorized to be adjudicated hereunder, shall afford a party due process of law and the hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Violation notices of any City Code shall be issued by the persons authorized under this Code and shall contain information and shall be certified and constitute prima facie evidence of the violation cited as hereinafter set forth. 
(2)  All full-time, part-time and auxiliary police officers as well as other specifically authorized individuals of any department of the city shall have the authority to issue violation notices. 
(3)  Any individual authorized hereby to issue violation notices and who detects any ordinance violation authorized to be adjudicated under this article, is authorized to issue notice of violation thereof and shall make service thereof as is hereinafter set forth. 
(4)  The violation notice of the City Code shall contain, but shall not be limited to, the following information: 
a.  The name of the party violating the ordinance, if known. 
b.  The date, time and place of the violation (date of issuance). 
c.  The particular ordinance violated. 
d.  The fine and any penalty which may be assessed for the ordinance violation. 
e.  The signature and identification number of the person issuing the notice. 
f.  The date and location of the adjudicating hearing of ordinance violations, and the penalties for failure to appear at the hearing. 
g.  That payment of the indicated fine and any late payment shall operate as a final disposition of the violation. 
(Code 1980, § 2-505; Ord. No. 99-63, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 01-56, 11-19-2001)  
Sec. 2-945. - Service. 
(a)  Service of any violation notice shall be made by the person issuing such notice by: 
(1)  Handing the notice to the person responsible for the ordinance violation; 
(2)  Handing the notice to the responsible person or leaving the notice with any person twelve (12) years of age or older at the residence of the responsible person; 
(3)  Mailing the notice by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the person responsible for the ordinance violation; or, 
(4)  Posting the notice upon the property where the violation is found when the person is the owner or manager of the property. 
(b)  The correctness of facts contained in any violation notice shall be verified by the person issuing said notice by: 
(1)  Signing his name to the notice at the time of issuance; or 
(2)  In the case of a notice produced by a computer device, by signing a single certificate, to be kept by the ordinance enforcement administrator, attesting to the correctness of all notices produced by the device while under his control. 
(c)  The original or a facsimile of the violation notice shall be retained by the ordinance enforcement administrator and kept as a record in the ordinary course of business. 
(d)  Any violation notice issued, signed and served in accordance herewith, or a copy of the notice, shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice. 
(Code 1980, § 2-506; Ord. No. 99-63, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-946. - Administrative hearings. 
An administrative hearing to adjudicate any alleged City Code ordinance violation on its merits shall be granted to the person named in the ordinance violation notice. All administrative hearings shall be recorded and shall culminate in a determination of liability or nonliability, made by the hearing officer, who shall consider facts and/or testimony without the application of the formal or technical rules of evidence. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonable prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. The hearing officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess fines, penalties and costs in accordance with section 2-952 hereof. Persons appearing to contest the alleged violation on its merits may be represented by counsel at their own expense. The burden of proof shall be on the alleged offender to refute the prima facie case set forth in the verified notice of violation. 
(Code 1980, § 2-507; Ord. No. 99-63, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-947. - Notices. 
(a)  Upon failure of the person receiving a notice of a violation of the City Code to appear at the time and date designated for a hearing, the ordinance enforcement administrator shall send, or cause to be sent, notices as provided in subsection (b) of this section, by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the person who received the notice of an ordinance violation. Service of notices sent in accordance herewith shall be complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. 
(b)  The notices sent pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be in the following sequence and contain, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Date and location of violation cited in the violation notice. 
(2)  Particular ordinance violated. 
(3)  Fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment. 
(4)  A section titled "Notice of Hearing" which shall clearly set forth that the person receiving a notice of the City Code ordinance violation may appear at an administrative hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice on the date and at the time and place as specified in the notice of hearing. 
(5)  Date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the alleged violation may be contested on its merits. 
(6)  Statement that failure to either pay fine and any applicable penalty or failure to appear at the hearing on its merits on the date and at the time and place specified will result in a final determination of liability for the "cited" violation in the amount of the fine and penalty indicated. 
(7)  Statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, available administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the city. 
(c)  A notice of final determination of liability shall be sent following the conclusion of administrative hearing, as is hereinafter set forth, and shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information and warnings: 
(1)  A statement that the unpaid fine and any penalty assessed is a debt due and owing the city; 
(2)  A statement of any sanction ordered or costs imposed which costs are debts due and owing the city; and
