Subdivision II. - Electrical Commission[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-799 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-181. - Established. 
There is hereby established an electrical commission. 
(Code 1980, § 6-91; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Electrical commission required, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2.  
Sec. 14-182. - Composition. 
The electrical commission shall be composed of the following persons: 
(1)  The chief electrical inspector. 
(2)  An electrical contractor. 
(3)  A representative of the electricity supply company. 
(4)  A representative of the inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters. 
(5)  A journeyman electrician. 
(6)  A registered professional engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 6-92; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2.  
Sec. 14-183. - Appointment of members. 
The members of the electrical commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 6-93; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2.  
Sec. 14-184. - Ex officio chairman. 
The chief electrical inspector shall serve as ex officio chairman of the electrical commission. 
(Code 1980, § 6-94; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2.  
Sec. 14-185. - Functions generally. 
The electrical commission shall recommend: 
(1)  Safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation and alteration of the electrical work designed to meet the necessities and conditions of the city. 
(2)  Reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits by the electrical inspection department. 
(3)  Reasonable fees to be paid for inspection by the electrical inspection department. 
The standards and specifications, rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits and fees so recommended shall become effective upon the passage of an ordinance adopting the same by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 6-95; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-3.  
Sec. 14-186. - Organizational meeting; notice thereof. 
Upon the appointment of the electrical commission its secretary shall notify in writing all members of the commission of a special meeting to formulate its actions in the future. 
(Code 1980, § 6-96; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-187. - Quorum; official actions. 
Four (4) members of the electrical commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business. A majority vote of the members present shall be sufficient to take official action on any matters. 
(Code 1980, § 6-97; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-188. - Records. 
The secretary of the electrical commission shall keep a full and correct record of the official proceedings of the electrical commission and an up-to-date record specifying names and addresses of all electricians licensed with the city. 
(Code 1980, § 6-98; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-189. - Appeals. 
The secretary of the electrical commission shall call a meeting of the electrical commission for hearing appeals; and at any time the commission meets to hear an appeal from an appellant, the appellant shall pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the city clerk, who shall deposit same in the corporate fund. 
(Code 1980, § 6-99; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Secs. 14-190—14-210. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Electrical Inspection Department[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Departments, § 2-566 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-211. - Established. 
There is hereby established an electrical inspection department. 
(Code 1980, § 6-106; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2) 
State Law reference— Power of city to establish an electrical inspection department, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2.  
Sec. 14-212. - Composition. 
The electrical inspection department shall consist of the chief electrical inspector and such assistants as may be necessary to enforce this article. Both the inspector and his assistants shall be appointed by the mayor. The chief electrical inspector shall be a practical electrician well-versed in all types of electrical construction work with not less than five (5) years of electrical experience and he shall have continuously resided in the city for at least five (5) years prior to his appointment. 
(Code 1980, § 6-107; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-213. - Bond of members. 
The chief electrical inspector and his assistants shall be required to give surety bonds in the sum as shall be determined by the city council, the cost of such bonds to be paid by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 6-108; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-214. - Enforcement duties generally. 
The electrical inspection department shall enforce this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-109; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-215. - Supervision of work. 
The electrical inspection department shall have immediate supervision of all electrical work according to the rules established by the electrical commission and by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 6-110; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-216. - Records of contractors. 
The electrical inspection department shall maintain an official record of all persons lawfully entitled to carry on or engage in the business of electrical work in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 6-111; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-217. - Issuance of permits. 
The electrical inspection department shall issue permits for installation and alteration of electrical work where application for such permit shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations applicable thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 6-112; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-218. - Inspections. 
The electrical inspection department shall inspect all electrical installations authorized by any permit to assure compliance with provisions of this article or amendments thereto, approving or condemning said work in whole or in part as conditions require. 
(Code 1980, § 6-113; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-219. - Plans and drawings. 
The electrical inspection department shall require the owner, lessee or their representatives to submit specifications, drawings, descriptions and/or diagrams necessary to show clearly the character, kind and extent of electrical work covered for said installations. If found to be in conformity with the requirements of this article and all other laws or ordinances the electrical inspector shall endorse it in writing or stamp plans and specifications "approved." 
(Code 1980, § 6-114; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-220. - Service charge. 
The electrical inspection department shall charge for their service in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-115; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-221. - Entry powers. 
The chief electrical inspector or the electrical inspectors shall have the power to enter any building or premises in order to examine, inspect, or test the electrical work in such building or premises. 
(Code 1980, § 6-116; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-222. - Monthly reports by inspector. 
The chief electrical inspector shall file a report with the city clerk and with the city council each month, setting forth all electrical inspection fees received, the type of work inspected, the name of the person requesting the inspection, the address where inspection was performed and the date of inspection. 
(Code 1980, § 6-117; Ord. of 12-30-1971, § 1)  
Sec. 14-223. - Police assistance. 
Whenever, in the opinion of the chief electrical inspector, it shall be the necessary to call upon the police department for the aid and assistance in carrying out or enforcing any of the provisions of this article, he shall have the authority to do so, and it shall be the duty of the department when called upon by said inspector to act according to the instructions of and to perform such duties as may be required by such inspector in order to enforce or put into effect the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-118; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Secs. 14-224—14-240. - Reserved.  
Subdivision IV. - Permits and Inspections 
 
Sec. 14-241. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provisions of this division shall be punished as provided by state law. 
(Code 1980, § 6-134) 
State Law reference— Penalty for violation of electrical ordinance, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-4.  
Sec. 14-242. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any person desiring an electrical permit shall, where the construction or alteration work is to be done in a single-family dwelling occupancy, apply to the electrical inspection department, giving such information as may be reasonably necessary to determine whether the permit should be issued, including a plan which shall include a wiring layout showing: 
(1)  The number and location of outlets. 
(2)  The size of wire and conduit to be used. 
(3)  The number of circuits and their ampere rating. 
(4)  The location of service entrance equipment. 
(5)  The location of major appliances. 
(6)  The size of existing old service. 
(7)  If an electrically heated home, the location and wattage of all heating equipment shown and circuits listed for same. 
(b)  Where construction or alteration work is to be done in other than single-family dwelling occupancies, the applicant shall submit with the application for permit, a complete wiring plan for approval. This plan shall indicate size of service conductors, the type and location of all outlets, the size of all meters and power-consuming equipment; that is, all current-consuming devices which shall make up the total connected load. It shall also include information concerning conduit runs and the size of conductors for branch circuits and feeders to be installed. The location of all panel boards and cabinets and the number and ampere rating of the circuits shall be indicated. 
(Code 1980, § 6-127; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 17)  
Sec. 14-243. - Compliance as prerequisite to permit issuance. 
All wiring, equipment for which an electrical permit is required and the installation thereof shall conform to all the specifications, rules and regulations contained in this article, and no permit shall be issued unless plans showing conformity with all provisions of this article have been submitted and approved. 
(Code 1980, § 6-128; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 3)  
Sec. 14-244. - Permit transfer fee. 
If the general contractor or owner changes to another electrical contractor other than the one to whom the electrical permit was originally issued, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid for the transfer of the permit. 
(Code 1980, § 6-130; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 18; Ord. No. 76-47, § 1, 12-9-1976)  
Sec. 14-245. - Suspension of permits to contractor. 
The failure on the part of any registered electrical contractor to correct any defect, error or deficiency in any work installed under the authority of a permit issued to him by the department of electrical inspection, within ten (10) calendar days after written notification thereof by the department, or within such further reasonable time as may be, upon request, prescribed by the chief electrical inspector shall, without further notice, stop the issuance of permits to such registered electrical contractor until such corrections have been made, inspected and approved. 
(Code 1980, § 6-131; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 22)  
Sec. 14-246. - Fee for reinspection or additional inspections. 
Whenever reinspections are required because of inaccurate or incorrect information on the plan or face of the application for an electrical permit or because of violations of this article or because of faulty construction, a charge of five dollars ($5.00) per hour shall be made by the electrical inspection department for the time consumed in making such reinspection; provided, however, that the minimum fee for such reinspection shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(Code 1980, § 6-132; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 18)  
Sec. 14-247. - Inspections and approval. 
(a)  No electrical work of any kind within the scope of this article, including conduit and raceways, shall be concealed or enclosed until it has been inspected by the electrical inspection department. It shall be the responsibility of the person doing the electrical installment work to notify the electrical inspection department, which shall make a roughing-in, trim and final inspection to assure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  No electrical service shall be supplied to any building or premises until the electrical work in such building or premises has been inspected and approved by the electrical inspection department. 
(c)  No electrical wiring, installation or equipment shall be used until after the final inspection and approval of the chief electrical inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 6-133; Ord. of 2-14-1963, §§ 2, 3, 18)  
Secs. 14-248—14-270. - Reserved.  
Subdivision V. - Dangerous Installations 
 
Sec. 14-271. - Correction required. 
When any electrical equipment is found by the chief electrical inspector to be dangerous to persons or property because it is defective or improperly installed, the person responsible for the electrical equipment shall be notified by him in writing and shall make any changes or repairs required by the chief electrical inspector to place such equipment in a safe condition. 
(Code 1980, § 6-141; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 20)  
Sec. 14-272. - Disconnection when corrections not made. 
If the corrections required by section 14-271 of this Code are not completed within ten (10) calendar days after the person responsible receives the notice to correct same, or any longer that may be specified by the chief electrical inspector in said notice, the chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to disconnect or order the discontinuance of electrical service to said electrical equipment. 
(Code 1980, § 6-142; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 20)  
Sec. 14-273. - Emergency disconnections. 
In case of an emergency, where necessary for safety to persons or property, or where electrical equipment may interfere with the functions of the fire department, the chief of the fire department or the chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to disconnect or cause the discontinuance of any electrical equipment or installation. 
(Code 1980, § 6-143; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 20)  
Sec. 14-274. - Condemnation. 
The chief electrical inspector shall have the power to condemn any electrical installation which is unsafe or hazardous to life or property, and in such case shall serve notice upon the person owning, using or installing same requiring him to place the same in a safe and secure condition. Any interested person aggrieved by the action of the chief electrical inspector under this section may by written request have the determination of the chief electrical inspector reviewed by the electrical commission, which commission may either reverse or concur in the action of the inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 6-144; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 21)  
Secs. 14-275—14-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 14-291. - Residential Electrical Maintenance Code for One- and Two-Family and Multifamily Dwellings, 1994 Edition—Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted NFPA 73—Residential Electrical Maintenance Code for One- and Two-Family and Multifamily Dwellings, 1994 Edition, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, for providing requirements for evaluating installed electrical systems within and associated with existing dwellings to identify safety, fire and shock hazards which are evident upon visual inspection of existing residential dwellings; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the Residential Electrical Maintenance Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 14-292. 
(Code 1980, § 6-84; Ord. No. 97-8, § 1, 2-13-1997)  
Sec. 14-292. - Same—Amended. 
The following sections [of] the Residential Electrical Maintenance Code One- and Two-Family and Multifamily Dwellings are hereby revised as follows: 
Section 1-2.1. Add after the word dwellings: 
"and multifamily dwellings". 
Section 2-2.1. Add: 
"The connected load shall be determined as per the latest adopted edition of the National Electrical Code. All residences shall have a minimum of one hundred (100) amp service and all apartments shall have a minimum sixty (60) amp service." 
Section 2-11.6. Delete and replace with: 
"Grounded receptacles shall be present in all kitchens, garages, unfinished basements, laundry rooms and bathrooms. Where allowed by the National Electrical Code, ground fault protection may be used in lieu of grounding." 
Section 3-1. Add: 
"All receptacles in rental dwellings, those buildings undergoing service upgrades or those requiring a point of sale inspection shall meet the latest edition of the National Electrical Code as approved by the City of Calumet City for ground fault protection." 
(Code 1980, § 6-85; Ord. No. 97-8, § 2, 2-13-1997)  
Secs. 14-293—14-310. - Reserved.

Subdivision II. - Chicago Electrical Code[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-48, §§ 2, 3, amended subdiv. II in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former subdiv. II, §§ 14-311—14-314, pertained to National Electrical Code. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
 
Sec. 14-311. - Chicago Electrical Code—Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the City of Calumet City, Cook County, Illinois that certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, known as the "2011 Chicago Electrical Code" for the regulation of the design, construction, installation, alteration, repairs, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of electrical systems and equipment; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of 2011 Chicago Electrical Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 12-48, § 3, 10-11-2012)  
Sec. 14-312. - Construction of certain terms used in Chicago Electrical Code. 
(a)  Whenever the word "municipality" or the word "city" is used in the Chicago Electrical Code, it shall be construed to mean the City of Calumet City, Illinois. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporation counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the code, it shall be construed to mean the city attorney of this city. 
(Ord. No. 12-48, § 3, 10-11-2012)

DIVISION 4. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 14-331. - Restrictions on contractors. 
All persons registered under this division shall be required to do their work in a proper manner. No registrant shall allow his name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, either to obtain permits or to do any electrical work under his registration. For violations of these requirements a person's registration may be revoked. 
(Code 1980, § 6-157; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Secs. 14-332—14-350. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Registration 
 
Sec. 14-351. - Registration required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of electrical contractor without being registered as an electrical contractor in the manner hereinafter set forth; provided, however, that if such person is already registered for the current year in another city or village within the state in conformity with the state law, such electrical contractor shall not be required to register or pay a registration fee in the city. Such person already registered in another city or village shall post with the department of inspectional services a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or as otherwise specified as set forth in section 14-352. 
(Code 1980, § 6-151; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2; Ord. No. 97-56, § 2, 10-9-1997) 
State Law reference— Registration of electrical contractors, 65 ILCS 5/11-33-1.  
Sec. 14-352. - Registration procedure generally. 
Any person desiring to register as an electrical contractor shall apply to the department of inspectional services. Upon the filing of such application in proper form, and the payment of the required registration fee and passing any required examination, proof of insurance and the posting with the department of inspectional services a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or as otherwise specified, the director of inspectional services or his agent shall register the applicant as an electrical contractor, and shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration which will authorize the applicant to engage in such business for the year in which it is issued. The surety bond shall indemnify and hold harmless the city against loss, costs, damage, judgement or liability of any kind whatsoever which the city may suffer or which may accrue against or be charged to the city or any of its officials arising out of or resulting from the conduct or operation of such business or the doings or failure to do any act in the connection herewith. 
(Code 1980, § 6-152; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2; Ord. No. 97-56, § 3, 10-9-1997)  
Sec. 14-353. - Registration fee. 
The fee for registration as an electrical contractor shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per annum, which sum shall be nonrefundable and shall be paid by the applicant to the city collector in advance upon filing the application. 
(Code 1980, § 6-153; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2; Ord. No. 88-16, § 2, 7-14-1988; Ord. No. 11-46, § 1, 8-11-2011)  
Sec. 14-354. - Qualification and examination of registrants. 
(a)  An applicant for registration as an electrical contractor shall not be less than twenty-one (21) years of age, and shall have had at least two (2) years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical wires, equipment and apparatus, or experience equivalent thereto. An applicant shall furnish the names and addresses of former employers, period of time employed and in what capacity, proof of which service shall be furnished in a manner satisfactory to the chief electrical inspector. 
(b)  Every applicant shall be required to take a written examination and answer correctly seventy (70) percent of the questions to show that he has sufficient knowledge and technical training to perform the work or to supervise the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electric wires and apparatus authorized by permits issued by the department of electrical inspection. Applicants shall also be required, to the satisfaction of the chief electrical inspector, to show satisfactory job performance. 
(Code 1980, § 6-154; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-355. - Registration card and certificate. 
The chief electrical inspector shall issue to every person who has complied with the provisions of this division relative to registration of electrical contractors a registration certificate and identification card. 
(Code 1980, § 6-155; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 14-356. - Expiration and transferability of registration certificate. 
An electrical contractor's certificate of registration shall expire on the last day of December of the year in which it was issued. A certificate of registration shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1980, § 6-156; Ord. of 2-14-1963, § 2)  
Secs. 14-357—14-380. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE 
 
Sec. 14-381. - Adoption of the BOCA Basic Energy Conservation Code. 
There is hereby adopted by the city, for the purposes of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, erection, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and structures, and to promote energy conservation, that certain code known as the BOCA Basic Energy Conservation Code 1990, drafted by the Building Officials Conference of America, and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, of which not less than three (3) copies in printed pamphlet form have been and now are filed for use and examination by the public, in the office of the city clerk, at least thirty (30) days prior to the adoption of this section, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling in the construction of all buildings and other structures in the city. 
(Code 1970, § 14.102; Code 1980, § 6-1(b); Ord. No. 77-39, § 1, 9-27-1977; Ord. No. 77-40, § 1, 9-27-1977; Ord. No. 88-7, § 1, 5-26-1988; Ord. No. 89-25, § 1, 7-13-1989; Ord. No. 91-58, § 1, 12-23-1991; Ord. No. 94-43, § 1, 7-28-1994; Ord. No. 97-3, § 1, 1-9-1997; Ord. No. 00-57, § 1, 10-12-2000) 
State Law reference— Power of city to adopt code by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2; 50 ILCS 220/2.  
Secs. 14-382—14-410. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FUEL GAS CODE 
 
Sec. 14-411. - Fuel gas code adopted. 
A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as "2006 International Fuel Gas Code" be and is hereby adopted by the city for the regulation of the installation of fuel gas piping systems, fuel gas utilization equipment and related accessories in order to provide minimum standards to safeguard life or limb, health, property and public welfare; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the 2006 International Fuel Gas Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part thereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 14-412. 
(Code 1980, § 6-441; Ord. No. 00-63, § 1, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-66, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 07-39, § 1, 4-26-2007)

Section 101.1. Insert "City of Calumet City" 
Section 103.1. Delete and replace with the following: The department of inspection shall also be known as the department of inspectional services and both references shall be interchangeable and the official in charge shall be known as the director of inspectional services. 
Section 106.5.2. Delete. 
Section 109.1. Delete and replace with the following: 
Decisions or determinations made by the director of inspectional services relative to the application and interpretation of this Code may be appealed by written application to the Chief of the Fire Department of the City of Calumet City who shall act on said appeal within five (5) business days of receipt. The decision of the fire chief may then in turn be appealed, in writing, to the public safety committee within five (5) business days and the committee's decision may subsequently be appealed to the full city council, in writing, within five (5) business days from the receipt of the decision of the committee. The decision of the city council shall be final and shall be subject to judicial review under the provisions of the Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). 
Sections 109.2 through 109.7. Delete. 
(Code 1980, § 6-442; Ord. No. 00-63, § 2, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-66, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 07-39, § 1, 4-26-2007)

A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as "2006 International Mechanical Code" be and is hereby adopted by the city for the regulation of the design, installation, maintenance, alteration and inspection of mechanical systems that are permanently installed and utilized to provide control of environmental conditions and related processes within buildings and also regulate those mechanical systems, system components, equipment and appliances specifically address therein; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the 2006 International Mechanical Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part thereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 14-401 of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 6-400; Ord. No. 97-11, §§ 1, 2, 2-13-1997; Ord. No. 00-64, § 1, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-68, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 07-41, § 1, 4-26-2007)

ARTICLE VIII. - PLUMBING CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-461. - Registration, Permits, Bond. 
(a)  An applicant for a plumbing permit shall first register with the department of inspectional services, showing proof of a plumber's license issued by the state department of public health and proof of insurance, and then may apply for a permit for such job of plumbing or drainage, describing explicitly the kind of work to be installed or performed with complete description of the premises where the work is to be done. 
(b)  This permit, when properly filled out, shall be at once filed with the department of inspectional services, authorizing the person to do all work for which the permit is granted on the condition that the same shall be in accordance with the provisions, rules and regulations of this Code. 
(c)  Every person desiring a plumbing permit shall pay to the city a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  An applicant for a plumbing permit, prior to the issuance of the permit, shall post a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or as otherwise specified with the department of inspectional services to indemnify and hold harmless the city against loss, costs, damage, judgement or liability of any kind whatsoever which the city may suffer or which may accrue against or be charged to the city or any of its officials arising out of or resulting from the conduct or operation of such business or the doings or failure to do any act in the connection herewith. 
(Code 1980, § 6-175; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 10; Ord. of 1-14-1965, § 1; Ord. No. 83-3, § 3, 2-24-1983; Ord. No. 89-4, § 2, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 97-56, §§ 4—6, 10-9-1997; Ord. No. 11-49, § 2, 8-11-2011)  
Secs. 14-462—14-480. - Reserved.

Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 14-481. - Reports. 
(a)  The city clerk shall file a monthly report with the city council indicating thereon the total plumbing fees received for the monthly period. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall file a monthly report with the city council, with a copy to the city clerk, showing the following: 
(1)  The number of inspections performed within the month. 
(2)  The person or persons for whom the inspection was performed. 
(3)  The total inspection fee charged. 
(4)  The address of the premises upon which the inspection was performed. 
(Code 1980, § 6-174; Ord. of 12-30-1971, § 1)  
Secs. 14-482—14-500. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Plumbing Inspector 
 
Sec. 14-501. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 6-169; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 1)  
Sec. 14-502. - Appointment and term of office. 
The plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and until his successor is duly appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1980, § 6-170; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 1)  
Sec. 14-503. - Oath. 
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the plumbing inspector shall be required to take and subscribe to an oath of office that he will faithfully perform the duties of said office and file same with the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 6-171; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 1)  
Sec. 14-504. - Bond. 
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the plumbing inspector shall file a surety bond payable to the city, which shall be approved by the city council and conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, in the office of the city clerk. Such bond shall be executed with any recognized and responsible surety company authorized to do business in the state as surety thereon. 
(Code 1980, § 6-172; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 1)  
Sec. 14-505. - Entry powers. 
The plumbing inspector shall have the right to enter any business or residential building or industrial plant or factory for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article at any reasonable hour of the day. 
(Code 1980, § 6-173; Ord. of 7-31-1947, § 1)  
Secs. 14-506—14-520. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 14-521. - Illinois Plumbing Code—Adopted. 
A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as "2004 Illinois Plumbing Code," be and is hereby adopted by the city for the regulation of the erection, installment, alteration, repairs, relocation, replacement, addition to, uses or maintenance of plumbing systems within the corporate limits; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of the 2004 Illinois Plumbing Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set forth herein in their entirety, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 14-522. 
(Code 1980, § 6-176; Ord. No. 88-7, § 2, 5-26-1988; Ord. No. 91-58, § 3, 12-23-1991; Ord. No. 94-43, § 2, 7-28-1994; Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 2-13-1997; Ord. No. 00-56, § 1, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-67, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 09-17, § 2, 5-14-2009)  
Sec. 14-522. - Same—Amended. 
(1)  The 2004 Illinois Plumbing Code is hereby amended by the following revisions: 
Section 890.110(b): Add to Section number 3) The following additional requirements shall apply: a) all new water lines for water services shall be copper, brass, or ductile iron pipe; b) all water lines below the ground within buildings shall be a minimum "K" copper; c) all water lines within structures shall be "L" copper or galvanized; d) all below ground materials for waste and vents within buildings and within the space five (5) feet or less from the building shall be cast iron; e) all sewer shall have a minimum six (6) inch cleanout; f) waste and vent line above ground within buildings may be plastic as allowed by the 2004 Illinois Plumbing Code. 
Section 890.120: Add to paragraph entitled "Private Sewer" the sentence: Permitted only upon specific approval by the Calumet City City Council and must be installed in accordance with the 1999 Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Code and the Cook County Sewage Disposal Ordinance. 
Section 890.120: Add to paragraph entitled "Private Water Supply" the sentence: Permitted only upon specific approval by the Calumet City City Council and must be constructed in accordance with the Illinois Water Well Construction Code. 
Section 890.170: Delete section "Sewer and/or Water Required" in its entirety and substitute the following: 
"Every building erected within the corporate limits of the City of Calumet City subsequent to the date of the adoption of this Chapter with an installed plumbing system and intended for human habitation or occupancy located on premises adjacent to or abutting a public water line and public sanitary sewer line shall have a connection made to the public water and public sewer system. If public water and/or sewers are not available, a well and/or private sewage disposal system may be permitted upon specific approval of the City of Calumet City and the Cook County Health Department." 
Section 890.1940 General Administration: Add to this Section the following language: 
"It shall be the obligation of the person installing, remodeling or repairing plumbing in the City to secure approval of alternative materials or methods from the Plumbing Inspector prior to beginning work." 
Section 890.320 0-1: Compression Type Joints: Add to this section "For Underground Use Only." 
Section 890.320 0-2: Compression Type Joints: Add to this section "For Underground Use Only." 
Section 890. Appendix C. Illustration C: Compression Type Joints: Add to this section "For Underground Use Only." 
Section 890.1360: Add new Section A-3: "Any sanitary waste which is below the outside building grade shall be discharged into a gas-tight covered and vented sump from which the waste shall be lifted and discharged into the building gravity drainage system by a 2 inch ejector pump and shall be protected against back flow by a check and gate valve between the pump discharge and the building gravity drainage system. Sumps receiving sanitary waste shall be of a one piece water-tight design." 
Section 890.1190(B): Delete the second sentence of the paragraph labeled "Water Supply Control" and substitute the following sentence: "In addition thereto, an accessible ball-type shutoff valve shall be provided inside near the entrance of the water service pipe into the building as well as on the house side of the water meter with a drip valve." 
Section 890.1580(B): "Size of Individual Vents:" Delete in its entirety and substitute the following new paragraph: "Size of the Individual Vents. The diameter of an individual vent shall not be less than one and one-half (1½) inch or less than one-half (½) the diameter of the drain to which it connects. See subsection (b) above." 
Section 890.1320(c): Add the following Section 1320(c): "Plumbing fixtures not exceeding two (2) inches in diameter are permitted in outside walls of construction. Insulation to be installed between exterior sheathing and pipes." 
Section 890.1140(J): Add the following Section 890.1140(J): "Locating hot and cold water lines in exterior walls is not permitted. If it is impossible to locate them in another place, they shall be insulated with a material having an "R" Factor of not less than seven (7) and the wall cavity shall be vented with high and low return grills to allow ambient air temperatures from the habitable area to interchanges with the wall cavity." 
(2)  The 2004 Illinois Plumbing Code is hereby amended by the following additions: 
a)  Water service pipe under two (2) inches in diameter shall be type "K" copper tube with flared fittings. Water service pipe greater than two (2) inches in diameter shall be ductile iron water main and fittings and shall be buried to a depth of not less than five (5) below grade from the "B" box to the riser for water meter attachment. Water distribution piping inside buildings shall be type "K" (soft) copper when underground, and type "L" (hard drawn) copper when above ground with sweat fittings. No type "M" copper shall be allowed for potable water piping. 
b)  Water Efficient Measures: 
1.  The installation of the following water efficient plumbing fixtures (based on a pressure at the fixture of 40 to 50 psi) shall be required in all new construction and in all repair and/or replacements of fixtures or trim: 
Maximum Flow 	Fixtures 
Water closets, residential 	1.6 gal. per flush 
Water closets, tank type 	3.5 gal. per flush 
Water closets, flushometer type 	3.0 gal. per flush 
Urinals, tank type 	3.0 gal. per flush 
Urinals, flushometer type 	3.0 gal. per flush 
Shower heads 	3.0 gal. per minute 
Lavatory, sink faucets 	3.0 gal. per minute 
 
2.  If an air conditioning system is installed, all closed system air conditioning shall be required in all new construction, and in all new remodeling. 
3.  All lavatories for public use in new construction or remodeling shall be equipped with metering or self-closing faucets. 
4.  All newly constructed or remodeled car wash installations shall be equipped with a water recycling system. 
c)  The drainage system conveying storm water from roofs, paved areas and courts and subsoil from or adjacent to buildings, shall be connected to the storm sewer, if available, or other approved disposal device in accordance with Calumet City Water or Sewer Department requirements. Storm water from roofs of private dwellings or accessory structures with or without gutters or down spouts may be spilled or discharged on the ground, provided structural, public health or other nuisance hazards are not created thereby. 
d)  Sub soil drains on the same lot shall be connected to the drainage system of the building within the lot lines. 
e)  "All plumbing contractors working within the City of Calumet City must furnish the Plumbing Inspector with a copy of his or her State of Illinois Contractor's Plumbing License and an up-to-date certificate of insurance prior to the issuance of a plumbing permit. All commercial plumbing installations, repairs, alterations or replacements must be performed by a licensed plumber. The Plumbing Inspector will be responsible for the maintaining of an up-to-date file of those plumbing contractors properly licensed." 
f)  In the case of improvements on residential, commercial or industrial buildings or property, the issuance of a plumbing permit is required to make the following repairs, replacements or changes: 
1.  Conversion from galvanized water piping to copper. 
2.  Addition of a plumbing fixture. 
3.  Replacement of nonresidential water heater or boiler. 
4.  Installation or conversion to overhead sewer system or anti-flood system. 
5.  Underground law sprinkling systems. 
6.  Any plumbing changes or additions to any part of the waste, vent, water piping or sewer system. 
g)  All lawn irrigation or sprinkling systems that are supplied by a potable water source must provide protection for this water source through the use of an RPZ reduced pressure backflow preventor. The RPZ shall be tested in-line before being placed into service and annually by a cross-connector control device inspector. 
Appendix A/Table 4 - APPROVED MATERIALS FOR WATER SERVICE PIPE - Delete numbers 1, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11. 
Appendix A/Table 6 - APPROVED MATERIALS FOR WATER DISTRIBUTION PIPE - Delete numbers 2, 5, 6 and 7. 
h)  All residential dwelling units shall have a clean out located outside the structure on the sanitary sewer line. 
i)  A copper (12-gauge) tracer wire shall be installed on all non-metallic sanitary and storm sewer pipe located underground. 
j)  Water tap to building shall be inspected by the Plumbing Inspector. 
k)  All inspection to irrigation system shall be made by the Plumbing Inspector. 
l)  All storm and sanitary sewer within a building shall be of cast iron or ductile iron for below grade but PVC pipe may be used for corrosive waste only. 
(3)  The 2004 Illinois Plumbing Code is hereby amended by the following deletions: 
Section 890.1520(F): Circuit Vent. 
Section 890.1500: Installation of wet venting. 
Section 890.1520: Circuit and loop venting. 
Section 890.1590(D): Size of circuit vents. 
(Code 1980, § 6-177; Ord. No. 97-10, § 2, 2-13-1997; Ord. No. 00-56, § 2, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-67, § 2, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 09-17, § 3, 5-14-2009)  
Secs. 14-523—14-550. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - HOUSING CODE[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-231 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-551. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless otherwise clearly indicated: 
Basement means a portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
Cellar means a portion of a building located partly or wholly underground and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
Dwelling unit means a room or group of rooms used or intended to be used as a housekeeping unit for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
Habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes. This term does not include bathrooms, toilet rooms, laundries, pantries, foyers, corridors, storage spaces, stairways or closets. 
Occupant means any person living, sleeping, cooking or eating in, or having actual possession of a dwelling unit. 
Owner means any person who has legal or equitable title to a dwelling unit, the agent of said person, or any person having management or control of any dwelling unit. 
Person means an individual who is an owner or occupant of a dwelling unit. 
Sleeping room means a room rented as sleeping and living quarters, but without cooking facilities, and with or without an individual bathroom. In a suite of rooms without cooking facilities, each room which provides sleeping accommodations shall be counted as one (1) sleeping room. 
(Code 1980, § 14-1; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 2)  
Sec. 14-552. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any provision of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this chapter shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 14-10; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 10)  
Sec. 14-553. - Conflicts. 
In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the public health and safety shall prevail. 
(Code 1980, § 14-2; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 12)  
Sec. 14-554. - Scope and application; compliance required. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to every dwelling unit used for human habitation which was erected, altered or converted after March 6, 1967. It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy or permit the occupancy of any dwelling unit which does not comply with the requirements of this chapter or the regulations of the building commissioner promulgated pursuant to this chapter; provided that compliance with this chapter shall not operate to exempt any dwelling unit from the requirements of the building code, the plumbing code, the zoning ordinance, or any other applicable ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 14-3; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 1)  
Sec. 14-555. - Relative maintenance responsibilities. 
(a)  The occupants of each occupied dwelling unit, whether rented or owned, shall be responsible: 
(1)  To keep such dwelling in a clean, sanitary and safe condition; 
(2)  To keep all plumbing and other fixtures required by this chapter in a clean and sanitary condition; 
(3)  To exterminate any insects, rodents or other pests which may be found on the premises; 
(4)  To dispose of all garbage and other refuse in the containers and in the manner required by this Code; 
(5)  To hang and remove all screens required for the dwelling unit; and 
(6)  Not to place on the premises any material which causes a fire hazard or otherwise endangers the health or safety of any occupant of such dwelling unit, nor place in storage on the premises any furniture, equipment or material which harbors insects, rodents or other pests. 
(b)  The owners of any dwelling unit which has been rented for human habitation shall be responsible for providing and keeping in good operating condition such equipment as is required in such dwelling by this chapter and maintaining in a clean, sanitary and safe condition the shared or public area of any of the building in which said dwelling units are located. 
(c)  The owner or owners of any dwelling unit or units which have been rented for human habitation who reside outside of the city shall provide, within thirty (30) days of the effective date of this chapter or within thirty (30) days of acquiring ownership of any dwelling unit or units located within the city, the name, address and telephone number of a management agent for the unit or units who reside in the city to the department of inspectional services and to the inhabitant of each dwelling unit unless such dwelling unit is inhabited by an on-site management agent. The name, address and telephone number of any on-site management agent shall also be provided to the department of inspectional services. 
(d)  All owners of dwelling units rented for human habitation shall abide by all applicable ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and policies established by the city and shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation of any provision contained therein. Each day any violation of any provision of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 14-4; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 7; Ord. No. 01-41, § 1, 8-9-2001)  
Sec. 14-556. - Basement and cellar dwellings. 
No basement space or cellar space shall be used for a dwelling unit unless: 
(1)  The floors and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness. 
(2)  The required minimum window area is located entirely above the finished elevation of the ground adjoining the building wall in which the windows are located. 
(3)  The dwelling unit meets the other requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 14-5; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 6)  
Secs. 14-557—14-570. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
 
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 14-571. - Enforcement generally. 
The building commissioner shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 14-6; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 8)  
Sec. 14-572. - Entry powers. 
For the purposes of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the building commissioner is hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey at all reasonable times all dwelling units. 
(Code 1980, § 14-7; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 8)  
Sec. 14-573. - Notice of violations; correction required. 
If any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be found to exist by the building commissioner after an inspection conducted pursuant to this chapter, the building commissioner shall serve written notice of such violation upon the owner or his agent or the occupant of the premises involved as the case may require. Such notice may be served at the time of inspection or by mail within ten (10) days after the date of such inspection. Such notice if not served personally shall be deemed properly served if a copy is sent to such occupant or to the owner as the case may require it, by U.S. mail at his last-known address. The notice shall indicate the provisions of this chapter which are being violated and may grant a period of time for compliance, which period shall not exceed fifteen (15) days. If such violations have not been eliminated within the time granted, the owner or occupant failing to comply shall be subject to the penalty provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1980, § 14-8; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 8; Ord. No. 81-34, § 1, 10-22-1981)  
Sec. 14-574. - Rules and regulations. 
The building commissioner is hereby authorized and empowered to make such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Such rules and regulations may be promulgated from time to time and shall be effective upon approval by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1980, § 14-9; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 9)  
Secs. 14-575—14-590. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Units Unfit for Human Habitation 
 
Sec. 14-591. - Defined. 
A unit shall be deemed to be unfit for human habitation if it is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin-infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public, or if it lacks illumination, ventilation or sanitation facilities adequate to protect the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(Code 1980, § 14-71; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 11)  
Sec. 14-592. - Vacating required. 
If, after a hearing at which all persons affected may appear and show cause why the dwelling unit should not be vacated, the building commissioner should determine that any dwelling unit is unfit for human habitation, he shall order such dwelling unit to be vacated within a reasonable time. Such unit shall remain unoccupied until the building commissioner shall determine that the defect or defects upon which the order of vacation was based have been eliminated. 
(Code 1980, § 14-72; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 11)  
Sec. 14-593. - Notice of hearing on subject. 
The building commissioner shall give ten (10) days' notice in writing to the owner and occupants of the hearing on the vacation of any dwelling unit; provided that if the building commissioner shall determine that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health and safety, he may order any dwelling unit to be immediately vacated without the notice and hearing provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 14-73; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 11)  
Sec. 14-594. - Notice to vacate. 
All dwelling units which the building commissioner has ordered to be vacated shall be placarded by him as follows: 
ORDER TO VACATE 
This dwelling unit has been found to be unfit for human habitation by the Building Commissioner of the City of Calumet City pursuant to the ordinance of Calumet City, setting a minimum standard of occupancy, ventilation, sanitation and maintenance for all dwellings used for human habitation in the City of Calumet City, Illinois. No person shall occupy or let for occupancy this dwelling until after _______, 19___. Any person occupying or letting for occupancy this dwelling unit after the above date, shall be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or incarceration in a penal institution other than the state penitentiary for a period not to exceed six (6) months or both for each day of such occupancy. 
(Code 1980, § 14-74; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 11)  
Sec. 14-595. - Removal of notice. 
Any person removing the placard required by this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 14-75; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 11)  
Secs. 14-596—14-610. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OCCUPANCY REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 14-611. - Area. 
Every dwelling unit shall contain not less than three hundred (300) square feet of floor space for the first two (2) occupants thereof, and one hundred (100) square feet of floor space for each additional occupant thereof; such floor area shall not include verandas, porches, terraces, balconies and basements; provided, however, that at least one (1) habitable room in each dwelling unit shall have no less than one hundred twenty-five (125) square feet of floor space. 
(Code 1980, § 14-22; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 3(a))  
Sec. 14-612. - Maximum occupancy. 
The number of persons occupying a dwelling unit shall not exceed one and one-half (1½) times the number of habitable rooms contained in such dwelling unit. In the calculation of the number of persons occupying a dwelling unit, children under one (1) year of age shall not be included and children under the age of twelve (12) years shall be counted as one-half of a person. 
(Code 1980, § 14-23; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 3(d))  
Sec. 14-613. - Area of sleeping rooms. 
(a)  Every sleeping room shall contain the following minimum floor space: 
Number of 
Occupants 
in Room 	Minimum 
Floor Space 
(square feet) 
1 ..... 	70 
2 ..... 	90 
3 ..... 	140 
 
For the fourth, and each additional occupant, the sleeping room shall contain an additional fifty (50) square feet of floor space for each such occupant. 
(b)  For the purpose of making the computations required by this section, children under the age of one (1) year shall not be considered in computing required floor space. 
(Code 1980, § 14-24; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 3)  
Sec. 14-614. - Ceiling height in habitable rooms. 
No habitable room shall have a ceiling height of less than seven and one-half (7½) feet. 
(Code 1980, § 14-25; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 3(c))  
Secs. 14-615—14-630. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - REQUIRED FIXTURES 
 
Sec. 14-631. - Water closet. 
Every dwelling unit shall contain within its walls and separate from all other rooms, a room equipped with a flush water closet. Such room shall contain a window which may be opened to outside air or mechanical or gravity ventilation in proper operating condition. Such water closet shall conform with the requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 14-37; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(a))  
Sec. 14-632. - Plumbing generally. 
Every kitchen sink, lavatory, bathtub, shower and water closet required by this article shall be maintained in good operating condition and shall be properly connected to water and sewer systems approved by the plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 14-38; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(c))  
Sec. 14-633. - Lavatory. 
Every dwelling unit shall contain a lavatory which is located in the same room as the flush water closet or as near to that room as is practicable. Such lavatory shall conform with the requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 14-39; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(b))  
Sec. 14-634. - Bathtub or shower. 
Every dwelling unit shall contain within its walls a room separate from the other habitable rooms and equipped with a bathtub or shower. 
(Code 1980, § 14-40; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(c))  
Sec. 14-635. - Location of certain sanitary facilities. 
The water closet, lavatory and bath or shower required by this article may be located in the same room provided that such room is separate from all habitable rooms in the dwelling unit. 
(Code 1980, § 14-41; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(c))  
Sec. 14-636. - Kitchen sink. 
Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink. 
(Code 1980, § 14-42; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(d))  
Sec. 14-637. - Heating facilities. 
Every dwelling unit shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and water closet compartments contained therein to a minimum temperature of seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit from September fifteenth to May fifteenth, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., and to a minimum temperature of sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; provided, however, that gas appliances designed exclusively for cooking or water heating purposes shall not be considered as heating facilities within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 14-43; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(f))  
Sec. 14-638. - Water heater. 
Every dwelling unit shall have a water heater which shall be kept in a good and efficient operating condition at all times. 
(Code 1980, § 14-44; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(h))  
Secs. 14-639—14-660. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - VENTILATION AND LIGHTING 
 
Sec. 14-661. - Windows required; total area generally. 
Every habitable room shall have a window which may be opened to the outdoors. The minimum total window area measured between the stops shall be ten (10) percent of the floor area of such room. 
(Code 1980, § 14-56; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 5(a))  
Sec. 14-662. - Screens. 
The windows and doors and other openings to external air of every dwelling unit shall be equipped with adequate screens and appliances so attached and arranged as to prevent the ingress of flies and mosquitoes to the interior of such dwelling unit from April fifteenth to November fifteenth of each year. 
(Code 1980, § 14-57; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 4(g))  
Sec. 14-663. - Sleeping rooms. 
Every sleeping room shall have a total area, openable to the outside air by means of windows, which is not less than three (3) percent of the floor area of such room. 
(Code 1980, § 14-58; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 5(b))  
Sec. 14-664. - Kitchens. 
Windows shall not be required in kitchens having a floor area of less than seventy (70) square feet provided such kitchens open into a habitable room which meets the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 14-59; Ord. of 1-12-1967, § 5(c))  
Secs. 14-665—14-690. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE

(Code 1980, § 6-221; Ord. No. 84-43, § 1, 12-13-1984; Ord. No. 88-7, § 3, 5-26-1988; Ord. No. 92-9, § 1, 2-27-1992; Ord. No. 94-43, § 3, 7-28-1994; Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 1-9-1997; Ord. No. 00-59, § 1, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-72, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 07-38, § 1, 4-26-2007)

No plastic sheeting may be installed, attached or maintained on the exterior of any structure for insulation, weatherproofing, or other purposes, except in the case of emergency weatherproofing approved by the department of inspectional services and not exceeding a forty-five (45) day period. Boarded up windows, doors, holes or other areas shall be painted or colored in a manner that is consistent with the building colors upon application to the building. The coating applied shall render the boarding used to cover windows, doors or other areas as inconspicuous as possible. A building inspection shall be performed by the department of inspectional services and building permit obtained prior to the boarding up of any vacant structure. The building permit can be waived for an emergency board up approved by the department of inspectional services. Certificates of inspections shall be posted within each elevator and one (1) copy shall be sent to the department of inspectional services. 
(Code 1980, § 6-222; Ord. No. 97-2, § 3, 1-9-1997; Ord. No. 98-3, § 1, 1-22-1998; Ord. No. 00-59, § 1, 10-12-2000; Ord. No. 05-72, § 1, 10-13-2005; Ord. No. 07-38, § 1, 4-26-2007; Ord. No. 10-64, § 3, 12-9-2010; Ord. No. 18-48, § 10, 8-23-2018)  
Secs. 14-693—14-710. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RENTAL DWELLING INSPECTIONS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-49, adopted June 22, 2006, amended division 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former division 2, which consisted of §§ 14-711—14-718, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1980 Code; Ord. No. 87-5, adopted Mar. 26, 1987; Ord. No. 87-16, adopted July 23, 1987; Ord. No. 88-2, adopted Feb. 25, 1988; Ord. No. 89-8, adopted Feb. 9, 1989; Ord. No. 89-40, adopted Nov. 9, 1989; Ord. No. 90-1, adopted Jan. 11, 1990; Ord. No. 94-16, adopted May 12, 1994; and Ord. No. 04-42, adopted June 29, 2004. 
 
Sec. 14-711. - Certificate of occupancy requirement. 
(a)  No owner, agent or person (hereinafter referred to as "responsible party") in charge of a one-family, two-family or multiple-family dwelling (hereinafter referred to as "rental dwelling"), as those terms are defined in the property maintenance code, shall allow any person to occupy the same as a tenant or lessee or for valuable consideration unless said dwelling or structure shall have been inspected and determined to be in compliance with all of the provisions of the property maintenance code as well as all health and building ordinances as evidenced by a certificate of occupancy issued by the department of inspectional services ("department"). Thereafter, all rental properties shall be inspected annually and an updated certificate of occupancy issued. 
(b)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless the applicant[,] owner or operator agrees in his application to an inspection pursuant to this section. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, when the city conducts inspections of a tenant's rental dwelling, the city must obtain the consent of such tenant to conduct the inspection. If a tenant refuses consent, the city may attempt to obtain a warrant pursuant to subsection (d) below. 
(c)  Prior to the time that the department is scheduled to conduct the inspection, the department shall deliver to the owner and occupants of the structure written notice that includes the following: 
(1)  Date and time of the inspection; 
(2)  A statement that the owner or tenant has the right to withhold his consent to the inspection and require the city to attempt to obtain a warrant to conduct the inspection; 
(d)  If the owner or occupant does not consent to the attempted inspection, the director of inspectional services ("director") or his designee shall seek in the circuit court of Cook County a warrant in accordance with the appropriate laws of the State of Illinois to allow an inspection. The application for the warrant shall specify the basis upon which the warrant is being sought and shall include a statement that the inspection will be limited to a determination whether there are violations of the city building and zoning ordinances or any applicable housing, fire or property maintenance codes or regulations. The court may consider any of the following factors along with such other matters as it deems pertinent in its decision as to whether a warrant shall issue: 
(1)  Eyewitness account of violation; 
(2)  Citizen complaints; 
(3)  Tenant complaints; 
(4)  Plain view violations; 
(5)  Violations apparent from city records; 
(6)  Property deterioration; 
(7)  Age of property; 
(8)  Nature of alleged violation; 
(9)  Similar properties in the area; 
(10)  Documented violations on similar properties in the area; 
(11)  Passage of time since last inspection; 
(12)  Previous violations on the property. 
(e)  If the annual inspection establishes that the rental dwelling complies with all the provisions of the property maintenance code as well as all other health, zoning, and building ordinances of the city, then the department of inspectional services shall issue a certificate of occupancy for said dwelling or structure. The certificate shall indicate the date of the inspection; that such dwelling or structure complies with the requirements of the property maintenance code as well as other health and building ordinances that apply to the dwelling. One (1) copy of the certificate shall be delivered to or mailed to the owner of the dwelling unit. A record of all certificates shall be kept on file by the department, and copies shall be furnished upon request to any person having a proprietary interest or tenancy interest in the dwelling affected. The director shall submit once a month to the mayor and the city council a list of addresses of those dwellings which have been inspected the previous month with an indication whether or not said dwellings have been issued certificate of occupancy permits. Every certificate of occupancy shall be issued for a period of one (1) year after its date of issuance, unless sooner revoked. 
(f)  Inspection fee schedule. 
(1)  Fifty dollars ($50.00) yearly. 
(2)  Ten dollars ($10.00) per additional unit. 
(3)  All inspection fees as herein provided shall be paid prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(4)  Each fee set for the above covers the cost of one (1) follow-up inspection to verify compliance. In the event that additional inspections are required because full compliance did not exist at the time of the reinspection, then an additional reinspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus ten dollars ($10.00) per unit shall be assessed. 
(5)  If an owner, agent or tenant has failed to appear for a scheduled inspection, an additional inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus ten dollars ($10.00) per unit shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006; Ord. No. 11-45, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Sec. 14-712. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Whenever the building official determines that any rental dwelling or the premises surrounding fails to meet the requirements set forth in this chapter or in applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto, the building official in accordance with the property maintenance code and the other city health, and building codes shall issue a notice setting forth the alleged failures and advising the responsible party that such failures must be corrected. This notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Set forth the alleged violations of this chapter or of applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto. 
(3)  Describe the rental dwelling where the violations are alleged to exist or to have been committed. Such written notice shall specify an appropriate or acceptable method of correction. 
(4)  Specify a specific date for the correction of any violation alleged. 
(5)  Be served upon the responsible party of the rental dwelling by the building official, or mailed to the responsible party. If one (1) or more persons to whom such notice is addressed cannot be found after diligent effort to do so, service may be made upon such persons by posting the notice in or about the rental dwelling described in the notice. 
(b)  At the end of the period of time allowed for the correction of any violation alleged, which was stated in the inspection notice, the building official shall reinspect the rental property described in the notice. 
(c)  If, upon reinspection, the violations are determined by the building official not to have been corrected, the building official, in turn, shall issue an O.V. (ordinance violation) ticket to initiate legal proceedings to be handled in Calumet City's housing court for the immediate correction of the alleged violations or shall order the rental property vacated within thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006)  
Sec. 14-713. - Responsibility of tenants. 
No tenant shall damage or cause to be damaged any unit or building leased nor shall any damage be caused to the general premises of any building used by the tenants. Each tenant and the families of each tenant shall maintain his rental unit free of any litter, and tenants shall not litter any of the premises or the buildings provided for use by the tenants. The tenants must maintain their responsibilities as outlined in the property maintenance code, subject to O.V. citations. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006)  
Sec. 14-714. - Penalties. 
Any responsible party of a rental dwelling who has received an order or notice of an alleged violation of this article shall be subject to a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each day the alleged violation continues after expiration of the specified reasonable consideration period; provided that no such penalty shall be applicable while reconsideration, hearing or appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction is pending in the matter. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006)  
Sec. 14-715. - Validity and severability. 
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase of this Code shall be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, this decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this Code, which shall continue in full force and effect, and to this end, the provisions of this Code are hereby declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006)  
Sec. 14-716. - Savings clause. 
This Code shall not affect violations of any other ordinance, code or regulation of the jurisdiction existing prior to the effective date hereof, and any such violation shall be governed and shall continue to be punishable to the full extent of the law under the provisions of those ordinances, codes or regulations in effect at the time the violation was committed. 
(Ord. No. 06-49, § 1, 6-22-2006)  
Secs. 14-717—14-750. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - FENCES 
 
Sec. 14-751. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
Fence means a manmade structure forming a barrier which is not a part of any building or structure and is more than two (2) feet in height over existing grade. 
Lock means a mechanism for keeping a door, lid, etc., fastened and typically operated only by a key of a particular form. 
Public safety means any organization including, but not limited to: emergency management agencies, law enforcement agencies, fire departments, rescue squads, and emergency medical services (EMS). 
Public safety personnel includes police officers, peace officers, firemen, firefighters, emergency medical technicians - ambulance, emergency medical technicians - intermediate, emergency medical technicians - paramedic, ambulance drivers, and other medical assistance or first aid personnel. 
Swimming pool means a receptacle for water, or an artificial pool of water having a depth at any point of more than two (2) feet, intended for the purpose of immersion or partial immersion therein of human beings, and including all appurtenant equipment. 
(Code 1980, § 9-1; Ord. of 12-11-1969, §§ 2, 6; Ord. No. 15-38, § 2, 9-10-2015)  
Sec. 14-752. - Construction permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build, construct or erect any fence without a fence construction permit issued by the building department. 
(Code 1980, § 9-2; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 1)  
Sec. 14-753. - Permit application. 
Any person desiring a fence construction permit shall apply in writing to the building department upon a form furnished by said department. In addition to the information required on said application, the application shall be accompanied by a sketch showing the proposed location of the fence in relation to lot lines and existing permanent improvements, the type of construction and materials to be used, and the proposed height of the fence. 
(Code 1980, § 9-3; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 1)  
Sec. 14-754. - Permit fee. 
Every person desiring a fence construction permit shall submit, along with the application for same, a permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Code 1980, § 9-4; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 1; Ord. No. 89-4, § 4, 1-26-1989)  
Sec. 14-755. - Restriction on air movement. 
No fence shall be constructed that will restrict fifty (50) percent of the surface air movement such as a solid fence would do. 
(Code 1980, § 9-5; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 3)  
Sec. 14-756. - Location with reference to lots or easements; releases. 
No fence shall be built, constructed or erected so as to extend past the front yard building line as established by the zoning ordinance, nor shall any fence be built past the side street yard on a corner lot as established by the zoning ordinance. No fence shall be erected in any public right-of-way. No fence shall be built, constructed or erected in any easement except wherein a release is given by the city prior thereto, absolving the city from all liability and damages resulting from subsequent entry for the purpose of repair, inspection, maintenance, installation or removal of utilities. Only one (1) fence shall be permitted along any lot line. 
(Code 1980, § 9-6; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4; Ord. No. 12-18, § I, 5-10-2012)  
Sec. 14-757. - Manner of construction when located in easement; liability of city. 
Any fence allowed or permitted in an easement shall be so constructed that the fence and post may be readily removable. The city shall in no way be held liable for the replacement of any fence removed, or any other expense entailed by the removal or reerection of any fence in the easement. 
(Code 1980, § 9-7; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4)  
Sec. 14-758. - Gate required. 
(a)  A gate or opening shall be provided in all fence enclosures. 
(b)  No lock, padlock or any device as defined in section 14-751 shall be placed on any gate or fence to prohibit ingress or egress of public safety personnel as defined therein. 
(Code 1980, § 9-8; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4; Ord. No. 15-38, § 3, 9-10-2015)  
Sec. 14-759. - Construction materials. 
Any suitable construction materials may be used for a fence except corrugated sheet steel, chicken wire, square-welded mesh wire, electrically charged wire, or a temporary snow fence. Except as otherwise provided, no fence shall be taped with sharp-edged materials; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not be construed to prohibit picket fences. The entire length of a fence shall be constructed of the same or of harmonious material. 
(Code 1980, § 9-9; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4)  
Sec. 14-760. - Barbed wire. 
Barbed wire may be used in commercial, office or manufacturing zoning districts provided that a fence constructed of same shall be located a minimum of seven (7) feet from the established grade and the barbed wire shall be turned to the inside of the property upon which it is erected. No such barbed wire shall be located closer than five (5) feet from any public street, sidewalk, alley, park or public right-of-way or public place. 
(Code 1980, § 9-10; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4)  
Sec. 14-761. - Height measurement. 
Except as otherwise provided, all height dimensions for a fence shall be measured from the established grade to the topmost section of the fence. 
(Code 1980, § 9-11; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4; Ord. of 7-6-1972, § 1; Ord. of 6-28-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 14-762. - Retention basins. 
All retention basins within the city shall be protected by a fence with a height of not less nor more than six (6) feet. This fence shall require a permit from the building department. The term "retention basin" is hereby defined as a receptacle for water or an artificial pool of water having a depth at any point of more than two (2) feet. 
(Code 1980, § 9-12; Ord. of 11-25-1975, § 1)  
Sec. 14-763. - Variances. 
The city council may approve a variance from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 9-13; Ord. No. 77-6, § 1, 3-10-1977)  
Sec. 14-764. - Maximum height in residential use districts. 
The maximum fence height in a residential use district shall be six (6) feet between buildings and shall be six (6) feet in height in the rear yard behind the building. 
(Code 1980, § 9-23; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 4; Ord. of 7-6-1972, § 1; Ord. of 6-28-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 14-765. - Maximum height in manufacturing use districts. 
(a)  The maximum height of any fence located in a manufacturing use district shall be eight (8) feet. 
(b)  The maximum height of a fence located in a commercial or office use district shall be seven (7) feet. 
(Code 1980, § 9-35; Ord. of 12-11-1969, § 5)  
Sec. 14-766. - Generally. 
All permanently constructed swimming pools shall be protected by a fenced enclosure as required for residential use, with a height of five (5) feet and shall be equipped with a self-closing gate and a latch five (5) feet over grade. This shall require an additional permit from the building department and the construction of said pool shall conform with the building code. All temporary, portable, sectional construction, aboveground or nonpermanent pools shall be protected by a fence enclosure as required for residential use with a height of not less than five (5) feet nor more than six (6) feet and shall be equipped with a self-latching gate. 
(Code 1980, § 9-47; Ord. of 7-6-1972, § 2; Ord. No. 93-33, § 1, 10-28-1993)  
Secs. 14-767—14-790. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - SWIMMING POOLS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-791. - Private residential pool defined. 
As used in this article, the term "private residential swimming pool" shall mean a receptacle for water, or an artificial pool of water having depth at any point of more than two (2) feet, intended for the purpose of immersion or partial immersion therein of human beings, and including all appurtenant equipment, constructed, installed and maintained in or above the ground outside of a building used for a single-family dwelling unit; provided further, that such private residential swimming pool is maintained by an individual primarily for the sole use of his household and guests and not for the purpose of profit or in connection with any business operated for profit. 
(Code 1980, § 6-187)  
Sec. 14-792. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  No portion of a private residential swimming pool shall be located at a distance less than eight (8) feet from any side or rear property line, or building line. Pumps, filters and pool water disinfection equipment installation shall be located at a distance not less than eight (8) feet from any side property line. Pools and appurtenant equipment shall not be permitted in the side yard between dwellings.
