(b)  No outdoor swimming pool intended for the use of members and their guests of a nonprofit club or organization, or limited to house residents of a multiple-dwelling unit, a block, subdivision, neighborhood, community or other specified areas of a residence, shall be permitted in a single-family residence district. 
(c)  A person may request a variance to locate a portion of a private residence swimming pool at a distance less than three (3) feet from any side or rear property or building line; provided that said person shall submit an application in writing to the city council setting forth the circumstances which, in the applicant's opinion, would justify a variance. A special variance may be granted when the city council deems necessary, and the applicant shall assume full responsibility in the operation and use of the pool so as not to be a nuisance or detriment to the adjoining property owner. 
(d)  All pools, whether permanent or temporary, shall only be allowed to be constructed, erected, and/or placed in the setback or backyard of the property on which they are located. 
(Code 1980, § 6-190; Ord. of 7-25-1974, § 1; Ord. No. 07-90, § 1, 9-13-2007)  
Sec. 14-793. - Operation and maintenance generally. 
(a)  All private residential swimming pools shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, and all equipment shall be maintained in satisfactory operating condition during the periods the pool is in use. 
(b)  No private residential swimming pool shall be used, kept, maintained or operated in the city if such use, keeping, maintaining or operating shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous to life or detrimental to health. 
(Code 1980, § 6-203)  
Sec. 14-794. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Purpose. This article provides the minimum requirements and standards for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Scope. The provisions of the article shall apply to the erection, installation, alteration, addition, repair, relocation, replacement, maintenance or use of any private or public pool system, including swimming pools, wading pools, spas, hot tubs, nonpermanent pools, hydrotherapy spas, soaking tubs and Jacuzzis. 
(c)  Existing installations. 
(1)  Any pool system lawfully installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section may have its existing use, maintenance or repair continued if the use, maintenance or repair is in accordance with the original design and location, and no hazard to the public health, safety or welfare has been created by such system. 
(2)  The owner or his/her designated agent shall be responsible for maintaining the pool system in a safe and sanitary condition. 
(d)  Nuisance declared, abatement. 
(1)  Any portion of a pool system found by the director of inspectional services or his designee to be unsanitary, as defined in this article, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(2)  Where a nuisance exists or poses a danger to life or is detrimental to the health and well-being of the residents and visitors of the city, or a pool system is maintained in violation of this article or any notice issued pursuant to this article, the director or code official shall require the nuisance or violation to be abated immediately and, where necessary, shall be subjected to the general penalty as provided in chapter 2, division 2, administration and enforcement, of the Municipal Code of Calumet City. 
(3)  If the director of inspectional services or his designee determines that a nuisance is present at a given location, said code enforcement official shall attempt to serve notice upon the owner or occupant of the nuisance. On the same day that attempted service of notice is made, notice shall be placed visibly on said house containing a nuisance declaration. Said notice shall provide for a forty-eight-hour period during which the owner or occupant of said property must abate said nuisance. During said forty-eight-hour period, the city shall attempt to secure a court order or warrant allowing for entrance onto the premises. If after the expiration of the forty-eight (48) hours said nuisance has not been abated, and after the city has obtained a court order or warrant allowing entrance onto the premises for the purpose of abating said nuisance, the director of inspectional services or his designee may undertake the abatement of the cited nuisance. After the abatement of the nuisance, the city comptroller shall notify the owner or occupant of the premises of the abatement and the costs incurred as a result of the city's removal and disposal of the nuisance. Said notice shall read as follows: 
"IT HAS BEEN DECLARED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF INSPECTIONAL SERVICES THAT THE _______ (swimming pools, wading pools, spas, hot tubs, hydrotherapy spas, soaking tubs and Jacuzzis) ON THIS PREMISES POSES A NUISANCE AND IS A THREAT TO THE LIFE, SAFETY, AND WELFARE OF THE CITIZENS AND VISITORS OF THE CITY OF CALUMET CITY. SAID NUISANCE MUST BE ABATED IMMEDIATELY. IF AFTER FORTY-EIGHT (48) HOURS AFTER THIS NOTICE IS POSTED SAID NUISANCE HAS NOT BEEN ABATED, THE CITY OF CALUMET CITY SHALL ENTER SAID PROPERTY UPON THE AUTHORITY OF A COURT ORDER OR WARRANT FOR THE SOLE PURPOSE OF ABATING SAID NUISANCE. THE CITY COMPTROLLER SHALL FORWARD AN INVOICE FOR THE COST OF SAID ABATEMENT TO THE PROPERTY OWNER. IF PAYMENT FOR SAID COSTS FOR THE ABATEMENT ARE NOT PAID IN FULL WITHIN THIRTY (30) DAYS OF ISSUANCE OF THE INVOICE, THE CITY COMPTROLLER OR HER DESIGNEE SHALL FILE A LIEN WITH THE OFFICE OF THE COOK COUNTY RECORDER OF DEEDS AND WITH THE CIRCUIT COURT OF ILLINOIS." 
(4)  In the event payment is not received within thirty (30) days of issuance of an invoice by the city, the city comptroller, or his/her designee, shall file a notice of lien in the office of the Cook County Recorder of Deeds, then such costs and expense shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens, except tax liens. 
(5)  Upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of, or persons interested in such property after a notice of lien has been filed, the lien provide for by this chapter shall be released by the city. 
(e)  Right of entry. 
(1)  Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this article, or whenever the director, code official or their authorized representative has reasonable cause to believe that there exist in any building or upon any premises any condition which makes such pool system unsafe, the director, code official or authorized representative may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the building or premises with the consent of the owner or occupant, or to perform any duty imposed upon the director by this article. If the building is unoccupied, the director, code official or authorized representative shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other personas having charge or control of the building or premises and demand entry. If the owner or occupant is unable to be located and the director deems that the threat is imminent, the director, code official or authorized representative shall document the condition which poses the danger and secure a warrant or court order to abate the nuisance. If such building or premises is occupied, the director, code enforcement official, or authorized representative shall first present proper credentials and demand entry, and state the reasons why they are there to inspect the pool or otherwise. If such entry is refused, the director, code official or his authorized representative shall have recourse to every remedy provided bylaw to secure entry. 
(2)  No owner or occupant, or any other person having charge, care or control of any building or premises, shall fail or neglect, after proper demand is made as provided in subsection (e)(1) of this section, to properly permit entry therein by the director, code official or their authorized representative for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to this article. Any person violating this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 06-58, § 1, 7-18-2006; Ord. No. 18-48, § 9, 8-23-2018)  
Secs. 14-795—14-810. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 14-811. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install, enlarge or alter private residential swimming pool and appurtenances unless all permits therefore have first been obtained from the building commissioner, the electrical and plumbing inspectors. Any and all inspections, including but not limited to, staking, repour, rough and final inspections, are required to secure building, plumbing and electrical permits. Any person constructing or installing wading pools and nonpermanent pools which are thirty-six (36) inches or deeper shall secure permits for said pool and appurtenances from the building commissioner, the electrical and plumbing inspector. 
(b)  Fee. The fee for a permit for the erection or construction of a private residential swimming pool shall be the current, applicable costs for building, electric and plumbing inspections for every one thousand (1,000) cubic feet or fraction thereof to be contained within the proposed pool. Persons constructing or installing wading pools or nonpermanent pool thirty-six (36) inches or deeper shall pay all applicable permit fees for building, electrical, and plumbing permits. 
(Code 1980, §§ 6-188, 6-189; Ord. No. 89-4, § 3, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 92-51, § 1, 11-12-1992; Ord. No. 06-58, § 2, 7-18-2006)  
Sec. 14-812. - Plans and drawings. 
(a)  All drawings and plans for the construction, installation, enlargement or alteration of any private residential swimming pool and appurtenances for which a permit is required shall first be presented to the building commissioner for examination and approval as to proper location, construction and use. 
(b)  All plans and drawings shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) of an inch to the foot, on paper or cloth, in ink, or by some process that will not fade or obliterate. All distances and dimensions shall be accurately figured and drawings made explicit and complete, showing the lot line, and including information pertaining to the pool, walk and fence construction, water supply system, drainage and water disposal systems, and all appurtenances pertaining to the swimming pool. Detail plans and vertical elevations shall also be provided in accordance with the building code. 
(c)  Such swimming pools, appurtenances, water supply and drainage system shall be constructed in conformity with the approved plans. If any deviations from such plans are desired, a supplementary plan covering that portion of the work involved shall be filed for approval and shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-191)  
Secs. 14-813—14-830. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION AND INSTALLATION STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 14-831. - Materials; slope of walls. 
(a)  Generally. Private residential swimming pool walls and floor shall be constructed of any impervious material which will provide a tight tank with white or light-colored finish and easily cleaned surfaces. The floor or bottom surface of the pool shall have a nonslip finish as smooth as possible. 
(b)  Walls. The side and end walls of a pool shall present a smooth finish and shall be vertical to a depth of at least six (6) feet or shall have a slope or curvature meeting one (1) of the following conditions: 
(1)  The pool wall may be vertical for thirty (30) inches from the water level below which the wall may be curved to the bottom with a radius at any point equal to the difference between the depth, at that point, and thirty (30) inches. 
(2)  To a depth of six (6) feet, except as in subsection (b)(1) of this section, the wall slope shall not be less than one (1) foot horizontal to six (6) feet vertical. 
(Code 1980, § 6-192)  
Sec. 14-832. - Water pressure; slope of bottom. 
Private residential swimming pools shall be designed to withstand the water pressure from within and to resist the pressure of the earth when the pool is empty, to a pressure of two thousand two hundred (2,200) pounds per square foot. The slope of the bottom of any part of a pool in which the water is less than five (5) feet in depth shall not be more than one (1) foot in each ten (10) feet. The maximum slope where water is five (5) or more feet in depth shall not exceed one (1) foot in two (2) feet. 
(Code 1980, § 6-193)  
Sec. 14-833. - Fencing. 
Private residential swimming pools shall be completely enclosed by a fence erected along the periphery of the pool walks. All fence openings or points of entry into pool area enclosure shall be equipped with gates. The fence and gates shall be five (5) feet above the walk grade level and shall be constructed of a minimum number nine (9) gauge woven wire mesh corrosion-resistant material, or material approved by the building commissioner. All gates shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices placed at the top of the gate and made inaccessible to small children. All fence posts shall be resistant to decay or corrosion and shall be set in concrete bases. 
(Code 1980, § 6-194; Ord. No. 93-34, § 1, 10-28-1993)  
Sec. 14-834. - Walks. 
Unobstructed walk areas not less than thirty-six (36) inches wide shall be provided to extend entirely around private residential swimming pools. The walk area shall be constructed of impervious material, and the surfaces shall be of such as to be smooth and easily cleaned and of nonslip construction. The slope of the walks shall have a pitch of at least one-fourth (¼) inch to the foot, designed so as to prevent back drainage from entering the pool. 
(Code 1980, § 6-195)  
Sec. 14-835. - Steps and ladders. 
Two or more means of egress in the form of steps or ladders shall be provided for all private residential swimming pools. At least one (1) such means of egress shall be located on a side of the pool at both the deep end and shallow end of the pool. Treads of steps and ladders shall be constructed of nonslip material and at least three (3) inches wide for their full length. Steps and ladders shall have a handrail on both sides. 
(Code 1980, § 6-196)  
Sec. 14-836. - Lifesaving personnel and equipment. 
(a)  A skilled swimmer shall be present at all times that private residential swimming pools are in use. 
(b)  Every private residential swimming pool shall be equipped with one (1) or more throwing ring buoys not more than fifteen (15) inches in diameter and having sixty (60) feet of three-sixteenths ( 3/16 ) inch manila line attached, and one (1) or more light but strong poles with blunted ends and no less than twelve (12) feet in length, for making reach assists or rescues. 
(Code 1980, § 6-197)  
Sec. 14-837. - Recirculation system. 
(a)  Private residential swimming pools shall be of the recirculation type in which circulation of the water is maintained through the pool by pumps, the water drawn from the pool being clarified and disinfected before being returned to the pool. 
(b)  Private residential swimming pool recirculation systems shall consist of pumping equipment, hair and lint catcher, filters, together with the necessary pipe connections to the pool inlets and outlets, facilities and pipe connections necessary for backwashing filters, and facilities and equipment for disinfecting the pool water. 
(c)  Every private residential swimming pool shall have a recirculating system with an hourly capacity equal to the pool volume divided by eight (8). 
(d)  Private residential swimming pool water recirculation system inlets shall be located so as to produce so far as possible uniform circulation of water throughout the pool without the existence of dead spots and to carry pool bottom deposits to the outlets, and shall discharge at a minimum depth of ten (10) inches below the pool overflow level. A minimum of one (1) recirculation system inlet shall be provided for every six hundred fifteen (615) square feet of surface area of the pool. 
(e)  The recirculation system pump shall have sufficient capacity to discharge the volume of water required for an eight (8) hour turnover of the pool against the maximum head in the recirculating system. 
(f)  The pump used for backwashing filters shall have sufficient capacity to provide a filter backwash rate of at least twelve (12) gallons per minute per square foot of filter area. 
(g)  A hair and lint catcher or strainer shall be installed on the suction side of the circulation pump to prevent hair, lint and other extraneous matter from reaching the pump and filters. Hair and lint catchers shall be so designed that they can be easily dismantled for cleaning and inspection and shall be so located as to be easily accessible for cleaning. The design features shall be such that water passes through the strainer from the outside. The strainer shall be made of noncorrosive material; the width or diameter of strainer openings shall be not more than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch, and the area of the strainer openings shall be at least five (5) times the cross-sectional area of the inlet pipe to the strainer. 
(h)  Recirculating systems shall contain rapid pressure filters. Sufficient filter area shall be provided to filter the entire contents of the pool in eighteen (18) hours at the rate of not more than three (3) gallons per square foot of filter area per minute. The filter backwashing facilities shall be sufficient to backwash at a rate of twelve (12) gallons per minute per square foot of filter area. All backwash water and effluents shall be discharged to the sewer through an indirect connection. Pressure filters shall be equipped with readily accessible air relief valves, loss of head or pressure gauges on the inlet and outlet pipes, and an access head or hole large enough to permit inspection, maintenance and repair work. Sight glasses that can be easily removed for cleaning shall be provided in the effluent line from the filter units. 
(i)  Equipment shall be provided for the disinfection of all pool water. Any disinfection method using materials other than chlorine compounds shall have sufficient capacity to maintain a minimum free chlorine residual of five (5) parts per million. The disinfectant shall be introduced into the recirculation system ahead of the filters. 
(j)  Gaseous chlorination systems shall not be made use of as a disinfection method for pool water. 
(Code 1980, § 6-198)  
Sec. 14-838. - Skimmers. 
In every private residential swimming pool, at least one (1) skimming device shall be provided for each eight hundred (800) square feet of surface area or fraction thereof. Skimmers shall be located at least thirty (30) feet apart. Handholes shall be provided and consist of a bull-nosed coping not over two and one-half (2½) inches thick for the outer two (2) inches or an equivalent approved handhold. The handhold must be no more than nine (9) inches above the normal waterline. Skimming devices shall be built into the pool wall, shall adequately remove floated oils and waste, and shall meet the following general specifications: 
(1)  Each skimmer shall be designed for a flow-through rate of at least thirty (30) gallons per minute and a total capacity of all skimmers on any pool shall be at least fifty (50) percent of the required filter flow of the recirculation system. 
(2)  They shall be automatically adjustable to variations in water level over a range of at least three (3) inches. 
(3)  An easily removable and cleansable basket or screen through which all overflow water must pass shall be provided to trap large solids. 
(4)  The skimmer shall be provided with a device to prevent airlock in the suction line. If an equalizer pipe is used, it shall provide an adequate amount of makeup water for pump suction should the water of the pool drop below the weir level. This pipe shall be at least two (2) inches in diameter and shall be located at least one (1) foot below the lowest overflow level of the skimmer. 
(5)  An equalizer line shall be provided with a valve that will remain tightly closed under normal operating conditions, but will automatically open at a differential of not more than four (4) inches between the pool level and the level of the overflow tank. 
(6)  The overflow weir shall be of sufficient length to maintain a rate of flow of at least twenty (20) gallons per minute per linear foot of weir lip. 
(Code 1980, § 6-199)  
Sec. 14-839. - Water supply. 
No source of water other than that secured from the city waterworks distribution system shall be used in private residential swimming pools unless such source shall have been and continues to be tested and found to be equal to the state standards of purity for drinking water. 
(Code 1980, § 6-200)  
Sec. 14-840. - Electrical requirements. 
(a)  No underwater lighting fixtures or their circuit wiring shall be permitted for either public or private swimming pools in the city. Ceiling lighting and side wall lighting brackets only shall be installed. 
(b)  In all public swimming pools, side wall lighting brackets, if used, shall be placed a minimum of twelve (12) feet above the deck. All lighting fixtures and brackets are to be controlled by switches placed outside the entrance door to the swimming pool. 
(c)  No portable electrical equipment shall be operated from the deck. If vacuum cleaner is to be used, current supply shall be from ground fault interrupter receptacles outside the entrance door to the swimming pool. 
(d)  In all private swimming pools, no underwater lighting fixtures or their circuit wiring are permitted. Approved lighting methods shall be P.A.R. 38 incandescent lamps mounted on eaves of residences or on standards twelve (12) feet in height and set back a minimum of eight (8) feet from the outer edge of the deck. Overcurrent protection or disconnecting means shall be located at a remote distance from the pool and at the residence. 
(e)  No current-carrying electrical conductors shall cross private residential swimming pools, either overhead or underground, or within fifteen (15) feet of such pools. 
(f)  All metal fences, enclosures or railings near or adjacent to private residential swimming pools which might become electrically alive as a result of contact with broken overhead conductors or from any other cause shall be effectively grounded. 
(Code 1980, § 6-201; Ord. No. 92-50, §§ 1, 2, 11-12-1992)  
Sec. 14-841. - Drainage. 
(a)  Swimming pools shall be equipped with facilities for completely emptying the pool, and the discharge of the pool water to the sewer shall be at a rate not exceeding two hundred (200) gallons per minute. 
(b)  No direct connection shall be made to the sewer. 
(c)  Water drained from the pool shall not be discharged to the sewer system during periods of rain or storms. 
(Code 1980, § 6-202)  
Secs. 14-842—14-870. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - PUBLIC SPAS 
 
Sec. 14-871. - Scope of article. 
The requirements of this article shall apply to all commercial public spas within the city limits. 
(Code 1980, § 6-411; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-872. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto: 
Health department means the Health Department of the City of Calumet City. 
Inlet means an opening through which filtered water enters the pool. 
Main drain means the outlet or outlets in the lowest point of the floor of the spa. 
National Electrical Code means a code for the practical safe-guarding of persons and of buildings and their contents from hazards arising from the use of electricity for light, heat, power, or radio signaling, prepared by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA). 
National Sanitation Foundation (NSF) means a nonprofit, noncommercial organization which wholly owns the National Sanitation Foundation Testing Laboratory, 2355 West Stadium Boulevard, P.O. Box 1468, Ann Arbor, MI 48106. 
Plumbing shall have the meaning in the Illinois State Plumbing License Law and Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890). 
Public water system means a system for the provision to the public of piped water for human consumption, if the system has at least fifteen (15) service connections or regularly serves an average of at least twenty-five (25) individuals daily at least sixty (60) days per year. 
Skimmer means a mechanical device connected to the recirculation piping which is used to remove materials from the water surface. 
Spa means a basin of water designed for recreational or therapeutic use which is not drained, cleaned, or refilled for each user. It may include hydrojet circulation, hot water, cold water mineral bath, air induction bubbles, or some combination thereof. Industry terminology for a spa includes "therapeutic pool," "hydrotherapy pool," "whirlpool," "hot spa," "hot tub," etc. 
Turnover means the time required to recirculate the water volume of the spa through the filtration system. 
(Code 1980, § 6-412; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-873. - Inspections. 
The director of the department of inspectional services or his designee and the director of the health department or his designee shall have the authority to inspect spa construction and operation for the purpose of enforcing rules and regulations and shall have the authority to require closing of any area when such action is considered necessary to prevent possible spread of infection or disease. 
(Code 1980, § 6-419; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-874. - Water supply. 
The water supply for drinking, showers, and bathing purposes and for all plumbing fixtures, as well as the supply serving the spa, shall be obtained from a public water system. 
(Code 1980, § 6-413; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-875. - Sewage disposal. 
Wastewater generated from the operation of a spa shall discharge to a public sewer. 
(Code 1980, § 6-414; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-876. - Spa construction. 
(a)  Structural design. The structural design and materials used in the spa shall be in accordance with local building codes. They shall provide a sound, durable structure which will safely sustain the weights and pressures for which they are designed. The spa shall be watertight and surfaces shall be inert, nontoxic, smooth and easily cleaned. Surfaces shall not constitute a cutting, puncturing or abrasion hazard to patrons. Spas shall have light-colored interiors. Wooden tubs shall not be allowed except where used in conjunction with a durable, inert liner. 
(b)  Depths and handholds. Spas shall be provided with handholds around their perimeter in areas where water depth exceeds three (3) feet, six (6) inches. 
(c)  Steps. Steps shall be of contrasting color from the bottom. Contrasting color bands or lines may be used to indicate breaks in the floor level of the spa. Step treads shall have slip-resistant surfaces. 
(d)  Heater and temperature requirements. Spa gas heaters must be certified as meeting the latest American National Standards Institute's (ANSI Z21.56) standard. All heaters for spas shall be tested and approved by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and bear the ASME seal. Current collectors having a separate ground shall be installed at each inlet and outlet of electric heaters. A heating coil or pipe shall not be installed in the spa. Thermometers shall be provided in the piping to check the temperature of the water returning from the spa and the temperature returning to the spa. A temperature and pressure relief valve shall be provided on all water heaters and shall be pied to within six (6) inches of the floor. Venting of gas or other fuel-burning water heaters shall be provided. The maximum operating temperature of spa water shall not exceed one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit (forty (40) degrees Celsius). A thermostatic control for the water temperature shall be provided to ensure that this limit is not exceeded. It shall be accessible only to the operator. 
(e)  Electrical requirements. The latest National Electrical Code shall be used for the wiring and grounding of all electrical equipment associated with a spa and the bonding and grounding of all metallic appurtenances. Electrical switches, outlets and equipment shall be at least fifteen (15) feet from the edge of the spa and accessible only to the operator. 
(f)  Inlets and outlets. An over-the-rim fill spout with a six (6) inch air gap between the spout opening and the deck, properly shielded so as not to create a hazard, shall be provided. The spout shall have no sharp edges and shall not protrude more than two (2) inches beyond the edge of the spa. Where the fill spout cannot be located adjacent to a ladder or railing or railing, a hose bib located near the deck shall be provided to fill the spa. A means shall be provided to completely drain the spa. A bottom drain shall be provided. The total velocity through grate openings shall not exceed one and one-half (1½) feet per second. The opening in the grates shall be designed to prevent the entrapment of fingers, toes, etc. Water outlets shall be provided which consist of one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Two outlets having the same pipe diameter (this may be two (2) outlet drains or an outlet drain and a skimmer); 
(2)  One antivortex drain, which shall not provide a tripping hazard and shall prevent flows in excess of two (2) feet per second; 
(3)  A twelve (12) inch by twelve (12) inch or larger grate. 
(g)  Recirculation systems. The recirculation equipment shall provide a turnover rate for the entire water volume at least once every thirty (30) minutes. 
(h)  Overflow systems. The overflow system shall be designed and constructed so that the water level of the spa is maintained at the opening level of the weir. When surface skimmers are used as the sole overflow system, one (1) surface skimmer shall be provided for each one hundred (100) square feet, or fraction thereof, of the spa surface area. 
(i)  Filters. All filters shall meet the requirements of the National Sanitation Foundation Standard 50, and shall bear the NSF seal. 
(j)  Pumps and strainers. The recirculation pump shall deliver the flow necessary to obtain the turnover required in subsection (e) of this section. 
(k)  Valves. All valves shall be located where they will be easily accessible. 
(l)  Air induction systems. An air induction system, when provided, must prevent water backup that could cause electrical shock hazards. Such system shall be connected to a fifteen (15) minute timer located out of reach of any person in the spa. 
(m)  Disinfectant. A means of disinfecting the spa shall be employed which provides the required disinfectant residual in the water. A chlorine residual shall be maintained between three (3.0) and five (5.0) parts per million (ppm) as free chlorine, or a bromine residual shall be maintained between three (3.0) and five (5.0) ppm as free available bromine at all times. Where chlorinated cyanurates are used, the cyanuric acid concentration shall not exceed two hundred (200) ppm. The pH of the water shall be maintained in a range of seven and two-tenths (7.2) to seven and six-tenths (7.6). The department may consider the maintenance of a higher pH in conjunction with maintenance of a higher disinfectant residual in special cases where corrosive water supplies dictate the need for such measures to protect equipment. 
(n)  Chemical feeders. 
(1)  General. The minimum chemical feed equipment required shall include a unit for feed of a disinfectant. Chemical feed equipment shall comply with NSF Standard 50. 
(2)  Equipment capacity. 
a.  Chlorine. Equipment for supplying chlorine or compounds of chlorine shall be of sufficient capacity to feed the chlorine at a rate of twenty (20) ppm based on the required turnover rate and type of chlorine compound to be used. 
b.  Bromine. Pot feeders for supplying brom-chloro-dimethylhydantoin sticks shall contain at least 0.50 pound of bromo-chloro-dimethylhydantoin per thousand (1,000) gallons of spa capacity. The feeder shall have a method of feed rate adjustment. 
c.  Ozone. Ozone may be used as a supplement to chlorination or bromination. No more than one (1) gram per day of ozone per ten (10) gallons per minute of design flow rate will be allowed. The ambient air ozone concentration shall be less than .05 ppm at all times either in the vicinity of the ozonator or at the spa water surface. 
(3)  Positive displacement pumps (hypochlorinators). Where positive displacement pumps are used to inject the disinfectant solution into the recirculation line, they shall be of variable flow type and shall be of sufficient capacity to feed the amount of disinfectant required by section 14-876(n)(2). If calcium hypochlorite is used, the concentration of calcium hypochlorite in the solution shall not exceed five (5) percent. The solution container shall have a minimum capacity equal to the volume of solution required per day at the feed rate required in section 14-876(n)(2). 
(4)  Gas chlorinators. Gas chlorinators shall not be allowed. 
(5)  Erosion type chlorine feeders. 
a.  Erosion type chlorine or bromine feeders shall be approved in accordance with NSF Standard 50. 
b.  Where erosion type feeders are used, only the chemical specified by the feeder manufacturer shall be used as the disinfecting agent. 
c.  The chlorine feed capacity shall comply with section 14-876(n)(2). 
The chemical compound and percentage of chlorine in the compound, as well as the feeder flow capacity, shall be specified. A valve shall be provided to adjust the flow. 
(6)  Testing equipment. 
a.  A calorimetric DPD test kit shall be provided to determine free disinfectant residual and pH of the spa water. 
b.  Spas using chlorinated cyanurates for disinfection shall have a test kit to measure the cyanoric acid concentration. The cyanuric acid test kit shall permit readings in excess of two hundred (200) ppm Where bromine or chlorine is used as a disinfectant, a calorimetric test kit shall be provided which will determine free bromine or free chlorine residual and pH. At least five (5) standards shall allow measurements of the disinfectant in a range from three (3.0) to five (5.0) ppm. 
(o)  Sanitary facilities. Separate bather preparation facilities shall be provided for men and women. Each bather area shall consist of at least one (1) toilet, lavatory and shower. Each bather preparation room shall contain a floor drain. 
(p)  Ventilation. Equipment rooms, dressing rooms, and toilet spaces shall be lighted and ventilated. 
(Code 1980, § 6-415; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-877. - Decks. 
(a)  Decks and ramps shall be slip-resistant and free of standing water at all times. 
(b)  A paved, four (4) foot minimum, continuous unobstructed deck, which may include the coping, shall be provided around fifty (50) percent or more of the spa. 
(c)  The installation of deck coverings of synthetic fibrous material may be used only in separate patio or refreshment areas. 
(Code 1980, § 6-416; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-878. - Operation. 
(a)  Operating personnel. At least one (1) employee on duty during operating hours shall have completed the Standard First-Aid and Personal Safety Course as offered by the American National Red Cross or an equivalent course and shall be certified in cardiopulmonary resuscitation. 
(b)  Refilling. Spas shall be emptied, thoroughly cleaned with a disinfectant and refilled every week or at any time the turbidity is such that the bottom is not visible. 
(c)  Signs. A caution sign shall be posted adjacent to the spa's entrance. It shall contain the following warnings: 
CAUTION 
• 	Pregnant women, elderly persons, infants and persons requiring medical care, or suffering from high or low blood pressure should not enter the spa without prior medical consultation and permission from their doctor. 
	
• 	Use of the spa while under the influence of alcohol, tranquilizers, or other drugs or medicines that may cause drowsiness or may lead to serious consequences is prohibited. 
	
• 	Do not use at water temperatures greater than 104°F. 
	
• 	Do not use alone. 
	
• 	Unsupervised use by children under the age of fourteen (14) is prohibited. 
	
• 	Long exposure may result in nausea, dizziness, or fainting. 
	
• 	Keep all breakable objects out of the area. 
 
A sign shall be posted in the immediate vicinity of the spa stating the location of the nearest telephone and indicating that emergency telephone numbers are posted at that location. Those emergency telephone numbers shall include the name and phone number of the nearest available police, fire and/or rescue unit, physician, ambulance service, and hospital. 
A sign shall also be posted requiring a shower for each user prior to entering the spa and prohibiting oils, body lotion, and minerals in the water. 
(d)  Oils, body lotions, and minerals. The use of oils, body lotions, and minerals is prohibited. 
(e)  Personal hygiene. A shower shall be required before entering the spa. 
(f)  Water quality. The spa shall be closed when bacteriological analyses results show any of the following: 
(1)  Coliform concentrations of ten (10) per one hundred (100) ml in two (2) consecutive samples. 
(2)  Presence of fecal coliform in any sample or when the chlorine or bromine residual is below three (3.0) ppm as free chlorine, or three (3.0) ppm as free bromine. 
(Code 1980, § 6-417; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 14-879. - First aid kit. 
Each facility shall have a first aid kit which contains the following items: 
Two (2) units of three (3) inch bandage compress; two (2) units of eye dressing packet; two (2) units of triangular bandages; one (1) unit scissors and tweezers; one unit of one (1) inch adhesive tape; one (1) box band-aids of various sizes; antiseptic. 
(Code 1980, § 6-418; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Secs. 14-880—14-910. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-911. - Definitions. 
(a)  As used in this article, the term "building contractor" shall mean and include anyone engaged in the business of cement or concrete contracting, either flat, form or wall work, or as a masonry contractor; or as a carpenter contractor, or as a general building contractor; and engaged in the construction, alteration, demolition or repair of buildings or other structures, or sidewalks or street pavements. 
(b)  As used in this article, engaging in the construction, repair or alteration of any building, structure or street or sidewalk pavement in the city for which a permit is required under the ordinances of the city shall be construed as doing business as a contractor in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 6-31; Ord. of 12-22-1949, § 1)  
Sec. 14-912. - Compliance with laws required. 
It shall be the duty of all building contractors to comply with all ordinances relating to the construction of buildings or other structures, to the construction of street or sidewalk pavements, and all laws or ordinances pertaining to or regulating the activities that they are engaged in. 
(Code 1980, § 6-37; Ord. of 12-22-1949, § 4)  
Sec. 14-913. - Performance bond. 
When a building contractor shall build new construction on lots which have been heretofore undeveloped within the city limits, said contractor shall be required to install streets, curbs, sewers and infrastructure in conformity with current building regulations as approved by the city council, said cost to be borne by the contractor, prorata to the number of lots on such street. The contractor shall furnish to the city assurance of completion of all infrastructure requirements in a timely fashion in the form of a bond for performance in an amount of one hundred fifteen (115) percent of the estimated amount of completion costs, incorporating by reference the provisions of all contracts entered into to guarantee such completion. 
(Code 1980, § 6-38; Ord. No. 97-52, § 1, 9-29-1997)  
Secs. 14-914—14-930. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 14-931. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in business as a building contractor without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  Prior to being issued a license, or upon annual renewal, each contractor who contracts to do work within the city limits shall post with the department of inspectional services a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or as otherwise specified to indemnify and hold harmless the city against loss, costs, damage, judgement or liability of any kind whatsoever which the city may suffer or which may accrue against or be charged to the city or any of its officials arising out of or resulting from the conduct or operation of such business or the doings or failure to do any act in the connection herewith, in addition to any required license and permit fees. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be penalized by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day any violation shall continue it shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 6-32; Ord. of 12-22-1949, §§ 1—6; Ord. No. 94-48, § 2, 8-11-1994; Ord. No. 97-51, § 1, 9-29-1997; Ord. No. 97-56, § 1, 10-9-1997)  
Sec. 14-932. - Subcontractors. 
Any person doing business as a subcontractor shall be construed as engaged in the business of a building contractor for which a license is required by this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-33)  
Sec. 14-933. - Exception to article. 
The provisions of this article shall not be construed to require a license for the operation of the business of a plumbing contractor or for an electrical contractor who have registered pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 6-34; Ord. of 12-22-1949, §§ 1—6)  
Sec. 14-934. - License fees. 
(a)  The annual fee for a license required by this article shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for all general contractors and subcontractors, except for those persons subject to section 14-933 of this Code. 
(b)  The fee for a license obtained on or after July 1, of any year shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for all general contractors and subcontractors, except for those persons subject to section 14-933 of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 6-35; Ord. of 12-22-1949, § 5; Ord. No. 94-48, § 1, 8-11-1994; Ord. No. 05-87, § 2, 12-8-2005; Ord. No. 18-51, § 2, 9-13-2018)  
Sec. 14-935. - License revocation. 
Any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article may be revoked by the city for the violation by the licensee of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-36; Ord. of 12-22-1949, § 4)  
Secs. 14-936—14-960. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - HOUSE MOVING[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. 
 
Sec. 14-961. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to move any building on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place without a permit from the building commissioner. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the permits required by this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state thereon the proposed route and the number of days it is intended that the building should occupy any portion of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. 
(c)  Approval; fee. Upon the approval of the intended route by the building commissioner, a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus ten dollars ($10.00) for each day or fraction thereof that it is intended that the building shall occupy any portion of any such public place shall be paid to the city clerk and the permit required by this article issued. An additional payment of five dollars ($5.00) for each day or fraction thereof over and above the time stated on the permit, during which any building shall occupy any such public place, shall be paid. 
(Code 1980, §§ 6-49, 6-50, 6-51; Ord. of 5-8-1958, § 13)  
Sec. 14-962. - Bond. 
Every person applying for a permit under this division shall submit with his application a bond in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) conditioned on his compliance with all the provisions of this article, and agreeing to pay, and holding the city harmless from any claim which may be made against it by reason of the occupying of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place by the building or structure moved. 
(Code 1980, § 6-52)  
Sec. 14-963. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of house or garage moving, raising or storage without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the city clerk. 
(b)  Fee. The fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00) per building. 
(Code 1980, §§ 6-64, 6-65; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 34; Ord. No. 05-87, § 2, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 14-964. - Lights and warnings. 
Whenever a street or alley is blocked by a house or structure which is being moved, warnings to that effect shall be placed by the city engineer so as to warn vehicles and persons from entering that portion of the street which is so blocked. The person moving any building through the streets shall keep warning signs and lanterns or lights at night on the building so as to guard any person or vehicle from colliding with it. 
(Code 1980, § 6-53)  
Sec. 14-965. - Wires. 
Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public utility in moving a building, the terms of any special or franchise ordinance governing shall apply and the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such terms apply then the building commissioner shall estimate the expense of fixing the wires and the bond shall be given to cover this. 
(Code 1980, § 6-54)  
Sec. 14-966. - Planking street. 
The pavement of any street, alley or sidewalk on or along which any house is moved shall be protected by two-inch planks along the route. 
(Code 1980, § 6-55)  
Sec. 14-967. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 6-56)  
Secs. 14-968, 14-969. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - VACANT BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 14-970. - Intent. 
It is in the intent of this article to protect the public health, safety, and welfare by establishing a registration process for vacant buildings and requiring responsible parties to implement a maintenance plan for such buildings to remedy any public nuisance, prevent deterioration, unsightly blight and consequent adverse impact on the value of nearby property. 
This article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable laws, ordinances, codes and regulations which prescribe standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall apply. 
This article shall be construed liberally and justly to effect its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-971. - Declaration of policy. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city by: 
(1)  Establishing a program for the identification, registration and regulation of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date of this article. 
(2)  Determining the responsibilities of owners of vacant buildings. 
(3)  Providing for the administration, enforcement, including abatement of public nuisances and imposition of penalties. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-972. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, and the interpretation and application thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words or phrases not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Building shall mean any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy or activity. 
Building official shall mean the building official, as designated by the director, as herein defined, for purposes of this Article. 
City shall mean the City of Calumet City, Cook County, Illinois. 
City Code shall mean the Municipal Code of the City of Calumet City, as from time to time supplemented and amended. 
Director shall mean the director of the department of inspectional services or his or her designee. 
Owner shall mean any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or city as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court; or any such entity or designated agent owning, maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any building. Nothing contained in the definition herein should be construed to include a federal government mortgagee as an owner. 
Person shall mean a corporation, a partnership, or other entity as well as an individual. 
Premises shall mean a lot, plot or parcel of land including any structure thereon. 
Public nuisance shall mean and includes the following: 
(1)  The physical condition, or uses of any building regarded as a public nuisance at common law, under the Illinois Complied Statutes, or under the City Code; 
(2)  Any physical condition, use or occupancy or any building or its appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences or structures; 
(3)  Any building which has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; 
(4)  Any building designated by the director as unsafe for human habitation or use; 
(5)  Any building which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or manifestly unsafe or insecure as to endanger life, limb or property; 
(6)  Any building which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; 
(7)  Any building that is dangerous, in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; open or vacant doors or windows, or other openings are boarded up or secured, by any means other than conventional methods used in design of the building or permitted for new construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide shelter, in danger of collapse or failure and dangerous to anyone on or near the premises; or 
(8)  Any building defined or determined as dangerous or unsafe by any section of the City Code. 
Vacant building shall mean a building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, or at which substantially all lawful business or construction operations or residential occupancy has ceased or which is substantially devoid of content, including buildings ordered vacated by the director pursuant to authority granted by the City Code, state law or a court of competent jurisdiction. In determining whether a building is "vacant," the building official may consider these factors, among others: 
(1)  A building at which substantially all lawful residential or business activity has ceased, or the building is unoccupied and secured by boarding, or other similar means, or is unoccupied and unsecured; 
(2)  The percentage of the overall square footage of occupied to unoccupied space or the overall number of occupied or unoccupied units shall be considered. 
(3)  The building is substantially devoid of contents. The condition and value of fixtures or personal property in the building are relevant to this determination. 
(4)  The building lacks utility services, i.e., water, sewer, electric or natural gas. 
(5)  The building is the subject of a foreclosure action. 
(6)  The building is not actively for sale as part of a contractual agreement to sell the building, the building lacks "for sale", "for rent" or similar signage. 
(7)  The building is unoccupied and the presence or recurrence of uncorrected code violations exist; 
(8)  The building is unoccupied and has been the site of unlawful activity within the previous six (6) months; 
(9)  The building is unlawfully occupied; or 
(10)  The building is unoccupied and during such time the city has issued an order to correct a public nuisance condition and said condition has not been corrected in a code-compliant manner. 
But not including: 
(1)  Vacant buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes, legislation and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011; Ord. No. 13-59, § 2, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 14-973. - Vacant building determination; notice. 
The building official shall evaluate all buildings in the city that the building official believes to be unoccupied and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a vacant building within the meaning of section 14-972. The building official may determine that a building which meets any of the criteria set forth in section 14-972 is not to be regulated under this article for a stated period, if consideration of the building under this article would not serve the public health, welfare and safety and makes written finding in support of the decision that state the factual basis for the determination. 
For buildings the building official determines to be vacant buildings, the building official shall, within thirty (30) days of making that determination, send notice of such to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County tax roll requesting the registration of the building and submission of a vacant building plan with the building official. In the event any public nuisance exists in connection with the building or premises thereto then the building official shall specify in the notice the existence of such nuisances. Said notice of determination shall be sent first-class United States Mail, with proper postage prepaid. Failure of delivery shall not excuse a person from complying with the article. The building official may personally serve or cause personal service of the notice of determination. Any person making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The building official shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent. 
The notice shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the registration from the owner is required to file pursuant to this article and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the building official's determination. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-974. - Appeal of determination of vacant building. 
(a)  An owner of a building determined by the building official to be a vacant building may appeal that determination to the director. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the director within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the notice of determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register the building as required by this article. The appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the building official's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The director shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the owner in the written appeal and the building official's written determination. 
(b)  The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade the director that had the evidence been known to the building official at the time the building official made the determination, the building official would more likely than not have determined that the subject building was not a vacant building. 
(c)  The director shall send written notice of the decision to the owner within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the appeal. The director may, but is not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The director may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more than thirty (30) additional days, to decide the appeal if it is determined that such additional time is required for consideration of the appeal. The decision of the director shall be final. 
(d)  An owner who wishes to challenge the applicability of the article to their building without the building official's determination having been made, shall set forth specific facts to support non-applicability in writing to the building official. In the event the building official determines that the subject building is a vacant building, the owner shall have the right to appeal the building official's determination as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-975. - Obligation to register vacant building. 
(a)  Except as provided in this article, whenever any building in the city is vacant or the owner who knows or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that their building is or has become a vacant building, or the owner, which the building official determines at any time to be a vacant building, or the owner whose appeal from the building official's determination has been denied shall register such building as a vacant building and submit a vacant building plan within thirty (30) days after either the date of the building official's notice of determination or occurrence of the facts that would cause a reasonable person to believe that the building was a vacant building, or denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable. 
(b)  Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable City Code requirements, including this article, nor does it preclude any of the actions the city is authorized to take pursuant to this article or elsewhere in the City Code. Registration shall be deemed as prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the city against the owner of a building. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-976. - Registration of vacant building; annual fee. 
The owner registering a vacant building shall supply the following information on such form provided by the city. The form shall set forth, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of owner, a post office box address is not an acceptable address. 
(2)  Name, address, and telephone number of any local agent or representative, a post office box address is not an acceptable address. 
(3)  Name, address and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest in the property, building, and premises, a post office box address is not an acceptable address. 
(4)  Legal description and permanent index number of the premises on which the building is situated. 
(5)  The common address of the building. 
(6)  Date on which building became vacant. 
(7)  Vacant building plan. 
(8)  The form shall require the owner to indicate his or her "acceptance of notice" consenting to service of notices sent or required to be sent, pursuant to this article, by any designated local agent or representative. Any owner who fails to register or fails to renew registration or fails to maintain as current with the building official the information required regarding the person designated to accept notice and service of process of a vacant building under this article shall be deemed to consent to receive, by posting at the building, any and all notices of violations and all process in an administrative proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the building. 
(9)  Obtain property and liability insurance and maintain such insurance for as long as the building is vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the building official. 
The vacant building registration shall be filed with the building official accompanied with a two hundred dollar ($200.00) annual non-prorated non-refundable filing fee. All eleemosynary, religious, education, government and benevolent property are exempt from the payment of the annual registration fee, but shall otherwise comply with the requirements of this article. 
Registration of a vacant building shall be valid for a period of one (1) year. If the building is vacant at the expiration of any registration period, then the owner shall re-register such building and pay such annual filing fee, as herein required. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-977. - Vacant building plan. 
When a building is registered as required herein, the owner or agent shall submit a vacant building plan. The plan shall contain the following: 
(1)  A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction of similar type. Boarding shall be accomplished with materials and methods described by the city. The proposed repair shall result in openings secured by conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted for new construction of similar type. 
(2)  For buildings and premises thereof which are identified as being or containing public nuisances, then the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisances. 
(3)  For each required plan, a time schedule shall be submitted identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and identified nuisance. 
(4)  When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition. 
(5)  A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this article and the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-978. - Approval of vacant building plan. 
(a)  The building official shall review the proposed vacant building plan in accordance with the standards below. The building official shall send notice to the owner of his determination. 
(b)  Standards for plan approval. In considering appropriateness of a vacant building plan, the director shall consider the following and shall make written findings in accordance herewith: 
(1)  The purposes of this article and intent of the corporate authorities to minimize the time a building is boarded or otherwise vacant. 
(2)  The affect of the building and the proposed plan on adjoining property. 
(3)  The length of time the building has been vacant. 
(4)  The presence of any public nuisances on the property. 
(5)  The likelihood that the plan or portion(s) thereof will prevent or ameliorate the condition it is designed to address. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-979. - Authority to modify vacant building plan, right of appeal. 
The building official shall, upon notice to the owner, have the right to modify the vacant building plan by modifying the dates of performance, the proposed methods of action, or by imposing additional requirements consistent with this article, if the building official deems necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. If the owner objects to the modifications made by the building official, such owner shall have the right of appeal to the director for final determination. Such appeal shall be filed with the director within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the building official's notice of modification. The appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the building official's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The director shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the owner in the written appeal and the building official's proposed modifications or written determination. The director shall send written notice of the decision to the owner within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the appeal. The director may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more than thirty (30) additional days, to decide the appeal if it is determined that such additional time is required. The decision of the director shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-980. - Failure to comply with vacant building plan. 
Failure to have an approved plan within thirty (30) days of filing the registration form or failure to comply with the approved plan, at anytime, shall constitute a violation of this article subjecting the owner of the building to penalties as provided in this article and to any remedies the City may avail itself of as provided for herein and elsewhere in the City Code, including, but limited to, an action to compel correction. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-981. - Maintenance of alarm and sprinkler systems. 
Whenever an owner is required to maintain an alarm or sprinkler system, the owner shall continue to maintain said alarm or sprinkler system during all times that a building is vacant. This shall include any and all necessary systems and appurtenances incident thereto to keep said alarm or sprinkler operable, including, but not limited to, source(s) of water, heat or electricity. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-982. - Owner responsibility to secure vacant building. 
Upon written notice of the building official, an owner shall provide bonded, licensed and insured guard service at the vacant building between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Such service shall remain in place until the building official gives written notice to the owner that the service is no longer required. Such service shall be required when the building official makes a written determination that the vacant building constitutes a fire hazard, is otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, involves illegal or improper use, occupancy, or maintenance, under such conditions that securing the building are insufficient to prevent the actual or threatened harm. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-983. - Other enforcement. 
The registration of a vacant building shall not preclude action by the city to demolish or to take other action against the building pursuant to other provisions of this article, the City Code, or other applicable legislation. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-984. - Change of ownership. 
The vacant building plan shall remain in effect notwithstanding a change in ownership. The new owner is required to file a new registration with the building official. The new registration shall be in the same form as the original registration, however, any remaining annual filing fee paid shall be prorated and credited to the new owner for such time remaining on the original registration. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-985. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
The director may issue rules and regulations for the administration of this article. These rules may designate materials and methods which must be used to secure a building or premises. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)  
Sec. 14-986. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to have violated any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) minimum per day per violation up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) maximum per day per violation, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the city. Such other remedies include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court of competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the city may have thereon. 
(b)  A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The city may enforce this article in its administrative adjudication system or through the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois. 
(d)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the city from immediately condemning as provided by law or the City Code, a building or taking other immediate action upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public, health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 2, 7-14, 2011)

(Code 1980, § 2-481; Ord. No. 01-19, § 2, 5-10-2001)  
Sec. 18-32. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the department shall be to develop programs for neighborhood rehabilitation and community preservation and to promote and secure economic development for the benefit of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-482; Ord. No. 01-19, § 2, 5-10-2001)  
Sec. 18-33. - Reserved.

(Code 1980, § 2-485; Ord. No. 01-19, § 2, 5-10-2001)  
Sec. 18-36. - Sale or lease of surplus real estate. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "surplus real estate" means any real estate owned by the city and, in the opinion of the city council, deemed no longer necessary, appropriate, required for the use of, profitable to or in the best interest of the city to be owned by it. 
(b)  The mayor and city council, by resolution, may authorize the sale of any surplus real estate or the leasing of any surplus real estate for a term not exceeding ninety-nine (99) years and shall establish a sale price deemed by them to be in the best interest of the residents of the city. 
(c)  The resolution authorizing the sale or lease of surplus real estate may direct such sale or lease to be conducted by the office of the corporation counsel. The resolution shall also contain pertinent information concerning the size, use and zoning of the real estate and the terms of sale. 
(Ord. No. 07-68, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Secs. 18-37—18-70. - Reserved.
