ARTICLE IV. - EQUITY ASSURANCE PROGRAM FOR SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCES 
 
Sec. 18-101. - Creation of program; purpose; name. 
There is hereby created an equity assurance program to be administered by the equity assurance commission of the city for the benefit of the citizens of the city. The purpose of the program is to insure the single-family residences in the city against the possibility of economic loss, and thereby help to eliminate irrational fears of racial change. The purpose of the program is not to insure against a regional or national decline in values in the single-family housing market. Therefore, in the event of a general economic decline in the value of single-family homes in the Chicago-Cook County-Metropolitan area single-family home market, the mayor and city council of the city reserve the right to review, revise and suspend payments under the equity assurance program. This program will provide greater community stability and will strengthen the tax base of the community by preserving and improving single-family home values. 
(Code 1980, § 2-411; Ord. No. 86-2, § 1, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-102. - Creation of the equity assurance commission. 
(a)  There is hereby created an equity assurance commission (hereafter referred to as EAC) whose role will be to administer the equity assurance program (hereafter referred to as EAP). The specific duties and functions of the EAC in policy and administration shall include the following: 
(1)  Conduct the day-to-day operations of the EAP, including the employment of appropriate personnel, acquisition of necessary office space, and the receipt and disbursement of EAP funds. 
(2)  Establish policies and procedures for the EAP and recommend substantive changes to the city council. 
(3)  Select and enter into contractual arrangements necessary to administer the EAP subject to the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  The equity assurance commission shall consist of seven (7) individuals, appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. The initial terms shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) members whose terms shall expire in one (1) year. 
(2)  Two (2) members whose terms shall expire in two (2) years. 
(3)  Three (3) members whose terms shall expire in three (3) years. 
No member shall serve more than three (3) consecutive years. 
(Code 1980, § 2-412; Ord. No. 86-2, § 2, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-103. - Definitions. 
As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed as follows: 
Application for standard appraisal fee means the fee established from time to time by the EAC for a standard appraisal on a single-family residence which becomes the application fee under the EAP. 
Appraised valuation means the dollar appraisal on the insured residence as determined by the certified appraiser on the appraised valuation date. 
Appraised valuation date means the date of certification of participation. 
Certified appraiser means one (1) of the members of a panel of appraisers approved by the EAC for determining appraised valuations under the provisions of this article. 
Family members means spouse, children, parents, parents of spouse, brothers and sisters. 
Insured residence means the single-family residence owned and used continuously as the place of residence by the member and described in the certificate of participation and entitled to coverage under this act. 
Member means a person who owns and occupies a single-family residence in the city and has applied for and been accepted as a member of the EAP as indicated by a certificate of participation; such family members who reside in the insured residence at least one (1) year prior to the death or incapacity of a member by a certificate of participation shall also be deemed members. 
Owner means the titleholder or beneficiary of the trust. 
Physical perils means physical occurrences such as, but not limited to, fire, windstorm, hail, water damage, nuclear explosion or seepage, war, insurrection, wear and tear, cracking, settling, vermin, rodents, vandalism, etc., and all such related occurrences or acts of God. 
Single-family residence means a building having not more than one (1) dwelling unit principally occupied by the members of no more than one (1) family, any appurtenant unoccupied structures, and grounds and private approaches thereto, provided that the dwelling is used principally as a private residence and that any business use of the premises is incidental to its use as a private dwelling. Exceptions may be owner occupied apartment buildings of not more than four (4) units; and owner occupied houses with a common wall separating each unit. Condominiums are excluded from the equity assurance program. 
Valuation at sale date means the dollar value of the insured residence stated in the consummated sales contract for the insured residence between the member and the prospective buyer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-413; Ord. No. 86-2, § 3, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-104. - Eligible applicants. 
Those persons eligible to apply for membership in EAP shall be limited to owner occupants of single-family residences in the city and the exceptions listed in section 18-103. 
(Code 1980, § 2-414; Ord. No. 86-2, § 4, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-105. - Application procedures. 
(a)  Eligible persons shall apply to the plan by submitting the application for standard appraisal fee. The standard appraisal fee for a single family residence is two hundred dollars ($200.00), one-half (½) of which is payable by the applicant and one-half (½) of which is subsidized by the city. The standard appraisal fee for owner-occupied two (2), three (3) or four (4) unit apartment buildings or townhouses is two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable by the applicant and the remainder subsidized by the city. Upon receipt of the appraisal fee, the dwelling of the applicant shall be appraised by a certified appraiser to determine the current appraised valuation of the residence. 
(b)  A certificate of participation shall then be issued to the applicant certifying membership in the EAP and detailing the appraised valuation, the appraised valuation date, the address and description of the insured residence, and a summary of the coverages, conditions, and exclusions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 2-415; Ord. No. 86-2, § 5, 1-23-1986; Ord. No. 96-26, § 1, 5-9-1996)  
Sec. 18-106. - Coverage provided by the equity assurance program. 
Members of their estates which are covered pursuant to section 18-107 of this program shall be paid eighty (80) percent of the difference between the appraised valuation as determined by this article and the valuation at sale date determined in section 18-107 below if the appraised valuation is higher than the valuation at sale date. Coverage provided by the EAP shall only apply to sales made five (5) years or more after date of issuance of the certificate of participation and coverage shall be provided subject to all of the terms, conditions and stipulations provided within this article. 
(Code 1980, § 2-416; Ord. No. 86-2, § 6, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-107. - Procedures for obtaining benefits. 
(a)  In order to be eligible for benefits, a member must follow the procedures set forth herein. 
(b)  When an insured residence is placed on the market with the intent of sale, the member shall submit verifiable evidence of such placement including the date that such placement took place. Verifiable evidence may include a copy of advertisements for sale, a contract with a licensed real estate broker, or other evidence found satisfactory to a majority of the EAC. 
(c)  Upon receipt of verifiable proof by the EAC of the act of placing the insured residence on the market, a one hundred twenty (120) day waiting period shall commence from the date the insured residence is placed on the market. During the first ninety (90) days of the one hundred twenty (120) day waiting period, no coverage is afforded under this article; during the last thirty (30) days of the one hundred twenty (120) day waiting period, coverage shall be afforded pursuant to subsection (f) of this section. 
(d)  A member may offer his insured residence for sale or may exclusively list said residence with a real estate broker for sixty (60) days from the date the insured residence is placed on the market. Thereafter, a member must notify the EAC in writing of his inability to obtain an offer for purchase at the appraised valuation or more and further must agree to list the insured residence with the South Suburban Board of Realtors Multiple Listing Service or an agency with comparable sales coverage in the City of Calumet City for not less than sixty (60) additional days or until the insured residence is sold, whichever is sooner. 
(e)  Seventy-five (75) days from date insured residence is placed on the market, an inspection of the insured residence shall be made. That inspection, by a certified appraiser, shall determine if the insured residence is currently in at least substantially the same state of repair as on the appraised valuation date. If the insured residence fails to meet this standard, the following procedures must be followed: 
(1)  The certified appraiser will determine the percentage depreciation of the insured residence due to the failure of the owner to maintain the premises. 
(2)  This percentage figure shall be multiplied by the appraised valuation to determine the dollar depreciation due to failure to maintain the premises. 
(3)  This dollar depreciation shall be subtracted from the appraised valuation to derive a lower appraised valuation to be used for the purpose of determining the amount of coverage afforded under this article. 
(f)  From ninety (90) through one hundred twenty (120) days from the date the insured residence is placed on the market, coverage shall be in effect as hereinafter set forth. During this period, a member shall immediately forward to the EAC all offers for purchase at less than the appraised valuation as determined in subsection (e) of this section. Within three (3) working days from receipt of the offer(s) for purchase, the EAC shall either: 
(1)  Approve the offer for purchase, whereupon the member must accept the offer and the EAC shall authorize the payment of the amount of coverage afforded by section 18-106 of this article subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Sales involving eminent domain shall be covered as set forth in section 18-103(k). 
b.  Sales subsequent to an insured property and casualty loss shall be covered as determined by the appraised valuation in section 18-107(e). 
(2)  Reject the offer, whereupon the member shall continue showing the insured residence to prospective purchasers an additional one hundred twenty (120) days listed with the South Suburban Realtors Association Multiple Listing. 
(g)  Days used to satisfy real estate sales contracts contingencies, including mortgage contingency provisions, shall not be used in compounding the one hundred twenty (120) day waiting period. 
(h)  Where an insured residence is to be acquired by use of eminent domain, the following procedures shall apply: 
(1)  If the member rejects an offer from the condemning body equal to or greater than the appraised value, there shall be no coverage under the EAP. 
(2)  If the condemning body offers less than the appraised value, the EAP may either: 
a.  Offer to pay eighty (80) percent of the difference between the appraised value and the offering price if the member agrees to sell at the offered price. If the member does not agree to sell at the offered price, then in no event shall the member receive from the EAP any payment in excess of the EAP payment provided for in this subsection (h)(2)a. 
b.  Advise the member that the offer is inadequate and should be refused. If the member under these circumstances desires to accept the offer, then the property shall be acquired from the member by the EAP at the offered price plus eighty (80) percent of the difference between the offered price and the appraised value. If the member refuses the offer pursuant to this subsection (h)(2)b and the court determination of the value of the property is less than the appraised value, then the EAP shall pay eighty (80) percent of the difference between the judgment and the appraised value. 
(Code 1980, § 2-417; Ord. No. 86-2, § 7, 1-23-1986; Ord. No. 86-12, § 1, 4-24-1986)  
Sec. 18-108. - Other conditions. 
Members shall agree to abide by all conditions, stipulations and provisions of this article and shall not be eligible for coverage hereby unless all such conditions, stipulations and provisions have been met. 
(Code 1980, § 2-418; Ord. No. 86-2, § 8, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-109. - Exclusions. 
(a)  Financial losses due to the occurrence of physical perils shall not be afforded coverage by this article. 
(b)  Depreciation due to failure to maintain in good repair the insured residence shall not be covered. This exclusion is reflected in the adjustment procedure of section 18-107(e), whereby a new, lower appraised valuation is derived reflecting this type of depreciation. 
(c)  Any person who knowingly affirms falsely to any matter or thing required to be affirmed by the terms of the equity assurance program is guilty of perjury. 
(d)  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or concealment on the part of a member in any process involving this article or the EAC shall negate all coverage provided that member by this article. 
(Code 1980, § 2-419; Ord. No. 86-2, § 9, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-110. - Methods for establishing a new appraised valuation and appraised valuation date. 
(a)  A member has the option of applying for a new appraisal by a certified appraiser. This new appraised valuation shall be subject to all of the conditions, stipulations and provisions of this article. 
(b)  The member will be issued a new certificate of participation which will state the new appraised valuation. 
(c)  Requests for a new appraised valuation will be initiated by a member no more than once within any twelve (12) month period. 
(Code 1980, § 2-420; Ord. No. 86-2, § 10, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-111. - Arbitration procedure. 
(a)  If a member or applicant disagrees with the appraised valuation determined by the certified appraiser, a three (3) person arbitration panel will be established composed of the following persons: The certified appraiser, an independent appraiser selected by the member or applicant, and an umpire selected and approved by these two (2) appraisers. If an umpire cannot be agreed upon within thirty (30) days, the umpire shall be selected by a judge of a court of record within the jurisdiction. The appraised valuation agreed to by any two (2) of the three (3) panel members shall be binding on all parties involved under this article. The cost of the independent appraiser shall be borne by the member or applicant. The cost of the umpire shall be borne equally by the applicant and the EAC. The cost of the certified appraiser shall be paid by the EAC. 
(b)  If a member disagrees with the amount of coverage afforded as determined by the EAC under this article, a three (3) person arbitration panel shall be established composed of the following persons: An appraiser chosen by the member, an appraiser chosen by the EAC, and an umpire chosen and approved by these two (2) appraisers. If an umpire cannot be agreed upon within thirty (30) days the umpire shall be selected by a judge of a court of record within the jurisdiction. The amount of coverage under the provisions of this article agreed to by any two (2) of these three (3) persons shall be binding on all parties involved under this article. Each party shall bear the cost of the appraiser chosen by them and the cost of the umpire and other arbitration expenses shall be evenly divided between the member and the EAC. 
(Code 1980, § 2-421; Ord. No. 86-2, § 11, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-112. - Suits. 
No suit brought under the terms of this article shall be sustainable in a court of law or equity unless all conditions, stipulations and provisions of this article have been complied with, and unless the suit is brought within twelve (12) months after the sales contract signed by the prospective buyer and the affidavit executed by the prospective buyer and seller have been presented to the EAC. 
(Code 1980, § 2-422; Ord. No. 86-2, § 12, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-113. - Other insurance. 
If other insurance or payment is available to provide coverage similar to that provided by this article, the EAC shall not be liable for a greater proportion of the loss than the amount of coverage provided by this article bears to the total amount of coverage available from all sources. 
(Code 1980, § 2-423; Ord. No. 86-2, § 13, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-114. - Amendments. 
The EAP may be amended by the city council, but no such amendment shall substantially affect rights that have been vested pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1980, § 2-424; Ord. No. 86-2, § 14, 1-23-1986)  
Sec. 18-115. - Penalty. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall in addition to other remedies provided by law be fined not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1980, § 2-425; Ord. No. 86-2, § 15, 1-23-1986)  
ARTICLE V. - LOT NEXT-DOOR PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 18-116. - Establishment of program. 
Pursuant to the powers and authority granted under Article VII of the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, and the home rule powers granted thereunder, the lot next-door program is hereby established by the City of Calumet City, a home rule unit of government. The lot next-door program shall be administered by the department of community and economic development. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-117. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter: 
Adjacent neighbor means a person who owns and occupies, as their primary residence, an improved parcel of real property immediately adjacent to a city-owned parcel of non-buildable vacant property, and who is not delinquent in the payment of any property taxes or any debt owed to the City of Calumet City, County of Cook or State of Illinois. 
City means the City of Calumet City. 
Department means the department of community and economic development. 
LNDP means the lot next-door program. 
Parcel means a parcel of vacant real property which is bounded on at least one (1) side by an owner-occupied improved parcel of residential real property, which is occupied by the owner as their primary residence. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-118. - List of city-owned real estate; required. 
The department shall prepare and maintain a list of city-owned real estate which shall include those parcels available for sale under LNDP. This list shall be made available to the public during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-119. - Minimum purchase price required; sale procedures. 
The minimum purchase price of any parcel sold pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Upon receipt of an offer by an adjacent neighbor to purchase a parcel, the department shall give written notice by certified mail to any owner of additional adjacent property indicating that the department may accept the offer of the adjacent neighbor unless, within thirty (30) days, the additional adjacent neighbor notifies the department of his/her desire to purchase one-half (½) of the parcel for five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-120. - Approval by city council. 
Any proposed conveyance under the LNDP must be approved by a majority of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-121. - Property index number consolidation. 
After conveyance, the current property index number shall be terminated and the parcel, or that portion conveyed to each adjacent neighbor, shall be consolidated with the property index number of the adjacent neighbor's primary residence. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-122. - Covenants in deed; termination of covenants. 
Any deed conveying a parcel to an adjacent neighbor pursuant to the provisions of the LNDP may contain covenants which (1) prohibit the adjacent neighbor from conveying, assigning or otherwise transferring the parcel except in conjunction with the conveyance of the parcel owned by the adjacent neighbor; and (2) require the adjacent neighbor to maintain the parcel in accordance with the provisions of the Municipal Code of Calumet City. The covenants shall terminate five (5) years after the date of the conveyance to the adjacent neighbor. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Sec. 18-123. - Rules and regulations. 
The department may establish rules, regulations and procedures for the advertising, bidding and sale of parcels pursuant to the provisions of the LNDP. All such rules, regulations and procedures shall be published and made available by the department. 
(Ord. No. 07-69, § 1, 6-14-2007)  
Secs. 18-124—18-129. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - BUSINESS RETENTION GRANT PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 18-130. - Establishment of grant program. 
A business retention grant program is hereby established by the city with such funding level being determined by the city council, on an annual basis, and administered by the department of community and economic development and the mayor's advisory committee on business development. 
(Ord. No. 08-27, § 2, 5-8-2008)  
Sec. 18-131. - Grant program, rules, regulations and funding requirements. 
The coordinator of the department of community and economic development shall establish rules, regulations and procedures necessary for the administration of the grant program to allow for the submission of applications and evaluation of grant program funding requests by the mayor's advisory committee on business development, pursuant to the following requirements: 
(a)  Grant program funding request shall be allocated in amounts no less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to a qualifying and for-profit business enterprise located in a commercial or industrial zoning district of the city not in arrears of any amount due or owing the city; 
(b)  Every project approved for grant program funding shall support private investment and shall be used to aid a business enterprise in an expansion plan, a real property improvement or such other endeavor providing for continued or increased employment opportunities; 
(c)  Every grant program funding award shall be a debt obligation due and owing the city against the business enterprise, as a recordable lien on the real property of the business, which shall be released by the city after a period of five (5) years and pursuant to all grant program funding rules, regulations and procedures; and 
(d)  Upon the submission of all required application documentation for a grant program funding request, the department of community and economic development and the mayor's advisory committee on business development shall determine eligibility and recommend any necessary action for the disbursement of a grant program funding award for approval by a majority vote of the city council before disbursement. 
(Ord. No. 08-27, § 2, 5-8-2008)  
Chapter 22 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30; law enforcement, ch. 46. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Ambulance service fees. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advanced  life support means the use of advanced paramedic equipment for life threatening injuries and/or sickness, including heart monitoring equipment and the administering of intravenous fluid and medications. The term advanced life support also includes the prescribed medications carried by the paramedical team for symptomatic injuries and/or illness and the use of telemetry for the notification of the resource hospital or the use of specific airway maintenance materials and the application of anti-shock devices. 
Basic  life support means any call which is not advanced life support. This includes responses for first aid and transport for victims who are sick and/or injured. 
Extrication  means any use of hand tools, forcible entry tools, battery powered tools, hydraulic tools, equipment or mechanical leverage required to remove an individual from a vehicle, building or debris. 
Hazardous  materials cleanup means the use of an damming, diverting or absorption of a hazardous substance or the use of detergents, foams or other chemical agents to dilute or dissolve a hazardous substance; provided that the amount and nature of the substance is such that it does not require a hazardous materials advisor be present to oversee operations. Incidents that require the presence of a hazardous materials advisor shall be subject to those regulations and fees, as described in chapter 26. 
(b)  Amount of fees. 
(1)  The fee structure for ambulance service shall be set at the following amounts: 
ALS treatment and transport ..... $800.00 
BLS treatment and transport ..... 700.00 
(2)  There shall also be a fee for ALS and BLS treatment without transport. These fees shall be separate from any fees billed by our resource hospital for supplies used in treatment. The fees shall be: 
ALS ..... $275.00 
BLS ..... 200.00 
(3)  Fees for mileage, oxygen and EKG therapy shall be billed at the following amounts: 
Oxygen ..... $50.00 
EKG ..... 60.00 
Mileage, per mile ..... 7.00 
(4)  Fees for extrication, cleanup, vehicle use and staff time shall be billed at the following amounts: 
Extrication ..... $500.00 
Vehicle Use, per hour ..... 125.00 
Staff Work, per hour ..... 35.00 
Command Response ..... 100.00 
Hazardous Materials Cleanup ..... 500.00 
(c)  Payment of fees. Said fees shall be paid to the city by the individual receiving such ambulance service within thirty (30) days after such service is provided; except that when such service is provided to a minor, such fee shall be paid by the parent or legal guardian. 
(d)  Destination. All transports performed by city fire department personnel shall be to St. Margaret Hospital, Hammond, Indiana; unless diverted by medical control or required by Illinois State law. 
(e)  Distribution of ambulance fees. Fees collected through ambulance fees shall be distributed in the following manner: 
(1)  Fifty (50) percent shall be deposited in the paramedic account to be used to pay for the following items: training of new paramedics, continuing education of current paramedics, supplies and equipment needed for the paramedic units, maintenance of the paramedic vehicles and equipment, and the purchase of new ambulances; and 
(2)  Fifty (50) percent shall be deposited into a new fire department apparatus account that would be used for repairs and supplies to current apparatus and purchase of new nonambulance apparatus (engines, aerial trucks, cars, etc.) for the fire department. 
(Code 1980, § 10-19; Ord. No. 89-42, § 1, 11-9-1989; Ord. No. 89-45, § 1, 11-21-1989; Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 8-10-1995; Ord. No. 99-19, § 1, 2-25-1999; Ord. No. 03-55, § 2, 9-25-2003; Ord. No. 09-48, § 2, 9-10-2009; Ord. No. 10-7, § 2, 1-28-2010)  
Secs. 22-2—22-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND DISASTERS 
 
Sec. 22-31. - Appropriations. 
The city council may make an appropriation for the purpose of the emergency services and disaster agency in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 12; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-32. - Tax levy. 
The city council may levy in addition to all other taxes and for emergency service and disaster purposes only, a tax not to exceed five-hundredths (0.05) of one (1) percent of the equalized, assessed value of all taxable property. However, the amount collectible under such a levy shall in no event exceed twenty-five cents ($0.25) per capita. 
(Code 1980, § 7-2; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 12; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-33. - Purchases and contracts. 
(a)  The city council may, on recommendation of the director of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the city in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any atomic or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster. 
(b)  In the event of such a disaster said director is authorized on behalf of the city to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations; provided, however, if the city council meets at such time he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
(Code 1980, § 7-3; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 9; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Secs. 22-34—22-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY 
 
Sec. 22-71. - Established. 
There is hereby established the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, in accordance with The Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1980, § 7-16; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 1; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-72. - Composition. 
The local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency shall consist of the director and such additional members as may be selected by the director. 
(Code 1980, § 7-17; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 2; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-73. - Appointment and removal of director. 
The director of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city council, and shall serve until removed by the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 7-18; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 2; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-74. - Acting director. 
In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve of the director of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency, the mayor or any other person designated by him, shall be and act as director until a new appointment is made as provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 7-19; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 2; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-75. - Duties of director. 
The director of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the emergency services and disaster agency, subject to the direction and control of the mayor as provided by statute. 
(Code 1980, § 7-20; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 2; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-76. - Compensation. 
(a)  Members of the local organization of the emergency services and disaster agency who are paid city employees or officers, if called for training by the state director of the emergency services and disaster agency, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held. 
(b)  Members who are not paid city employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 7-21; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 7; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-77. - Oath. 
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the director: 
I, _______, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the Government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the municipal emergency services and disaster agency, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the Government of the United States or of this State by force or violence. 
(Code 1980, § 7-22; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 10; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-78. - Office. 
The mayor is authorized to designate space in the city hall or elsewhere as may be provided for by the city council for the local organization for emergency services and disaster agency. 
(Code 1980, § 7-23; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 11; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-79. - Functions generally. 
The local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency shall perform such emergency and disaster services within the city as shall be prescribed in and by the state emergency services and disaster plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by law. All emergency services and disaster personnel shall be authorized to issue citations for parking violations and authorize the removal and towing of motor vehicles which impede traffic or otherwise are in violation of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 7-24; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 3; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987; Ord. No. 90-33, § 1, 7-26-1990)  
Sec. 22-80. - Mutual aid agreements. 
The director of the local organization for emergency services and disaster may negotiate mutual aid arrangements with other political subdivisions, municipal corporations or bodies politic within the state for reciprocal emergency and disaster aid and assistance in case of a disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted, which arrangements shall not, however, be effective unless and until approved by each of such political subdivisions, municipal corporations or bodies politic as are parties thereto, in the manner provided by law, and unless and until filed with and approved in writing by the state director of the emergency services and disaster agency. 
(Code 1980, § 7-25; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 5; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-81. - Emergency functions. 
If the governor declares an emergency services and disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile actions, it shall be the duty of the local organization for emergency services and disaster to cooperate fully with the state emergency services and disaster agency and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-26; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 6; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Secs. 22-82—22-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE SUPPORT TEAMS 
 
Sec. 22-101. - Designation. 
All or any members of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the state director of emergency services and disaster agency as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-34; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 4; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-102. - Designation of leader. 
The leader of each mobile support team shall be designated by the director of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency. 
(Code 1980, § 7-35; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 4; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-103. - Status of members. 
(a)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a city employee or officer, while serving on call to duty by the governor, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. 
(b)  Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the municipality, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-36; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 4; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Sec. 22-104. - Treasurer's duty. 
The city treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the city for expenses incident to training members of the local organization for the emergency services and disaster agency as prescribed by the state director, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the municipality in response to a call by the state emergency services and disaster agency, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to emergency services and disaster activities as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-37; Ord. of 9-29-1952, § 8; Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 4-9-1987)  
Secs. 22-105—22-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 22-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm conditions means alarms activated by unlawful violation of a user's property or other violations that the systems were designed to protect against, acts of God, other violent conditions or by outside agencies or external forces not under the control of an alarm user. 
Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring attention and to which the police or fire department are expected to respond. 
Alarm user means any person responsible for the premises on which an alarm system is maintained within the city except for alarm systems on motor vehicles, whether such person owns, leases or uses such premises. Also included are users of those systems which employ an audible signal or a flashing light or beacon intended to alert or signal persons outside the premises. 
Direct line means a telephone line leading directly into the telecommunications center that is for use only to report signals on a person-to-person basis. 
False alarm means the activation of an alarm system caused by improper operation, negligence of the alarm user or lessee of an alarm user or the employee, agent or visitor of any alarm user or equipment malfunction. 
Local alarm means a signaling system which, when activated, causes an audible or visual signaling device to be activated in or on the premises within which the system is installed. 
Primary trunk line means a telephone line leading into the telecommunications center that is for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person-to-person basis, and which line is identified by a specific listing among the emergency numbers in the telephone directory issued by the telephone company serving the city. 
Special trunk line or operator trunk line means a telephone line leading into the telecommunications center that is for the primary purpose of handling emergency messages which originate from automatic protection devices and which are transmitted directly or through an intermediary, but in any event utilizes the microphone of a telephone for transmitting messages. 
Telephone company means the public utility that has a franchise from the city authorizing it to furnish telephone service to subscribers in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 18-170; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 22-132. - Permit required; fees. 
(a)  An alarm user shall not install, operate or maintain an alarm system within the boundaries of the city without first obtaining a permit. No alarm system which is connected to the telecommunications center or any sound alarm audible beyond the premises being served shall be installed within the boundaries of the city without first obtaining a permit. 
(b)  All applications for permits shall be made to the fire or police chief or his designated agent on a form provided by the city clerk. Permits shall be issued by the department of inspectional services, provided the system complies with all applicable sections of this article and this Code and an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00) has been paid for each residential system and twenty dollars ($20.00) for all other systems. 
(c)  The annual fee shall be paid at the time of application or renewal of a permit. At any time there is a change in information required in the application the alarm user must file an amended application for review and approval. 
(Code 1980, § 18-171; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 22-133. - Testing of equipment. 
No alarm system designed to transmit alarm conditions directly to the telecommunications center for the city police and fire departments shall be tested or demonstrated without first obtaining permission. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting alarm conditions directly to the telecommunications center. Failure to notify the department prior to testing or demonstration of such an alarm system shall constitute a false alarm. 
(Code 1980, § 18-172; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 22-134. - False alarms. 
(a)  A fine of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) shall be assessed against the alarm user for each false alarm in excess of two (2) but less than five (5) in any calendar year. 
(b)  A fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be assessed against the alarm user for each false alarm in excess of four (4) but less than eight (8) in any calendar year. 
(c)  A fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed against the alarm user for each false alarm in excess of seven (7) in any calendar year. 
(d)  Where a security alarm user is in arrears for more than sixty (60) days with respect to payment of an outstanding fine set forth in this section, the police or fire chief may order a restricted response to any alarm signal from the alarmed premises or disconnection. 
(Code 1980, § 18-173; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 22-135. - Suspension or revocation of alarm system privileges. 
(a)  After eight (8) false alarms within a calendar year have been recorded for any alarm user, the fire or police chief, or his designated agent, shall send a letter, by postage paid U.S. mail to the security alarm user including the following: 
(1)  The date and time of which each false alarm was recorded; 
(2)  The need to take corrective action to eliminate false alarms; and 
(3)  A warning that after ten (10) false alarms within a calendar year, the police or fire chief may order the suspension or revocation of alarm system privileges. 
(b)  In accordance with this section, the police and fire chief may order the restricted response of departmental personnel to any alarmed premises for which: 
(1)  Ten (10) or more false alarms have been recorded in any calendar year; 
(2)  Fines due pursuant to this section remain unpaid for sixty (60) or more days. 
(Code 1980, § 18-174; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 22-136. - City's limited liability. 
(a)  The city assumes no liability for any defects in the operation of any alarm system or for the failure or neglect of any person associated with the installation, operation or maintenance of any alarm system; for the transmissions of alarm signals; for the relaying of such signals and messages; for the failure or neglect of any alarm user; for the transmission or receipt of alarm signals; or for any failure or neglect to respond upon receipt of an alarm signal from any source. 
(b)  In the event the city finds it necessary to revoke a permit, or to otherwise provide for the disconnection of any fire alarm system, the city shall have no liability for such action. 
(c)  No special duty other than that owed to the general public shall be created by virtue of this article, by virtue of the issuance of a permit or payment of a fee; or as a result of the transmission to or receipt of a transmission to the telecommunications center. 
(Code 1980, § 18-175; Ord. No. 02-13, 4-25-2002)  
Chapter 26 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Animals, ch. 10; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; community development, ch. 18; floods, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; planning, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; hazardous waste tax, § 82-511 et seq.; utilities, ch. 94; subdivisions, app. A; zoning, app. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Burning grass and leaves. 
(a)  No person shall make or cause a fire to be made for burning any combustible waste material including, but not limited to, grass and leaves in any public street or any public way. 
(b)  No person shall cause or allow open burning within the city except as provided under the Illinois Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) and 35 Illinois Administration Code, Part 237. 
(c)  No person shall cause or allow the burning of any refuse in any chamber or apparatus unless such chamber or apparatus is designed for the purpose of disposing of the class of refuse being burned. 
(Code 1980, § 10-13; Ord. of 9-26-1963, § 1; Ord. No. 86-37, § 1, 12-22-1986) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30.  
Secs. 26-2—26-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES 
 
Sec. 26-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Combustible means any substance having a flashpoint above eighty (80) degrees Fahrenheit to and including one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit as determined by the Tagliabue open cup test, except the combustibility of solids or contents of self-pressured containers shall be determined by methods generally applicable to such materials or containers respectively. 
Corrosive means any substance which in contact with living tissue causes destruction of tissue by chemical action, but does not refer to action on inanimate surfaces. 
Flammable means any substance that has a flashpoint of above twenty (20) degrees to and including eighty (80) degrees Fahrenheit as determined by the Tagliabue open cup test, except the flammability of solids and of the contents of self-pressured containers shall be determined by methods generally applicable to such materials or containers respectively. 
Hazardous material incident means an incident that threatens public health or safety involving the actual or potential release of a hazardous substance or hazardous material. 
Hazardous substance or hazardous material means any substance or material or mixture of substances that is toxic, corrosive, an irritant, a strong sensitizer, radioactive, flammable, combustible, or that generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means and that may cause injury or illness to humans, domestic livestock, or wildlife or as defined by the state environmental protection act or any federal law. 
Irritant means any substance, not corrosive, which on immediate, prolonged or repeated contract with normal living tissue will include local inflammatory reaction. 
Radioactive means any substance that emits ionizing radiation. 
Strong sensitizer means any substance that will cause on normal living tissue through an allergic or photodynamic process a hypersensitivity, which becomes evident on reapplication of the same substance. 
Toxic means any substance, other than a radioactive substance, that has the capacity to produce bodily injury or illness to man through ingestion, inhalation, or absorption through any body surface. 
(Code 1980, § 10-70; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 26-32. - City liability. 
The city, its officers, agents or employees shall not have any liability or responsibility for any claim, injury or damage of any kind resulting from a hazardous material incident to which the city or any of its departments, officers, agents or employees respond. 
(Code 1980, § 10-71; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 26-33. - Control of hazardous substances or hazardous materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, store, deliver or transport hazardous substances or hazardous materials or cause the use, storage, delivery or transporting of hazardous substances or hazardous materials in any manner inconsistent with the requirements of the fire prevention code of the city or any other applicable section of this Code, city ordinance, state law or federal law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle carrying, transporting or containing a hazardous substance or hazardous material to park or stand, other than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaging in loading or unloading, on private property without the knowledge and the express consent of the person who is in charge of the property and who is aware of the nature of the hazardous substance or hazardous material the motor vehicle contains. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle carrying, transporting or containing a hazardous substance or hazardous material to fail to comply with all applicable sections of chapter 90 of this Code relating to traffic. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person using, storing, manufacturing, producing, disposing, treating, transporting or causing the use, storage, manufacture, production, disposal, treatment or transportation of any hazardous substance or hazardous material in any manner that results in a hazardous material incident. 
(Code 1980, § 10-72; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 4-25-2002)  
Sec. 26-34. - Hazardous material incident expense recovery. 
(a)  Any person causing or permitting a hazardous material incident shall be responsible for all of the following: 
(1)  Reimbursement in full for any and all costs incurred by the city in connection with the operation, maintenance, and staffing required to respond to such hazardous material incident in accordance with the following hourly fee or any fraction of an hour for each employee or vehicle or both who participates in such response to a hazardous material incident: 
Fire engine ..... $500.00 
Fire ladder truck ..... 500.00 
Ambulance ..... 250.00 
Command vehicle chief officer ..... 150.00 
Hazardous materials advisor ..... 100.00 
City supervisory advisors ..... 100.00 
Support personnel ..... 50.00 
Police car ..... 100.00 
ESDA car ..... 50.00 
Telecommunicator ..... 50.00 
Sewer vactor ..... 500.00 
Dump truck ..... 250.00 
Street sweeper ..... 500.00 
High lift ..... 250.00 
Public works foreman ..... 100.00 
Garbage truck ..... 250.00 
Plow ..... 250.00 
Miscellaneous DPW or city vehicle ..... 50.00 
An administrative fee of ten (10) percent shall be applied on the total amount to cover costs associated with the preparation of all accounting and billing. Dumping fees shall be extra. 
(2)  Reimbursement in full for any and all costs incurred by the city for equipment and materials used, damaged, lost, spent destroyed or rendered irreparable in connection with a hazardous material incident. 
(3)  Assumption of any and all liability and costs for any additional expense associated with a hazardous material incident, including but not limited to any evacuation, lodging or medical treatment of residents or city personnel. 
(4)  Assumption of any and all liability and costs for any cleanup or removal resulting from a hazardous material incident, including but not limited to any independent cleanup contractor necessitated by such hazardous material incident. 
(b)  The fire department shall prepare and forward to the person causing or permitting a hazardous material incident a bill for the total costs and expenses incurred for which such person is responsible pursuant to this section; provided, however, any cost in connection with any independent cleanup contractor shall be billed directly by such contractor. Payment of the total bill shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt. Any bill or portion of a bill remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days of receipt shall accrue interest on the unpaid balance at the rate of one and one-half (1½) percent per month, or any fraction of a month. 
(Code 1980, § 10-73; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 4-25-2002)  
Secs. 26-35—26-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TOXIC SUBSTANCE USE AS RAW MATERIALS IN MANUFACTURING 
 
Sec. 26-61. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this article shall be upon conviction fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and separate offenses shall be deemed committed on each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1980, § 15-680; Ord. No. 82-9, § 2, 5-13-1982)  
Sec. 26-62. - Prohibition. 
The city council deems it necessary and advisable for the health, welfare and safety of its residents to ban the use of the following toxic substances as a raw material in a manufacturing process or to be manufactured within the city, namely: Acrylonitrile, arsenic, asbestos, benzene, beryllium, cadmium, chlorinated solvents (chloroform, trichlorethylene, (TCE), perchlorethylene (PCE), methycloroform), chlorofluorocarbons, chromates, coke oven emissions, diethylstilbestrol (DES), disromochloropropane (DBCP), ethylene dibromide, ethylene oxide, lead, mercury, nitrosamines, ozone, polybrominated biphenyls (PBBs) polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), ionizing radiation, sulphur dioxide, vinyl chloride, and toxic waste disposals. Any person, firm or corporation using any of said substances as of the date of enactment of this article shall be permitted to continue using said substances, and this article shall not apply to such uses and shall not be construed to prohibit such uses. 
(Code 1980, § 15-679; Ord. No. 82-9, § 2, 5-13-1982)  
Secs. 26-63—26-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FUMIGATION AND PEST CONTROL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-91. - Exception to chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the fumigation of greenhouses or grain elevators. 
(Code 1980, § 12-2)  
Sec. 26-92. - Sale of material for generating hydrocyanic acid gas. 
No person shall sell or give away material for the purpose of fumigating premises with hydrocyanic acid gas, except to a person licensed as provided in this chapter unless a signed statement in writing is first obtained from the buyer or recipient of the material to the effect that it will not be used for the purpose of fumigating any building or portion thereof for which a permit is required to conduct such activity. 
(Code 1980, § 12-1)  
Secs. 26-93—26-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FUMIGATION PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 26-111. - Compliance required; scope. 
When hydrocyanic acid gas and/or other dangerous gases or fumes are used for exterminating purposes, the method of procedure in this article shall be followed. 
(Code 1980, § 12-16)  
Sec. 26-112. - Permit required. 
It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this chapter, intending to generate or release hydrocyanic acid gas and/or other dangerous gases or fumes for fumigation purposes, before starting such generation or release, to notify, in writing, the health commissioner, giving the location of the building or enclosed space to be fumigated, and to secure from him a permit which shall state the day and hour when the work will be performed. Each application for such permit shall be accompanied by a fee of one dollar ($1.00) unless otherwise provided in this article, which fee shall be paid to the city treasurer before such permit shall be issued. Such permit shall be kept on the premises to be fumigated. Should the applicant be unable to perform the work on the hour and day set forth in the permit, and so notifies the health commissioner, sixteen (16) hours prior to the time set forth in the permit, the time of the permit may be extended. 
(Code 1980, § 12-17)  
Sec. 26-113. - Notification of occupants and vacating of premises. 
(a)  Before fumigating, the operator shall personally inspect the premises, and shall serve notice, over his signature, upon all responsible occupants in each room or apartment within the danger area, stating the danger of the process and the precautions to be observed, designating the rooms or apartments which must be vacated and indicating the time when the gas is to be generated or liberated (the form of this notice shall be approved by the health commissioner). 
(b)  Every room in the danger area shall be vacated. In the case of a building in which there are inner court, vent shaft or light well, or a lot line court with part wall, or in the case of two (2) buildings having adjacent lot line courts, upon which any room being gassed, opens, every room with windows or other apertures opening to such inner or lot line courts, vent shafts or light wells, shall be vacated and securely locked. Where the walls of any adjoining buildings are located within ten (10) feet of the rooms or apartments being gassed, the operator shall notify, over his signature, all responsible occupants of rooms or apartments with window openings in such walls that such windows as are directly opposite or above the area of the adjoining building which is under gas must remain closed, of the rooms vacated during the time the building gassed is being flushed or aired. All rooms or apartments ordered vacated but not under gas shall be well-ventilated during the process by keeping the windows of rooms or apartments open. 
(c)  Such vacation of premises and notification of occupants shall not be necessary where the fumigation is done in special rooms or vaults in furniture stores, secondhand stores, or household goods warehouses, when such special rooms or vaults are approved as to their location, construction and gas tightness by the health commissioner, and a provision is made for the airing of such vaults so as to allow the escape of gases at such location by a system of ducts and ventilation approved by him. Permits for fumigation of these last-named places shall be procured each time the premises are fumigated. The applicant for fumigation permit for the type of premises covered by this subsection shall be required to pay for no more than two (2) permits during any given year. 
(Code 1980, § 12-18)  
Sec. 26-114. - Danger area. 
The danger area shall be those portions of any structure or dwelling which lie within the boundary of the outside walls or the building under gas, the roof and basement or cellar floor, and such cutoff or fire walls as may exit in the structure in question. Such cutoff or fire walls shall be of solid masonry, gastight, at least eight (8) inches in thickness extending from the basement through the attic, with all openings locked and guarded against entry and effectively sealed against gas leakage. 
(Code 1980, § 12-19)  
Sec. 26-115. - Sealing rooms. 
Before fumigation with hydrocyanic acid gas and/or other dangerous gases or fumes, the operator shall securely seal all cracks, holes, crevices, openings and apertures in walls, ceilings and floors in such a way as to confine the gas to the premises intended to be fumigated. 
(Code 1980, § 12-20)  
Sec. 26-116. - Locking rooms and adjoining rooms or apartments; placarding generally. 
Before fumigation, it is required that the operator shall personally inspect all rooms and apartments ordered vacated under this article, and be assured that they are unoccupied by persons or domestic animals; afterwards all doors to all rooms or apartments, excepting one exit door to the rooms or apartments to be gassed, shall be securely locked; in addition, such windows or other wall openings as might possibly be used to gain entrance shall be locked or barred in such a way as to prevent entrance while still permitting thorough airing of the rooms. Immediately upon generating or liberating the gas, the door through which the operator leaves shall be securely locked and sealed, and all keys obtainable to all rooms or apartments ordered vacated shall be retained by the operator until all danger is passed. As an additional precaution, all rooms and apartments vacated shall be placarded. 
(Code 1980, § 12-21)  
Sec. 26-117. - Warning card. 
(a)  Prior to releasing the gas, suitable warning signs shall be posted on all entrances or doors to the premises to be fumigated, as follows: 
DANGER 
Skull and 
Crossbones 	Fumigating with
Cyanide Gas
Deadly Poison 	Skull and 
Crossbones 
 
All persons are warned to keep away
by order of the health commissioner
(Name and address of licensee as well as telephone number) 
(b)  Such signs shall be printed in red ink on white cardboard. The letters in the word "Danger" shall be at least two (2) inches high, all others except the signature at least three-fourths (¾) of an inch high. At night such signs shall be illuminated as to make the reading matter thereon plainly legible. Warnings posted where the natural light between sunrise and sunset is dim shall be artificially illuminated. 
(Code 1980, § 12-22)  
Sec. 26-118. - Guards. 
Whenever hydrocyanic acid gas and/or other dangerous gases or fumes are generated or liberated in any room or portion of a structure in the city, a sufficient number of capable, alert watchmen shall remain on duty at the entrance or entrances to the room, building or enclosed space vacated for gassing, to prevent people from entering while gas is present and for two (2) hours after the room or area gassed is open for airing. All guards or watchmen shall be reliable persons and must be acceptable as proper guards by the health commissioner. The licensee shall be held strictly responsible and accountable for the conduct of the guards or watchmen. In every case where the entire building is not vacated, the licensee, or his approved representative shall remain on the job during the progress of fumigation and airing, and shall constantly supervise the occupancy of the structure to ensure that no persons will be endangered by gas leakage. The licensee shall give all guards definite and proper instructions, and shall visit the premises being fumigated at regular and frequent intervals during the process to ensure that they are properly guarded. 
(Code 1980, § 12-23)  
Sec. 26-119. - Food removal. 
The operator shall see that all ice, food and drink are removed from the rooms ordered vacated; except that such food or drink as is sealed in airtight containers need not be removed. Completely dry foods, such as flour and cereals, when stored in elevators, warehouses or mills need not be removed when the fumigation is for the purpose of destroying vermin or insects or pests infecting these foodstuffs. 
(Code 1980, § 12-24)  
Sec. 26-120. - Fires. 
All fires within the premises under gas shall be put out whenever a flammable gas is used. For the purpose of this article, the health commissioner shall designate upon request whether the gas to be used shall be regarded as flammable or nonflammable. The licensee shall notify the fire department of any rooms, building or structure other than approved vaults placed under hydrocyanic acid gas or other dangerous gas fumigation. 
(Code 1980, § 12-25)  
Sec. 26-121. - Ingredient containers. 
An impermeable receptacle for containing the ingredients used for fumigation is hereby required. 
(Code 1980, § 12-26)  
Sec. 26-122. - Spilling of cyanide. 
No cyanide crystals shall be dropped on the floor or left exposed where people or domestic animals may come in contact with them. 
(Code 1980, § 12-27)  
Sec. 26-123. - Opening of rooms after gassing. 
At the conclusion of the gassing process, it shall be the duty of the operator to throw open doors and windows of the premises. Until all rooms have been opened for free access of air, no person other than the operator or operators shall be permitted to enter the premises until all traces of the gas have disappeared, and in no case shall the occupants of the rooms or areas gassed be permitted to enter until twelve (12) hours after airing. The operator or watchman shall keep all persons away from the doors and windows of the premises for two (2) hours after airing. Infants and children under six (6) years of age shall not be permitted to reenter the premises until eighteen (18) hours after the rooms or apartments are opened for airing. The licensee shall inform all occupants having children of this provision, in writing, over his signature. No room or space, except where the whole building is vacated, shall be left under gas after the time of sunset. 
(Code 1980, § 12-28)  
Sec. 26-124. - Residue disposal. 
The operator shall pour the residue left in the jars or containers, and the water used for cleaning such jars or containers, down the toilet bowl, which shall then be flushed thoroughly with water to remove all traces of the chemicals. 
(Code 1980, § 12-29)  
Sec. 26-125. - Containers. 
Every container in which hydrocyanic acid, either alone, mixed with or absorbed in, other material is handled, shipped or sold, shall be of a type of construction material and thickness approved by the health commissioner in order that accidental poisonings during handling, storage and shipment of such containers may be prevented. This approval shall not be necessary where the containers are accepted by United States officials for interstate shipment. 
(Code 1980, § 12-30)  
Sec. 26-126. - Additional rules. 
The health commissioner is hereby authorized and directed to prescribe and enforce such rules and regulations not in conflict with the provisions of this chapter as he may deem necessary for the protection of life and public health. 
(Code 1980, § 12-31)  
Sec. 26-127. - Warning gases. 
The health commissioner is hereby authorized to prescribe that a stink gas or tear gas shall be mixed with hydrocyanic acid gas or other dangerous gases or fumes to be used for fumigating, specifying in whatever detail he shall deem necessary the time and method for the generation or release of such stink or tear gases. 
(Code 1980, § 12-32)  
Secs. 26-128—26-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FUMIGATORS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 26-151. - Employees. 
No person shall be engaged by a licensee under this article to work at the occupation of exterminator or fumigator employing the use of hydrocyanic acid gas and/or other dangerous gases or fumes as insecticides to kill or destroy insects, vermin, rats or other pests, without first filing an application and statement of experience and qualifications with and receiving the approval of the health commissioner. 
(Code 1980, § 12-50)  
Secs. 26-152—26-170. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 26-171. - License required. 
No person shall use hydrocyanic acid gas, cyanogen, chloropicrin, or any other poisonous, noxious or dangerous gases or fumes liable to affect human beings by causing severe sickness or death, for the extermination of household insects or vermin in any place of domestic habitation, hotel, apartment building, tenement building, office building, furniture store, secondhand store, household goods warehouse, place of public assembly, lodginghouse, roominghouse, asylum, hospital, home, institution or similar places without a license. 
(Code 1980, § 12-44)  
Sec. 26-172. - License application; processing. 
(a)  Any person desiring a license to engage in the extermination of household insects, vermin, rats or other household pests shall make written application for such license at the office of the city clerk. In addition, the applicant shall file with the health commissioner a sworn statement listing the training and experience tending to qualify the applicant for the performance of fumigating with hydrocyanic acid gas and other dangerous and noxious gases. In the case of firms or corporations, the statement shall cover the training and experience of the responsible officers. 
(b)  The health commissioner and city chemist shall make a thorough investigation of the training, experience, general qualifications, character and reputation of the applicants for licenses to fumigate with poisonous or noxious gases. The health commissioner and city chemist shall also examine applicants by giving such mental, written and oral examinations as they may deem necessary to determine the fitness and reliability of the applicant and to ascertain his knowledge of the requirements in regard to said business as set forth in this article and on any rules and regulations of the health commissioner in regulating and controlling said business. 
(c)  In the case of a firm or corporation, the responsible officers of such organizations or any agents or officials designated by such firm or corporation to supervise and control its fumigating work shall be subject to examinations of the applicants as herein provided. 
(d)  Based on the findings and recommendations of the health commissioner and city chemist, the health commissioner shall approve the issuance of a license to applicants he finds and considers reliable and safe to engage in the business of fumigating with hydrocyanic acid gas and other dangerous and noxious gases. 
(Code 1980, § 12-45)  
Sec. 26-173. - License fee. 
The fee for the license required by this article shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, § 12-46; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 30; Ord. No. 05-87, § 2, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 26-174. - License renewal. 
The approval of the health commissioner shall be obtained before the license required by the provisions of this article is renewed. 
(Code 1980, § 12-47; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 30)  
Sec. 26-175. - License expiration date. 
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on the thirty-first day of May following the date of issuance. 
(Code 1980, § 12-48; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 30)  
Sec. 26-176. - License revocation. 
The license required by this article of any person violating any of the provisions of this article may be revoked by the mayor upon recommendation of the health commissioner, who shall give due hearing to the licensee before such recommendation. 
(Code 1980, § 12-49; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 30)  
Secs. 26-177—26-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WEEDS AND VEGETATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-201. - Removal. 
(a)  The city may undertake the removal and disposal of plant growth in violation of this chapter from any lot, block or parcel within the boundaries of the city at a cost of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per lot within a residential district and five hundred dollars ($500.00) per lot within a commercial district. 
(b)  After the abatement of the nuisance provided for above, the city comptroller, in conjunction with the superintendent of public works or his designee, shall notify the owner or occupant of the premises from which all plantings have been removed of the costs incurred as a result of the city's removal and disposal of plantings as were in violation of this chapter as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1980, § 28-4; Ord. No. 8-22-1935, § 5; Ord. No. 81-36, § 2, 10-22-1981; Ord. No. 94-33, § 1, 7-14-1994; Ord. No. 02-24, § I, 6-13-2002; Ord. No. 05-43, § 1, 7-14-2005; Ord. No. 18-48, § 4, 8-23-2018)  
Sec. 26-202. - Prohibited; nuisance declared. 
Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cockleburr, or other weeds of a like kind, found growing in any lot or tract of land are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place. 
(Code 1980, § 28-1; Ord. of 8-25-1955, § 1)  
Sec. 26-203. - Maximum height; nuisance declared. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit weeds, grasses or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding six (6) inches; any such weeds, grasses or plants exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1980, § 28-2; Ord. of 8-25-1955, § 2; Ord. No. 81-36, § 1, 10-22-1981; Ord. No. 05-36, § 1, 6-9-2005)  
Sec. 26-204. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-37, § 1, adopted June 10, 2004, repealed § 26-204, which pertained to barberry bushes and was derived from Code 1980, § 28-3; and Ord. of 8-25-1955, § 3.  
Sec. 26-205. - Citation to owner. 
It shall be the duty of the department of inspectional services to serve or caused to be served a citation upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which plantings were removed by the city in order to abate the nuisance and forward a copy of this citation to the city comptroller. In addition, the city comptroller shall prepare an invoice for the cost and expense of removal and forward said invoice to the owner with a demand for payment in full within thirty (30) days of the invoice. 
(Code 1980, § 28-5; Ord. of 8-25-1955, § 4, Ord. No. 90-22, § 1, 5-10-1990; Ord. No. 02-24, § II, 6-13-2002; Ord. No. 18-48, § 5, 8-23-2018) 
State Law reference— Power of city to destroy weeds at expense of property owner, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6.  
Secs. 26-206—26-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REMOVAL LIEN 
 
Sec. 26-231. - Filing for. 
In the event payment is not received within thirty (30) days of issuance of an invoice by the city, the city comptroller shall file a notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds, then such cost and expense shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens, except tax liens. 
(Code 1980, § 28-6; Ord. No. 02-24, § III, 6-13-2002; Ord. No. 18-38, § 6, 8-23-2018) 
State Law reference— Power of city to obtain lien for weed removal, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7.  
Sec. 26-232. - Notice. 
The notice of lien required by this chapter shall consist of a sworn statement setting out a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service and the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the city or person authorized by it. 
(Code 1980, § 28-7) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7.  
Sec. 26-233. - Validity. 
The lien provided for by this chapter shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to the weed cutting and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. 
(Code 1980, § 28-8) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7.  
Sec. 26-234. - Release of lien upon payment. 
Upon payment of the costs and expense by the owner of, or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien provided for by this chapter shall be released by the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(Code 1980, § 28-9) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7.  
Chapter 30 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Board of fire and police commissioners, § 2-811 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; emergency services, ch. 22; burning grass and leaves, § 26-1; fireworks, § 62-171 et seq.; obstructions to doors, windows or fire escapes, § 70-3; attaching to fire escape or standpipe, § 70-4; burning garbage, § 74-38; directing traffic at fire, § 90-42. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 30-1. - Conduct of spectators at fires. 
It shall be the duty of all spectators at fires to obey the orders of the members of the fire department on duty there with respect to keeping away from the scene of the fire or the handling or interference with the apparatus of the department. 
(Code 1980, § 10-10)  
Sec. 30-2. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  The fire chief may require and designate public or private fire lanes as deemed necessary for the efficient and effective use of fire apparatus. 
(b)  Designated fire lanes shall be maintained free of obstructions and vehicles and marked in a manner prescribed by the fire chief. 
(c)  No person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle or obstruction in said fire lane. 
(d)  The street and alley commissioner shall post the appropriate signs. Any signs posted in commercial shopping centers shall be at the expense of the respective shopping center. 
(e)  Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1980, § 10-17; Ord. No. 84-8, § 1, 2-23-1984) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 90.  
Sec. 30-3. - Smoke detectors. 
All detectors installed in dwellings, rooming houses or apartment houses constructed or remodeled on or after the passage of this section [Ord. No. 85-5] shall be powered by a nonswitchable 120VAC source or an approved fire alarm control panel. Detectors installed within dwelling units or rooming units constructed before the passage of this section shall be powered by batteries, a nonswitchable AC source, or an approved fire alarm control panel. All detectors installed within common stairwells of buildings constructed before the passage of this section and containing less than six (6) dwellings or rooming units shall be powered by an AC source or an approved fire alarm control panel. Detectors installed in common stairwells or hallways of buildings containing six (6) or more dwelling units shall be monitored and powered by an approved fire alarm control panel. 
(Code 1980, § 10-18; Ord. No. 85-5, § 1, 2-14-1985; Ord. No. 86-18, § 1, 7-10-1986; Ord. No. 92-49, § 1, 11-12-1992)  
Secs. 30-4—30-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Departments, § 2-566 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-31. - Established. 
There is hereby established a fire department, an executive department of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 10-26; Ord. of 2-27-1942, § 1)  
Sec. 30-32. - Composition. 
The fire department shall consist of the fire chief, deputy chief, assistant chief, four (4) captains, four (4) lieutenants, nine (9) engineers and such number of firefighters as may be provided from time to time by the mayor and council. Provided, however, that any person holding rank in the fire department upon the adoption of this section shall continue to hold said rank, but no person may be appointed to said rank if the appointment would increase the number of captains, lieutenants or engineers above the number herein provided. 
(Code 1980, § 10-27; Ord. No. 82-32, § 1, 12-9-1982; Ord. No. 85-13, § 1, 4-11-1985; Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 7-26-1990)  
Sec. 30-33. - Fire chief, deputy chief, assistant chief—Generally.
