(a)  If the identity or location of the owner or other person entitled to possession of stolen property has not been ascertained within six (6) months after the police department obtains possession of said property, the chief of police shall effectuate the sale of the property for cash to the highest bidder at a public auction, notice of which (including time, place and a brief description of said property) shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city wherein the police chief has authority at least ten (10) days prior to such auction. Property offered but not sold at such public auction may be offered and sold at a subsequent public auction without such notice. 
(b)  Proceeds of the sale of the property at public auction, less reimbursement to the police department of the reasonable expenses of custody thereof, shall be deposited in the treasury of the city. 
(c)  The owner or other person entitled to possession of such property may claim and recover possession of the property at any time before its sale at public auction upon providing reasonable and satisfactory proof of ownership or right to possession and reimbursing the police department for all reasonable expenses of custody thereof. 
(d)  No person shall be responsible for consequent damages to another occasioned by an act or omission in compliance with this section. 
(Code 1980, § 20-11; Ord. No. 77-38, § 1, 9-22-1977)  
Sec. 46-42. - Special police. 
Any person of good character having duties which require it, may be appointed a special policeman by the mayor or chief of police, provided that, except upon authorization by the council, no such special policeman shall be entitled to any compensation from the city by reason of such appointment. Special policemen shall obey all rules of the police department applicable to them, and may be deprived of their appointment by the mayor or chief at any time. 
(Code 1980, § 20-12) 
State Law reference— Auxiliary policemen, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20.  
Sec. 46-43. - Reserve or part-time police. 
(a)  A reserve police division is hereby authorized which shall be required to comply with all federal, state, county and local laws relative to qualifications of reserve police officers. 
(b)  Applicants for the reserve police force shall be appointed by the chief of police, subject to budgetary city council approval. 
(c)  Members of the reserve police division shall serve when called upon by the mayor or chief of police under the supervision of the regular police department. They shall be conservators of the peace with the power to make arrest, as provided by statute. 
(d)  Applicants must be twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(e)  Applicants must submit to a polygraph and personnel screening test. 
(f)  Applicants must be of good character without previous police record. 
(g)  Applicants must submit to a thorough background investigation. 
(h)  Reserve police officers, also known as reserve officers or part-time officers, must successfully complete all training required by statute, ordinance or departmental regulation. 
(i)  Reserve police officers shall be paid at a rate set from time to time by the city council. Reserve police officers shall be paid at said rate only for actual hours worked. 
(j)  Reserve police officers shall report to the regular police officer in charge of the shift both when they begin and end their tour of duty. 
(k)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his designee to set the requirements, qualifications and duties to be performed by reserve police officers, consistent with applicable federal, state, county and local law, which requirements, qualifications and duties shall be written and published. 
(l)  Any reserve police officer may be terminated by the chief of police, with notice to the mayor, city council and appropriate payroll personnel. 
(m)  Residence requirements. 
(1)  All employees covered by this agreement must reside in a city, township, or other municipality where some part of said city, township, or other municipality is within a twenty-mile radius from the city limits of the City of Calumet City as determined by Microsoft 2002 Streets and Trips. 
(2)  The Illinois cities, towns or municipalities include: Alsip, Bedford Park, Beecher, Berwyn, Blue Island, Bridgeview, Broadview, Brookfield, Burbank, Burnham, Burr Ridge, Calumet City, Calumet Park, Chicago, Chicago Heights, Chicago Ridge, Cicero, Country Club Hills, Countryside, Crestwood, Crete, Dixmoor, Dolton, East Hazel Crest, Evergreen Park, Flossmoor, Ford Heights, Forest Park, Forest View, Frankfort, Glenwood, Goodenow, Grant Park, Harvey, Hazel Crest, Hickory Hills, Hinsdale, Hodgkins, Holbrook, Homer-Glen, Hometown, Homewood, Indian Head Park, Justice, LaGrange, LaGrange Park, Lemont, Lynwood, Lyons, Manhattan, Matteson, McCook, Merrionette Park, Midlothian, Mokena, Monee, New Lenox, North Riverside, Oak Forest, Oak Lawn, Oak Park, Olympia Fields, Orland Hills, Orland Park, Palos Park, Park Forest, Phoenix, Posen, Richton Park, Riverdale, Robbins, Sauk Village, South Chicago Heights, South Holland, Steger, Stickney, Summit, Thornton, Tinley Park, University Park, Western Springs, Willow Springs, Willowbrook, Worth. 
(3)  The unincorporated Illinois townships include: Crete Township, Frankfort Township, Green Garden Township, Homer Township, Lemont Township, Manhattan Township, Monee Township, New Lenox Township, Orland Township, Peotone Township, Washington Township and Yellowhead Township. 
(4)  The Indiana cities, towns or municipalities include: Burns Harbor, Cedar Lake, Creston, Crown Point, Dyer, East Chicago, Gary, Griffith, Hammond, Highland, Hobart, Klassville, Lake Station, Leroy, Lowell, Merrillville, Munster, New Chicago, Ogden Dunes, Portage, Schereville, South Haven, St. John, Whiting, Winfield. 
(5)  The unincorporated Indiana townships include: Cedar Creek Township, Center Township, Eagle Creek Township, Hanover Township, St. John Township, West Creek Township, Winfield Township, Union Township, Porter Township. 
(n)  Reserve police officers shall submit to physical examinations at such times and places as directed by the chief of police. 
(o)  The physical standards of a reserve police officer shall be the same as the requirements for a regular police officer. 
(p)  All new appointees shall submit to an initial physical examination at their expense by a medical doctor designated by the chief of police. 
(q)  Reserve police officers shall submit to polygraph tests at such times and places as directed by the chief of police. 
(r)  No reserve police officer shall work more than one thousand five hundred sixty (1,560) hours annually or as may be regulated by the state. 
(s)  Reserve police officers are at-will employees and serve at the will of the city and acquire no rights or benefits not conferred by statute. 
(Code 1980, § 20-13; Ord. of 8-28-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 78-43, § 1, 9-28-1978; Ord. No. 82-11, § 1, 6-10-1982; Ord. No. 85-28, § 1, 8-8-1985; Ord. No. 85-34, § 1, 10-10-1985; Ord. No. 99-5, § 1, 1-14-1999; Ord. No. 04-71, §§ 1, 4, 10-14-2004) 
State Law reference— Auxiliary policemen, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20.  
Sec. 46-44. - Rules, regulations and orders. 
The chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the hours of duty, vacations, uniforms and conduct of the members of the police department as he shall deem advisable, and such rules when approved by the mayor or council shall be binding on such members. All rules, orders and regulations shall be promulgated through the chief of police. 
(Code 1980, § 20-14)  
Sec. 46-45. - Preference for original appointments to police department for persons having prior qualified training. 
Persons whose names appear on any register of eligibles resulting from an examination for original entrance in the classified service of the police department shall be given preference for original appointment if they have satisfactorily completed the Basic Law Enforcement Police Training Institute course given by the University of Illinois or the certified course and curriculum of the state law enforcement commission conducted by the county sheriff's police academy or other qualified institute, by adding to the final grade average which they receive or will receive as a result of any examination held for original entrance, five (5) points; provided, however, that the additional five (5) points shall not be added to the final grade average if said person has also requested and been granted five (5) points to be added to the final grade average and given preference for appointment as a police cadet. 
(Code 1980, § 20-15; Ord. No. 83-5, § 1, 2-24-1983)  
Sec. 46-46. - Assistant chiefs. 
Two assistant chiefs of police shall be appointed by the police chief from the ranks of captain or lieutenant. The assistant chiefs shall serve at the police chief's pleasure, and shall hereby be second in command of the police department, and perform duties assigned by the police chief. 
(Code 1980, § 20-16; Ord. No. 90-35, § 3, 7-26-1990; Ord. No. 01-30, § 2, 7-12-2001; Ord. No. 11-4, § 2, 1-27-2011)  
Sec. 46-47. - Civil service rank. 
Any person filling the position of chief of police or assistant chief shall retain their civil service rank while serving in such position, but there shall not be a vacancy in the rank that they are holding. 
(Code 1980, § 20-17; Ord. No. 90-35, § 4, 7-26-1990)  
Sec. 46-48. - Supervisor of records and communications. 
There is hereby created the position of supervisor of records and communications, which shall be an exempt, nonbargaining unit command position. 
(Code 1980, § 20-18; Ord. No. 01-30, § 3, 7-12-2001) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-231 et seq.  
Sec. 46-49. - Lateral transfers of police officers. 
(a)  The Calumet City Police Department may accept lateral transfers without the necessity of participating in the competitive hiring process as long as the lateral transfer meets the requirements of being a full- or part-time member in good standing of a regular police department; has completed any applicable probationary period of employment; is a certified police officer pursuant to the Illinois Police Training Act, 50 ILCS 705/1, et seq.; and has documentation that he or she has fulfilled the requirements of their respective training boards and be eligible to receive certification through the Illinois Training Board. If the officer is from out of state and is fully trained as required above, he or she may be laterally transferred and is on additional probation until fully certified in the State of Illinois, but shall only have ninety (90) days to complete all requirements for certification. Employees so appointed shall be given the rank of probationary patrolman and will be the last person on the seniority list and receive probationary patrolman salary. 
(b)  The city council, from time to time, may authorize the police chief and board of police and fire commissioners to advertise for qualified officers. The police chief shall interview and otherwise assess each applicant for an available position and shall forward such recommendation to the board of police and fire commissioners. The board of police and fire commissioners may hire an officer recommended by the police chief as long as previously receiving authorization from the city council to fill an open position. Every applicant must pass a polygraph and psychological exam and any other applicable requirements as set forth by the board of police and fire commissioner. 
(c)  Upon hiring, such officers shall be under the authority of the board of police and fire commissioner for purposes of promotion and discipline as well as under the terms of any collective bargaining agreement between the union and the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-59, §§ 1—3, 5-17-2007; Ord. No. 08-5, § 2, 1-24-2008)  
Secs. 46-50—46-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PENSION FUND 
 
Sec. 46-71. - Established. 
There is hereby established a police pension fund. 
(Code 1980, § 20-26) 
State Law reference— Police pension fund required, 40 ILCS 5/3-101.  
Sec. 46-72. - Police pension board. 
(a)  Created; membership. There shall be a police pension board consisting of five (5) members. Of these members, two (2) shall be appointed by the mayor, serving a term of two (2) years each; two (2) shall be elected from the regular police force of the city, and one (1) shall be elected from the beneficiaries of the police pension. Each member shall serve for two (2) years and the elected members shall be selected in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the members of the police pension board to manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all moneys pertaining thereto in the manner provided by statute and to pay beneficiaries as is provided by statute. 
(Code 1980, §§ 20-34, 20-35) 
State Law reference— Duties of board, 40 ILCS 5/3-126 et seq.; similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-126.  
Chapter 50 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Established. 
There is hereby established a public library and reading room for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of the city under the provisions of The Illinois Local Library Act (75 ILCS 5/1-0.1 et seq.). 
(Code 1980, § 21-1; Ord. of 12-22-1927, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— The Illinois Local Library Act, 75 ILCS 5/1-0.1 et seq.  
Secs. 50-2—50-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF LIBRARY DIRECTORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-799 et seq. 
 
Sec. 50-21. - Established. 
There is hereby established a board of library directors for the management and control of the city library. 
(Code 1980, § 21-16; Ord. of 12-22-1927, § 3)  
Sec. 50-22. - Composition. 
The board of library directors shall consist of nine (9) members. 
(Code 1980, § 21-17; Ord. of 12-22-1927, § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 75 ILCS 5/4-1.  
Sec. 50-23. - Appointment. 
The members of the board of library directors shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 21-18; Ord. of 12-22-1927, § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 75 ILCS 5/4-1.  
Sec. 50-24. - Term. 
The board of library directors shall serve for terms of three (3) years. The term of each director shall commence with the first day of July following his appointment. Three (3) shall be appointed annually. 
(Code 1980, § 21-19) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 75 ILCS 5/4-1.  
Sec. 50-25. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies occurring in the membership of the board of library directors shall be filled in the manner in which the original appointments were made. 
(Code 1980, § 21-20) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 75 ILCS 5/4-4.  
Sec. 50-26. - Powers and duties. 
The board of library directors shall have the powers and duties provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 21-21; Ord. of 12-22-1927, § 3) 
State Law reference— Powers of board, 75 ILCS 5/4-7 et seq.  
Chapter 54 - LICENSES AND PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6; ambulance license, § 38-131 et seq.; commercial districts, § 70-201 et seq.; taxation, ch. 82; telecommunications, ch. 86. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Conflicts with certain Home Rule county ordinances. 
(a)  Employers located within the city shall comply with all applicable federal and/or state laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time with regard to both the payment of minimum hourly wages and paid sick leave. Employee eligibility for paid sick leave and minimum hourly wages shall also be in compliance with all applicable federal and/or state laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time. 
(b)  No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave, or minimum hourly wages, including without limitation, any additional obligations by ordinance adopted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners, shall apply to employers located within the city, except those required by federal and/or state laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time. The city opts out of any such ordinance(s) adopted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners, and the ordinance codified in this section of the city, conflicts with any such ordinance(s) adopted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners that imposes additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave or minimum hourly wages. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "employee" means an individual permitted to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons the employer employs, and the term "employer" means any person employing one (1) or more employees, or seeking to employ one (1) or more employees, if the person has its principal place of business within the city or does business within the city. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, the term "employer" does not mean: 
(1)  The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the government of the United States; 
(2)  An Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe; 
(3)  The government of the state or any agency or department thereof; or 
(4)  The government of any municipality. 
(Ord. No. 17-23, § 2, 6-22-2017)  
Secs. 54-2—54-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES 
 
Sec. 54-31. - Scope; effect. 
The provisions of this article are hereby declared to be of a regulatory nature because each commercial establishment located in the city is a basic part of and affects the physical and economic well-being of the city, necessitating services from the city in the form of fire, health, police and other services. Such commercial establishments shall be in all respects in full compliance with the provisions hereinafter contained in this article. This article is designed to promote, protect and safeguard the public safety, health and welfare of the citizens of the city, and to enable the effecting of an accurate record of commercial establishments located and carrying on commercial activities or commerce within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 15-1; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 1)  
Sec. 54-32. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall mean as follows: 
Owner means any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in a commercial establishment to maintain and manage its operation. 
Retail, wholesale or manufacturing dealer means a building or premises or portion thereof the principal use of which is the sale, manufacture or distribution of material goods or chattels not included with or related to the sale of material goods or chattels or the providing of services of food establishments or service establishments. 
Service dealer means a building or premises or a portion thereof the principal use of which is the rendering of personal or material services for profit, the wholesale distribution or storage of material goods or chattels, the sale or servicing or storage of motor equipment, the washing or cleaning or dyeing or repair of fabrics or wearing apparel or footwear on the premises, the storage or assembly or distribution or servicing or repair of building materials or electrical equipment or mechanical equipment, the storage of or distribution of fuels or petroleum products, the services of printing or blueprinting or photocopying or multilithing or publishing or duplicating or similar reproduction services, the provisions of facilities for instruction or training or participating in or presentation of the fine arts, or athletic skills or dexterity, or physical skills or dexterity. 
(Code 1980, § 15-2; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 17)  
Sec. 54-33. - License applications. 
Applications for all licenses and permits shall be made in writing on forms to be provided by the city clerk and shall be submitted to the city clerk unless express provision to the contrary is made. A new application shall be necessary to renew any license at its expiration. 
(Code 1980, § 15-3; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 54-34. - License issuance. 
All licenses or permits, except as may otherwise be specifically provided, shall be granted and signed by the mayor and issued by the city clerk. Any application may be ordered by the mayor to be presented to and approved by the city council before issuance of a permit or license, and the city council may overrule the decision of the mayor in reference to any application for license. Forms of licenses and permits shall be prescribed and furnished by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 15-4; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 3)  
Sec. 54-35. - Investigations and inspections. 
(a)  In case any provision of this Code requires an investigation into the character of any applicant, or into the premises to be used, the mayor shall cause such investigation to be made, and whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary thereto to secure compliance with any code provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the city who is authorized and qualified to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever inspections of premises are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to permit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection, any official or employee of the city who is authorized to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(Code 1980, § 15-5; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 4; Ord. No. 78-39, § 1, 9-28-1978)  
Sec. 54-36. - Bond. 
In case a bond is required for the issuance of any license or permit, such bond shall be a surety company bond to be approved by the city council and must be filed with the city clerk before the license or permit is issued. The mayor or city council may in any case require a bond from a licensee where deemed necessary to protect the city. Said bond shall in no event be less than the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Code 1980, § 15-6; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 5)  
Sec. 54-37. - Payment of fees. 
The fees required for licenses and permits must be paid at the time that application is made. In no event shall any rebate be made of any license fee, or part thereof, by reason of the death of the licensee, or by reason of nonuse of the license or by reason of a change of location or occupation of such licensee. Provided, however, that any fee required for licenses pursuant to the City Municipal Code which is due January first and is not paid on or before January thirty-first of the current year shall be subject to a late charge of an additional fifty (50) percent of the license fee. 
(Code 1980, § 15-7; Ord. of 12-3-1963, §§ 6, 7; Ord. No. 93-45, § 1, 12-20-1993)  
Sec. 54-38. - License expiration; fee proration; expiration notice. 
(a)  Except where otherwise provided, all licenses or permits shall expire on the last day of December of each year, unless such license or permit is issued for a period of time less than a year. No license shall be issued at the yearly rate of license fees except for the full license year; provided, however, that where such license is issued on or after the first day of July, the license fee shall be one-half (½) of the yearly license fee for the unexpired term of the license year. 
(b)  If a license is issued for a period in excess of one (1) month, it shall be the duty of the city clerk, at least ten (10) days prior to the termination of license period, to cause a written notice to be mailed to each licensee, stating that a new license will be required on the day following the expiration of his existing license, and stating also the amount of the license fee, and the penalty for failure to procure a license in accordance with the provisions of this Code; provided, however, that failure on the part of the city clerk to cause such notice to be mailed to any such licensee shall not waive the requirements that a license be procured. 
(Code 1980, § 15-8; Ord. of 12-3-1963, §§ 8, 9)  
Sec. 54-39. - Waiving license fees. 
Whenever, in the opinion of the city council, it is to the best interests of public welfare, and the permit sought is for charitable purposes for the interests of a department of the city or sponsored by some association or group of persons not for profit, the license fee provided for by this Code may be waived. In any other cases which might arise, the license fee shall be waived only upon a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the city council and in no case shall the filing of an application be waived. 
(Code 1980, § 15-9; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 16)  
Sec. 54-40. - Transferability; unlawful use. 
(a)  No license or permit issued hereunder shall be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable, transferable or assignable, voluntary or involuntary, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated, which shall include, but not be limited to, the giving, selling or conveyance of a license or permit or of fifty (50) percent or more of the total number of shares of stock, or securities convertible into stock, of a corporation or entity that holds a license or permit. 
(b)  No licensee shall assign, sell or transfer a license or permit to any other person or entity, even if such other person or entity intends to conduct the same business, occupation or activity as the licensee at the location used by the licensee. Such other person or entity shall apply and pay the fee for a new license or permit in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  No license or permit shall authorize any person or entity to do business or act under such license or permit other than the person or entity named in such license or permit. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to transfer, loan or give away any license or permit issued to such licensee. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to transfer any license or permit to a location different than the location identified on the license or permit. It shall also be unlawful for any person or entity to use or display any license or permit which has been unlawfully acquired. No person or entity shall alter, deface, forge, or counterfeit any license or permit issued by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 15-10; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 10; Ord. No. 08-43, § 2, 7-10-2008)  
Sec. 54-41. - Posting license. 
Every license granted for the purpose of conducting any business or occupation required to be licensed, and which designates the particular room, store, office or place in which such business so licensed is to be conducted, shall be posted at all times in a conspicuous place, so that the same may be easily seen, upon the wall of the principal room or office of the store or place in which such licensed business or occupation is carried on. When such license shall have expired, it shall be removed from such place in which it has been posted, and no license which is not in force and effect shall be permitted to remain posted upon the wall or upon any part of any room, store, office or place of business after the license has expired. 
(Code 1980, § 15-11; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 11)  
Sec. 54-42. - Record of licenses. 
The city clerk shall cause to be kept a record showing every license and every permit issued, showing the amount of fee paid, and the purpose for which such license or permit was issued, the location where the licensed or permitted privilege is to be exercised, and the name of the licensee or person receiving the permit. 
(Code 1980, § 15-12; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 12)  
Sec. 54-43. - Compliance with ordinances. 
No license for carrying on any business or occupation shall be issued when it appears that the premises of the building on or in which the business or occupation licensed is to be conducted does not comply with any ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 15-13; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 13)  
Sec. 54-44. - Licenses not specified by Code. 
Whenever a person desires to conduct a business or occupation within the city not specifically covered in this Code, unless no license is required under law, an application shall be made to the city clerk; and the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall grant or refuse a license or permit, fix a fee therefor and amount of bond, if one is required. 
(Code 1980, § 15-14; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 15)  
Sec. 54-45. - License revocation. 
Any license or permit may be revoked by the officer authorized to issue such license or permit for any violation of the terms or conditions upon which the license was issued, or of any ordinance relating to the license or the subject matter thereof, and it shall be unlawful to continue to exercise any privilege or authority granted by any license or permit issued by the city or any of its duly authorized officers or employees, after such license or permit has been so revoked. 
(Code 1980, § 15-15; Ord. of 12-3-1963, § 14)  
Sec. 54-46. - Additional prerequisites to license issuance. 
All licenses required in accordance with ordinances of the city shall be processed under the following procedure: 
(1)  All applications for licenses shall be submitted along with the required fee. 
(2)  A copy of the license application shall be sent to all members of the permits and license committee and the alderman of the ward in which the business is located. 
(3)  The alderman of said ward shall inform the permits and license committee within five (5) working days thereafter of the alderman's approval or disapproval. The permits and license committee shall interview all applicants when deemed necessary. If said license cannot be issued the committee will advise the applicant as soon as possible and return the fee previously tendered. 
(4)  No building permit may be issued until the business license application has received preliminary approval of the permits and license committee. Upon the chairman of the permits and license committee granting preliminary approval the license application shall then be forwarded to the respective departments for inspections and approval, such as the building department, police department, fire department, and health department when applicable. The inspections shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt by the respective department. 
(5)  Upon satisfactory completion of the required departmental inspections, the permits and license committee shall sign the application indicating approval. 
(6)  No certificate of occupancy for said premises shall be issued until a business license has been issued. 
(7)  The license application shall then be submitted to the mayor for his signature and upon execution thereof said license shall be issued. 
(8)  No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business if the premises and building to be used for the licensed purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the city, including a lack of any indebtedness owed to the city as the result of the existence, use or operation of said premises. No such license shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning ordinance of the city. No new or renewal license shall be issued to a license applicant, and the validity of any license granted under this chapter shall terminate if the licensee, license applicant, or business entity operating under the license issued hereunder shall owe a debt to the city for in excess of thirty (30) days beyond its due date. Such debt shall include but is not limited to debts, fines, fees, water bills, code enforcement citation fines or costs, traffic or red light photo enforcement citation fines, or any other indebtedness due the city. The city shall not reinstate a business license or service of a city provided utility until such overdue indebtedness has been paid in full, or other assurances that the debt will be paid, have been approved in writing by the mayor or mayor's designee. No new or renewal license shall be issued to a license applicant if the premises to be used for the licensed activity is delinquent in its Cook County property tax bills for in excess of two (2) years from said bills initial due date. 
(Code 1980, § 15-16; Ord. No. 82-10, § 1, 5-27-1982; Ord. No. 18-14, § 2, 4-23-2018)  
Secs. 54-47—54-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - AMUSEMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-81. - Scope; application. 
The provisions of this division, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the city, whether specifically licensed in another division in this article or not. 
(Code 1980, § 15-27)  
Sec. 54-82. - Licenses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the public and for admittance to which a fee is charged, without having first obtained a license therefor; provided that the provisions of this section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed elsewhere. 
(b)  Applications for such license shall be made to the city clerk and shall comply with all of the general provisions of this Code relating to such application. 
(c)  For such licenses the following fees shall be paid: 
Menageries, per day ..... $75.00 
Other amusements, per day ..... 75.00 
(Code 1980, § 15-28; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-83. - Street shows. 
No permit shall be granted or given for any exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such place that the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public place, except on order of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 15-29) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78.  
Sec. 54-84. - Athletic exhibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for conduct, operate or exhibit any race between persons, animals or vehicles, or any baseball game, boxing or wrestling matches or any other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged without having first procured a license therefor. 
(b)  The proprietor of such exhibition shall submit to the city clerk a statement verified under oath of the gross receipts of each such game, contest or race, within one (1) week after such exhibition. At the same time, the proprietor or person exhibiting or operating such exhibition shall pay to the clerk a sum equal to three (3) percent of the gross receipts. 
(c)  Sufficient members of the police department shall be admitted free of charge, to all such exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining order, and the city clerk may post any number of persons at the box office of each such performance, and may examine all the books pertaining to such performance showing or tending to show the gross receipts. 
(Code 1980, § 15-30) 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate athletic exhibitions, 65 ILCS 5/11-54-1.  
Sec. 54-85. - Order; crowding. 
(a)  The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks. 
(Code 1980, § 15-31)  
Sec. 54-86. - Indecent shows. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of public amusement or show. 
(Code 1980, § 15-32)  
Sec. 54-87. - Exhibitions of criminals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit any criminal or the body of any criminal or any person who shall have become notorious because of the commission of a crime, in any theatrical, exhibition or other public place. 
(Code 1980, § 15-33)  
Sec. 54-88. - Creation of riot. 
It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance. 
(Code 1980, § 15-34)  
Sec. 54-89. - Smoking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe on or beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred (100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainments are offered, presented, operated or exhibited. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner of such premises or of the occupant in charge, to provide and place printed signs on which the words "NO SMOKING" shall appear in letters at least four (4) inches high in conspicuous places, at least two (2) signs being upon the stage or in the wings thereof and one (1) sign in each dressing room. 
(Code 1980, § 15-35)  
Sec. 54-90. - Exit lights. 
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainment is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign on which the word "EXIT" shall appear in letters at least six (6) inches high, over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom; and a light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign, which light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall. 
(Code 1980, § 15-36)  
Sec. 54-91. - Premises. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or permit the operation of any amusement licensed in this article unless the premises on which such amusement is operated or permitted to be operated conforms with all the provisions or requirements in this Code relating to public buildings and public gatherings. 
(Code 1980, § 15-37)  
Sec. 54-92. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and fire marshal to see that every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is inspected by a member of both the police and fire departments, and to ensure conformity with all provisions of this Code concerning such amusements. 
(Code 1980, § 15-38)  
Secs. 54-93—54-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES GENERALLY  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-111. - Exception. 
No license shall be required under the provisions of this division for coin-operated or rented radios or television receivers located in hotel rooms, hospital rooms or other rooms rented for living quarters. 
(Code 1980, § 15-52)  
Sec. 54-112. - Identification sticker required. 
All automatic amusement devices, pinball machines, or any other automatic machine or device for which a fee is charged, for the purpose of amusement, and licensed hereunder, shall have a sticker affixed to said machine designating the name, address and telephone number of the company distributing, owning and/or servicing the machine. 
(Code 1980, § 15-52.1; Ord. No. 97-74, § 1, 12-23-1997)  
Secs. 54-113—54-130. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 54-131. - License required. 
No person shall operate or maintain in the city any automatic amusement devices, pinball machines, or any other automatic machine or device for which a fee is charged, for the purpose of amusement, without first having obtained a license for each of said devices so operated and maintained. Amusement devices as used in this division shall include all automatic coin-operated amusement devices and all other nonautomatic amusement devices for the use of which a fee is charged, excepting however, amusement devices specifically licensed and regulated by some other provision of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 15-46)  
Sec. 54-132. - Inspections. 
All devices licensed pursuant to this division shall be available for inspection by the proper city authorities for the purpose of ascertaining and declaring whether state law and this Code are being complied with. 
(Code 1980, § 15-51)  
Sec. 54-133. - License applications. 
Any person desiring to operate or maintain in the city any amusement device shall make application for a license for each such device to the city clerk in which application the applicant shall set forth the full name and address of the applicant, the description of the device for which a license is requested, the location of said device and such other pertinent information as may be required by said city clerk. Upon receipt of proper application and upon payment of the license hereinafter set forth, the city clerk shall issue a license for each said amusement device. 
(Code 1980, § 15-47)  
Sec. 54-134. - License fees. 
The following annual license fees shall be paid by each applicant for each of the following devices: 
Bowling machine ..... $75.00 
Target machine ..... 75.00 
Shuffleboard ..... 75.00 
Pool table machine ..... 75.00 
Penny arcade with one (1) machine (limited) ..... 360.00 
Each additional machine ..... 75.00 
Amusement arcades and amusement centers. A flat one thousand five hundred dollar ($1,500.00) annual license fee will apply for amusement arcades and amusement centers with not more than fifty (50) machines. An additional license fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per machine will apply for all machines in excess of fifty (50). 
(Code 1980, § 15-48; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 1; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005; Ord. No. 17-5, § 2, 2-23-2017)  
Sec. 54-135. - Illegal machines. 
No license shall be issued for any amusement device which violates any law or provision of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 15-50)  
Sec. 54-136. - License sticker. 
The licenses provided for in this division shall be in the form of a gummed sticker, which shall be serially numbered. Said license shall be affixed in plain view to the device for which it is issued and shall not be transferrable. 
(Code 1980, § 15-49)  
Secs. 54-137—54-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRONIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND CENTERS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-161. - Conditions under which an amusement license or amusement arcade license shall be conducted. 
(a)  The operation of any amusement center having been issued a license as herein provided shall be conducted only where no other retail business is located on the premises or no food or beverages are sold or consumed on the premises. 
(b)  The operation of any amusement arcade having been issued a license as herein provided shall be conducted only when it is a part of a commercial operation in excess of one hundred thousand (100,000) square feet and such operation provides such security. 
(c)  In each amusement center or amusement arcade having been issued a license as herein provided the following conditions shall be required: 
(1)  No smoking shall be permitted on the premises; 
(2)  Said amusement center or amusement arcade shall not be located within five hundred (500) feet from any school or church; 
(3)  An alarm system shall be installed on the premises to be connected to the police department and fire department of the city in a manner prescribed by the chief of police and the chief of fire; 
(4)  No person shall be allowed on a license premises in violation of section 62-484 of this Code (curfew for minors); and, 
(5)  No person who is enrolled in a school and is eighteen (18) years of age or younger shall be allowed on the license premises during the respective school hours unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or an adult member of the immediate family. 
(Code 1980, § 15-58; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982; Ord. No. 02-62, § III, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 54-162. - Suspension or revocation of licenses. 
If the permits and license committee of the city council has reason to believe that the licensee has failed or refused to comply with the terms of this division, a hearing may be held in regard to suspension, revocation or denial of issuance of said license. The permits and license committee shall give due notice to the licensee of the time and place and said licensee may be represented by counsel. If after the public hearing the permits and license committee determines that the licensee has failed or refused to comply with the terms of this division, or has failed or refused to comply with other law applicable to the business of keeping or providing electronic or electric amusement devices, or has been convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of any provision of this division, the committee may recommend to the city council to suspend or revoke the license, or deny the issuance of said license. Based upon the recommendation, the city council may suspend or revoke or deny the issuance of said license issued hereunder. That annually the permits and license committee shall review each licensee prior to issuance of an amusement center license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-59; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982)  
Sec. 54-163. - License fee. 
The following annual license fees for the period January first to December thirty-first shall be paid by each applicant for each of the following devices: 
Electronic or electric machine ..... $75.00 
Amusement center with one (1) machine (limited) ..... 360.00 
Each additional machine ..... 75.00 
(Code 1980, § 15-60; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982; Ord. No. 82-25, § 1, 9-23-1982; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-164. - Video gaming. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Video gaming means the ownership, placement, maintenance, operation or use of a video gaming terminal in a public place or in a fraternal or veterans' establishment within the city. 
Video gaming terminal means any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion or payment of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including, but not limited to, video poker, line up and blackjack, as authorized by the Illinois Gaming Board, utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens, or is for amusement purposes only. 
(b)  Video gaming license required. No person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other business entity shall have or keep a video gaming terminal or device in any public place or place of public resort unless the city license fees as set forth herein are paid and a valid license is issued and maintained in force by the State of Illinois. 
(c)  Annual fee. The first annual license fee, as set forth in subsection (j), for each video gaming terminal or device will be due not later than August 1, 2018. In all subsequent years beginning January 1, 2019, the annual license fee, as set forth in subsection (j), for each video gaming terminal or device will be due not later than January 31 of each year. All issued licenses, unless paid on or before January 31 shall expire on the 31st day of January of that year. This fee is not in lieu of any fee or payment payable to the state or the Illinois Gaming Board. No license may issue where the license applicant owes a debt, fine, fee, tax or penalty to the city. 
(d)  Application requirements. Applications for a video gaming license shall be made to the city clerk upon a form to be supplied by the city and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant, age, place of birth, and date of incorporation or establishment as a business entity, if applicable; 
(2)  Prior convictions, if any, of applicant; 
(3)  Place where the video gaming terminal is to be displayed or operated, and the business conducted at the place; 
(4)  Number of video gaming terminals to be displayed or operated; 
(5)  Description of video gaming terminal to be covered by the license, mechanical features and serial number; 
(6)  Copy of valid Illinois Gaming Board License; 
(7)  Copy of valid Illinois Liquor License; 
(8)  Copy of valid City of Calumet City Liquor License; and 
(9)  Such other information as the city may determine as necessary as set forth in the application form. 
(e)  Issuance. The applicant must obtain proper state licenses and exhibit proof of said licenses prior to the issuance of a license pursuant to this subsection. Upon approval of the application and payment of the annual license fee as set forth in subsection (j), the city shall issue a City of Calumet City Video Gaming License and it will be included on the business license issued to the licensee. One (1) license shall be issued for each establishment and list the number of video gaming terminals licensed for said establishment and it shall be affixed in a conspicuous place. 
(f)  Operation of video gaming terminals. All such video gaming devices or terminals shall at all times be kept, placed, operated and monitored pursuant to State of Illinois laws and applicable regulations including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Prohibiting persons under age twenty-one (21) in the gaming area and restricting access in the gaming area to individuals who are visibly intoxicated; 
(2)  Video gaming terminals shall be placed in an area restricted to individuals' age twenty-one (21) or over. If individuals under the age of twenty-one (21) are allowed in any portion of the licensed premises, the establishment shall limit visibility of video gaming terminals from outside the room in which they are located; 
(3)  The operation of video gaming devices or terminals shall only be allowed during the legal hours of operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed establishment. Upon the suspension or revocation of a licensee's liquor license, the licensee's video gaming license shall automatically be suspended (or revoked in the event of a liquor license revocation) without the requirement of any further action by the city. Licensee's gaming license shall be suspended for the same period of time as the suspension or revocation of the licensee's liquor license; 
(4)  The video gaming area shall be physically monitored by an employee over twenty-one (21) years of age at all times during the legal hours of operation; and 
(5)  Providing for camera surveillance of the video gaming area that meets the specifications of the city as specified in license application, with equipment that has the ability to record and may be accessed by the police department upon request to investigate a suspected violation of this section, any law or administrative code, or any unlawful activity. 
(g)  Signage. Required signage pursuant to State of Illinois laws, regulations and city ordinances shall be posted at all times in the establishment's video gaming terminal area and should further include signage prohibiting the video gaming terminal area to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age. All signage shall be approved by the city prior to its posting in the establishment. 
(h)  Responsible gaming policy. Licensees are required to submit their establishment's responsible gaming policy, which outlines all employee education and training programs, self-exclusion policies, and procedures to promote responsible gaming with their license application. If standardized training for responsible gaming becomes available at the future date, it shall be required as part of the video gaming license application. 
(i)  Inspection. As a condition for issuance of the video gaming license to the licensee, the city reserves the right to inspect the premises at any time for compliance with this section and all other applicable ordinances and statutes. 
(j)  Annual license fees. The annual license fee per video gaming terminal is five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(k)  Penalties. Any licensee violating this section shall be subject to a mandatory fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus court costs for each separate violation. Every day a violation continues in effect will be considered a separate and distinct violation subject to imposition of a mandatory fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per day for each day the violation continues. 
(l)  Enforcement. Proceedings to enforce violations of this section may be initiated and conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the city ordinances providing for administrative adjudication of code violations or by any other means provided by law. 
(m)  Additional penalties. 
(1)  If, after a hearing or proceeding conducted pursuant to subsection (l), it is determined a violation of this section occurred, the mayor and city council may, in addition to any fine imposed, suspend or revoke any video gaming license issued pursuant to this section. 
(2)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsections (k) and (j)(1), the city mayor, acting in her capacity as local liquor commissioner, may also initiate an appropriate proceeding pursuant to the applicable provisions of chapter 6 of the Municipal Code of Calumet City, entitled "alcoholic liquor," to revoke or suspend the liquor license of a licensee or cause a fine to be imposed and paid by the liquor licensee as provided for in the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 18-31, § 2, 6-28-2018)  
Secs. 54-165—54-180. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Device Licenses 
 
Sec. 54-181. - License required. 
No person, firm or corporation shall place or install or maintain or operate in any building or place within the city any electronic or electric amusement device for use by the public and for which a fee is charged without first having obtained a license for each place or location for such electronic or electric amusement device, which games use a video screen or electrical impulses which is so constructed that the result of the operation depends upon chance, or upon the skill of the operator, or upon both. 
(Code 1980, § 15-53; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982)  
Sec. 54-182. - License applications. 
(a)  Generally. Any person desiring to operate or maintain in the city any electronic or electric amusement device using video screens or electrical impulses shall make application for a license for each such device to the city clerk, in which application the applicant shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  Principal kind of business engaged in; 
(2)  Statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager or managers and the name, address, date of birth and authority of each such manager, statement of personal history of each manager conducting business; 
(3)  The location of the place of business, the place where the amusement devices are to be kept or displayed and the description of all such devices to be kept or displayed on the premises. 
(b)  When applicant is a corporation. If the applicant is a corporation, the applications filed shall contain the following information in addition to such information as is required in subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  Corporate name and address and date of incorporation; 
(2)  Name, date of birth and address of each corporate officer and director and of each person, firm or organization owning directly or indirectly five (5) percent or more of the corporation's stock; 
(3)  Statement of whether any officer, manager, director or shareholder owning directly or indirectly five (5) percent or more of the stock of the corporation has ever been convicted of any criminal offense. 
(c)  When applicant is a partnership. If the applicant is a partnership, the applications filed shall contain the following information in addition to such information as is required in subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  Name, date of birth and address of each general partner and each limited partner owning directly or indirectly five (5) percent or more interest in the partnership; 
(2)  Statement of whether any general partner or any limited partner owning directly or indirectly five (5) percent or more interest in the partnership or any manager of the partnership has ever been convicted of any criminal offense. 
(d)  When applicant is an individual. If the applicant is an individual, the applications filed shall contain the following information in addition to such additional information as is required in subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  Name, date of birth and address of the applicant; 
(2)  Statement of whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any criminal offense. 
(e)  Investigation. The city clerk and the chief of police, fire chief and the building inspector shall investigate the information contained in the application and shall determine the following: 
(1)  That the premises designated by the applicant as the location of the business comply with the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city and that there be not less than forty (40) square feet per machine; 
(2)  That the premises and the manager comply with the provisions of this division; and 
(3)  That the applicant and each manager meet the standards for issuance of licenses. 
(f)  Issuance of license. Subject to the limitation established as to the maximum number of coin-operated amusement device business licenses to be issued hereunder, if the investigation shows the compliance of the applicant, its business and its managers with each of the requirements established in subsection (e) of this section, the mayor shall instruct the city clerk to issue the license, and upon payment by the applicant of the license fee required hereunder, such license shall be issued. 
(Code 1980, § 15-54; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982)  
Sec. 54-183. - Maximum number of amusement device business licenses to be issued. 
A person may be issued no more than three (3) amusement device business licenses as herein provided unless said person operates an amusement center, as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1980, § 15-55; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982)  
Sec. 54-184. - Identification sticker required. 
All electronic or electric amusement devices licensed hereunder shall have a sticker affixed to said device designating the name, address and telephone number of the company distributing, owning and/or servicing said device. 
(Code 1980, § 15-60.1; Ord. No. 97-74, § 2, 12-23-1997)  
Secs. 54-185—54-200. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Amusement Center Licenses 
 
Sec. 54-201. - Application; amusement arcade license. 
(a)  Any person may apply for an amusement center license by filing an application as provided in section 54-182 of this division. The total number of amusement center licenses to be issued shall be one (1). No new or additional amusement center licenses shall be issued to increase the total number of licenses. 
(b)  A person may apply for an amusement arcade license by filing an application as provided in section 54-182 of this division. The total number of amusement arcade licenses to be issued shall be one (1). No new or amusement arcade licenses shall be issued to increase the number of such licenses. 
(Code 1980, § 15-57; Ord. No. 82-8, § 1, 4-22-1982; Ord. No. 02-62, § II, 11-25-2002; Ord. No. 17-4A, § 2, 2-14-2017)  
Secs. 54-202—54-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - AUTOMATIC MUSIC DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— For similar provisions, see 65 ILCS 5/11-55-1. 
 
Sec. 54-221. - Defined. 
As used in this division, the term "automatic music device" means any phonograph, player piano, music box, jukebox, or other instrument or device capable of producing or reproducing any vocal or instrumental sounds, other than a motion picture sound machine, which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token. 
(Code 1980, § 15-61)  
Sec. 54-222. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall keep, or permit to be kept, for gain or profit from operation within the city, any automatic musical device without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for a license required by this division shall be made to the city clerk. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the description of the automatic musical instrument or instruments intended to be kept for use on his premises. 
(c)  Fee: 
(1)  The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each device kept or installed on the licensed premises. 
(2)  The annual fee for a distributor's license shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  Transferability. No license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(e)  Identification sticker. All automatic music devices licensed hereunder shall have a sticker affixed to said device designating the name, address and telephone number of the company distributing, owning and/or servicing said device. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-62, 15-63, 15-64, 15-65, 15-67; Ord. No. 97-74, § 3, 12-23-1997; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-223. - Disturbing the peace; immoral or indecent selections. 
No license issued under this division shall permit the operation of any automatic instrument at any place or in any manner which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. No immoral or indecent selections shall be played on any such instrument. 
(Code 1980, § 15-66)  
Secs. 54-224—54-250. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - BOWLING ALLEYS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate bowling alleys, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2. 
 
Sec. 54-281. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate a bowling alley open to the public without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for the license required by this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number of alleys to be used.
