Sec. 54-282. - Minors. 
Persons under the age of sixteen (16) years shall not under any circumstances frequent, loiter, go or remain in any bowling alley licensed under this division at any time, unless it be upon some lawful errand and sent under the direction and with the consent of and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the lawful custody of such minor. It shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any bowling alley so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or remain within the bowling alley in violation of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 15-89)  
Secs. 54-283—54-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - GO-CART TRACKS 
 
Sec. 54-301. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any rental cart tracks, or place where persons are permitted, for hire, to use a motor vehicle in an enclosed area for amusement or entertainment, without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for a license required by the provisions of this division shall comply with the general licensing provisions of this Code. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be two hundred ten dollars ($210.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-96, 15-97, 15-98; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 2; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-302. - Location restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful to locate or operate any establishment required to be licensed by this division except in accordance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance; provided further, that such location shall not be established within three hundred (300) feet of any area zoned for residence purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 15-99)  
Sec. 54-303. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  The surface of each track required to be licensed by this division shall be asphalt, concrete or similar construction, and the track shall not exceed one-fourth (¼) of a mile in length nor be less than one-twenty-fifth ( 1/25 ) of a mile. The minimum width shall be sixteen (16) feet and the maximum width shall be thirty-four (34) feet, excepting that an additional ten (10) feet may be allowed at the starting and stopping areas. A twenty (20) foot safety apron shall be maintained around the track on all sides. 
(b)  The track shall be protected by a fence at least four (4) feet high with posts ten (10) feet apart, the posts being outside the fence around the track and protected from collision impact. Such fence shall be a galvanized welded fence of ten (10) gauge two and five-eighths (2 5/8 ) mesh or chain link nine (9) gauge two (2) inch mesh, or a solid wood fence. The area for the spectators shall be separated from the track. Adequate lighting shall be provided, so located as to prevent glare outside the premises and so far as possible to prevent glare in the eyes of drivers of vehicles. 
(Code 1980, § 15-100)  
Sec. 54-304. - Operational restrictions. 
(a)  The maximum speed of any vehicle on a track required to be licensed by this division shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour. Carts shall have a wheelbase of not less than forty (40) inches, nor more than fifty (50) inches measured from axle centers with an overall length of not more than seventy-two (72) inches. The tread width shall be a minimum of two-thirds of the measurement of the wheel base, the height not to exceed twenty-four (24) inches at the center of the seat, and the tire size shall be a maximum of twelve and one-half (12½) inches with a minimum of nine (9) inches. Wheel bearings shall be ball bearings or rollers. Axle ends must be cottered, keyed or safety wired. The safety shell above the wheel centers may be plastic or metal. There shall be a metal sheath between the driver and the engine. 
(b)  Steering shall be direct, and safety designed for such operation as is anticipated, and the rod ends must be of the universal type with swivel joints. Engines shall be two (2) or four (4) cycles, mounted behind the driver, and all engines shall be properly muffled with exhaust fumes directed away from the driver. No gear box type shall be used, and brakes shall be pedal operated and effective on all four (4) wheels. Each such vehicle shall be equipped with a clutch, and a foot throttle with a self-operating returning spring. 
(c)  The ignition switch shall be within easy reach of the driver, and the driver's compartment shall be equipped with side rails of a maximum of four (4) inches above the seat. Fuel tanks shall be mounted in back of the driver. 
(d)  Each such vehicle shall be equipped with front and rear bumpers, constructed so far as possible so as to avoid hooking with other similar carts. No such vehicle shall be equipped with roll bars or safety belt seats. 
(e)  No more than six (6) carts shall be permitted in operation on a track having a length of less than one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of a mile, ten (10) carts where the length is less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) of a mile, and twelve (12) carts where the length is less than one-fourth (¼) of a mile. 
(Code 1980, § 15-101)  
Sec. 54-305. - Prizes. 
No prizes shall be permitted or awards allowed for any competition between drivers on a track required by this division to be licensed. 
(Code 1980, § 15-102)  
Sec. 54-306. - Inspections. 
The chief of police, the chief of the fire department, and the building commissioner shall make such inspections as are necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-103)  
Secs. 54-307—15-320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - GOLF PRACTICE RANGES 
 
Sec. 54-321. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, operate or maintain a golf practice range for the use of which a fee is charged without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for the license required by this division shall be accompanied by plans or drawings showing the area to be used and showing compliance with the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for a license to conduct or operate a golf practice range shall be two hundred ten dollars ($210.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-111, 15-112, 15-113; Ord. of 12-12-1973, § 3; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-322. - Construction regulations; maintenance. 
Each golf practice range shall be constructed according to nationally recognized safe practice standards for such amusements to protect patrons, passersby and the surrounding area. Sufficient off-street parking for patrons shall be furnished and maintained. The premises shall be maintained in an orderly manner and grass and weeds kept down. 
(Code 1980, § 15-114)  
Sec. 54-323. - Concessions. 
Any food or beverage sold or offered for sale at a golf practice range, whether such sale is by operator, the owner or employees or by a concession, must comply with the provisions of this Code relating thereto and an additional fee for such sales shall be paid when required by this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 15-115)  
Sec. 54-324. - Inspections. 
The chief of police shall inspect golf practice ranges as often as necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-116)  
Secs. 54-325—54-350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - KIDDIE PARKS 
 
Sec. 54-351. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to maintain, operate or conduct any commercial playground or kiddie park, for which admission is charged and to which children are invited to attend and do attend without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for a license required by this division shall be accompanied by plans or drawings of such playground or park showing compliance with the zoning regulations of the city and the location of each ride or other proffered amusement. 
(c)  Fee. The annual license fee for kiddie parks shall be computed on the basis of the area of the premises to be licensed, and shall be as follows: 
Area (sq. ft.)     Fee 
Up to 1,000 ..... ..... $300.00 
Each additional 500, or portion thereof ..... 150.00 
(d)  Revocation. The license required by the provisions of this division may be revoked by the mayor for any violation of the provisions of this division; the chief of police or the building commissioner may seal any ride or other amusement so licensed when such ride or amusement is deemed dangerous to children or in an unsafe condition. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-124, 15-125, 15-126, 15-130; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 5; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-352. - Construction and maintenance. 
Each playground or kiddie park shall be constructed according to nationally recognized safe practice regulations for such amusement parks. The provisions of this Code relating to public buildings and public gatherings shall be complied with both in constructing and maintaining such playgrounds or parks. 
(Code 1980, § 15-127)  
Sec. 54-353. - Supervision. 
A competent operator shall be in charge of each ride or other amusement in an establishment required to be licensed by this division. Sufficient number of persons to supervise the entire playground or park and maintain order therein shall be supplied by the owner or operator thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 15-128)  
Sec. 54-354. - Inspections. 
The chief of police and the building inspector shall make or cause to be made as many inspections as are necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-129)  
Secs. 54-355—54-380. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - MINIATURE GOLF COURSES 
 
Sec. 54-381. - License—Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a miniature golf course to which a fee is charged for admittance without a license.  
Sec. 54-382. - Same—Application. 
Applications for the license required by this division shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this Code relating to applications for licenses, and to the zoning regulations.  
Sec. 54-383. - Same—Fee. 
The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be two hundred ten dollars ($210.00). 
(Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 4; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-384. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful to keep any miniature golf course in the city open for business or to permit the same to be used or patronized at any time between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.  
Secs. 54-385—54-400. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS 
 
Sec. 54-401. - License required. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture, or theatrical, for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for a license required by the provisions of this division shall be made in conformance with the general provisions of this Code relating to such applications, and shall state in addition to the other information required the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be nine hundred sixty dollars ($960.00). 
(d)  Effect of license. Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures, or theatricals, naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented, may present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional fee. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-151, 15-152, 15-153, 15-154; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 6; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-402. - Fee on unlicensed premises. 
For motion pictures or theatricals which are to be presented in premises which are not covered by the license required in this division, the fee to be paid shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per day; provided that no such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of this Code relating to public gatherings and to maintenance of buildings for this purpose. 
(Code 1980, § 15-155)  
Sec. 54-403. - Building requirements. 
It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture in any building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required by this Code or by state law concerning buildings or places intended for motion picture performances or in premises which do not comply with the provisions of this Code relating to public gatherings, or in premises in which the electric wiring does not fully comply with this Code. All places used for the exhibition of theatricals must be kept adequately ventilated during the performance and for as long a time as the audience remains therein. 
(Code 1980, § 15-156)  
Sec. 54-404. - Prohibited pictures. 
It shall be unlawful to permit any person to offer or present any motion picture which has a tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace, or any immoral, indecent or blasphemous picture or performance. 
(Code 1980, § 15-160)  
Secs. 54-405—54-430. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 12. - PUBLIC DANCES 
 
Sec. 54-431. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the city without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for licenses required by this division shall be made in conformance with the general provisions of this Code relating to licenses, and shall specify the location of the proposed dance or dances, and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
(c)  Qualifications of applicant. No license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the city by a person of good moral character. 
(d)  Investigation of applicant. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant for a license required by this division and report the results of such investigation to the city council. 
(e)  Fee. The annual license fee for public dances shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-171, 15-172, 15-173, 15-174; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-432. - Premises. 
It shall be unlawful to conduct a public dance in any hall or place which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits, and no hall or building which is not provided with at least two (2) exits of four (4) feet or more in width shall be used for such purpose. 
(Code 1980, § 15-175)  
Sec. 54-433. - Prohibited conduct. 
It shall be unlawful to indulge in or to permit any improper or immoral conduct at any public dance. 
(Code 1980, § 15-176)  
Secs. 54-434—54-460. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - SHOOTING GALLERIES 
 
Sec. 54-461. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct any shooting gallery in the city without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for shooting galleries shall be two hundred ten dollars ($210.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-184, 15-185; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 7; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-462. - Safety. 
Targets in a shooting gallery shall be placed before a backstop of steel, sufficiently thick to prevent any bullet from piercing it, and so arranged that there will be no danger from ricocheting bullets or deflected pieces of bullet. 
(Code 1980, § 15-186)  
Sec. 54-463. - Sanitation. 
Premises used for shooting galleries shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1980, § 15-187)  
Sec. 54-464. - Hours of operation. 
No shooting gallery shall be open for business or used between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Code 1980, § 15-188)  
Sec. 54-465. - Conduct. 
All persons present in any shooting gallery shall conduct themselves in an orderly manner, and shall not make or cause to be made any loud or unnecessary noise. It shall be unlawful to gamble or bet in any such place. 
(Code 1980, § 15-189)  
Secs. 54-466—54-490. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 14. - SKATING RINKS 
 
Sec. 54-491. - Defined. 
The term "public skating rinks" as used in this division shall mean and include roller skating and ice skating rinks. 
(Code 1980, § 15-196)  
Sec. 54-492. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the city without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for a license required by this division shall be made in conformance with the general provisions of this Code relating to licenses and shall specify the location of the proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
(c)  Qualifications of applicant. No such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the city by a person of good moral character. 
(d)  Investigation of applicant. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant and report the results of such investigation to the mayor and city council. 
(e)  Fee. The fee for skating rinks shall be two hundred ten dollars ($210.00) for an annual license. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-197, 15-198, 15-199; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 8; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-493. - Premises; inspection as license prerequisite. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct a public skating rink in any hall or building which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits; no hall or building which is not provided with at least two (2) exits of four (4) feet or more in width shall be used for such purpose. 
(b)  No license shall be issued until an inspection of the premises shall have been made by the chief of police and building commissioner, and report made that said premises were in a safe condition, and that proper safeguards had been taken for the protection of patrons and the public. 
(Code 1980, § 15-200)  
Sec. 54-494. - Conduct; music. 
It shall be unlawful to indulge in any improper conduct or to permit any improper conduct at any public skating rink and it shall be unlawful to permit music at any public skating rink after the hour of 11:00 p.m. 
(Code 1980, § 15-201)  
Sec. 54-495. - Hours of operation. 
No person shall keep open, operate or use any skating rink licensed hereunder after the hour of 10:30 p.m., Mondays through Fridays, or 11:00 p.m. on Saturdays. The hours of operation on Sunday shall be from 2:30 p.m. until 10:30 p.m. 
(Code 1980, § 15-202)  
Secs. 54-496—54-520. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 15. - TRAMPOLINE CENTERS 
 
Sec. 54-521. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Trampoline center means and includes any business establishment or place where rebound tumbling equipment is provided or maintained for public use or where a fee is charged for the use of such equipment. 
Rebound tumbling equipment shall be construed to mean and include any device or apparatus designed to provide resilience, by virtue of its own elasticity or that provided by elastic or spring suspension or support to be used for jumping, bouncing or acrobatic tumbling. 
(Code 1980, § 15-211)  
Sec. 54-522. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, conduct or operate a trampoline center without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the license required by this division shall be in compliance with the general provisions of this Code relating to licenses. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-212, 15-213, 15-214; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 9; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-523. - Insurance. 
No trampoline center shall be operated unless there is in force a public liability insurance policy to cover any injury suffered as a result of the use of the equipment or the operation of the center in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one (1) occurrence and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for injury to any person. 
(Code 1980, § 15-215)  
Sec. 54-524. - Inspections. 
The building commissioner shall make, or cause to be made, such inspections as are necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-224)  
Sec. 54-525. - Supervision. 
At all times when an establishment licensed by this division is open to the public or is in use, there shall be one (1) responsible adult for each eight (8) units or fraction thereof in operation to supervise and enforce the regulations applicable to such use. 
(Code 1980, § 15-216)  
Sec. 54-526. - Equipment. 
(a)  All rebound equipment in a trampoline center shall be maintained in good condition, safe for the purpose for which it is intended. Each unit shall be placed so that there is three (3) feet between the sides of the units and any other unit or the nearest fence or wall; and five (5) feet between the end of such unit and the nearest other unit or fence or wall. 
(b)  Pits for such units shall have a depth of not less than three (3) feet nor more than four (4) feet at the center, and solidly framed. 
(c)  The frame of such equipment shall be padded with pads two (2) inches thick filled with cotton linters or similar pads with equal resiliency. 
(Code 1980, § 15-217)  
Sec. 54-527. - Accidents and first aid. 
Every mishap in a trampoline center resulting in any injury to any person from the use of the equipment shall be promptly reported to the chief of police. There shall be maintained on the premises a first-aid kit of at least sixteen (16) units as defined in the first-aid manual of the American Red Cross. 
(Code 1980, § 15-218)  
Sec. 54-528. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the influence of alcohol to use such equipment as is referred to in this division, or to permit such person to use such equipment. 
(b)  The person in charge of any such center may at any time request a patron to cease any activity which is unduly dangerous to the patron or others and may, upon refund of the fee paid, if any, cause such person to leave the premises upon failure to comply with such request. 
(Code 1980, § 15-219)  
Sec. 54-529. - Noise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to permit or cause any noise in a trampoline center so loud or of such a nature as to disturb the peace. 
(b)  The operation of any amplifier on the premises shall comply with the provisions of this Code relating to such devices. 
(Code 1980, § 15-220)  
Sec. 54-530. - Closing hours. 
Excepting when operated within a building, no such trampoline center shall be operated between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1980, § 15-221)  
Sec. 54-531. - Sanitary facilities. 
No trampoline center shall be operated unless there is on the premises separate toilet accommodations for men and women, and drinking water facilities complying with the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 15-222)  
Sec. 54-532. - Other regulations. 
A trampoline center shall be considered as a place of public amusement or entertainment and shall be subject to all provisions of this Code relating thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 15-223)  
Secs. 54-533—54-560. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MERCHANTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 54-561—54-580. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AUCTIONEERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate auctioneers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 
 
Sec. 54-581. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction in the city or to do business as an auctioneer without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for an auctioneer's license shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state thereon the place of business, if any, intended to be occupied; and the names of any employees who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority of the license. 
(c)  Fee. The fee, payable in advance, for auctioneers shall be forty-five dollars ($45.00) for each day of an auction. 
(d)  Investigation of applicant. The chief of police, or any other officer designated by the mayor, shall investigate the character of every applicant for an auctioneer's license and no such license shall be issued to any person who is not of good character. 
(e)  Designation of employees; additional license. Every person licensed as an auctioneer may designate not to exceed two (2) employees who may be authorized by him to conduct auctions. Notice containing the names of employees so designated shall be given to the city clerk, and an employee's license shall be issued on the payment of a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). This license shall be good for one (1) year, and it shall be unlawful for any person not licensed under this section to conduct an auction, or for any auctioneer to permit an auction to be conducted by an unlicensed employee. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-243, 15-244, 15-245, 15-246, 15-247; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 17; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-582. - Exception to division. 
Nothing in this division shall apply to any public auction or sale made or conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or process or by virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed. 
(Code 1980, § 15-249)  
Sec. 54-583. - Street auctions. 
No person shall sell or attempt to sell or offer for sale at public auction any goods, chattels or personal or real property of any kind upon the public streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 15-248)  
Secs. 54-584—54-610. - Reserved.

Sec. 54-611. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to do business as a coal dealer or maintain a coal yard without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).

DIVISION 4. - FIREARMS AND ASSAULT WEAPONS DEALERS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-641. - Title. 
This division shall be known as the "Calumet City Firearms and Assault Weapons Control Ordinance." 
(Code 1980, § 15-707; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-642. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meaning: 
Chief means the Chief of Police of the City of Calumet City. 
Department means the Police Department of the City of Calumet City. 
Engaged in the business has the same meaning as in 18 U.S.C. 921(a) (21). 
Firearm means any device, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile or projectiles by the action of an explosion; expansion of gas or escape of gas, excluding, however: 
(1)  Any pneumatic gun, spring gun, paint ball gun or B-B gun which either expels a single globular projectile not exceeding .18 inch in diameter or breakable paint balls containing washable marking colors; 
(2)  Any device used exclusively for signaling or safety; and required or recommended by the United States Coast Guard or the Interstate Commerce Commission; 
(3)  Any device used exclusively for the firing of stud cartridges, explosive rivets or similar industrial ammunition; or 
(4)  An antique firearm (other than an assault weapon), which, although designed as a weapon, the Department of State Police finds by reason of the date of its manufacture, value, design, or other characteristic is primarily a collector's item and is not likely to be used as a weapon. 
Firearm ammunition means any self-contained cartridge or shotgun shell, by whatever name known, which is designed to be used or adaptable to use in a firearm, excluding, however: 
(1)  Any ammunition exclusively designed for use with a device used exclusively for signaling or safety and required or recommended by the United States Coast Guard or the Interstate Commerce Commission; 
(2)  Any ammunition designed exclusively for use with a stud or rivet driver or other similar industrial ammunition. 
Firearms dealer means any federally licensed firearms dealer, excluding any person licensed solely as a "collector" pursuant to section 923(b) of Title 18 of the United States Code (U.S.C.) and possessing only a Type 03 license. 
Gun shop means the premises of any federally licensed firearms dealer where the only or primary business or commercial enterprise conducted on the premises is the purchase or sale of firearms or firearm ammunition. 
Mayor means the Mayor of Calumet City. 
Person means any individual, public or private corporation, partnership, firm, society, or unincorporated association. 
(Code 1980, § 15-709; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-643. - Penalties. 
Failure to comply with the provisions of this division shall result in a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day. Each day of operation in violation of section 54-671 of this division shall constitute a separate and distinct violation. 
(Code 1980, § 15-716; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-644. - Destruction of weapons confiscated. 
(a)  Whenever any firearm is surrendered or confiscated pursuant to the terms of this division, the chief of police shall ascertain whether such firearm is needed as evidence in any matter. 
(b)  If such firearm is not required for evidence, it shall be destroyed at the direction of the chief of police. A record of the date and method of destruction and inventory of the firearm so destroyed shall be maintained. 
(Code 1980, § 15-719; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-645. - Applicability. 
(a)  It is intended that this division shall preempt all county licensing or other regulatory schemes for firearms, firearms dealers and assault weapons. As provided in Article VII, Section 6(c) of the State of Illinois Constitution of 1970, if a county ordinance conflicts with an ordinance of a municipality, the municipal ordinance shall prevail within its jurisdiction. 
(b)  It is specifically intended that this division shall preempt the Cook County Firearms Dealer's License and Assault Weapons and Ammunition Ban Ordinance as now in effect or as may be hereafter amended. 
(c)  Licenses issued pursuant to this division shall be issued separate and apart from any general business license issued by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 15-708; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Secs. 54-646—54-670. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 54-671. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of dealing in firearms at an address within the corporate limits of the city without having applied for or obtained a city firearms dealer's license pursuant to this division within sixty (60) days of the adoption of this ordinance from which this division is derived. A city firearms dealer's license shall be required in addition to any other license required by law. All applicants for a city firearms dealer's license must possess a valid federal firearms dealer's license. Possession of a valid federal firearms dealer's license shall be deemed proof of being engaged in the business of dealing in firearms in the city and thus requiring a city firearms dealer's license. An applicant for a city firearms dealer's license shall meet all other applicable city ordinances and regulations. 
(b)  Any person who becomes a federally licensed firearms dealer after adoption of this division and is required under this division to obtain a city firearms dealer's license shall apply for such license within forty-five (45) days of receipt of the federal firearms dealer's license. 
(c)  Any person licensed under federal law at more than one (1) location within the city limits must obtain a city firearms dealer's license for each individual location. A separate application and license fee is required for each location. 
(d)  No license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable to any other person or any other location. 
(Code 1980, § 15-710; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-672. - Application; issuance. 
(a)  All applications for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the chief of police on a form provided for that purpose. In addition to any other information required by the chief, each application shall contain: 
(1)  The applicant's full name, residence, and the address and telephone number where the person is engaged in the business of dealing in firearms; 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation, the corporate name, business, and principal place of business of the applicant; the date and state of incorporation; and the names and residence addresses of the corporate officers and its registered agent; 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and business address and telephone number of the principal office or place of business; the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all partners; the name, address and telephone number of a person authorized to receive notices issued pursuant to this division. 
(b)  The chief shall not issue a city firearms dealer's license to any person who fails to provide proof of a valid federal firearms dealer's license and a valid firearm owner identification card issued by the state. 
(Code 1980, § 15-713; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-673. - Administration. 
(a)  The chief of the police department shall administer the licensing of firearms dealers and shall approve or deny the applications for licenses and revoke existing licenses pursuant to this article. 
(b)  (1)  The chief shall promulgate reasonable rules, definitions and regulations necessary to carry out the duties imposed by this division, including, but not limited to developing reasonable procedures consistent with existing practices of licensing persons engaged in the business of dealing in firearms and including seeking the assistance of the city police department or other law enforcement agencies as necessary to conduct investigations or inspections in connection with licensing. 
(2)  Any rules or regulations promulgated under this article shall be filed in the police department's principal office and in the office of the city clerk and shall be made available for public inspection. Copies shall be made available upon request and payment of a reasonable fee as determined by the department or the city clerk to cover the cost of providing the copy. 
(Code 1980, § 15-711; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-674. - Fee. 
The annual fee for a city firearms dealer's license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Code 1980, § 15-712; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-675. - Denial. 
(a)  The chief may deny any application for a license if the applicant fails to provide the information required by, or is otherwise not in compliance with, any provisions of this article or any applicable rules or regulations. Such denial shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for the denial. Any person seeking to appeal the denial may do so by filing a written request for a hearing with the mayor, with a copy to the chief. Such a request must be filed within thirty (30) days of the denial, and a hearing must be held within thirty (30) days of receipt of the request. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures provided herein. 
(b)  The chief may revoke or suspend the license of any person who violates any provision of this article or rules or regulations adopted pursuant to this article. Before any such revocation or suspension is effective, the licensee shall be notified by certified mail or personal delivery of the specific basis for the suspension or revocation and the date for a hearing on the matter. Such hearing shall occur not fewer than seven (7) days and not more than fourteen (14) days after the mailing of the notice. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures provided herein. 
(Code 1980, § 15-714; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-676. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  If a person wishes to appeal the denial of a city firearms dealer's license, or in the event of a revocation or suspension of a city firearms dealer's license, the mayor shall appoint a hearing officer who shall conduct the hearing. The hearing officer is authorized to conduct a hearing concerning any matter covered by this division and may determine factual and legal matters raised by the parties to the hearing. 
(b)  The hearing officer may: 
(1)  Examine any books, papers, records or memoranda bearing upon the business or activities of the licensee; 
(2)  Request the circuit court to issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of any person having personal knowledge of any contested issues; 
(3)  Request the circuit court to issue subpoenas duces tecum for the production of books, records, papers or memoranda; 
(4)  Administer oaths; 
(5)  Take testimony; 
(6)  Make rulings as to the admissibility of evidence; and 
(7)  Take any other action as may be required for the expeditious conduct of the hearing. 
(c)  The hearing officer is not bound by the technical rules of evidence. No informality in any proceeding or in the manner of taking testimony or receiving evidence shall invalidate any order, decision, ruling or recommendation of the hearing officer or final administrative decision of the mayor. 
(d)  The department's books, papers, records and memoranda or parts thereof may be proved in any hearing or legal proceeding by the original documents or by reproduced copy under the certificate of the chief. Without further proof, the original documents or reproduced copy shall be admissible into evidence at any hearing. 
(e)  If the circuit court issues a subpoena duces tecum , the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Service shall be made as provided by the Illinois Civil Practice Law, 735 ILCS 5/2-201, et seq.; 
(2)  Fees of witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees of witnesses before the circuit court of the county and shall be paid after the witness is excused from further attendance; 
(3)  When a subpoena or subpoena duces tecum is issued at the instance of either party, the hearing officer may require that party to bear the cost of service and witness fees. 
(f)  Any party to a hearing may apply to any judge of the circuit court of this state for enforcement of any subpoena or subpoena duces tecum issued by a hearing officer holding a hearing authorized by this article. 
(g)  At any hearing held under this article, the chief's initial decision to deny or revoke a license shall be presumed prima facie correct and the person contesting the decision shall have the burden of proving with books, records and other documentary or testimonial evidence that it is incorrect. 
(h)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a recommendation to the mayor. The mayor shall adopt, reject or modify the recommendation based on a review of the record within seven (7) days of receiving the hearing officer's recommendation and shall issue a final decision. The mayor shall give written notification to the licensee of the decision and the reasons for such decision. The mayor's decision shall be a final decision reviewable under Section 3-101 of the Illinois Administrative Review Law. 
(i)  A person seeking judicial review of the mayor's final decision shall bear the cost of certification. If the licensee or protesting party prevails on appeal, the city shall reimburse that party for the cost of certification. 
(j)  Items constituting the record may include notices and demands; the initial decision; the written protest and petition for hearing; all relevant pleadings, briefs and memoranda of law; evidence admitted at the hearing; the transcribed testimony given at the hearing; the recommendation of the hearing officer; and the final decision of the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 15-715; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Secs. 54-677—54-700. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Assault Weapons 
 
Sec. 54-701. - Defined. 
As used in this article, the following term shall have the following meaning: 
Assault weapon means any weapon which shoots, is designed to shoot, or can be readily restored to shoot, automatically, more than one (1) shot, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger. The term shall also include the frame or receiver of any such weapon, any part designed and intended for use in converting a weapon into a machine gun, any combination of parts from which a machine gun can be assembled if such parts are in the possession or under the control of a person. 
(Code 1980, § 15-717; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Sec. 54-702. - Assault weapons; sale prohibited, exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall sell, offer or display for sale, give, lend, transfer ownership of, acquire or possess, manufacture or distribute any assault weapon or within the city limits. This subsection shall not apply to: 
(1)  The sale, distribution, or the possession for sale and distribution by any firearms dealer licensed pursuant to this article, of an assault weapon to any officer, agent, or employee of the city or any other municipality, county, body politic or state or of the United States, members of the armed forces of the United States, or the organized militia of this or any other state, and peace officers to the extent that any such person is otherwise authorized to acquire or possess an assault weapon and is acting within the scope of his duties; 
(2)  Transportation of assault weapons if such weapons are broken down and in a nonfunctioning state and are not immediately accessible to any person. 
(b)  Any assault weapon possessed, sold or transferred in violation of subsection (a) of this section is hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized and disposed of in accordance with the provisions in section 54-644 of this article. 
(c)  Any person found in violation of this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  Any person who, prior to the effective date of this article, was legally in possession of an assault weapon prohibited by this section shall have fourteen (14) days from the effective date of this article to do any of the following without being subject to prosecution hereunder: 
(1)  To remove the assault weapon from within the city limits; 
(2)  To modify the assault weapon either to render it permanently inoperable or to permanently make it a device no longer defined as an assault weapon under this article; or 
(3)  To surrender the assault weapon to the chief of police or his designee for disposal as provided in section 54-644. 
(Code 1980, § 15-718; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 4-12-1995)  
Secs. 54-703—54-720. - Reserved.

(Code 1980, § 15-288)  
Secs. 54-784—54-810. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - SECONDHAND PERSONAL PROPERTY, GEMS AND PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-811. - Definitions. 
As used in this division the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
Secondhand dealer means a secondhand dealer is hereby defined to mean an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust association, or any other legal entity however organized engaged in or conducting business in the city for purchasing, trading, bartering, or exchanging secondhand personal property, gold, silver, and other precious metals. 
Engaged in or conducting business means the purchase, sale, barter, or exchange of any item aforesaid, including advertising therefore and including such business conducted by an established dealer in a permanent location. 
Secondhand goods means secondhand goods or used personal goods shall consist of any item of personal property or object of value such as gold, silver, jewelry, and/or other precious metals, which is not purchased or sold as new. Secondhand or used personal goods do not include property purchased by one (1) licensed, established merchant in the normal course of business from another licensed established merchant. Secondhand or used personal goods shall include but are not limited to the following items: 
(1)  Jewelry of any kind and/or any metal, precious or semiprecious in nature; 
(2)  Gold, silver, and/or other precious metals in whatever identifiable form except for numismatic coins or bullions; 
(3)  Any type of gem or precious stone, including diamonds; 
(4)  Office supplies; 
(5)  Furniture fixtures; 
(6)  Electronic equipment such as televisions, radios, and stereos; 
(7)  Appliances. 
Precious metals means any item containing as part of its composition in any degree, gold, silver, platinum or pewter. 
Gems means any item containing or having any precious or semi-precious stones customarily used in jewelry or ornamentation. 
Exclusions means the provisions of this division do not apply to the following businesses or dealers: 
(1)  Junk; 
(2)  Used motor vehicles; 
(3)  Antique dealers which for purpose of this exclusion shall be read to be defined as any dealer who engages exclusively in the business or occupation of selling, bartering, or exchanging any painting, furniture, china, or other object painted or made more than fifty (50) years prior to the date of sale, which is valuable primarily by reasons of age, scarcity or the skill and craftsmanship of the article and artisan. Antiques will not include family heirlooms made of gold and silver or other precious metals; 
(4)  Coin collectors or coin shops which engage exclusively in the coin business or occupation. Further, that this exclusion does not exempt such dealers or businesses from compliance with the regulations as hereinafter provided in relation to any gold, silver, platinum or other precious metal or jewelry which they may purchase, trade, barter, or exchange in addition to their coin and bullion operations; 
(5)  Flea market; 
(6)  Neighborhood garage sales; 
(7)  Nonprofit or charitable secondhand goods or thrift type shops. 
(Code 1980, § 15-301; Ord. No. 86-9, § 1, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-812. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any violation of this division shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1980, § 15-307; Ord. No. 86-9, § 7, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-813. - Purchasing from minors. 
No secondhand dealer shall purchase, trade or deal in secondhand articles with a minor (an individual under the age of eighteen (18) years of age; or receive any goods or articles from any minors, to wit: seventeen (17) years old on down). 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-814. - Records of transactions required. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall keep a record, which record system guidelines shall be established in conjunction with the chief of police of the city for the purpose of promoting uniformity and accessibility to the police department with minimum inconvenience to both the dealer and the department. However, under no circumstances will a looseleaf system be considered to be a proper medium of recordkeeping. 
(b)  The record of all transactions shall be written in the English language and in a clear, legible manner. 
(c)  The record maintained by the secondhand dealer shall be made at the time of the transaction and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  Name, age, sex, general description of the individual with whom the transaction is had, as well as the individual's residence and his signature on the receipt and permanent record kept by the dealer; 
(2)  Confirmation of identification, by also securing a driver's license number along with the state of issuance of such license, military identification card number and the account number of a major credit card account, if used for purchase. This number shall be recorded along with the information hereinabove designated. 
(3)  The price or consideration paid or received at the time of the transaction. 
(4)  A description of every article (except as to the sale of goods by him of newspapers, magazines, or other wastepaper, rags, and clothing) received, purchased, sold, or exchanged by the dealer giving the manufacturer's name and other marks of identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to, the serial number, of any, on the article. 
(5)  If the property is delivered by motor vehicle, the license number of the delivering vehicle and the issuing state of said license shall be recorded along with all other identification requirements enumerated hereinabove; 
(6)  All entries in the record shall be signed by the person making the entry; 
(7)  Such records shall be retained for a period of one (1) year from the date of the transaction. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-815. - Report to the chief of police or his designated agent. 
It shall be the duty of every secondhand dealer to make out and make available for the inspection of the chief of police or his designated agent before the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon, each and every business day, a copy of the records required to be kept under the terms of this division, reflecting the completed transactions of the previous day. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-816. - Record inspection. 
The record book, the goods, articles or things purchased, received or kept for sale or exchange, by every secondhand dealer, shall be open to inspection of any member of the police department at all reasonable business times, or any person duly authorized in writing for such purpose by the chief of police. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-817. - Goods to be kept without concealment for seven business/working days. 
Every dealer in secondhand goods must keep without concealment for a period of seven (7) working/business days, subject to the inspection by any police officer, all goods, wares and merchandise, purchased or received from any person, before selling, shipping or otherwise disposing of the same. 
Proviso: Any goods, wares, or merchandise purchased or received from any person may be sold, shipped, or otherwise disposed of prior to the expiration of the seven (7) working/business day holding period if the goods, wares, or merchandise have been sooner inspected by the chief of police or his designated agent and received written clearance for such further disposition. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-818. - Melting, wrecking and remodeling. 
No secondhand dealer shall melt any watch, watchcase, jewelry or other identifiable article composed or manufactured in whole or in part of gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals until such dealer shall have made a record of his intention to do so along with all other data required to be recorded by the specific recordation provisions of this section and shall have reported the same to the chief of police or his designated agents within the burglary and theft division and unless and until he shall have kept such article intact in his licensed place of business, for inspection for seven (7) working/business days after the report provided for in this division has been made available to the chief of police or his designated agent; unless the identifiable article proposed to be melted down, wrecked or remodeled has been sooner inspected by the chief of police or his designated agent and received written clearance for such melting, wrecking or remodeling from same. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-819. - Coin dealers, coin collection swap meets and conventions. 
(a)  Coin collectors and coin dealers shall not be subject to the extensive record keeping and goods retention requirements for secondhand goods or used personal property dealers to the extent of their actual dealings in coins. However, if any such coin establishment also purchases, trades, barters or exchanges any other type of secondhand personal property including gold, silver and/or other precious metals or jewelry in conjunction with its coin dealership, such establishment shall be subjected to the extensive record keeping, licensing and goods retention requirements as established in this division, as far as these other items of gold, silver and/or precious metals or jewelry are concerned. 
(b)  Coin collectors and coin dealers although not subject to the record keeping, licensing requirements, and goods retention provisions of this division as relates to their coin dealings, nonetheless will be required to meet the conditions set forth in subsection (c) of this section as they relate to their coin business. 
(c)  Registration. 
(1)  All coin dealers and/or collectors who conduct a coin business and conduct no other precious metal business shall be required to register with the city clerk. 
(2)  All coin swap meets and conventions shall be required to register with the city clerk no later than three (3) days before the scheduled date of the swap meet. The sponsor or sponsors of such a swap meet shall be required to submit the following information at the time of registration: 
a.  The type of swap meet to be conducted; 
b.  The location of the swap meet or convention; 
c.  The time and date of the swap meet or convention and its expected duration; 
d.  The approximate number of participants. 
(Code 1980, § 15-306; Ord. No. 86-9, § 6, 3-27-1986)  
Secs. 54-820—54-840. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 54-841. - License—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association, or other legal entity to engage in the business of secondhand goods or used personal property, gold, silver and/or other precious metals dealer as defined in this division, without first obtaining a license therefor, as hereinafter provided. A separate license shall be required for each location, place or premises used for the conduct of the business of the secondhand dealer. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-842. - Same—Application. 
Applicants for a license under this division, whether a person, firm, corporation, or other legal entity, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners, if a partnership, by all members of the joint venture or association, and by the president of a corporation with the city clerk, showing: 
(1)  The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business; 
(2)  The local address or addresses of such person while engaged in the business; 
(3)  The permanent address or addresses of such persons; 
(4)  The capacity in which such person or persons will act, that is, whether as proprietor, agent, or otherwise; 
(5)  If a corporation, other than an Illinois corporation, the laws of the state that the same is incorporated under; 
(6)  The place or places in the city where it is proposed that the applicant's business will be conducted; 
(7)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; 
(8)  Credentials from the person, firm or corporation, for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; 
(9)  Whether or not the person or persons having management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishments assessed therefore; 
(10)  The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where applicant, within the six (6) months prior to this current application, conducted a previous business in secondhand or used personal goods, stating the nature thereof and giving the street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-843. - Same—Fee. 
The annual license fee is to be paid to the city in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-844. - Place of business; license restrictions. 
Any license issued under the provisions of this division shall designate the place in which the secondhand dealer shall carry on such business; and such business shall not be carried on or conducted in any other place than that designated in or by such license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-845. - Location change during unexpired term of license. 
In the event that a secondhand dealer should move either his main or satellite licensed dealership from the existing location to a new location before the expiration of his current license, he shall be permitted to secure a transfer license at a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per unexpired license to be valid until his existing license should expire. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-846. - Exhibition of license; additional licenses. 
The license issued under this division shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one (1) place within the city, separate licenses shall be issued for each place of business, and shall be conspicuously in each place of business. A separate five hundred dollars ($500.00) fee will be charged for each additional license issued. A separate license application will be needed for each additional place of business. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-847. - License not transferable. 
The privilege extended by the above described license is a personal privilege and shall not be transferable to another individual or entity, nor shall there be any abatement of the fee for such license by reason of the fact that the license holder shall have exercised the privilege for any period less than it was granted. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-848. - Appeal from denial of license. 
(a)  An appeal from the city clerk or mayor's decision to deny application for a license shall be made to the mayor or the city clerk in writing, within seven (7) days of the receipt of the decision. 
(b)  The appeal shall state the specific grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  The applicant will be granted the opportunity to present his evidence at the council hearing to show why the mayor or the city clerk's decision should not be sustained. 
(Code 1980, § 15-305; Ord. No. 86-9, § 5, 3-27-1986)  
Sec. 54-849. - Suspension and revocation of license. 
Upon conviction for a violation of any of the provisions of this division, the license granted under the provisions of this division shall be suspended for a period not less than thirty (30) days in duration at the end of which the individual must secure a clearance from the city clerk verifying the expiration of the suspension period. 
Upon a second conviction for a violation of any provisions of this division within the license period under which the previous suspension occurred, the license granted under the provisions of this division shall be revoked for a period no less than one (1) year in duration at the end of which the individual may submit a reapplication for another license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-302; Ord. No. 86-9, § 2, 3-27-1986)  
Secs. 54-850—54-880. - Reserved.

Sec. 54-882. - Private schools, day care centers, and child care centers to be licensed or registered. 
(a)  All private schools, day care centers, or child care centers shall be licensed and/or registered by the appropriate state agency. The owners, operators, and/or financial officers for each of the aforementioned businesses shall apply to and follow all proper procedures with the appropriate state agency, in order to procure said license and/or registration. 
(b)  All parties applying to the Illinois State Board of Education for registration must provide proof to the city of said application and of said approval or denial before any license or occupancy permit will be issued. All parties regulated under this ordinance must also provide the city with its mission statement and/or purpose and must comply with all other applicable regulations or statutes, ordinances or other rules as passed by the general assembly and/or the city council. 
(c)  Should the party applying for said license or registration not be granted favorable status by the applicable agency, no occupancy permit shall be issued. 
(d)  All private schools, day care centers, or child care centers shall be subject to an occupancy inspection. The property must comply with all applicable laws and codes adopted by the City of Calumet City and other appropriate governmental agencies. Following the initial inspection, the city reserves the right to conduct annual inspections, suspicion based inspections, and random inspections to ensure compliance with the applicable codes, regulations and laws. 
(e)  Any violation of this ordinance may result in a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per offense. Each day shall be considered a new offense. Any violations will be heard by the Calumet City licensing authority. Violations may also result in further remedies up to and including revocation of any municipal licenses or permits issued to that facility. In the event that a facility's license is revoked or otherwise suspended, terminated, or removed, the facility's owners, operators, share-holders, managers, assistant managers, and any other party managing the facility either implicitly or outright shall not be allowed to operate a like facility in the City of Calumet City. 
(Ord. No. 06-51, §§ 1—5, 6-29-2006; Ord. No. 06-78, §§ 1—5, 9-25-2006)  
Secs. 54-883—54-920. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ANIMAL HOSPITALS 
 
Sec. 54-921. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate any hospital for the treatment of small animals without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-323, 15-324; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 45; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-922. - Sanitation. 
Every place used, maintained or operated as a small animal hospital shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain thereon for more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Code 1980, § 15-325)  
Sec. 54-923. - Attendant. 
There shall be a competent attendant on the premises used for a small animal hospital at all times. 
(Code 1980, § 15-326)  
Sec. 54-924. - Treatment of animals. 
All animals which are harbored in a small animal hospital shall be treated in a humane manner. 
(Code 1980, § 15-327)  
Secs. 54-925—54-950. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AUTOMATIC DRY CLEANING MACHINES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1; fire prevention power of city generally, Ch. 24, § 11-8-4. 
 
Sec. 54-951. - Defined. 
An automatic dry cleaning machine, as the term is used in this division, shall be construed to include and mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by any but the owner, or an employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or contains perchloroethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. 
(Code 1980, § 15-336)  
Sec. 54-952. - Compliance with division and state law required. 
It shall be unlawful to install, operate or maintain any automatic dry cleaning machine except in compliance with the provisions of this division, or without complying with all of the provisions pertaining to the installation and operation of such machine herein contained, or in violation of any laws, rules or regulations of the Illinois Department of Public Health relating thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 15-340)  
Sec. 54-953. - Permit. 
It shall be unlawful to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without having secured a permit. Applications for such permit shall contain full information as to the mechanical equipment of such machine and provisions for ventilation for both the machine and the room in which the machine will be located. The fee for such permit shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for each unit or machine. 
(Code 1980, § 15-337)  
Sec. 54-954. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of maintaining an automatic dry cleaning machine for use by the public without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be ninety dollars ($90.00) plus fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each unit in addition to five (5) maintained in any one (1) establishment. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-338, 15-339; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-955. - Installation regulations. 
(a)  Each automatic dry cleaning machine shall be completely enclosed by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and the outlet at or near the bottom of such machine. Groups of machines may be entirely enclosed or supported on all open sides by an enclosure topped with a hood vented as provided for each individual machine. 
(b)  The exhaust system shall maintain a minimum flow of one hundred (100) cubic feet per minute face velocity through the loading door whenever the door is open. 
(c)  The discharge stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines are located shall extend at least two (2) feet above the level of any window which can be opened located within fifty (50) feet away from any fresh air intake leading to any premises. 
(d)  The machines must be so constructed as to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be equipped with a transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the cleaning cycle. 
(e)  Any connection of such machine with the water supply system must be equipped with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the condenser, with no control valves downstream from such gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap. 
(f)  The room in which such machine is installed shall be ventilated so that there shall be a minimum flow of air per machine from the area to which the public is admitted, of at least five hundred (500) cubic feet per machine per minute in a room where there are no more than three (3) machines installed; four hundred (400) cubic feet per minute where there are no more than eight (8) machines installed; three hundred seventy-five (375) cubic feet per minute where there are no more than sixteen (16) machines installed; and three hundred sixty (360) cubic feet per minute where there are more than seventeen (17) machines installed. For this purpose each cleaning cell shall be considered as one (1) machine. 
(g)  Each machine must be so designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage of liquids, gas or vapors. 
(Code 1980, § 15-341)  
Sec. 54-956. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  No automatic dry cleaning machine shall be operated unless all the equipment described in section 54-955 is properly installed and in good operating condition. 
(b)  No establishment for which a license is required under this division shall be open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the public or customers into the room where such machines are located unless there is on duty in the establishment at all times a competent person in charge of the establishment, and in charge of the operation of such machines. There shall be warning signs posted in places of easy observation warning of the dangers in the event leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to permit any residue containing solvent to flow into the sewer system of the city; tightly covered metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the contents and dangers involved in handling, and shall be locked if in an unenclosed place. 
(d)  At least one (1) legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the establishment, and of the service department or agency responsible for the proper maintenance of the machines. 
(Code 1980, § 15-342)  
Sec. 54-957. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the mayor to cause such inspections to be made as are necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-343)  
Secs. 54-958—54-980. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BARBERSHOPS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate barbers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 
 
Sec. 54-981. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a barbershop in the city without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the license required by this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and shall state thereon the number of chairs to be used in the establishment. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) per chair; no such license shall be issued except upon payment of the fee. 
(d)  Revocation. In addition to any penalty provided by law, any barbershop violating any of the provisions of this division, or any other applicable ordinance shall be subject to having the license revoked. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-351, 15-352, 15-353, 15-354; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-982. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the health commissioner or some other person designated by the mayor and council to inspect every establishment licensed under this division as often as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division and all other ordinances relative thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 15-357)  
Sec. 54-983. - Sanitation. 
Premises used for a barbershop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it shall be unlawful to permit waste material of any kind to accumulate therein. It shall be unlawful to employ therein any person afflicted with a venereal or contagious disease. 
(Code 1980, § 15-355)  
Sec. 54-984. - Implements. 
It shall be unlawful to use in any establishment used as a barbershop any implements or tools upon any person after the same have been used upon a person afflicted with any skin or scalp disease without first sterilizing such implement or tool. It shall be unlawful to use any towel on any customer after the same has been used before without having such towel sterilized and cleaned prior to such second usage. 
(Code 1980, § 15-356)  
Secs. 54-985—54-1010. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - RESERVED[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) ---

Secs. 54-1011—54-1070. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINES  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-1071. - Penalty. 
The violation of section 54-1072 shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more five hundred dollars ($500.00); and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. A second or subsequent violation of section 54-1072 may subject a licensee to a suspension or revocation of the machine license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-377)  
Sec. 54-1072. - Sales of tobacco to minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any cigarette vending machine licensee or any officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for sell, buy for, give away, furnish or deliver tobacco products to persons under the age of eighteen (18) years. Unlawful acts constituting a violation of this provision by an officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act had been done by the licensee personally. 
(Code 1980, § 15-376; Ord. No. 96-47, § 1, 7-25-1996)  
Secs. 54-1073—54-1090. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Licenses 
 
Sec. 54-1091. - Distributor's license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to distribute cigarette vending machines for use on premises not owned or operated by the distributor without a license. 
(b)  The annual fee for the license required by this section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1980, § 15-374)  
Sec. 54-1092. - Machine license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate, maintain or expose for use any cigarette vending machine without a license. 
(b)  The annual fee for the retail sale of cigarettes from vending machines shall be one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) for each such machine. 
(Code 1980, § 15-375; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1093. - Suspension; revocation of license; hearing. 
The mayor shall be charged with the administration of this division. The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provision of this division, if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this division. However, no such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the mayor with a seven (7) day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven (7) day notice provisions shall begin the day following delivery by certified mail or by personal service. 
The mayor shall within seven (7) days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and state either the amount of the fine, the period of suspension or the revocation of the license and serve a copy of such order within the seven (7) days upon the licensee. 
Any licensee determined by the mayor to have violated any of the provisions of this division shall pay to the city the costs of the hearing before the mayor on such violation. The mayor shall determine the costs incurred by the city for said hearing, including, but not limited to: court reporters' fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the city or such less sum as the mayor may allow. 
The licensee shall pay said costs to the city within thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the mayor. Failure to pay said costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this division and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of a fine. 
(Code 1980, § 15-378; Ord. No. 96-47, § 1, 7-25-1996)  
Sec. 54-1094. - Use of premises after revocation. 
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to said licensee for the period of six (6) months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling tobacco products in the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-379; Ord. No. 96-47, § 1, 7-25-1996)  
Secs. 54-1095—54-1140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - DAY CARE HOMES  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 54-1141. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this division, the following terms are defined to mean: 
Certificate of compliance shall mean a certificate issued by the city evidencing that a day care home has been found to be in compliance with all applicable health and safety regulations of the city, including but not limited to the requirements of this division. 
Certified in food service sanitation shall mean a person who has completed the requirements of Subpart J: of Title 77: Public Health, Chapter I; Department of Public Health, Subchapter m: Food, Drugs and Cosmetics, Part 750 Food Service Sanitation Code. 
Day care home means a family home which receives more than three (3) or a maximum of twelve (12) children for less than twenty-four (24) hours per day. The age distribution shall be governed by those guidelines of Part 406 of the State of Illinois licensing standards. The maximum of twelve (12) children includes the family's natural, foster or adopted children and all other persons under the age of twelve (12). The term does not include facilities which receive only children from a single household. 
Department means the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. 
D.I.S. means the Calumet City Department of Inspectional Services. 
Operator means an individual or individuals operating a day care home from the family residence. 
Part 406 shall mean Title 89: Social Services, Chapter III: Department of Children and Family Services, Subchapter e: Requirements of Licensure, Part 406, Licensing Standards for Day Care Homes. 
(Code 1980, § 15-663; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997)  
Secs. 54-1142—54-1170. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Certificate of Compliance 
 
Sec. 54-1171. - Required; transferability. 
(a)  No person shall operate a day care home within the city unless the operator obtains an annual certificate of compliance by the city department of inspectional services. 
(b)  The certificate of compliance shall not be transferable to any other person or any other premises by any means. 
(Code 1980, § 15-663.1; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997)  
Sec. 54-1172. - Minimum standards; requirements. 
No certificate of compliance shall be issued to a day care home unless the operator complies with the following regulations, restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  Day care homes may be operated only in R-1 zones. 
(2)  Each day care home shall comply with all building, zoning, fire and other health and safety regulations of the city as they may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  No day care home may operate unless the operator possesses a valid day care home license issued by the department. 
(4)  No day care home may operate in violation of any regulation of the department or those additional regulations set forth in this division. 
(5)  Each day care home shall be subject to at least twice yearly inspections by the city to determine compliance with the provisions of this division, and the operator shall cooperate with authorized inspecting agents of the city. 
(6)  Each operator shall make available at all times to the D.I.S. a list indicating the names, addresses and phone numbers of all children being cared for in the day care home. 
(7)  Each operator shall annually furnish to the city evidence that the operator and all employees have submitted to at least fifteen (15) hours annually of training in child care, in addition to current certification in first aid.
