Each operator and employee shall annually submit evidence of current certification in adult, child and infant CPR and emergency care for choking. These certificates shall be issued by the American Red Cross or the American Heart Association. It is the responsibility of each person to keep his certification in a continuously valid status. 
(8)  Each operator shall maintain a working and easily accessible telephone at all times. Affixed to or immediately adjacent to each phone shall be the emergency phone numbers for police, fire and EMS in addition to the street address and phone number of the day care home. 
(9)  The operator of each day care home shall provide a safe means of ingress and egress for children being transported to or from a day care home. In particular, an off-street drop-off/pickup area must be provided if a day care home is located on an arterial street, including but not limited to Wentworth Avenue, Burnham Avenue, Michigan City Road, Pulaski Road (154th St.), Sibley Boulevard, Memorial Drive (152nd St.), and State Street or any other location deemed necessary by the D.I.S. 
(10)  The operator shall maintain a day care home at a temperature no lower than sixty-eight (68) nor greater than eighty (80) degrees Fahrenheit during those times when the home is operating as a day care home. 
(11)  The operator shall immediately notify the city clerk and the D.I.S. by phone and within three (3) days in writing, after the operator's receipt of any action or complaints received from the department. 
(12)  Operations of a day care home shall fulfill all the requirements set forth by the department in accordance with Part 406 with the following amendments. These amendments shall supersede those of Part 406. 
Section 406.8(a)(2). Additional ABC fire extinguishers shall be located within ten (10) feet of each primary exit and at least one (1) on each level of the day care home. 
Section 406.8(a)(3). Extension cords shall not be permitted. All cords shall be arranged to have the minimum amount of cord exposed. All outlets on or below grade level, in the areas accessible to those children in the day care home, shall be ground fault circuit interrupter protected except where specifically excused by the National Electric Code. 
Section 406.8(a)(4)(A). All smoke detectors shall be of the a/c type with battery back-up. They shall be hard wired, interconnected and maintained in a continuously functional status. 
Section 406.8(a)(4)(B). Carbon monoxide (CO) detectors of the a/c type shall be located on each level and maintained in a continuously functional status. 
Section 406.8(a)(5), (6). Fireplaces, woodburning stoves or space heaters shall not be permitted to be in use while the premises is functioning as a day care home. 
Section 406.8(a)(15). The operator of the home shall notify the parent(s) or guardian of any child accepted for care that firearms and ammunition are stored on the premises. This notification shall require written confirmation of receipt by the parents/guardian. This written receipt shall be available for inspection by an agent of the city. 
Section 406.8(a)(16). At least one (1) drill every six (6) months shall be monitored by the fire department. 
Section 406.8(a)(20). Each swimming pool or spa shall also contain a functional entry alarm at all times it is not in use. 
Section 406.8(b)(1). The operator shall be certified in food service sanitation and must maintain this certification in a current status. 
Section 406.8(b)(2). The premises shall be inspected regularly by the health commissioner or his designee for compliance with the applicable portions of the Food Service Sanitation Code. 
Section 406.8(g)(1). This certification shall be done annually with copies of the certifications forwarded to the D.I.S. 
Section 406.8(g)(2). Uncertified animals shall not be permitted on the premises. 
Section 406.8(g)(4). All animal bites or scratches shall be reported to the city police department's animal control division. 
Section 406.8(g)(5). Cat litter boxes shall not be permitted in areas of child care activities, food preparation or serving areas and shall be arranged so as they are inaccessible to infants and toddlers. 
Section 406.8(g)(6). Reptiles shall not be permitted in the premises at any time. 
Section 406.8(j). Yards shall be completely fenced and gated. Gates shall be secured by means as to prevent the opening of them by toddlers and small children. Play spaces shall be protected by physical means and adult supervision. 
Section 406.8(k). Operations of other business on the premises shall not be allowed at any time that the premises is functioning as a day care home. 
Section 406.17(g). Tap water used for drinking and food preparation shall be tested by a commercial lab for the presence of lead. Copies of the test reports shall be submitted to the D.I.S. If lead is found to be present in the water, bottled water shall be used for drinking and food preparation. 
Section 406.24(m). The city clerk and the D.I.S. shall also be notified within the same time frame should any of these events occur. 
Section 406.24(o). The fire department and the D.I.S. shall also be notified within the same time frame should any of these events occur. 
(Code 1980, § 15-664; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997)  
Sec. 54-1173. - Application for certificate of compliance; requirements. 
(a)  Each applicant for a certificate of compliance to operate a day care home in the city shall complete an application form provided and furnished by the city, which form shall require the operator to furnish the following: 
(1)  Name, address and phone number of the operator. Post office box numbers are not acceptable. 
(2)  Name, address and phone numbers of all employees over the age of sixteen (16) involved in the operation of the day care home. 
(3)  A notarized copy of the operator's current valid day care home license issued by the department. 
(4)  Whether the operator or any employee has been, or is currently subject to any proceeding involving the suspension or revocation of the license issued by the department. 
(5)  The operator and all employees shall be fingerprinted by the city police department, and shall pay the city an additional amount as may be required by the State of Illinois and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to process such fingerprints. By making application for a certificate of compliance, the operator and employees authorize the city to forward the results of the fingerprint identification to the department. A certificate of compliance shall not be issued until the result of fingerprint checks are complete. 
(6)  Such other information relating to the terms and provisions of this division. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a completed application and the fee as provided in section 54-1174, the department of inspectional services and the health commissioner or his designee shall inspect the premises of the day care home for purposes of determining compliance with this division. Upon such determination, a certificate of compliance shall be issued and the operator shall be authorized to operate a day care home within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 15-665; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997)  
Sec. 54-1174. - Certificate of compliance fee; license year. 
Each applicant for a certificate of compliance to operate a day care home shall pay an annual fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to the city at the time of making application for such certificate of compliance. The certificate shall be issued on the May 1 fiscal year basis. Applications for an initial certificate made after December 1 shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). There shall be no proration of any fee in the event a day care home discontinues operation during the course of any license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-666; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1175. - Existing day care homes. 
Any day care home licensed by the department which is operating as of the effective date of this division shall have thirty (30) days after passage in which to make application to the city for a certificate of compliance and ninety (90) days in which to comply with all requirements of this division. No punitive action will be taken by the city against such facility during the pendency of the city's review in the event of a timely application. 
(Code 1980, § 15-667; Ord. No. 97-64, § 1, 10-28-1997)  
Secs. 54-1176—54-1200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - DRY CLEANING PLANTS 
 
Sec. 54-1201. - Permit fee. 
The annual fee for the permit required by the Fire Prevention Code to operate a dry cleaning plant shall be two hundred forty dollars ($240.00). 
(Code 1980, § 15-384; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 28; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Secs. 54-1202—54-1240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - EXPRESSMEN AND DRAYMEN[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate expressmen, draymen, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-6. 
 
Sec. 54-1241. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct the business of drayman, carter, trucker or expressman without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the license required by this division shall be made to the city clerk, and shall designate thereon the name of the licensee, the location of his business, and the number of vehicles intended to be used by him. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each vehicle used for such business. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-391, 15-392, 15-393; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 29; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1242. - Stolen property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person required to have a license by the provisions of this division to receive, move or conceal any goods or articles which he knows or has reason to suspect has been stolen. 
(Code 1980, § 15-394)  
Sec. 54-1243. - Vehicles. 
Every vehicle used for the business licensed by this division shall have printed thereon on a place easily visible from the side of the vehicle the name and address of the owner in letters legible to one of normal eyesight at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet. 
(Code 1980, § 15-395)  
Secs. 54-1244—54-1270. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Fire prevention powers of city, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-4. 
 
Sec. 54-1271. - Defined. 
A service station is any place of business where gasoline, or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal-combustion engines, are sold or offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into fuel tanks of such motor vehicles. It shall include also the private storage and dispensing of such products for the same purpose as those served by a service station, whether the storage is maintained for the use or benefit of the owner, lessee, agents or employees of either, or of any others. 
(Code 1980, § 15-406)  
Sec. 54-1272. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct a gasoline service station without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00). 
(c)  Locations and equipment compliance. No gasoline service station license shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with all ordinances. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-403, 15-404, 15-405; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 21; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1273. - Nonbusiness stations. 
Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles for the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person shall comply with all of the provisions of this division other than the requirement for the payment of a license fee. 
(Code 1980, § 15-407)  
Sec. 54-1274. - Bulk sales prohibited. 
No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion system of such vehicles; provided however, that individual sales up to five (5) gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the Gasoline Lotter Act (430 ILCS 20/0.01 et seq.), such individual sales to be limited to five (5) gallons to any one (1) person. 
(Code 1980, § 15-408)  
Secs. 54-1275—54-1320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - HANDBILL AND SAMPLE DISTRIBUTORS 
 
Sec. 54-1321. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to distribute indiscriminately to the public, by leaving at stores, offices, houses or residences in the city, any cards, circulars, samples of merchandise, handbills or any advertising matter whatsoever without having first secured a permit; provided that this section shall not be construed to apply to the sale of articles by licensed solicitors. 
(b)  Application. All applications for the permit required by this division shall be made to the city clerk and shall contain a statement of the nature of the article, cards or advertisement to be distributed and the name of the applicant and the name of the manufacturer or distributor of such article or service advertised. 
(c)  Investigation of applicant. No such permit shall be issued to any but a person of good character. The chief of police shall make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant and shall report the results thereof to the clerk before any such permit is issued. 
(d)  Fee. The fee for the permit required by this division shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per day. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-434, 15-435, 15-436; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 32; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1322. - Indiscriminate distribution prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute indiscriminately to the public any cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise or any advertisement or advertising matter whatsoever on any public street or sidewalk or other public place in the city; provided that this section shall not be construed to prohibit the peddling or sale of any article or publication that may carry or be accompanied by advertising matter where a charge is made or a price is paid for such article or publication. 
(Code 1980, § 15-437)  
Secs. 54-1323—54-1350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 12. - HOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES 
 
Sec. 54-1351. - License. 
(a)  Required for hotels. It shall be unlawful to operate a hotel or a building or part thereof used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for twenty (20) or more persons for a period of one (1) day or more without a license. 
(b)  Required for roominghouses. It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a rooming house or building, apartment or portion of a building, in which any person or persons not related to the owner or occupant of such premises by blood or marriage are furnished sleeping accommodations for hire without a license. 
(c)  Fees: 
(1)  Hotels. The annual fee for a hotel license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first unit and thirty dollars ($30.00) for each additional unit. 
(2)  Rooming houses. The fee for a rooming house license shall be one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-444, 15-445; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 33; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1352. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect every hotel or rooming house operated in the city as frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-451)  
Sec. 54-1353. - Premises condition. 
All premises used for hotel or rooming house purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and all portions of such premises and hotels that are open for use by all guests or by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are so open to use. All such premises shall be kept heated between October first and May first to a temperature of not less than sixty-eight (68) degrees between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and to a temperature of not less than fifty-five (55) degrees at all other hours. 
(Code 1980, § 15-446)  
Sec. 54-1354. - Exits. 
(a)  No building shall be used for a hotel unless it is furnished with the number of exits and fire escapes required by the building ordinances of the city for the construction of a new hotel. 
(b)  No premises shall be used for a roominghouse unless there are at least two (2) exits to the outdoors from such premises. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any exit from any premises used for a hotel or roominghouse. 
(Code 1980, § 15-447)  
Sec. 54-1355. - Sanitary facilities. 
Water closets and lavatories shall be available to all guests using any hotel or rooming house and there shall be at least one (1) bathroom equipped with water closet, shower or tub, and lavatory facilities for each ten (10) residents on the premises. 
(Code 1980, § 15-448)  
Sec. 54-1356. - Guest register. 
Each hotel proprietor, and each operator therein, shall keep or cause to be kept a register of guests as required by state law. Such register or list shall be available for inspection by any member of the police department at any time. 
(Code 1980, § 15-449)  
Sec. 54-1357. - Harboring fugitives. 
It shall be unlawful to permit knowingly any fugitive from justice to stay in any roominghouse or hotel. 
(Code 1980, § 15-450)  
Secs. 54-1358—54-1390. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - JUNK DEALERS[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license, tax and regulate junk stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 
 
Sec. 54-1391. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store or place for the purchase or sale of junk rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or empty bottles, without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the license required by this division shall be made in conformance with the provisions of this Code relating to licenses. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-461, 15-462, 15-463; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 35; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1392. - Premises. 
Any premises, area or piece or parcel of land licensed and used as a junkyard shall have not more than two (2) entrances and two (2) exits each of which shall not exceed fifteen (15) feet in width at the perimeter of the premises. Such premises, areas, pieces or parcels of land shall be enclosed with either a solid nontransparent wall or fence or line-weave steel wire or combination thereof with a minimum height of seven (7) feet from the ground level excepting for entrances and exits. The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind excepting one (1) sign of the licensee not exceeding one hundred (100) square feet in size. 
(Code 1980, § 15-464)  
Sec. 54-1393. - Stolen goods. 
Every keeper of a junk shop who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination. 
(Code 1980, § 15-465)  
Sec. 54-1394. - Vehicles. 
Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 15-466)  
Secs. 54-1395—54-1420. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 14. - KENNELS AND PET SHOPS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 10. 
 
Sec. 54-1421. - Defined. 
As used in this division, the term "kennel," "pet shop" or "small animal store" shall be construed to include any establishment for the raising, training, boarding or selling of dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or other small animals for hire or profit, or where more than three (3) dogs or cats are harbored or kept. 
(Code 1980, § 15-475)  
Sec. 54-1422. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate a kennel, pet shop or small animal store anywhere in the city without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-476, 15-477; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 36; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1423. - Sanitation. 
Every place used as a kennel, pet shop or small animal store shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain thereon for more than twenty-four (24) hours. All animals shall be humanely treated, and any animal having any disease shall be properly isolated and treated. 
(Code 1980, § 15-478)  
Secs. 54-1424—54-1440. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 15. - LAUNDRIES AND LAUNDROMATS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 
 
Sec. 54-1441. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall operate or conduct a laundry, including a self-service laundry, in the city without a license; provided that establishments licensed as dry cleaning establishments need not obtain a laundry license in addition to a dry cleaning license. 
(b)  Application. All applications for the license required by the provisions of this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state thereon the location of the premises intended to be occupied. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for laundry licenses shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and no license shall be issued except upon the payment of the fee. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-486, 15-487, 15-488; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 37; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1442. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other official designated by the mayor and council to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this division at least once every six (6) months. Any violation under the terms of this division, which are discovered, shall be reported to the mayor and council. 
(Code 1980, § 15-490)  
Sec. 54-1443. - Sanitation. 
Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No refuse of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate on such premises, and the premises must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin. It shall be unlawful to employ any person with a venereal or contagious disease in a laundry. 
(Code 1980, § 15-489)  
Secs. 54-1444—54-1470. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 16. - MACHINE SHOPS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate machine shops, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 
 
Sec. 54-1471. - Defined. 
The term "machine shop" as used in this division shall be construed to include every workshop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws, or other metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery. 
(Code 1980, § 15-501)  
Sec. 54-1472. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall conduct, operate or manage a machine shop in the city without a license; provided, that this section shall not be construed as requiring an additional license for any class of machine specifically licensed under any other provision of this Code. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-502, 15-503; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 38; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1473. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the health commissioner to make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-506)  
Sec. 54-1474. - Operating hours. 
No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. in any place in which a majority of the buildings within a radius of four hundred (400) feet are used exclusively for residential purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 15-504)  
Sec. 54-1475. - Sanitary requirements. 
No building, structure or part thereof used in connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the public. The owner, lessee, occupant or manager of any such machine shop shall cause all floors or other surfaces around or beneath any machine or workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient and sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are intended for any other use. No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in or about any machine where cutting compound or fluid is used. All such cutting compound or fluid shall be kept free from harmful or infectious matter. 
(Code 1980, § 15-505)  
Secs. 54-1476—54-1500. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 17. - MOTELS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate public sleeping accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-5. 
 
Sec. 54-1501. - Defined. 
The term "motel" as used in this division shall be construed to mean any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where transient sleeping accommodations are afforded or provided on the same premises for the public or for the occupants of such automobiles; provided that a hotel which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with the hotel shall not be construed to be a motel. 
(Code 1980, § 15-515; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 1)  
Sec. 54-1502. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a motel without a license. 
(b)  Application. Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain a motel shall file an application with the city clerk and shall state thereon the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the owner or manager thereof, the location of the motel and the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the motel showing the proposed or existing locations of all buildings, toilet, bath and wash basin facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections, driveways and other improvements. 
(c)  Fee. The annual license fee for the license required by this division shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first unit and thirty dollars ($30.00) for each additional unit. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-516, 15-517, 15-518; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 4; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1503. - Inspections. 
The chief of police shall inspect all motels to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-525; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 7)  
Sec. 54-1504. - Lights. 
Any area or premises of a motel open to use by the public or by all persons staying at or being accommodated in such motel shall be kept adequately lighted at nighttime; provided that such lights must be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any adjacent premises. 
(Code 1980, § 15-520; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 8)  
Sec. 54-1505. - Sanitation. 
All motels shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times; waste material shall be removed from same at least once every twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Code 1980, § 15-521; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 7)  
Sec. 54-1506. - Sanitary facilities. 
No motel shall be operated as such unless it is equipped with adequate toilet and other sanitary facilities to serve the total number of persons accommodated therein. All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system of the city if the premises are located on a street served by such sewer. 
(Code 1980, § 15-522; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 6)  
Sec. 54-1507. - Prohibited conduct. 
It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any ordinance or statute in any motel or to permit any portion of same to be used for immoral purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 15-523; Ord. of 6-25-1959, § 7)  
Sec. 54-1508. - Trailers. 
It shall be unlawful to permit the use of or to use the premises of any motel for the accommodation of a trailer unless all requirements of this Code pertaining to trailer camps are complied with; provided that where a license fee for a trailer camp has been paid, it shall not be necessary to pay an additional fee for the operation of a motel on the same premises. 
(Code 1980, § 15-524)  
Secs. 54-1509—54-1530. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 18. - NURSING HOMES 
 
Sec. 54-1531. - Defined. 
For the purpose of this division, a "home" is hereby defined to mean any institution, place or dwelling house used for the reception or care, for a longer period than twenty-four (24) hours, of three (3) or more children or infants, apart from their parents. A "home" shall further mean any institution used for the reception or care of persons who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall be understood to include homes for aged or infirm, orphan asylums, refugees and shelters, and also boarding homes caring for three (3) or more women with their children when such children are less than fourteen (14) years of age. 
(Code 1980, § 15-534)  
Sec. 54-1532. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the city or of the state or any association or institution for the care of children which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the state, pursuant to an act of the legislature, to regulate the treatment and control of dependent, neglected and delinquent children, to open, conduct, manage or maintain any homes within the corporate limits without a license. 
(b)  Application. Any person desiring the license required by this division shall make application in writing to the city clerk. Such applications shall conform to the general provisions of this Code relating to applications for licenses and shall state the location or proposed location of the home, the purpose for which it is to be opened, conducted or maintained, the accommodations for the inmates thereof, the nature and kind of care, instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given therein, the name and address of the officials conducting, managing or maintaining said home, the name and address of the chief physician, surgeon, or attending physician or surgeon, or the names and addresses of the board of physicians or surgeons attending therein if there is such a board. 
(c)  Fee. The license fee to be paid annually to the clerk for the license required by this division shall be three hundred sixty dollars ($360.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-535, 15-536, 15-537; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 37; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1533. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the health commissioner, upon presentation of a license application, to make or cause to be made strict inquiry into the facts set out in such application, and if upon inquiry and inspection he shall find that such home complies with all ordinances and statutes relating thereto, he shall recommend to the mayor and city council that a license be issued. 
(Code 1980, § 15-538)  
Sec. 54-1534. - Accommodations for inmates; sanitary regulations. 
(a)  In every home required to be licensed by the provisions of this division, each room occupied or to be occupied by inmates shall be of such dimensions as shall give each inmate not less than four hundred (400) cubic feet of air space. Every such room shall have at least one (1) window connecting with the external air for each four (4) beds. Said windows shall be of such dimensions as shall secure to each inmate at least one thousand five hundred (1,500) cubic feet of fresh air per hour by ventilation; or in case said window shall not secure one thousand five hundred (1,500) cubic feet of fresh air per hour by natural ventilation, then each room shall in addition thereto be fitted with such appliances for ventilation as shall secure to each inmate in said room at least one thousand five hundred (1,500) cubic feet of fresh air per hour. Each bed shall have at least forty (40) square feet of floor space, and in every room or dormitory containing more than one (1) bed the beds shall be so arranged as to leave a passageway of not less than two (2) feet horizontally on all sides of each bed. 
(b)  Each ward or wing in said home shall have running water furnished in one (1) or more places, either in said ward or convenient thereto so that the same may be adequate and convenient to the occupants thereof. The plumbing, water closets, bathrooms and other sanitary appliances and equipment shall be constructed in accordance with the ordinances relating thereto. The floor of cellar or basement in the building used as a home shall be properly cemented so as to be watertight. 
(c)  The halls of each floor shall be open to the external air with suitable windows, and shall have no room or other obstruction at either end thereof, unless sufficient light and ventilation is otherwise provided for such halls, and the building as a whole shall be provided with adequate and proper fire escapes, stairways or inclines for exits. 
(d)  All homes, including the culinary department, dining rooms, laundry, laboratory, morgue and post-mortem rooms connected with the same, shall be equipped from May fifteenth to November fifteenth with doors, screens and other appliances necessary for the exclusion of flies. 
(Code 1980, § 15-539)  
Sec. 54-1535. - Closing or vacating pending compliance. 
In the event of a conviction of any person for a violation of any of the provisions of this division relating to the safety and accommodations of inmates, it shall be the duty of the health commissioner to close such home and to cause its vacation pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the occupancy of its inmates and to make it comply with the terms of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-540)  
Secs. 54-1536—54-1560. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 19. - PAINT, DRUG AND CHEMICAL FACTORIES 
 
Sec. 54-1561. - Defined. 
The term "paint, drug or chemical factory" as used in this division shall be construed to mean and include any premises or establishment where soda, soda ash, sal soda, bicarbonate of soda, caustic soda, alcohol, ether, essential oils, carbonic acid gas, chlorine, aniline, perfumes, coal tar chemicals, inks, dyes, bluing, boiler compounds, disinfectants, cleaning compounds, explosives, photographic chemicals, glycerine, proprietary or patent medicines, paints, linseed oil, shellac, varnish, enamels or other chemicals, drugs or preparations containing any of the foregoing are made, mixed, compounded, purified or prepared for sale or for commercial or industrial use. 
(Code 1980, § 15-547)  
Sec. 54-1562. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate a paint, drug or chemical factory as defined in this article without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for a license required by this division shall be made in compliance with the general provisions relating to licenses, and each such application shall state whether or not a certificate of occupancy has been issued covering the premises and use contemplated. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-548, 15-549, 15-550; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 40; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1563. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this Code applicable to the premises required to be licensed by this division. 
(Code 1980, § 15-552)  
Sec. 54-1564. - Sanitation. 
All premises required by this division to be licensed shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all dirt, refuse and debris at least once every twenty-four (24) hours. Each building, or part thereof, used for such purposes shall be adequately equipped with devices to remove and eliminate all fumes, odors and dust. Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities for employees shall be provided. 
(Code 1980, § 15-551)  
Secs. 54-1565—54-1590. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 20. - PARKING LOTS[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate parking lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-12. 
 
Sec. 54-1591. - Defined. 
The term "parking lot" as used in this division shall be construed to mean and include any place maintained for the outdoor parking of cars, excepting on a street, alley or other public place, where such parking is permitted upon the payment of compensation or is made available to patrons or customers of any places of business. 
(Code 1980, § 15-561)  
Sec. 54-1592. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a parking lot without a permit. 
(b)  Application. Applications for the permit required by this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall contain all necessary information to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division, including a description of the location, size, number of cars to be accommodated, and a statement of any services other than parking, or of any commodities for sale, offered to patrons of the parking lot. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the permit required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-562, 15-563, 15-564; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 41; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1593. - Location restrictions. 
No parking lot shall be established or operated in any place where such establishment or operation would be in violation of any ordinance pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 15-565)  
Sec. 54-1594. - Prohibited use. 
It shall be unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or for sale or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an automobile repair shop. 
(Code 1980, § 15-566)  
Sec. 54-1595. - Surface. 
It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot unless the surface thereof is covered with concrete, asphalt, macadam or similar paving; and such parking lot shall at all times be kept clean and free from dust or refuse. 
(Code 1980, § 15-567)  
Sec. 54-1596. - Driveways. 
No driveway to a parking lot shall be constructed excepting in full compliance with this Code relative to the issuance of permits for driveways; it shall be the duty of the operator of each parking lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which such driveway passes in good condition. 
(Code 1980, § 15-568)  
Sec. 54-1597. - Markings; minimum exits. 
Each parking lot shall be marked so as to show the parking place allotted each car, and shall have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of cars without obstruction to traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 15-569)  
Sec. 54-1598. - Capacity. 
Not more than one (1) car for each two hundred (200) square feet of area shall be accepted for parking in any parking lot. 
(Code 1980, § 15-570)  
Sec. 54-1599. - Buildings. 
Any buildings constructed on a parking lot shall be constructed in full compliance with the ordinances pertaining thereto, and shall have exterior walls of nonflammable material, provided, that any structure used or to be used for office purposes only may have less than the minimum area requirements prescribed for residences or commercial buildings. 
(Code 1980, § 15-571)  
Sec. 54-1600. - Rates; attendants. 
At the entrance of each parking lot there shall be posted in words and figures large enough to be read by prospective patrons a statement of the rates to be charged and of the closing hours. There shall be at least one (1) attendant on the premises at all times during which the parking lot is open for business. 
(Code 1980, § 15-573)  
Sec. 54-1601. - Condition of vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to park or store in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a condition ready for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot. 
(Code 1980, § 15-574)  
Sec. 54-1602. - Intoxicating liquors. 
It shall be unlawful to serve intoxicating liquor for consumption in any car parked in a parking lot, and it shall be unlawful for any person in a car parked in a parking lot to drink any intoxicating liquor while therein. 
(Code 1980, § 15-575)  
Sec. 54-1603. - Sanitation, trash containers. 
If a parking lot is maintained in connection with a licensed establishment serving food for consumption on the premises, and food and drinks are served to occupants of cars, sufficient and adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the premises must be kept thoroughly clean by the proprietor. 
(Code 1980, § 15-576)  
Sec. 54-1604. - Other business. 
If any business other than that of operating a parking lot is conducted on the same premises with a parking lot, such business shall be conducted in full compliance with all ordinances pertinent thereto; and any license required for the operation of such business must be obtained and the fee therefor required must be paid. 
(Code 1980, § 15-577)  
Secs. 54-1605—54-1620. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 21. - PAWNBROKERS 
 
Sec. 54-1621. - Restrictions. 
The number of pawnbrokers permitted within the city limits of the city shall be limited to one (1) per eight thousand five hundred (8,500) residents. 
(Code 1980, § 15-583; Ord. No. 98-5, § 1, 2-12-1998; Ord. No. 11-60, § 2, 10-27-2011)  
Sec. 54-1622. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for pawnbroker's licenses shall be made to the city clerk and shall state thereon the name of the applicant, the place of business and the number of employees indented to be engaged. The chief of police or any other officer of the city designated by the mayor and council shall investigate each applicant for such license, and shall report back whether or not such applicant is a person of good character. No license shall be issued to a person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen goods or of burglary or robbery. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee to be paid for a pawnbroker's license shall be three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00), and this fee shall be payable in advance, and no license shall be issued until the fee is paid. 
(d)  Revocation. The mayor and city council may revoke any pawnbroker's license for any violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-584, 15-585, 15-586, 15-587; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005; Ord. No. 11-60, § 2, 10-27-2011)  
Sec. 54-1623. - Records. 
Every pawnbroker doing business in the city shall keep a record of every article pledged with him or sold to him, and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during normal business hours. 
(Code 1980, § 15-588)  
Sec. 54-1624. - Minors. 
No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who is not eighteen (18) years of age or over; no pawnbroker shall employ a person of less than eighteen (18) years of age to assist him in his business. No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as pawnbroker with any person less than eighteen (18) years of age, except with the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor to each particular transaction. 
(Code 1980, § 15-589) 
State Law reference— Authority, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3.  
Sec. 54-1625. - Weapons. 
No pawnbroker shall receive as a pledge or purchase any revolver, pistol, blackjack or sawed-off shotgun, and no pawnbroker shall display in his window or shop any such weapons for sale. 
(Code 1980, § 15-590)  
Sec. 54-1626. - Stolen or lost goods. 
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged to him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost, and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. 
(Code 1980, § 15-591)  
Sec. 54-1627. - Secondhand dealers. 
No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained the license required for such dealer in addition to his pawnbroker's license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-592)  
Secs. 54-1628—54-1650. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 22. - PUBLIC GARAGES[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to license and regulate parking garages, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-12. 
 
Sec. 54-1651. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a public garage in the city without a license. 
(b)  Application. An application for a license required by this division shall be made to the city clerk, in writing, and shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-601, 15-602, 15-603; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 43; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1652. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to make or cause to be made such inspections of public garages as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. Any police officer may be permitted at any reasonable time to view any car stored or kept in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any motorcar or motor vehicle from inspection. 
(Code 1980, § 15-607)  
Sec. 54-1653. - Premises. 
It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building, or in any building or structure used for school, church or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the building ordinances. The premises of every garage must be kept clean and free from flammable waste. 
(Code 1980, § 15-604)  
Sec. 54-1654. - Changing identification marks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to change the identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile in any public garage. And it shall be unlawful to change the license tags on such cars, excepting in accord with the register of motor vehicles kept by the secretary of state. 
(Code 1980, § 15-605)  
Sec. 54-1655. - Smoking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a cigarette, pipe or cigar in any public garage. 
(Code 1980, § 15-606)  
Secs. 54-1656—54-1680. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 23. - REAL ESTATE AND INSURANCE BROKERS 
 
Sec. 54-1681. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall operate as a broker of real estate or insurance without a license; provided that this section shall not be construed to require an additional broker's license from employees of a licensed broker. 
(b)  Application. Applications for real estate or insurance broker's license shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and no such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good character, and it shall be the duty of the clerk to cause or make such an investigation into the character of such applicant. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for a real estate or insurance broker's license shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-616, 15-617, 15-618; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 24; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1682. - Fraud. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating as a real estate or insurance broker to practice fraud or deception of any sort or to make false pretenses of any kind or to represent both parties to a transaction without the consent and knowledge of both parties. 
(Code 1980, § 15-619)  
Secs. 54-1683—54-1700. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 24. - TOBACCO DEALERS[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
State Law reference— Power of city to regulate tobacco, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-3. 
 
Sec. 54-1701. - Penalty. 
The violation of section 54-1704 or 54-1705 shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. A second or subsequent violation of section 54-1704 or 54-1705 may subject a licensee to a suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Code 1980, § 15-631; Ord. No. 96-48, § 1, 7-25-1996; Ord. No. 12-3, § 2, 2-9-2012)  
Sec. 54-1702. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at retail of cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form without a license. 
(b)  Application. Applications for licenses required by the provisions of this division shall be made to the city clerk and no such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character or to any corporation that is not represented in the city by a person of good character. 
(c)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  Suspension or revocation. 
(1)  The mayor shall be charged with the administration of this division. The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provision of this division; if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this division. However, no such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the mayor with a seven (7) day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven (7) day notice provisions shall begin the day following delivery by certified mail or by personal service. 
(2)  The mayor shall within seven (7) days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and state either the amount of the fine, the period of suspension or the revocation of the license and serve a copy of such order within the seven (7) days upon the licensee. 
(3)  Any licensee determined by the mayor to have violated any of the provisions of this division shall pay to the city the costs of the hearing before the mayor on such violation. The mayor shall determine the costs incurred by the city for said hearing, including, but not limited to: court reporters' fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the city or such less sum as the mayor may allow. 
(4)  The licensee shall pay said costs to the city within thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the mayor. Failure to pay said costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this division and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of a fine. 
(5)  When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to said licensee for the period of six (6) months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling tobacco products in the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-626, 15-627, 15-628, 15-632, 15-633; Ord. No. 96-48, § 1, 7-25-1996; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1703. - Sanitation. 
Premises and buildings used for the sale of cigarettes, cigars and tobacco shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition; the health commissioner shall investigate such places sufficiently often to ensure compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 15-629)  
Sec. 54-1704. - Prohibited sales to minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any retail tobacco dealer licensee or any officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to sell, offer for sale, buy for, give away, furnish, or deliver tobacco products to persons under the age of eighteen (18) years. Unlawful acts constituting a violation of this provision by an officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act has been done by the licensee personally. 
(Code 1980, § 15-630; Ord. No. 96-48, § 1, 7-25-1996)  
Sec. 54-1705. - Sale of single or loose cigarettes prohibited; license revocation. 
(a)  The sale or distribution by any person, whether a minor or not, of a tobacco product, including, but not limited to, a single or loose cigarette that is not contained within a sealed container, pack or package as provided by the manufacturer, which container, pack or package bears the health warning required by federal law is prohibited. 
(b)  If any officer, director, manager, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of a licensee is found guilty of violating a provision of this section, such unlawful act shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; as if such act has been done by the licensee in the course of the licensee's business and shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of licensee's license, as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 12-3, § 2, 2-9-2012)  
Secs. 54-1706—54-1730. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 25. - TATTOO AND BODY PIERCING PARLORS 
 
Sec. 54-1731. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words shall have their given meanings: 
Animal means every living creature, domestic or wild, but does not include human beings. 
Aseptic technique means a practice that prevents and hinders the transmission of disease-producing microorganisms from one (1) person or place to another person or place. 
Body piercing means the puncturing of skin for the purpose of inserting items of decoration, including, but not limited to, jewelry. Piercing of the ears shall not be considered body piercing. 
Body piercing artist means an individual who performs body piercing. 
Facial tattoo means any tattoo applied above the jawline, anterior to the ear and frontal hairline, including the eyelids, eyebrows or lips. 
Physician means a person licensed to practice medicine and all its branches under the Medical Practice Act of 1987. 
Tattoo means any permanent marks, designs, letters or numerals affixed upon a person by puncturing the skin and inserting indelible colors therein. 
Tattoo artist means an individual who practices tattooing or body piercing. 
Tattoo and/or body piercing parlor means any premises where a tattoo artist practices tattooing and shall also include premises where body piercing is performed. 
(Code 1980, § 15-650; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995; Ord. 97-62, §§ 1—3, 10-23-1997)  
Sec. 54-1732. - Penalty for violation. 
The violation of any provision of this division shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a term of imprisonment up to six (6) months or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or both. 
(Code 1980, § 15-661; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995)  
Sec. 54-1733. - License. 
(a)  Required; fee. No person shall operate a tattoo and/or body piercing parlor in the city without first obtaining a license therefor in accordance with the licensing provisions of chapter 54, article II, of this Code. The annual license fee for each tattoo and/or body piercing parlor shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). The annual license fee for each tattoo artist shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(b)  Investigation of premises. In addition to the application procedures outlined in chapter 54, article II of this Code, the premises intended to be used as a tattoo and/or body piercing parlor shall be investigated by the city health authority or his designee for the purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of said premises for the conduct of such business from a sanitary standpoint, and as to whether the applicant has complied with any applicable state laws and provisions of this Code regulating health, sanitation and safety so as to safeguard properly the lives and health of the persons tattooing or being tattooed. The city health authority or his designee may, from time to time, at his own discretion, but not less than once each year upon renewal of the license, investigate or cause to be made an investigation of the licensed premises in order to assure its clean and sanitary condition. Every tattoo and/or body piercing parlor shall at all times be open to inspection by the city health authority or his designee whenever and as often as he/she deems proper. 
(c)  Denial, suspension, revocation, nonrenewal of licenses. A license may be suspended, revoked or the renewal of a license may be denied for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Violation of any of the provisions of this division; 
(2)  Conviction of an applicant or licensee of an offense arising from false, fraudulent, deceptive, or misleading advertising. The record of conviction or a certified copy shall be conclusive evidence of the conviction. 
(3)  Aiding or abetting an unlicensed person, knowingly combining or conspiring with an unlicensed person, allowing one's license to be used by an unlicensed person, or acting as agent or associate of an unlicensed person, in order to enable the unlicensed person to evade the restrictions on use of title imposed by this division. Upon denial of an application, refusal to renew a license, suspension of a license or revocation of a license, the city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing. The notice shall specify the charges or reasons for the contemplated action. If a license is suspended or revoked and such suspension or revocation is disputed by the licenseholder, the licenseholder must request a hearing within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice. Failure to request a hearing within ten (10) days shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing. 
(d)  Conduct of hearing. 
(1)  Upon suspension or revocation of a license, should a licenseholder request a hearing, such hearing shall be conducted by the city health authority or an individual designated in writing by the city health authority as a hearing officer. The city health authority or hearing officer may compel by subpoena or subpoena duces tecum the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers and administer oaths to witnesses. The hearing shall be conducted at a place designated by the city health authority or hearing officer. The procedures governing hearings in the issuance of final decisions under this division shall be in accordance with rules adopted by the permits and licenses committee of the city council. 
(2)  All subpoenas issued by the city health authority or hearing officer may be served as provided for in civil actions. The fees for witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees for witnesses before the circuit court and shall be paid by the party to the proceedings at whose request the subpoena is issued. If a subpoena is issued at the request of the city health authority or hearing officer, the witness fee shall be paid as an administrative expense. 
(3)  In cases of refusal of a witness to attend or testify or to produce books or papers concerning any matter upon which he might be lawfully examined, the circuit court of the county wherein the hearing is held, upon application of any party to the proceeding, may compel obedience by proceeding as for contempt as in cases of a like refusal to obey a similar order of the court. 
(4)  The city health authority or hearing officer shall make findings of fact and conclusions of law in a hearing, and the city health authority shall render his decision, or the hearing officer his proposal for decision within forty-five (45) days after the termination of the hearing. A copy of the final decision shall be served upon the applicant or licensee in person or by certified mail. 
(e)  Surrender of license. Upon the revocation of a license, a licenseholder shall be required to surrender the license to city health authority and upon his failure or refusal to do so, the city health authority shall have the right to seize the same. 
(f)  Appeal. All final administrative decisions of the city health authority under this division may be appealed for review by the city council. If the city council concurs with the decision of the city health authority, such decision shall be subject to judicial review under the provisions of Article 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure. 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-651, 15-659, 15-660; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1734. - Restrictions. 
(a)  A tattoo artist shall be twenty-one (21) years of age prior to being issued a valid license. 
(b)  No tattoo artist shall practice tattooing in any place other than a tattoo and/or body piercing parlor having a valid license. 
(c)  No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo to or pierce the body of any person who appears to be or admits to being under the influence of intoxicating substances, including, but not limited to, alcohol, drugs, paints and glues, nor shall any tattoo artist practice his trade while in an intoxicated state. 
(d)  No tattoo artist shall apply a tattoo in violation of Section 1210 of the Criminal Code of 1961 (720 ILCS 5/12-10), which states that "any person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine in all its branches, who tattoos or offers to tattoo a person under the age of twenty-one (21) is guilty of a Class C misdemeanor." 
(e)  The number of tattoo parlors permitted within the city limits of the city shall be limited to one (1) per ten thousand (10,000) residents. 
(Code 1980, § 15-652; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995; Ord. No. 97-62, §§ 3, 4, 10-23-1997; Ord. No. 95-57, § 1, 10-9-1997)  
Sec. 54-1735. - Tattooing procedure. 
(a)  The tattoo artist shall explain the following to each client before a tattoo application: 
(1)  The application procedure; 
(2)  Possible tissue reactions following application; 
(3)  Importance of after application care. 
(b)  The tattoo and/or body piercing parlor license holder shall maintain proper records of each client. The records shall include the following: 
(1)  The date on which the tattoo was applied; 
(2)  The name, address and age of the client; 
(3)  The design and location of the tattoo; 
(4)  The name of the tattoo artist; 
(5)  The signature of the client; 
(6)  The manufacturer, dye lot and expiration date of the dye or pigment injected into the client. 
(c)  The information required in subsection (b) of this section shall be permanently recorded in a bound book that shall be made available for examination by the city health authority or his designee and shall be kept in the tattoo and/or body piercing parlor for at least two (2) years following the date of the last entry. 
(d)  All tattoo artists shall comply with the following: 
(1)  All tattoo artists shall wash their hands, using good mechanical action with soap or detergent and warm water, and shall dry their hands using clean single service or single use towels or other approved method immediately before and after tattooing; 
(2)  The area of the client's skin to be tattooed shall be adequately cleaned. Shaving, if done, shall be performed with a single service razor; 
(3)  Before placing the design on the client's skin, the tattoo artist shall treat the skin area with seventy (70) percent alcohol or other effective germicidal solution which shall be applied using aseptic technique; 
(4)  If petroleum jelly or other substances are used in applying stencil designs to the skin, they shall be dispensed from collapsible metal or plastic tubes; 
(5)  Reusable stencils for transferring the design to the skin shall be thoroughly cleansed and sanitized after each use; 
(6)  Only sterilized needles and tubes or tips, in good condition, shall be used for tattooing; 
(7)  Single service or individual portions or dyes or pigments in sterilized containers or single service containers shall be used for each client. After tattooing, the remaining unused dyes or pigments in the single service or individual containers shall be discarded; 
(8)  Immediately after tattooing, the tattoo artist shall advise the client on the care of the tattoo and instruct the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection. 
(Code 1980, § 15-653; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995; Ord. No. 97-62, § 3, 10-23-1997)  
Sec. 54-1736. - Sterilization procedure. 
(a)  After each use, needles and assemblies shall be cleansed to remove protein residue (blood and tissue) and sterilized. 
(b)  One of the following methods of sterilization shall be used: 
(1)  Autoclave—Steam under pressure. 
a.  One hundred twenty (120) degrees Celsius (two hundred fifty (250) degrees Fahrenheit) for not less than thirty (30) minutes after the chamber of the autoclave has been evacuated of air and has reached temperature; or 
b.  As specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual. 
(2)  Dry heat sterilization (for steel tubing only): 
a.  One hundred seventy (170) degrees Celsius (three hundred thirty-eight (338) degrees Fahrenheit) for not less than two (2) hours after the sterilizer has reached temperature; or 
b.  As specified in the manufacturer's operator's manual. 
(c)  Sterilization shall be monitored by the use of chemical and heat-sensitive (color change) indicators with each batch of equipment sterilized. 
(d)  Sterilized equipment shall be stored, wrapped, or covered in a manner that ensures the equipment will remain sterile until used. 
(e)  Sterile equipment, stored in an approved manner and not used within thirty (30) days after sterilization, shall no longer be considered sterile and shall be resterilized before use. 
(Code 1980, § 15-654; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995)  
Sec. 54-1737. - Facial tattoo. 
Application of facial tattoos is prohibited except by a physician. 
(Code 1980, § 15-655; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995)  
Sec. 54-1738. - Sanitation requirements for tattoo parlors. 
(a)  The tattooing and waiting area shall be separated by a solid partition or barrier that prevents unauthorized entry into the tattooing area. 
(b)  The shop shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(c)  The walls and ceiling shall be easily cleanable, smooth, durable, and light colored. All walls and ceilings shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(d)  Tattooing area floors and floor coverings shall be constructed of materials that are smooth, durable, nonabsorbent, and easily cleanable. All floors shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(e)  Adequate lighting shall be provided. 
(f)  Adequate ventilation shall be provided. 
(g)  Each tattoo and/or body piercing parlor shall be provided with a sink at the work station for the exclusive use of the tattoo artist for handwashing and preparing the client for tattooing. 
(h)  Animals shall not be permitted in the tattoo and/or body piercing parlor, except for guide or service animals accompanying persons with disabilities. 
(i)  Smoking and the use of tobacco in any form shall be prohibited in the tattooing room. 
(j)  Any other business or dwelling shall be completely separated from the tattoo and/or body piercing parlor by at least a solid partition from the floor to the ceiling. 
(Code 1980, § 15-656; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995; Ord. No. 97-62, § 3, 10-23-1997)  
Sec. 54-1739. - Equipment. 
(a)  Needles, tubes and tips shall be constructed in a manner that permits easy cleaning and sterilization. 
(b)  Needles and assemblies designed to be disposable shall be used one (1) time, on one (1) person only, and then discarded. 
(c)  All dyes and pigments used in tattooing shall be nontoxic, free from adulteration, and made from materials generally regarded as safe. 
(d)  Each tattoo artist shall be provided with adequate storage cabinets for the exclusive storage of instruments, dyes, pigments, carbon, stencils and other paraphernalia used in the parlor. 
(Code 1980, § 15-657; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995)  
Sec. 54-1740. - Disposal of infectious waste. 
Used tattoo needles and other infectious waste shall be stored, treated and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Title XV of the Environmental Protection Act, which regulates the management and disposal of infectious waste. 
(Code 1980, § 15-658; Ord. No. 95-52, § 1, 9-28-1995)  
Sec. 54-1741. - Body piercing procedure. 
(a)  The tattoo artist or body piercing artist shall explain the following to each client before a body piercing procedure: 
(1)  The piercing procedure; 
(2)  Possible tissue reactions following the procedure; 
(3)  The importance of after-procedure care. 
(b)  The tattoo and/or body piercing parlor licenseholder shall maintain proper records of each client. The records shall include the following: 
(1)  The date on which the body piercing procedure was performed; 
(2)  The name and address of the client; 
(3)  The location of the body piercing; 
(4)  The name of the tattoo artist. 
(c)  The information required in subsection (b) of this section shall be permanently recorded in a bound book that shall be available for examination by the city healthaAuthority or his designee and shall be kept in the tattoo and/or body piercing parlor for at least two (2) years following the date of the last entry. 
(d)  All tattoo artists or body piercing artists shall comply with the following: 
(1)  All tattoo/body piercing artists shall wash their hands, using good mechanical action with soap or detergent and warm water, and shall dry their hands using clean single service or single use towels or other approved method immediately before and after body piercing; 
(2)  The area of the client's skin to be pierced shall be adequately cleaned. Shaving, if done, shall be performed with a single service razor; 
(3)  Before piercing the client's skin, the tattoo artist shall treat the skin area with seventy (70) percent alcohol or other effective germicidal solution which shall be applied using aseptic technique; 
(4)  All needles, piercing guns or other tools used in the piercing procedure shall be sterilized before use; 
(5)  Immediately after body piercing, the tattoo/body piercing artist shall advise the client on the care of the pierced area and instruct the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection. 
(e)  No body piercing artist shall pierce the body of any person who appears to be or admits to being under the influence of intoxicating substances, including, but not limited to, alcohol, drugs, paints and glues, nor shall any body piercing artist perform his trade while in an intoxicated state. 
(Code 1980, § 15-662; Ord. No. 97-62, § 5, 10-23-1997)  
Secs. 54-1742—54-1760. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 26. - UNDERTAKERS 
 
Sec. 54-1761. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to maintain an undertaking establishment or to engage in business as a mortician within the city without a license. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for the license required by this division shall be two hundred forty dollars ($240.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 15-638, 15-639; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 31; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 05-87, § 1, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 54-1762. - Compliance with state law. 
Every person maintaining an undertaking establishment or engaging in business as an undertaker or mortician within the city shall maintain such establishment and conduct such business in strict compliance with all state laws. 
(Code 1980, § 15-642)  
Sec. 54-1763. - Notices to police. 
It shall be the duty of every undertaker to notify the police department whenever a body is brought to him or turned over to him for his services. 
(Code 1980, § 15-641)  
Sec. 54-1764. - Exhibitions of bodies. 
It shall be unlawful for any undertaker to permit his establishment to be used for the exhibition of the body of any deceased person to the public, other than friends and relatives of the deceased. 
(Code 1980, § 15-640)  
Secs. 54-1765—54-1790. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 27. - USED MOTOR VEHICLE SALES LOTS[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 09-2, adopted Jan. 8, 2009, amended div. 27 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 27 consisted of §§ 54-1791—54-1794, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1980 Code; and Ord. No. 99-23, adopted Mar. 11, 1999. 
 
Sec. 54-1791. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, and the interpretation and application thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words or phrases not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Used motor vehicle sales lot means a business displaying five (5) or more used motor vehicles for the purpose of wholesale or retail sale to the general public. 
Used motor vehicle means every motor vehicle which has been sold, bargained, exchanged, given away, or title transferred from the person who first acquired it from the manufacturer or importer, dealer or agent of the manufacturer or importer and so used as to have become what is commonly known as "second hand" within the ordinary meaning thereof. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1792. - License required. 
No person, firm, association, partnership or corporation shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate any used motor vehicle sales lot in violation of any of the provisions contained in this article and without having first obtained a license as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1793. - State licensing required; compliance with state law. 
Any person, firm, association, corporation or partnership applying for or holding a Used Motor Vehicle Sales Lot license, pursuant to this Article, must also hold a license to operate from the State of Illinois, whenever such license is required pursuant to the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/5-100, et seq., or pursuant to any other licensing provision of the State of Illinois and must show that such state license is current and active. In addition, any person, firm, association, corporation or partnership operating a used motor vehicle sales lot within the city must at all times be in full compliance with all laws, rules and regulations of the State of Illinois pertaining to the operation of a used motor vehicle sales lot. Failure to achieve and maintain full compliance with all laws, rules and regulations shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1794. - License application and issuance; fee. 
(a)  Application for a used motor vehicle sales lot license shall be made to the city clerk on such form as prescribed and furnished by the city clerk. The application shall identify the State of Illinois license number and shall be accompanied by good and sufficient proof of compliance with all State of Illinois licensing laws pertaining to a used motor vehicle sales lot. 
(b)  The annual fee for the license required by this article shall be two-hundred forty dollars and no cents ($240.00). 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2008)  
Sec. 54-1795. - Term of license. 
See section 54-38 of the Municipal Code of the City of Calumet City. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1796. - License regulations. 
Every used motor vehicle sales lot shall be maintained and operated in accordance with the statutes of the State of Illinois as well as the regulations of the Municipal Code and Zoning Ordinance of the City, as from time to time supplemented and amended. A used motor vehicle sales lot operating before the effective date of this article, which does not conform to the requirement of the zoning ordinance shall be exempt from said requirement provided that such used motor vehicle sales lot is not enlarged, extended, reconstructed, structurally altered or changed to a different use, unless modified to conform with the provisions of the zoning ordinance to the fullest extent. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1797. - License transfer. 
See section 54-40 of the Municipal Code of the City of Calumet City. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1798. - Display of used motor vehicle, exception. 
No used motor vehicle shall be displayed for sale on any property within the city unless it is displayed on a used motor vehicle sales lot. This article shall not apply to a homeowner or lessee displaying a personally owned used motor vehicle for sale on the residential property on which that homeowner or lessee lawfully resides, excepting that only one (1) such Used Motor Vehicle shall be displayed at any one (1) time. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 54-1799. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Every day that a violation exists constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  Proceedings to enforce violations of this article may be initiated and conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the Municipal Code of the City providing for administrative adjudication of Code violations or by any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 09-2, § 2, 1-8-2009)  
Secs. 54-1800—54-1820. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - GARAGE SALES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-1821. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section: 
Garage sale shall mean and include all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises in any residential zone, as defined by the zoning ordinance, for the purpose of disposing of personal property including, but not limited to, all sales titled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," "flea market," or "rummage" sale. This definition shall not include a situation where no more than five (5) specific items are held out for sale and all advertisement of such sale specifically names those items to be sold. 
Personal property shall mean property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of his residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. It does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
(Code 1980, § 15-681; Ord. No. 86-23, § 1, 8-14-1986)  
Sec. 54-1822. - Exemptions.
