(b)  Permit. A permit is not required for exempted signs. A permit must be obtained from the department for all other existing and new signs. Owners of existing signs that require a permit under this chapter shall apply for a permit within six (6) months of the effective date of this chapter. 
(c)  Application. Applications for sign permits shall be made upon a form provided by the department for this purpose. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, phone, and if available, fax and e-mail, of the person applying for the permit. 
(2)  Name, address, phone, and if available, fax and e-mail, of the person owning the parcel upon which the sign is proposed to be placed along with evidence of written consent of said owner of the building, structure or lot to which or upon which the sign is to be erected. 
(3)  Location of the building, structure, and parcel on which the sign is or will be attached or erected. 
(4)  Position of the sign in relation to nearby buildings, structures, property lines, existing or proposed rights-of-way, ordinary high water marks of waterways, and the setback of applicable zoning ordinances. 
(5)  Two (2) copies of the plans and specifications. The method of construction and/or attachment to a building or in the ground shall be explained in the plans and specifications. 
(6)  Copy of stress sheets and calculations, if deemed necessary by the department, showing the structure as designed for dead load and wind pressure. 
(7)  Name, address, phone, and if available, fax and e-mail of the person who has or will be erecting the sign. 
(8)  Insurance policy as required by this chapter. 
(9)  Such other information as the department may require to show compliance with this chapter, and any other applicable laws. 
(10)  The seal or certificate of a registered structural or civil engineer, when required by the department. 
(11)  The zoning district in which the sign is to be placed. 
(12)  A statement that: "Any change in the information in this application, such as change of address, shall be submitted to the department within seven (7) days after the change." 
(d)  Insurance certificates. An applicant for a billboard sign permit shall provide a certificate of insurance to the department. The insurance shall provide public liability in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to one (1) person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries to more than one (1) person, and property damage insurance in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The billboard sign permit shall automatically be revoked if the insurance is permitted to lapse. The insurance policy shall require written notice to the department at least sixty (60) days before the insurance is cancelled or materially altered. 
(e)  Bond. Every applicant for a sign permit to erect, alter or maintain a sign over or on public property or in the public right-of-way shall file with the department for each such sign, or for each premises on which signs are erected, a continuing bond in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) executed by the applicant and approved surety company, conditioned to indemnify, save and keep harmless the city from all claims, damages, liabilities, losses, actions, suits or judgments which may be presented, sustained, brought or secured against the city on account of the erection, alteration or maintenance of said sign, or by reason of any accident caused by or resulting therefrom. 
(f)  Permit fees. Every applicant, before being granted a sign permit, shall pay the fee specified as follows: 
(1)  Three dollars ($3.00) per square foot of sign area, if such sign is not electrically lighted or electrically wired. 
(2)  Six dollars ($6.00) per square foot of sign area, if such sign is electrically lighted or wired. 
In no event shall the fee for any sign be less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(g)  False information. A person providing false information under this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and not eligible to apply for a permit for twelve (12) months from the date the department determines false information was presented. 
(h)  If the work authorized under a permit has not been completed within one (1) year after its date of issuance, the permit shall become null and void. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-8. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Material. Where feasible, signs should be constructed of weather-resistant wood, or other natural material. 
(b)  Codes. All signs shall conform to the latest edition of the applicable building and electrical codes. 
(c)  Fastenings. All signs must remain safe and secure during the period of use. All parts of the signs, including bolts and cables, shall remain painted, and free of corrosion. 
(d)  Windows, doors, fire escapes. A sign may not obstruct or prevent the free ingress or egress from any window, door or fire escape. 
(e)  Traffic hazard. No sign structure shall be erected at any street intersection in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision of motorists in a moving traffic lane of intersecting traffic. 
(f)  Lighting. External lighting shall be shielded from view and shall be focused upon the sign to avoid stray lighting. Flashing, rotating, and intermittent lighting are prohibited. 
(g)  Identification. All signs for which a permit is required shall identify the name and operating telephone number of the person responsible for the sign, in such lettering as to be visible from a distance of at least two (2) feet from the sign. 
(h)  Proximity to electrical conductors. Signs and all supporting structures shall be no closer to electrical utilities than is permitted by applicable codes. No sign, including cables and supports, shall, in any event, be within six (6) feet of any electrical conductor, electrical light pole, electric street lamp, traffic light, or other public utility pole. 
(i)  Sanitation. Property surrounding any sign shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be free from weeds, rubbish, and flammable material. 
(j)  Landscaping. The area beneath and around a sign shall be landscaped with plants, ground cover and materials so as to complement the site and integrate the sign with buildings, parking areas, surrounding vegetation and natural features of the landscape. 
(k)  Responsibility for compliance. The owner of the parcel on which a sign is placed and the person maintaining the sign are each fully responsible for the condition and the maintenance of the sign, and the area around the sign. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-07)  
Sec. 70-9. - Appeals. 
Appeals to the determination of the department may be made in writing directly to the designated governing body of the city authorized to hear the appeal within sixty (60) days. Variances may be granted if all of the following criteria are fulfilled: 
(a)  That the circumstance are not of the applicant's making; 
(b)  That the applicant's request mitigates unusual site conditions; 
(c)  That the applicant's request would not create a detriment to the neighborhood or reduce property value; 
(d)  That the applicant's request is consistent with the spirit and intent of this chapter; 
(e)  That without a variance, the applicant would experience a hardship and cannot make any reasonable use of the property. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-10. - First Amendment protection. 
Any sign allowed under this chapter may contain, in lieu of any other copy, any otherwise lawful noncommercial message that does not direct attention to a business operated for profit or to a commodity or service for sale and that complies with all other provisions of this chapter including the specific provisions for signage in the land use category on which the sign is placed. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-11. - Administration. 
(a)  Administration. The department shall assign personnel to administer and enforce the terms and conditions of this chapter and all other provisions relating to signs. 
(b)  Enforcement. The department shall issue permits as required by this chapter. The department shall also ensure signs comply with this chapter and any other applicable law. The department shall also enforce the requirement that all signs properly comply with this chapter by procuring a permit. The department shall make such inspections as may be necessary and shall initiate appropriate action to enforce compliance with this chapter and other applicable laws. 
(c)  Department powers. The department shall have the power and authority to administer and enforce this chapter. Included among such powers are the following specific powers: 
(1)  Every sign for which a permit is required shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the department, including verification of the use of the parcel, and thus the standards that apply to signage. When deemed advisable, a sign may be inspected at the point of manufacture. 
(2)  Upon presentation of proper identification to the sign owner or owner's agent, the department may enter the sign area for purposes of inspecting the sign, sign structure, and any fasteners securing the sign to a building or support. In cases of emergency, where imminent hazards to persons or property are known to exist, and where the sign owner, or owner's agent, is not readily available, the department may enter the sign area for purposes of inspection or remediation. When on private property, the department shall observe rules and regulation concerning safety, internal security, and fire protection. If the department is denied admission to inspect any sign, inspection shall be made only under authority of a warrant issued by a court of proper jurisdiction. When applying for such warrant, the department shall submit an affidavit setting forth a belief that a violation of this chapter exists with respect to a particular sign, and the reasons for forming this belief. The affidavit shall designate the place and name of the person believed to own or possess the sign. If the court finds probable cause exists for the search of the sign, and supporting structures, then a warrant authorizing the search shall be issued. The warrant shall describe the property with sufficient certainty to identify the same. This warrant shall constitute authority for the department to enter the sign area and to inspect the property. 
(3)  Upon issuance of a stop order from the department, work on any sign that is being conducted in any manner contrary to this chapter shall be immediately stopped. This notice and order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the parcel, the sign owner, or to the person performing the work. The stop order shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. The police department shall have authority to enforce a stop order. 
(4)  The department has the authority to deny or revoke any permit authorized by this chapter if the sign violates this chapter or another law, provided that the department shall offer the sign owner an opportunity to be heard. The person whose permit is under consideration shall be given at least ten (10) days' written notice of the time, place, and reason for the hearing. The sign owner and/or party identified in the permit shall be permitted to present relevant facts and legal argument concerning the pending permit denial or permit revocation. Following this hearing, the department shall consider the merits of the case and shall present a written decision. 
(5)  If the department has determined that a violation has occurred, the owner shall have thirty (30) days to bring the sign into compliance or remove the sign. If, however, the department believes the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens is endangered by any violation of this chapter, the department may immediately revoke any sign permit. 
(6)  A sign installed after the effective date of this chapter, and not conforming to this chapter, shall be removed by the owner. The sign owner shall not be entitled to compensation for the sign removal and shall reimburse the department for any cost incurred in connection with the removal. 
(7)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be issued a citation with a forfeiture of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day, subsequent to the 30-day period allowed for corrective action, shall constitute a separate violation. The city is authorized to adjudicate the offense with a summons and complaint and to take any other action, legal, injunctive and equitable, to assure compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-12. - Changing copy. 
The text or image posted on any sign may be changed without the city's permission. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-13. - Nonconforming signs. 
Any sign that was approved or in existence at the time this chapter was passed, and was legal pursuant to the city's previous sign regulations, variances, or agreements, will be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. The structure, dimensions, location, and/or other physical characteristics of any such sign shall not be substantially altered without first complying with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-14. - Maintenance. 
All signs must be maintained in a state of good repair. When the department or authorized city official believes that a sign is dangerous or has otherwise become a public nuisance or is an abandoned sign they shall contact the owner of the sign in writing at the address listed on the application and request that the problem be repaired or corrected. If the owner has not appealed the official's determination to the governing body or corrected the problem(s) within thirty (30) days of the date of the written notice, the city shall arrange for removal of any such sign and bill the owner for all costs of such removal. If, however, the department believes the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens is endangered by any violation of this chapter, the department may immediately revoke any sign permit. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-15. - License. 
(a)  License. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of maintaining, erecting, placing, posting or painting any sign in or on any place so that the sign is visible from any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place to do business in the city without having first secured a license therefor as is required in this section; provided, that no license issued under this section shall be construed to permit the use for advertising purposes of any structure, natural or artificial, which is located in any public way, street, alley or other public place. 
(b)  Application; fee. Application for a license shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a list of all such places, including billboards or natural structures, on which it is intended to place a sign or advertisement. This list shall be added to from time to time by the licensee as a right to post or place an advertisement or sign at additional places. The annual fee for such license shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(c)  Bond or insurance. Every person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of maintaining, erecting, placing, posting or painting any sign in or on any place so that the sign is visible from any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place shall file, in the alternative, either a bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with sureties deemed adequate by the department, conditioned that said person shall pay any lawful claims or judgments for damage sustained by the city due to the existence of such sign or due to the granting of a sign permit, or evidence that the person has in effect public liability insurance protecting the person against such claims or judgments, in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for property damage, with an insurance company qualified to write such insurance under the laws of the state. Said bond or insurance shall be in force while the sign is erected or maintained. Said person shall present evidence at least once each year that said bond or insurance is still in effect. Said bond or evidence of insurance shall be held by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Sec. 70-16. - Future developments. 
Where the owner or developer of a commercial, residential, or other development seeks permission to post signs on such development as part of the approval process, such signs may be approved by the city council, or any other person or body the council shall designate, as part of the normal process for approving design and building plans for new developments under the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 07-21, § 3, 4-17-2007)  
Chapter 74 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; health and sanitation, ch. 38; mobile home parks, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 94. 
State Law reference— Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; power of city to provide for disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 74-1. - Evidentiary presumption. 
The fact that garbage, refuse or ashes remain on any occupant's premises in the city in violation of this article shall be prima facie evidence that the occupant of such premises is responsible for the violation. 
(Code 1980, § 13-19; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 16)  
Sec. 74-2. - Enforcement. 
The commissioner of streets and alleys, or his authorized designee, shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 13-20; Ord. No. 89-37, § 1, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-3. - Notice of violations; correction required. 
If any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be found to exist by the commissioner of streets and alleys, or his authorized designee, after an inspection conducted pursuant to this chapter, the commissioner of streets and alleys, or his authorized designee, shall serve written notice of such violation upon the owner or his agent or the occupant of the premises involved as the case may require. Such notice may be served at the time of inspection or by mail within ten (10) days after the date of such inspection. Such notice, if not served personally, shall be deemed properly served if a copy is sent to such occupant or to the owner, as the case may require it, by U.S. mail at his last known address. The notice shall indicate the provisions of this chapter being violated and may grant a period of time for compliance, which period shall not exceed fifteen (15) days. If such violations have not been eliminated within the time granted, the owner or occupant failing to comply shall be subject to the penalty provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1980, § 13-21; Ord. No. 89-37, § 1, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-4. - Rules and regulations. 
The commissioner of streets and alleys, or his authorized designee, is hereby authorized and empowered to make such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Such rules and regulations may be promulgated from time to time and shall be effective upon approval by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1980, § 13-22; Ord. No. 89-37, § 1, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-5. - Compliance. 
Any person disposing of any garbage, refuse or ashes, except as provided under the Municipal Code of the city, shall be subject to the penalties as provided herein. Any garbage, refuse or ashes which are disposed of within the city in violation of this chapter, and which require the removal and disposal of same by the city, shall subject such person to the reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city for removal and disposal. 
(Code 1980, § 13-23; Ord. No. 89-38, § 1, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-6. - Sharps. 
(a)  Disposal. All medical waste consisting of sharp health care products, including but not limited to, needles, syringes and lancets shall be discarded by placing it in a puncture proof, opaque or colored hard plastic container or metal container, sealed with a tape reinforced lid and clearly marked in large letters "DO NOT RECYCLE," which shall then be clearly separated from recyclable items. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of section. A fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be imposed upon the owner and/or resident of any residential or commercial address found to be in violation of this section. 
(Code 1980, §§ 13-75, 13-76; Ord. No. 99-35, § 1, 6-10-1999)  
Secs. 74-7—74-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-31. - Definitions 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. 
Garbage means the wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food or the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Recyclable materials means the material designated by the commissioner of streets and alleys or his designee, under promulgations and regulations established by him from time to time, a list of which designated materials shall be published and posted in the same manner as ordinances. 
Refuse means combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, grass clippings, garden refuse, wood furniture, bedding; noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, other mineral waste; street rubbish, including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt, contents of litter receptacles. Refuse shall not include earth and wastes from building operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as food processing wastes, boiler house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings. 
(Code 1980, § 13-1; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 1; Ord. No. 80-21, § 1, 8-28-1980; Ord. No. 94-35, § 1, 7-28-1994)  
Sec. 74-32. - Container. 
It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain in any place any garbage or other material subject to decay other than leaves or grass, except in a tightly covered metal container. 
(Code 1980, § 13-2; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 74-33. - Disposal. 
It shall be unlawful to dispose of any garbage, refuse or ashes except in a disposal device, properly constructed and operated, or in a lawfully established garbage or refuse dump. Such material not so properly disposed of shall be placed in containers for collection by the city as prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 13-3; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 6)  
Sec. 74-34. - Dumping on another's property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any premises in the city without the consent of the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1980, § 13-4; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 5)  
Sec. 74-35. - Street deposits. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage, refuse or ashes on any public street or alley in the city; provided, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse or ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this article preparatory to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 13-5; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 4) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78.  
Sec. 74-36. - Uncovered garbage. 
It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the city any garbage or other material subject to decay other than leaves or grass, except in a tightly covered metal or plastic container. 
(Code 1980, § 13-6; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 2; Ord. No. 94-36, § 1, 7-28-1994)  
Sec. 74-37. - Placement of certain windblown refuse in containers. 
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes or trash of such a material that it can be blown away by the wind, except in a covered container. 
(Code 1980, § 13-7; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 3)  
Sec. 74-38. - Burning garbage. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to burn garbage within the city limits. 
(Code 1980, § 13-8; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 13) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30.  
Sec. 74-39. - Size of tree branches. 
All tree branches shall be cut into three (3) foot lengths and bundled with rope or twine and stacked in the alley, if available, or at curbside. Notice to the department of public works of placement of such branches shall be the responsibility of the resident. 
(Code 1980, § 13-9; Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 7-28-1994)  
Sec. 74-40. - Nonresidential users; exemption from fee. 
Whenever any commercial establishment, apartment, restaurant, food dealer, factory, place of public entertainment, or other business place shall produce satisfactory evidence to the commissioner of streets and alleys that garbage, refuse and ashes are being removed from their premises, by privately operated scavenger service or by means other than city employees, then no fee shall be charged by the city to such person for collection. 
(Code 1980, § 13-18; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 12)  
Sec. 74-41. - Termination of service for nonpayment of fee. 
When an occupant of any premises fails to pay the city's fee for removal of garbage, refuse or ashes when due, the commissioner of streets and alleys shall notify the occupant of this act and shall refuse further collection until the required fee is paid. 
(Code 1980, § 13-16; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 16)  
Secs. 74-42—74-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 74-61. - Commissioner of streets and alleys to have charge; number of pickups per week. 
The commissioner of streets and alleys shall have charge of the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes in the city. The collection shall be made from all premises at least once each week, provided that the material is properly stored for collection in a container, complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 13-10; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 7; Ord. of 12-14-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 78-49, § 1, 10-26-1978)  
Sec. 74-62. - Separation of certain items. 
No refuse which is flammable shall be mixed or mingled with refuse that is nonflammable. Garbage shall be kept separate from all other types of refuse. Separate containers shall be provided for each class of garbage or refuse to be collected by the city. Provided, however, that no person shall commingle in said containers garbage and refuse with any yard waste such as grass, leaves, branches and garden waste. Separate containers must be provided for garbage/refuse and yard waste. 
(Code 1980, § 13-11; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 10; Ord. No. 94-38, § 1, 7-28-1994)  
Sec. 74-63. - Containers; size and placement; penalty for violation of section. 
(a)  All garbage, refuse and ashes for collection by the city shall be placed in containers equipped with a cover and equipped with handles so that they may be lifted and carried by one (1) man. No such containers shall have a capacity of less than ten (10) gallons or more than thirty (30) gallons. No commercial establishment, restaurant or food dealer shall provide more than two (2) containers which have a capacity of less than ten (10) gallons nor more than thirty (30) gallons. 
(b)  All containers placed for collection pursuant to this chapter shall be placed in front of the premises, at curbside, where no alley is available. No containers shall be placed for collection prior to 3:30 p.m. on the day before the scheduled pickup, and such containers shall be removed from their collection points by 9:00 a.m. of the day following pickup. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). Each day any violation of any provision of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 13-12; Ord. of 2-27-1964, § 1; Ord. No. 78-49, § 2, 10-26-1978; Ord. No. 88-11, § 1, 6-10-1988; Ord. No. 89-18, § 1, 6-8-1989; Ord. No. 94-39, § 1, 7-28-1994)  
Sec. 74-64. - Recyclable materials. 
(a)  Definition. Recyclables shall mean materials having an economic value in the secondary materials market. The following materials have such economic value: aluminum cans and articles, bi-metal cans, glass containers, corrugated paper (cardboard and paper boxes), magazines, computer printout paper, computer tab cards, office paper, steel cans, newspaper, paper products not chemically coated. 
(b)  Program established. There is hereby established a recycling program for the mandatory separating of recyclables from garbage and rubbish in the city, to be effective as of June 14, 1990. 
(c)  Separation of recyclables and placement for removal. Recyclables shall be prepared and separated from other refuse as required, and shall be collected by the city or under subcontract by its designated agent. Recyclables shall be placed either at the curbside to be collected at times designated by the city or shall be taken to a recycling facility. 
(d)  Time for placement of containers. All containers placed for collection pursuant to this section shall be placed in front of the premises. No containers shall be placed for collection prior to 3:30 p.m. on the day before the scheduled pickup, and such containers shall be removed from their collection points by 9:00 a.m. of the day following pickup. 
(e)  Collection by unauthorized person. 
(1)  From time of placement of recyclable at the curb or in recycling shelters for collection in accordance with the terms thereof, it shall be and become the property of the city or its authorized agent. It shall be a violation of this section for any person unauthorized by the city to collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such items. Any and each such collection in violation hereof from one (1) or more locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as hereinafter provided. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for a person to collect, remove or dispose of solid waste which contains recyclables combined with other forms of solid waste. 
(f)  Additional methods of disposal. Any person may donate or sell recyclables to any other person whether operating for profit or not for profit. 
(g)  Violation and penalty. Any person who violates or neglects to comply with any provision of this section or any regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00), except that the maximum fine for failure to comply with subparagraph (c) hereof shall not exceed ten dollars ($10.00) for the first offense or fifty dollars ($50.00) for any succeeding offense. No enforcement of subparagraph (c) of this section shall be made until six (6) months from the effective date hereof. 
(Code 1980, § 13-15.1; Ord. No. 80-21, §§ 2—5, 8-28-1980; Ord. No. 90-27, § 1, 6-14-1990; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-27-1990)  
Secs. 74-65—74-90. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Fees 
 
Sec. 74-91. - Schedule of fees; exemptions; rate increases. 
(a)  The fees for city garbage, refuse and ash collection shall be paid monthly in advance and shall be as follows: 
Class of User 	Monthly Fee 
Single-family Residence 	$19.72 
Apartment, per unit (not more than four units 	$19.72 per unit 
Apartment, more than four units 	Requires private scavenger 
Commercial establishment, restaurants, food dealers, factories, places of public entertainment and other places of businesses 	Requires private scavenger 
Any person, age 65 years of age as of May 1 of each year, shall pay 50 percent of the current single family residence monthly fee for any single family residence or apartment unit occupied by said person who shall be the owner or lessee of said single-family residence or the owner or lessee of said apartment and shall be the person to whom the bill for water services to said dwelling or apartment is charged, upon furnishing the water billing department such registration certificate, birth certificate or any other document reasonably required in order to show the age of the applicant 	50 percent of current single-family residence fee; for unit occupied by person age 65 years of age by May 1 
 
For all users, the maximum number of weekly pickups shall be one (1). 
(b)  Each single-family resident and apartment unit up to four (4) units will be issued one (1) garbage tote and one (1) recycling tote per unit. Residents requesting additional garbage totes are required to make the request from the garbage/refuse hauler and will be charged by the garbage/refuse hauler. 
(c)  Commencing February 1, 2019, and February 1 of every year thereafter, the refuse rate will automatically be increased and the increase will be based on the garbage/refuse hauler fee charged to the city by the garbage/refuse hauler contracted to provide solid waste collection and removal. 
(Code 1980, § 13-13; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 7; Ord. of 12-14-1967, § 1; Ord. of 11-25-1970, § 1; Ord. No. 78-49, § 1, 10-26-1978; Ord. No. 80-18, § 1, 7-24-1980; Ord. No. 83-2, § 1, 1-27-1983; Ord. No. 87-22, § 1, 10-8-1987; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 90-12, § 1, 3-8-1990; Ord. No. 92-30, § 1, 7-23-1992; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1, 3-10-1994; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 7-27-1995; Ord. No. 18-23, § 2, 6-6-2018)  
Sec. 74-92. - Special fees when normal amounts of garbage are exceeded. 
Whenever the collection of garbage from any establishment or place shall exceed the normal amount for such a place so that the fee prescribed for such collection is not fair and reasonable as applied to that particular place, the commissioner of streets and alleys shall recommend to the city council the establishment of a special rate for such place. 
(Code 1980, § 13-14; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 8)  
Sec. 74-93. - Billing and due date. 
Bills for the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes by the city shall be sent out at such times as may be directed by the city council. They shall be due and payable when the water bill is due and payable. Each bill shall be accompanied by the schedule of collection charges. 
(Code 1980, § 13-15; Ord. of 4-30-1963, § 11)  
Secs. 74-94—74-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SCAVENGERS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 74-111. - Refuse defined. 
The term "refuse" as used in this article shall include, but not be limited to, garbage, such as all animal debris, fruit or vegetable matter and all other substances capable of decay, fermentation or putrefaction, leaves, grass, paper, wastepaper, rags, floor sweepings, tin cans, glassware, crockery, bottles, ashes, cinders, clinkers and other household waste with the exception of stone, dirt or waste material resulting from landscaping and the remodeling of old or construction of new buildings. 
(Code 1980, § 13-31; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 2)  
Sec. 74-112. - Licensee's duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the person holding a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article to comply fully with the provisions of this article and the terms and conditions of any agreement made by said licensee with the city respecting the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes. 
(b)  Each such person and his agents or employees shall do his work with dispatch and in every particular in a manner as cleanly and free from offense and with as little danger or prejudice to life and health as possible and also shall perform the work in such a way that no nuisance will be created thereby. 
(Code 1980, § 13-40; Ord. of 3-19-1970, §§ 1, 10)  
Sec. 74-113. - Collection vehicles. 
(a)  Any person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and ashes in the city shall cause all such vehicles, and all implements used in connection with the loading and unloading hereof, when not in use, to be stored and kept in such place or places and in such manner as not to create a nuisance; and shall cause all such vehicles and implements to be thoroughly disinfected and put in an offensive condition when so stored and not in use. 
(b)  Vehicles used for the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes shall be of the all metal and totally enclosed type. 
(c)  Such vehicles and implements shall be thoroughly disinfected at least once each week, whether in use or not, unless the same shall not have been used since the last disinfection thereof. 
(d)  No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and ashes in the city shall cause or permit any such vehicle to be so loaded, or to be in such defective condition, or to be so out of repair, or to be of such faulty construction, or to be so improperly driven or managed that any garbage, refuse or ashes contained in it shall drop or fall out on any public way or other place in the city. Such vehicle, and any box, can or other receptacle carried therein or thereon, shall be so constructed as to be strong and virtually airtight and watertight so as to prevent any such garbage, refuse or ashes from emitting any odor and so as to prevent any part of the contents or load thereof from falling, leaking or spilling. 
(Code 1980, § 13-41; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 11)  
Sec. 74-114. - Cleanup of items falling from vehicles. 
Every person in possession or control of any vehicle used to collect and remove any garbage, refuse or ashes shall replace at once, on or in such vehicle, any of the contents thereof which fall, drop or spill, or may have fallen, dropped or spilled from such vehicle or any box or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any public way or other place. 
(Code 1980, § 13-42; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 11)  
Sec. 74-115. - Disposal of materials. 
The garbage, refuse or ashes collected and removed by any refuse disposal contractor licensed pursuant to this article shall under no circumstances be disposed of in any place in the city, or within one (1) mile of the corporate limits thereof, except by approval of the city council and subject to all applicable requirements of the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city, and the agencies and instrumentalities thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 13-43; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 12)  
Sec. 74-116. - Refuse containers. 
All refuse containers provided by any refuse disposal contractor licensed pursuant to this article shall be equipped with a cover for health, safety and sanitary conditions. 
(Code 1980, § 13-44; Ord. No. 90-3, § 4, 1-25-1990)  
Secs. 74-117—74-140. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 74-141. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger, or the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse, or offal, or refuse of any kind, without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1980, § 13-32; Ord. of 3-19-1970, §§ 3, 5)  
Sec. 74-142. - Application. 
Every application for the license required by this article shall be made in writing to the city clerk on a form provided for that purpose. Such application shall contain the name of the person desiring the same and the place of business of the applicant. If the applicant is a partnership or firm, the application shall contain the names and addresses of each of its members; if a limited partnership, the names and residence addresses of each general partner thereof; and if a corporation, the names and addresses of the principal officers. 
(Code 1980, § 13-33; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 4)  
Sec. 74-143. - Issuance. 
Every application for a license required by this article shall be transmitted by the city clerk to the city council; no license shall be granted to any applicant therefor, except upon approval of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 13-34; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 5)  
Sec. 74-144. - Fee. 
The annual fee for the issuance or renewal of a license required by this article shall be one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for up to two (2) trucks and the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each additional truck. 
(Code 1980, § 13-36; Ord. of 3-19-1970, §§ 7, 8; Ord. of 12-27-1973, § 4; Ord. No. 90-3, § 2, 1-25-1990; Ord. No. 05-87, § 2, 12-8-2005)  
Sec. 74-145. - Term. 
Every license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall expire at the end of each calendar year. 
(Code 1980, § 13-37; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 7)  
Sec. 74-146. - Compliance with article provisions. 
Every refuse disposal contractor's license issued by the city council shall be subject to the express condition that the licensee shall comply with all of the provisions of this article and such additional requirements as the city may impose from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 13-38; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 5)  
Sec. 74-147. - Insurance coverage required. 
(a)  Certificate of insurance; coverage limits. Every applicant for a license required by this article shall submit satisfactory proof in the form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state showing that the applicant has procured comprehensive public liability insurance fully protecting the city against any loss, damage or liability that may result from the applicant's proposed operations in the city. Such insurance shall provide for limits of coverage of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person, not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury to any group of persons resulting from any one (1) accident and not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to property resulting from any one (1) accident. A copy of said insurance certificate shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Workmen's compensation; occupational disease insurance. The applicant shall also furnish proper proof in the form of a certificate or certificates of insurance issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state, evidencing that said applicant has obtained workmen's compensation and occupational disease insurance fully protecting the city against any and all claims of employees, subcontractors, and other persons, by reason of bodily injury, or death, that may result from the applicant's proposed operations in the city. 
(c)  Expiration dates to be furnished city; notice to city prior to modification or cancellation. The applicant shall also furnish evidence of the expiration dates of the insurance coverages required hereunder, and shall duly certify that such coverages shall not be canceled or modified except upon ten (10) days' prior written notice given to the city. Upon the cancellation, expiration or modification of any coverages required hereunder without prior consent of the city, any license issued pursuant to this article to said applicant shall become void. 
(Code 1980, § 13-39; Ord. of 3-19-1970, § 9; Ord. No. 90-3, § 3, 1-25-1990)  
Secs. 74-148—74-170. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Collection of Rates and Charges 
 
Sec. 74-171. - Owner's failure to pay scavenger. 
Any owner of private rental property who is responsible for payment of scavenger services and refuses to pay for such services resulting in the scavenger's refusal to pick up refuse at that location shall have three (3) days after receiving notice from the city to submit payment to the scavenger. Thereafter, the city may provide for the removal and disposal of refuse and collect from the owner the reasonable cost thereof, which is hereby established at fifteen dollars ($15.00) per can per pickup, two (2) cans required per unit, plus a fifteen (15) percent administrative charge. 
(Code 1980, § 13-45; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998)  
Sec. 74-172. - Notice. 
It shall be the duty of the streets and alleys commissioner or his authorized designee to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner and the city comptroller of any such premises where scavenger service has been halted because of nonpayment of fees. 
(Code 1980, § 13-46; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998; Ord. No. 18-38, § 7, 8-23-2018)  
Sec. 74-173. - Lien. 
If the payment required by section 74-171 is not received by the scavenger within the time specified, the city, after removing and disposing of the uncollected refuse, shall file a notice of lien upon the real estate affected with the county recorder of deeds, superior to all subsequent liens, except tax liens. 
(Code 1980, § 13-47; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998)  
Sec. 74-174. - Notice of lien. 
The notice of lien required by this chapter shall consist of a sworn statement setting out a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service and the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 13-48; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998)  
Sec. 74-175. - Validity of lien. 
The lien provided for by this chapter shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to the removal of refuse and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. 
(Code 1980, § 13-49; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998)  
Sec. 74-176. - Release of lien. 
Upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of, or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien provided for by this chapter shall be released by the city and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(Code 1980, § 13-50; Ord. No. 98-62, § 1, 10-8-1998)  
Secs. 74-177—74-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - SANITARY LANDFILL 
 
Sec. 74-201. - Enforcement. 
The health commissioner of the city is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the standards and regulations as established by this article, and shall make such inspections as may be necessary to see to such enforcement. 
(Code 1980, § 13-63; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 9)  
Sec. 74-202. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall dump or deposit or cause to be dumped or deposited anywhere within the city, any garbage, ashes, refuse, trash, rubbish, miscellaneous waste, manure or other substance that may contain disease germs, or decompose, or become filthy, noxious or unhealthful, except at a sanitary landfill site for which a license has been properly issued by the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Application. Application for such license to operate a sanitary landfill on private property shall be made to the mayor and city council and shall be accompanied by: 
(1)  Written consent of the owner or his authorized agent and evidence of payment of the most recent real estate property tax; 
(2)  An indemnifying bond with good and sufficient sureties in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned that the said applicant will comply with the regulations of this article; 
(3)  A site plan and survey, which shall include a description of the property, the method of operation, the type of available cover, fencing, fire-fighting equipment, access roads, and rodent control measures. 
(c)  Fees. License fees shall be as provided in section 54-881. 
(d)  Issuance. The mayor and city council shall issue a license for a sanitary landfill operation upon application, provided there is compliance with all provisions of this article and all other ordinances of the city applicable thereto. Such license shall be issued subject to the licensee's compliance with the provisions of this article and the plan of operation as submitted by the licensee and approved by the mayor and city council. Prior to the issuance of said license, the mayor and city council may request the investigation and approval by the board of health and building department of the city. 
(Code 1980, §§ 13-55, 13-56, 13-57, 13-1958; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 1—4)  
Sec. 74-203. - Compliance with state department of public health. 
In addition to the requirements set forth in this article, sanitary landfill operations and sites shall comply with all rules and regulations now or hereafter promulgated by the department of public health of the state. 
(Code 1980, § 13-62; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 8)  
Sec. 74-204. - Site requirements. 
Sites for sanitary landfills shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The subsoil structure shall be such that there is reasonable assurance that leachate from the landfill will not contaminate the ground, waters or streams in the area, or that suitable procedures to prevent such contamination will be followed. 
(2)  The surface contour of the area shall be such that surface runoff will not flow into or through the operational or completed fill area. Grading, diking, terracing, diversion ditches, or tiling may be approved when practical. 
(3)  Areas having high groundwater tables may be restricted to landfill operations which will maintain a safe vertical distance between deposited refuse and the maximum water table elevation. Any operation which proposes to deposit refuse within or near the maximum water table elevation shall include corrective or preventive measures which will prevent contamination of the groundwater stratum. Monitoring facilities may be required. 
(Code 1980, § 13-59; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 5)  
Sec. 74-205. - Site improvements. 
Sites of sanitary landfills shall be improved in the following manner: 
(1)  Enclosure. The site shall be enclosed, with an entrance gate that can be locked and posted. 
(2)  Roadways. All-weather operational roads shall be provided for vehicular movement within the site. Separate operational areas may be operated within the site to allow for wet or dry weather operation and access. 
(3)  Facilities. A shelter, convenient for use by operating personnel, shall be furnished. The shelter shall be screened and provided with heating facilities and adequate lighting. Provisions shall also be made for safe drinking water and sanitary hand-washing and toilet facilities. 
(Code 1980, § 13-60; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 6)  
Sec. 74-206. - Method of operation and controls. 
(a)  Unloading. Unloading of refuse on the site shall be confined to the smallest possible area and shall be used when necessary to prevent blowing litter from the unloading site. The fill and surrounding area shall be policed as necessary to collect all scattered material. 
(b)  Equipment. Sufficient equipment in operational condition shall be available at the site at all times to permit operation of the landfill according to the approved plan. 
(c)  Spreading and compacting of refuse. As refuse is admitted to the site, it shall be spread and compacted in layers not to exceed eight (8) feet in compacted depth depending upon the type of material and the compaction equipment. The completed cell shall consist of the refuse admitted and compacted during one (1) working day, regardless of overall height and area covered. 
(d)  Cover. Cover material shall be of such quality as to prevent fly and rodent attraction and breeding, blowing litter, release of odors, fire hazards, and unsightly appearance. Cover shall be applied as follows: 
(1)  Daily cover. A compacted layer of four (4) to six (6) inches of material shall be used to cover all exposed refuse at the end of each working day. 
(2)  Final cover. A compacted layer of eighteen (18) to twenty-four (24) inches of material in addition to the daily cover shall be placed over the entire surface of all compacted portions of the fill. Final cover shall be graded to prevent ponding. The surface of the final cover shall be maintained at the plan elevation at all times, by the placement of additional cover materials where necessary. 
(e)  Vector control. Insect and rodent control measures shall be employed as directed by the commissioner of health. 
(f)  Salvage operations. Salvage operations are not recommended in conjunction with a sanitary landfill. In the event that salvage operations are carried out, the following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  All salvage operations shall be conducted in a sanitary manner. 
(2)  Salvage operations shall be confined to an area remote from the operating face of the fill. 
(3)  Salvage operations shall not interfere with, or otherwise delay the fill operation. 
(4)  All salvaged materials shall be removed from the landfill site daily, or properly stored such that they will not create a nuisance, rodent harborage, or unsightly appearance. 
(g)  Sanitary landfill variation. Large quantities of inorganic and noncombustible waste such as boiler-house cinders, ashes, broken paving, or materials resulting from construction or demolition operations may be disposed of at a sanitary landfill by open dumping, or may be used as cover material. Such material shall be leveled and spread at sufficient intervals to prevent unsightly appearance or rodent harborage, and shall be finally covered as required for a completed sanitary landfill in subsection (f) of this section unless approved plan provides for other cover. 
(h)  Prohibited activities. The following activities shall be prohibited in conjunction with, or upon the site of the sanitary landfill: 
(1)  All scavenging operations. Scavenging shall mean the manual sorting of refuse, either in the trucks, at the face of the fill, or in unconfined truck discharge areas. 
(2)  All feeding of farm domestic animals. 
(3)  Burning, except in an approved incinerator. 
(Code 1980, § 13-61; Ord. of 12-28-1967, § 7)  
Secs. 74-207—74-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - RECYCLING 
 
Sec. 74-231. - Findings. 
After due investigation and consideration, the city council finds that it is in the best interest of the health and welfare of the residents of the city that the city reduce its reliance on landfills and avoid the use of incineration as a means of permanent disposal of refuse, in order to restrict the burial of potentially harmful substances in soil and the release of such substances and their byproducts into groundwater, surrounding soil and the atmosphere. 
(Code 1980, § 13-71; Ord. No. 89-35, § 1, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-232. - Recycling coordinator. 
The mayor shall appoint a recycling coordinator, within forty-five (45) days of adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived, who shall serve as a member of the mayor's administrative staff and report directly to the mayor. The mayor shall provide for adequate budget to fulfill to requirements of this section. The recycling coordinator shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  To develop an educational and promotional program on the methods and benefits of recycling by residents and business operators; 
(2)  To develop methods of adherence to the goals stated in this article for recycling activities, and to coordinate and supervise implementation of those methods; 
(3)  To coordinate and monitor the activities of curbside collection of recyclable materials and buyback facilities dealing in such materials throughout the city; 
(4)  To identify potential markets for recyclable materials; and 
(5)  To submit, on September 1 of each year, to the mayor and the city council, an annual report on recycling activities in the city, with special emphasis on activities performed or sponsored by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 13-72; Ord. No. 89-35, § 2, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-233. - Regular recycling service. 
(a)  Established. On or before January 1, 1993, the city shall provide regular recycling service to one hundred (100) percent of the households in low-density dwellings. This service shall provide sufficient recycling capacity to meet the disposal needs of the included residents with respect to the designated materials and shall be designed so as to assure reasonable ease of access to the regular recycling services for all included residents. "Regular recycling service" shall mean the collection of at least three (3) materials by one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  Weekly alley or curbside collection of recyclable materials by the city or by a private for-profit or nonprofit collection service; 
(2)  A buyback center within one (1) mile of any building not receiving curbside or alley collection; 
(3)  Drop-off boxes arranged in a network, no more than two (2) city blocks distant from each other, for deposit of recyclable materials. 
(b)  Implementation. The regular recycling service shall be implemented in stages, as follows: 
(1)  By January 1, 1991, no less than fifty (50) percent of the households in low-density dwellings shall have regular recycling service. 
(2)  By January 1, 1993, all households in low-density dwellings shall have regular recycling service. 
(c)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the term "low density dwellings" means single-family residences and apartment buildings containing six or less residential units. The term "recyclable materials" means any of the following: newsprint, aluminum cans, steel cans, glass bottles and jars, and plastic containers. 
(Code 1980, § 13-73; Ord. No. 89-35, § 3, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 74-234. - Restrictions on transporting and delivering municipal refuse. 
Municipal refuse collected by the city or private haulers under contract with the city shall not be transported or delivered to a municipal refuse incinerator, refuse-derived fuel incinerator or mixed refuse processing facility that produces refuse-derived fuel. 
(Code 1980, § 13-74; Ord. No. 89-35, § 4, 10-26-1989)  
Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Commissioner of streets and alleys, § 2-461 et seq.; board of local improvements, § 2-841 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; house moving, § 14-961 et seq.; community development, ch. 18; environment, ch. 26; floods, ch. 34; library, ch. 50; streets show, § 54-83; solicitation, § 54-1011 et seq.; solicitors, § 54-2121 et seq.; mobile home parks, ch. 58; streets in mobile home parks, § 58-171 et seq.; carrying or discharging air rifles on public streets, § 62-214; planning, ch. 66; signs, ch. 70; street deposits of solid waste, § 74-35; telecommunications, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90; right-of-way; yield streets and stop streets, § 90-211 et seq.; utilities, ch. 94; vehicles for hire, ch. 98; subdivisions, app. A; zoning, app. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Veteran's Way. 
That portion of Schrum Road from Wentworth Avenue to 159th Street, River Oaks Drive shall hereinafter be referred to as "Veteran's Way." 
(Code 1980, § 17-117; Ord. No. 99-29, § 1, 5-27-1999)  
Secs. 78-2—78-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DRIVEWAYS 
 
Sec. 78-31. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall construct a driveway for vehicles or animals across any sidewalk in the city without a permit therefor. 
(b)  Application. An application for a permit required by this article shall be made to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by the required fee. 
(c)  Issuance restrictions. No permit for construction of a driveway for commercial use, or for the habitual use of other than the owner or occupant of the premises served shall be issued except upon the order of the city council. All permits shall be subject to approval of the commissioner of streets and alleys. 
(d)  Fee. The fee for the permit required by this article shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1980, §§ 25-18, 25-19, 25-20, 25-21)  
Sec. 78-32. - Specifications. 
Driveways shall be constructed in such a manner that they are as flat as possible. A low area should be pitched toward the inside rather than the outside. The pitch should be four (4) inches for every twenty-five (25) feet, approximately, which pitch is to be maintained from either the middle or from the rear of the building or structure; provided, however, in the event any objection is raised in connection with a proposed driveway, that the building commissioner shall report said objection to city council for its determination. 
(Code 1980, § 25-22; Ord. of 4-25-1974, § 1)  
Sec. 78-33. - Grade surfaces. 
No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp depression or other obstruction on the sidewalk. The grade shall be as nearly as possible the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk. It shall be unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway where the same crosses the sidewalk constructed of such materials as to render it slippery or hazardous to pedestrians, or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk, or be other than level. 
(Code 1980, § 25-23)  
Sec. 78-34. - Repair. 
It shall be the duty of the person maintaining the driveway to keep the driveway in good repair where it crosses the sidewalk, and free from obstruction and openings. 
(Code 1980, § 25-24)  
Secs. 78-35—78-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND OVERSIZE VEHICLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-71. - Provisions declared supplemental. 
The provisions of this article shall be in addition and supplemental to all other provisions of this Code and ordinances. 
(Code 1980, § 25-36)  
Sec. 78-72. - Regulations authorized. 
In granting a permit required by this article, the commissioner of streets and alleys may impose reasonable regulations, including but not limited to: 
(1)  The manner of making the excavation, boring or tunneling. 
(2)  The location of the excavation, boring or tunneling. 
(3)  Protection of underground utility installations. 
(4)  The duration of the excavation, boring or tunneling. 
(5)  Required safety precautions, such as barricades, lighting, warning devices, etc. 
(6)  The extent and size of the excavation, boring or tunneling. 
(7)  Steps to be taken to protect nearby property owners. 
(Code 1980, § 25-42)  
Sec. 78-73. - Utilities. 
The applicant for the permit required by this article shall also show that the applicant has contacted all operators of gas, electric, telephone, water, sewer or any other public utility service in the area, as well as the city itself to receive from them the information as to the existence and location of any underground facilities, so that the proper precautions can be taken to avoid accidents through damage to the underground structures. 
(Code 1980, § 25-41; Ord. of 11-26-1963, § 3)  
Secs. 78-74—78-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 78-91. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commence work on any excavation, or on any construction work involving driving or hauling machinery, trucks or equipment over any parkway or sidewalk area or involving excavating or leveling of any parkway or sidewalk area without a permit issued by the commissioner of streets and alleys. 
(Code 1980, § 25-37; Ord. of 11-26-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 78-92. - Application—Filing; contents. 
The applicant for a permit required by this article shall file an application with the commissioner of streets and alleys. This application shall clearly set out the purpose of the excavation, location of excavation, size of the opening, type of pavement (if any) to be removed, and approximate length of time excavation will remain open. 
(Code 1980, § 25-38; Ord. of 11-26-1963, § 2)  
Sec. 78-93. - Same—Duplicate. 
A duplicate copy of the approved application for making the permit required by this article shall be made a part of the permanent city records. 
(Code 1980, § 25-39; Ord. of 11-26-1963, § 4)  
Sec. 78-94. - Deposit and inspection fees. 
(a)  Every person desiring the permit required by the provisions of this article shall make a deposit with the city in an amount to be determined as follows: 
(1)  For each opening in Sealkote pavement ..... $100.00 
(2)  For each opening in asphalt pavement ..... 150.00 
(3)  For each opening in concrete ..... 200.00 
(4)  For each opening in concrete sidewalk ..... 50.00 
(b)  A five dollar ($5.00) inspection fee shall be charged against each deposit. No refund shall be issued of any deposit made hereunder unless the commissioner of streets and alleys recommends said refund to the city council and the city council approves of his recommendation to refund said deposit. 
(Code 1980, § 25-40; Ord. of 10-26-1972, § 1)  
Sec. 78-95. - Bond. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commence work on any excavation, or on any construction work involving driving or hauling machinery, trucks or equipment over any parkway or sidewalk area or involving excavating or leveling of any parkway or sidewalk area, unless the person doing such work shall first have filed with the city a bond, with corporate surety, conditioned to indemnify the city for any damages done to any city property, including any curb, pavement, cable, pipe, shut-off box or other equipment, in the course of such work. 
(b)  Where the work contemplated includes the making of any excavation for any structure or foundation, the bond shall also be conditioned that the building or structure contemplated shall be completed within one (1) year from the date of commencement of work or the excavation refilled and the surface restored to its original condition. 
(Code 1980, § 25-43; Ord. of 5-8-1958, § 21)  
Sec. 78-96. - Assets or insurance required. 
When required by the commissioner of streets and alleys the applicant for a permit under this article shall submit satisfactory evidence that he has sufficient assets or insurance to indemnify the city for any costs, losses or liabilities that it may incur by reason of such excavation, and to satisfy any judgments or liabilities arising out of the excavation. 
(Code 1980, § 25-44)  
Sec. 78-97. - Permit revocation. 
In addition to any other penalty imposed by law, any person violating any provision of this article shall have his excavation permit revoked. 
(Code 1980, § 25-46)  
Secs. 78-98—78-130. - Reserved.

(Code 1980, § 25-58; Ord. of 11-21-73, § 1)

(Code 1980, § 25-59; Ord. of 9-14-1972, §§ 1, 2)  
Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-881 et seq.; licenses and permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 54. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 82-1—82-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TAX PROCEDURES AND TAXPAYERS' RIGHTS 
 
Sec. 82-31. - Title. 
This article shall be known as, and may be cited as, the "Locally Imposed and Administered Tax Rights and Responsibility Ordinance." 
(Code 1980, § 26-201; Ord. No. 00-81, § 1, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-32. - Scope. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to the city's procedures in connection with all of the city's locally imposed and administered taxes. 
(Code 1980, § 26-202; Ord. No. 00-81, § 2, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-33. - Definitions. 
Certain words or terms herein shall have the meaning ascribed to them as follows: 
Act means the "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act." 
City means the City of Calumet City, Illinois. 
Corporate authorities means the city's mayor and city council. 
Local tax administrator shall refer to the city clerk who is charged with the administration and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes, including staff, employees or agents to the extent they are authorized by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax administrator's stead. The local tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the terms of this article to give full effect to this article. The exercise of such authority by the local tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this article and the act. 
Locally imposed and administered tax or tax means each tax imposed by the city that is collected or administered by the city and not an agency or department of the state. It does not include any taxes imposed upon real property under the property tax code or fees collected by the city other than infrastructure maintenance fees. 
Notice means each audit notice, collection notice or other similar notice or communication in connection with each of the city's locally imposed and administered taxes. 
Tax ordinance means each ordinance adopted by the city that imposes any locally imposed and administered tax. 
Taxpayer means any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax is placed and with respect to consumer taxes includes the business or entity required to collect and pay the locally imposed and administered tax to the city. 
(Code 1980, § 26-203; Ord. No. 00-81, § 3, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-34. - Notices. 
Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the notice is to be in writing mailed not less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the day fixed for any applicable hearing, audit or other scheduled act of the local tax administrator. The notice shall be sent by the local tax administrator as follows: 
(1)  First class or express mail, or overnight mail, addressed to the persons concerned at the persons' last known address, or 
(2)  Personal service or delivery. 
(Code 1980, § 26-204; Ord. No. 00-81, § 4, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-35. - Late payment. 
Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made to the city pursuant to any tax ordinance shall be considered late unless it is: 
(1)  Physically received by the city on or before the due date; or 
(2)  Received in an envelope or other container displaying a valid, readable U.S. postmark dated on or before the due date, properly addressed to the city, with adequate postage prepaid. 
(Code 1980, § 26-205; Ord. No. 00-81, § 5, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-36. - Payment. 
Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in the following order: 
(1)  First to the tax due for the applicable period; 
(2)  Second to the interest due for the applicable period; and 
(3)  Third to the penalty for the applicable period. 
(Code 1980, § 26-206; Ord. No. 00-81, § 6, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-37. - Certain credits and refunds. 
(a)  The city shall not refund or credit any taxes voluntarily paid without written protest at the time of payment in the event that a locally imposed and administered tax is declared invalidly enacted or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction. However, a taxpayer shall not be deemed to have paid the tax voluntarily if the taxpayer lacked knowledge of the facts upon which to protest the taxes at the time of payment or if the taxpayer paid the taxes under duress. 
(b)  The statute of limitations on a claim for credit or refund shall be four (4) years after the end of the calendar year in which payment in error was made. The city shall not grant a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest, or penalties to a person who has not paid the amounts directly to the city. 
(c)  The procedure for claiming a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest or penalties paid in error shall be as follows: 
(1)  The taxpayer shall submit to the local tax administrator in writing a claim for credit or refund together with a statement specifying: 
a.  The name of the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim; 
b.  The tax period for the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim; 
c.  The date of the tax payment subject to the claim and the canceled check or receipt for the payment; 
d.  The taxpayer's recalculation, accompanied by an amended or revised tax return, in connection with the claim; and 
e.  A request for either a refund or a credit in connection with the claim to be applied to the amount owed, and, as applicable, related interest and penalties; provided, however, that there shall be no refund and only a credit given in the event the taxpayer owes any monies to the city. 
(2)  Within ten (10) calendar days of the receipt by the local tax administrator of any claim for a refund or credit, the local tax administrator shall either: 
a.  Grant the claim; or 
b.  Deny the claim, in whole or in part, together with a statement as to the reason for the denial or the partial grant and denial. 
(3)  In the event the local tax administrator grants, in whole or in part, a claim for refund or credit, the amount of the grant for refund or credit shall bear interest at the rate of four (4) percent per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty-five (365) days and the number of days elapsed, from the date of the overpayment to the date of mailing of a refund check or the grant of a credit. 
(Code 1980, § 26-207; Ord. No. 00-81, § 7, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-38. - Audit procedure. 
Any request for proposed audit pursuant to any local administered tax shall comply with the notice requirements of this article. 
(1)  Each notice of audit shall contain the following information: 
a.  The tax; 
b.  The time period of the audit; and 
c.  A brief description of the books and records to be made available for the auditor. 
(2)  Any audit shall be conducted during normal business hours and if the date and time selected by the local tax administrator is not agreeable to the taxpayer, another date and time may be requested by the taxpayer within thirty (30) calendar days after the originally designated audit and during normal business hours. 
(3)  The taxpayer may request an extension of time to have an audit conducted. The audit shall be conducted not less than seven (7) calendar days nor more than thirty (30) calendar days from the date the notice is given, unless the taxpayer and the local tax administrator agreed to some other convenient time. In the event taxpayer is unable to comply with the audit on the date in question, the taxpayer may request another date within the thirty (30) calendar days, approved in writing, that is convenient to the taxpayer and the local tax administrator. 
(4)  Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the taxpayer's business or activities, including original source documents and books of entry denoting the transactions which had given rise or may have given rise to any tax liability, exemption or deduction. All book shall be kept in the English language and shall be subject to and available for inspection by the city. 
(5)  It is the duty and responsibility of every taxpayer to make available its books and records for inspection by the city. If the taxpayer fails to provide the documents necessary for audit within the time provided, the local tax administrator may issue a tax determination and assessment based on the best estimate of the taxpayer's tax liability. 
(6)  If an audit determines there has been an overpayment of a locally imposed and administered tax as a result of the audit, written notice of the amount of overpayment shall be given to the taxpayer within thirty (30) calendar days of the city's determination of the amount of overpayment. 
(7)  In the event a tax payment was submitted to the incorrect local governmental entity, the local tax administrator shall notify the local governmental entity imposing such tax. 
(Code 1980, § 26-208; Ord. No. 00-81, § 8, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-39. - Appeal. 
(a)  The local tax administrator shall send written notice to a taxpayer upon the local tax administrator's issuance of a protestable notice of tax due, a bill, a claim denial, or a notice of claim reduction regarding any tax. The notice shall include the following information: 
(1)  The reason for the assessment; 
(2)  The amount of the tax liability proposed; 
(3)  The procedure for appealing the assessment; and 
(4)  The obligations of the city during the audit, appeal, refund and collection process. 
(b)  A taxpayer who receives written notice from the local tax administrator of a determination of tax due or assessment may file with the local tax administrator a written protest and petition for hearing, setting forth the basis of the taxpayer's request for a hearing. The written protest and petition for hearing must be filed with the local tax administrator within forty-five (45) days of receipt of the written notice of the tax determination and assessment. 
(c)  If a timely written notice and petition for hearing is filed, the local tax administrator shall fix the time and place for hearing and shall give written notice to the taxpayer. The hearing shall be scheduled for a date within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the written protest and petition for hearing, unless the taxpayer requests a later date convenient to all parties. 
(d)  If a written protest and petition for hearing is not filed within the forty-five (45) day period, the tax determination, audit or assessment shall become a final bill due and owing without further notice. 
(e)  Upon the showing of reasonable cause by the taxpayer and the full payment of the contested tax liability along with interest accrued as of the due date of the tax, the local tax administrator may reopen or extend the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing. In no event shall the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing be reopened or extended for more than ninety (90) days after the expiration of the forty-five (45) day period. 
(Code 1980, § 26-209; Ord. No. 00-81, § 9, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-40. - Hearing. 
(a)  Whenever a taxpayer or a tax collector has filed a timely written protest and petition for hearing under section 82-39, the local tax administrator shall conduct a hearing regarding any appeal. 
(b)  No continuances shall be granted except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the taxpayer. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance granted shall not exceed fourteen (14) calendar days. 
(c)  At the hearing the local tax administrator shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the tax determination, audit or assessment. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the local tax administrator shall make a written determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing. The taxpayer or tax collector shall be provided with a copy of the written decision. 
(Code 1980, § 26-210; Ord. No. 00-81, § 10, 12-14-2000)  
Sec. 82-41. - Interest and penalties. 
In the event a determination has been made that a tax is due and owing, through audit, assessment or other bill sent, the tax must be paid within the time frame otherwise indicated. 
(1)  Interest. The city hereby provides for the amount of interest to be assessed on a late payment, underpayment or nonpayment of the tax, to be ten (10) percent per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty-five (365) days and the number of days elapsed. 
(2)  Late filing and payment penalties.
