No. 19-04, § 1, 1-24-2019)  
Sec. 90-318. - Residential district; commercial and recreational vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, and the interpretation and application thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words or phrases not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Commercial vehicle means a vehicle which has a gross weight in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds, represented by "C" license plates or above, used primarily for commercial or business purposes, including vehicles for transporting more than seven (7) persons; semitrailers with tractors attached or tractors alone, bus or school bus; tow trucks; truck with snow plow attached; special hauling vehicles and tank vehicles. 
Recreational vehicle means any motor home, camper, boat, trailers including house, boat or camping trailers which are self-propelled or not self-propelled; recreational vehicle with a height of six (6) feet, eight (8) inches and/or length of eighteen (18) feet, or trailer licensed to transport recreational vehicle or equipment. 
(b)  Regulations. No person shall park or allow to remain standing a commercial or recreational vehicle upon any street or public right-of-way within a residential district or within three hundred (300) feet of the property line of a residence located within such district, except as follows: 
(1)  While expeditiously loading or unloading passengers, freight, materials or merchandise between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.; 
(2)  While effecting emergency repairs when a vehicle is so disabled as to render it unsafe to proceed further; 
(3)  Vehicles and equipment engaged in street construction, maintenance and repair or construction, maintenance or repair of public service utilities; and 
(4)  Vehicles serving as emergency vehicles. 
(c)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to church, school, nursing and retirement home or government vehicles owned by such entities or institutions. 
(Code 1980, § 17-139; Ord. No. 88-8, § 1, 5-26-1988; Ord. No. 08-56, §;s 2, 3, 8-14-2008)  
Sec. 90-319. - Recreational vehicles; location limitations. 
Recreational vehicles may be kept and stored on premises in the city, including residential premises, provided that such recreational vehicles are not occupied for living quarters; and further provided that in areas zoned residential such recreational vehicles are owned or leased to and used by the owner or tenant of the premises; provided further that such recreational vehicles may not be stored in a location closer to the front line than the living area excluding garages of the principal building on said premises and shall be no closer to the side and rear lot lines than building restrictions applicable to the lot in question. 
(Code 1980, § 17-140; Ord. No. 88-8, § 1, 5-26-1988)  
Sec. 90-320. - Parking in yards in residential zone. 
No vehicle which has a gross weight in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds, represented by "C" license plates or above, used primarily for commercial or business purposes, including vehicles for transporting more than seven (7) persons; semitrailers with tractors attached or tractors alone, nor any airplane, boat or trailer shall be parked or stored in a location closer to the front lot line than the living area, excluding garages of the principal building on said premises, and shall be no closer to the side and rear lot lines than the building restrictions applicable to the lot lines than the building restrictions applicable to the lot in question or the side yard facing a street on a corner or reverse corner lot in a residential zone except: Motor vehicles as hereinabove defined may be parked on permanently constructed driveways within such front or side yards for reasonably expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicles. 
(Code 1980, § 17-141; Ord. No. 88-8, § 1, 5-26-1988)  
Sec. 90-321. - Repair of motor vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, and the interpretation and application thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words or phrases not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Repair or maintenance means body work, engine work, washing engines, lubricant changes and parts changes or installation but does not include washing and waxing the exterior or interior of a vehicle. 
Residential property means private residential property, including all property used, in whole or in part, for residential purposes, but excluding a residential garage for the accommodation of a vehicle. 
Right-of-way means public right-of-way including streets, alleys, parkways, sidewalks and property owned by the city. 
(b)  Regulations. 
(1)  Repair or maintenance of a vehicle is prohibited on the right-of-way, unless immediate repairs are necessary to make the vehicle operable but no later than twenty-four (24) hours after said vehicle has stopped working at that place. No vehicle shall be towed or driven to any right-of-way for the purpose of repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Repair or maintenance of a vehicle is prohibited on residential property, except on a vehicle owned by the occupant thereof and bearing valid state registration plates and a current city vehicle sticker evidencing that the vehicle is registered at that address. No person may repair or maintain a vehicle of others on their residential property whether for compensation or not. 
(Ord. No. 08-51, § 2, 7-24-2008)  
Sec. 90-322. - Curb parking prohibited. 
No person shall stand or park a vehicle in any of the following places: On a sidewalk, curb, parkway, catwalk, street lawn area, unpaved or unfinished surface. 
(Ord. No. 08-42, § 2, 7-10-2008)  
Secs. 90-323—90-340. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - METERED PARKING 
 
Sec. 90-341. - Definitions. 
The terms used in this article shall have the following meanings ascribed to them: 
Parking meter means a mechanical device intended to assist public authorities in enforcing the provisions of this article, limiting the time during which vehicles may be parked on any street or highway within a parking meter zone. 
Parking meter zone means a street or highway or portions thereof, on which parking meters are installed, operated and used pursuant to an ordinance passed by the city council. 
Vehicle means any conveyance of any character for the transportation of persons or property. 
(Code 1980, § 17-148; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 2)  
Sec. 90-342. - When article applies. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply on Sundays and legal holidays. 
(Code 1980, § 17-149; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 4)  
Sec. 90-343. - Meters and spaces. 
(a)  Parking meters shall be placed upon the sidewalk or curb immediately adjacent or next to each designated parking space in all parking meter zones and in such manner as to show or display by a signal that the parking space controlled by such meter is not legally occupied. Each parking meter shall indicate by a proper legend the established rate and the legal parking time and, when in operation, shall also indicate on or by its dial or pointer the duration of the period of legal parking and any illegal or overparking. 
(b)  All parking spaces shall be plainly marked by lines on the street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-150; Ord. of 4-12-1951, §§ 6, 7)  
Sec. 90-344. - Parking within lines required. 
Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle parked in any parking meter zone shall be entirely within the lines of the designated parking space and adjacent to the parking meter controlling such parking space. 
(Code 1980, § 17-151; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 8)  
Sec. 90-345. - Coins. 
Except as otherwise provided, upon parking any vehicle in a parking meter zone, the operator of the parked vehicle shall deposit, or cause to be deposited immediately after parking, either a one-cent ($0.01) coin or two (2) one-cent ($0.01) coins or three (3) one-cent ($0.01) coins or four (4) one-cent ($0.01) coins or five (5) one-cent ($0.01) coins or a five-cent ($0.05) coin, and, in like manner, up to ten (10) one-cent ($0.01) coins or two (2) five-cent ($0.05) coins of the United States of America in the parking meter controlling such parking space. The deposit of each one-cent ($0.01) coin shall entitle the vehicle to occupy said space for a period not to exceed twelve (12) minutes immediately following such deposit and an additional twelve (12) minutes for each additional one-cent ($0.01) coin so deposited, not however, to exceed ten (10) such coins; the deposit of a five-cent ($0.05) coin shall entitle the vehicle to occupy said space for a period not to exceed one (1) hour immediately following such deposit, and the deposit of two (2) five-cent ($0.05) coins shall entitle the vehicle to occupy said space for a period not to exceed two (2) hours immediately following such deposit, with five (5) hours for a twenty-five-cent ($0.25) coin. 
(Code 1980, § 17-152; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 9)  
Sec. 90-346. - Use of funds. 
The coins required by this article to be deposited are levied and assessed as fees to provide for the proper regulation and control of traffic upon the highways, including the cost of supervising and regulating the parking of vehicles in the parking meter zones herein created and the cost of the purchase, supervision, inspection, installation, operation, maintenance, control and use of the aforesaid parking meters. The coins so required to be deposited shall be collected and accounted for under the direction of the finance committee of council, and deposited in the city's general fund. 
(Code 1980, § 17-153; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 10)  
Sec. 90-347. - Maximum parking. 
Except as otherwise provided, no person shall park any vehicle in a parking meter zone for a period of time longer than indicated by signs posted in said zones or on the meters located therein. 
(Code 1980, § 17-154)  
Sec. 90-348. - Overtime parking; violations generally. 
No owner or operator of any vehicle shall cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked overtime or beyond the period of the legal parking time established and set forth in this article, nor shall he cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked in any manner contrary to the manner prescribed by this article. 
(Code 1980, § 17-155; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 11)  
Sec. 90-349. - Slugs. 
No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter, any slug device, foreign substance or substitute for a coin of the United States. 
(Code 1980, § 17-156; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 12)  
Sec. 90-350. - Injuring meters. 
No person shall deface, injure, tamper with, or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter. 
(Code 1980, § 17-157; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 13)  
Sec. 90-351. - Free parking. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the city from providing for free parking space for unloading commercial vehicles, for bus stops, for taxicabs stands, or for other matters of a similar nature; provided further, that the mayor shall have authority to provide for, and issue free parking space privileges to members of the press, physicians and to city residents who reside in parking meter areas, upon the express condition, however, that such free parking privileges for residents shall be restricted to the block in which such resident resides, and otherwise shall be of no force and effect. 
(Code 1980, § 17-158; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 14; Ord. of 12-10-1953, § 1)  
Sec. 90-352. - Violation ticket; notice of violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police department, acting in accordance with instructions issued by the chief of police, to deposit with the desk sergeant, the stub of every violation ticket issued pursuant to this article. Such stub shall contain: 
(1)  The number of the parking meter adjacent to the vehicle which was parked in violation of this article. 
(2)  The state license number of such vehicle. 
(3)  The day and hour at which such vehicle was parked in violation of this article. 
(4)  Any other facts which the officer deems necessary to properly understand the circumstances of the violation. 
(b)  Every such police officer shall also place on such vehicle a notice to the owner thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of the provisions of this article and instructing such owner to report to the office of the police department, or such authority as the chief of police may designate, in regard to such violation. 
(Code 1980, § 17-159; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 16; Ord. of 10-8-1953, § 1)  
Sec. 90-353. - Enforcing authority. 
The duties of enforcing the provisions of this article shall be upon the police department. 
(Code 1980, § 17-160; Ord. of 4-12-1951, § 15)  
Secs. 90-354—90-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES AND TOY VEHICLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 90-421. - Passengers on bicycles and motorcycles. 
It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride upon any bicycle propelled by human power upon any street, or for any person to ride upon any motorcycle other than upon a seat permanently attached to said vehicle to the right or rear of the operator. 
(Code 1980, § 17-104)  
Sec. 90-422. - Clinging to vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person on any street riding a bicycle, motorcycle or any toy vehicle to cling to or attach himself or his vehicle to any moving motor vehicle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-105)  
Sec. 90-423. - Toy vehicles on roadways. 
It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle to go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. 
(Code 1980, § 17-106)  
Sec. 90-424. - Skateboards. 
(a)  Skateboard shall mean a single platform mounted on wheels, which is propelled solely by human power and which has no mechanism or other device with which to steer or to control the movement or direction of the platform. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, upon a skateboard, to go upon, remain or travel upon any roadway or street within the city other than at a crosswalk in a reckless manner. 
(c)  Skateboarding shall be prohibited upon any sidewalk in any portion of the city designated as a commercial district. Skateboarding shall be permitted on bike paths and all other sidewalks within the city. Skateboarding may be prohibited in the parking lots of any schools, and commercial areas, provided that appropriate signs are posted within said areas. 
(d)  Skateboard operators shall be classified as pedestrians, but shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles and to all other pedestrians (nonskateboard) traffic upon the sidewalk, street or bike path. 
(e)  No more than one (1) person shall operate or ride on a skateboard at one time. 
(f)  Any person operating a skateboard in a residential area of the city in violation of this section shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  Issuance of a warning ticket upon a first offense; 
(2)  A fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a second offense; and 
(3)  A fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each and every offense thereafter. 
(g)  Any person operating a skateboard in a commercial area of the city in violation of this section shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  A fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a first offense and 
(2)  A fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each and every offense thereafter. 
(Code 1980, § 17-110; Ord. No. 90-26, § 1, 6-14-1990)  
Secs. 90-425—90-450. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLES  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 90-451. - Parental responsibility. 
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 17-191)  
Sec. 90-452. - Applicability of traffic ordinances. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this article and those provisions in the ordinances which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1980, § 17-192)  
Sec. 90-453. - Obedience to devices. 
Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official traffic-control signals, signs and devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Code 1980, § 17-193)  
Sec. 90-454. - Riding abreast. 
When more than two (2) persons in a group are operating bicycles on a roadway they shall ride single file. 
(Code 1980, § 17-194)  
Sec. 90-455. - Clinging to vehicles. 
No person operating a bicycle shall cling or attach himself, or the bicycle, to any other moving vehicle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-195)  
Sec. 90-456. - Extra passenger. 
No person operating a bicycle shall carry another person on the handlebars of such bicycle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-196)  
Sec. 90-457. - Speed. 
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1980, § 17-197)  
Sec. 90-458. - Duty to keep to right. 
Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right-hand side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(Code 1980, § 17-198)  
Sec. 90-459. - Emerging from alley, driveways and garages. 
The operator of a bicycle emerging from any driveway, garage or private sidewalk, shall stop the bicycle immediately prior to driving onto or across a public sidewalk, or onto or across a public sidewalk line projected across an alley, and shall exercise extreme care in making such movements. 
(Code 1980, § 17-199)  
Sec. 90-460. - Intoxication, drugs; physical inability. 
No person shall operate a bicycle while under the influence of liquor, or drugs, or while physically or mentally unfit to safely operate the same. 
(Code 1980, § 17-200)  
Sec. 90-461. - Operation on sidewalks. 
Bicycles may be operated on sidewalks in public parks and in residence districts, but in single file only. Under all circumstances, the rider shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians using the sidewalk, and due and proper care shall at all times be exercised by the rider for the pedestrians. When approaching a pedestrian on the sidewalk the speed of a bicycle shall be reduced to a speed which is no greater than necessary to continue the operation of the bicycle without the rider dismounting. Bicycles shall not be operated upon any sidewalk in the business portion of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 17-201)  
Sec. 90-462. - Parking. 
(a)  Bicycles, when parked in the business district, shall be parked in zones or places designated and marked for that purpose. It shall be unlawful to park any bicycle along buildings in such a manner as to interfere with traffic, or with persons getting into or out of motor vehicles. 
(b)  No person other than the owner or operator shall move, or in any manner interfere with, any bicycle properly parked, nor shall any person interfere or in any manner hinder any person from properly parking a bicycle, except members of the police department and fire department may move, or, in proper cases, prevent the parking of the bicycle, when in the judgment of the policeman or fireman, his action is necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property. 
(Code 1980, § 17-202)  
Sec. 90-463. - Trick riding. 
No person shall, while operating a bicycle, indulge or engage in any kind of trick or unsafe riding. 
(Code 1980, § 17-203)  
Sec. 90-464. - Turns; proper signals. 
The operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when making a right turn shall follow the right-hand edge of the roadway, and the operator of a bicycle on a roadway when making a left turn shall approach the point of turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway. No operator of a bicycle shall start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn without first indicating such movement as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 17-204)  
Sec. 90-465. - Mechanical condition. 
No person shall operate a bicycle which is not in such mechanical condition so that it can be safely operated. 
(Code 1980, § 17-206)  
Secs. 90-466—90-490. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - License 
 
Sec. 90-491. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle upon any street, sidewalk or other public place in the city without having first registered such bicycle and secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1970, § 19.201; Code 1980, § 17-208)  
Sec. 90-492. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  An application for a bicycle license shall be made by the owner upon duplicate forms furnished by the city clerk. The owner shall give the information required on such forms. 
(b)  Such application shall be presented to the chief of police. The bicycle to be registered and licensed shall be brought to the police station at the time of presenting the application for the purpose of examination. 
(c)  The chief of police or some person authorized by him shall examine the bicycle and if he finds the mechanical condition thereof such that it can be safely operated, and that it is equipped with the lights and attachments as herein provided, and further finds that the statements made in the application are true, he shall mark the application and duplicate "approved," attach his signature, and return the same to the applicant. The applicant shall thereupon file the application with the city clerk and pay an annual license fee of fifty cents ($0.50). 
(d)  The city clerk shall, upon receiving such application and license fee, issue to the owner of the bicycle a registration card which shall contain the name and address of the owner and the description of the bicycle contained in the application. The applicant shall affix his signature to the registration card when issued in the presence of the city clerk, who shall, with said certificate, also issue to the owner a metal license plate which shall contain the words "Calumet City" and the number of the license, and indicate the year of issuance. The registration card and the license plate shall have the same number. The license plate shall be attached to the bicycle on the front thereof immediately below the steering bar or wheel. 
(e)  After the issuance of the registration card and plate, the city clerk shall endorse upon the application, and the duplicate, the date of issuance and the number thereof; the original application shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the duplicate thereof shall be delivered to the chief of police, and shall be kept on file in his office. 
(Code 1970, § 19.202; Code 1980, § 17-209)  
Sec. 90-493. - Term. 
The license so issued shall be effective for one (1) year. The license year shall be from January 1 to December 31. 
(Code 1970, § 19.203; Code 1980, § 17-210)  
Sec. 90-494. - Loss, sale or destruction of any bicycle. 
(a)  When any bicycle which has been registered and licensed, as herein provided, is sold, or is otherwise disposed of, or destroyed, the licensee shall immediately surrender to the chief of police the registration card and the license plate issued therefor, with the name and address of the new owner, if any, written on the face of the registration card; and the chief of police shall immediately make proper endorsements on his records, retain the card and plate, and issue a new card and plate to the new owner. 
(b)  The number of any license surrendered as provided in this section shall not be reissued. 
(Code 1970, § 19.204; Code 1980, § 17-211)  
Sec. 90-495. - Loss of license plate. 
The licensee shall report immediately to the chief of police the loss or destruction of the license plate of the licensee, and the circumstances surrounding the loss or destruction thereof. With the approval of the chief of police, the city clerk shall issue a duplicate license plate upon payment of a fee of twenty-five cents ($0.25). 
(Ord. No. 77-42, § 1, 9-22-1977; Code 1980, § 17-212)  
Secs. 90-496—90-540. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - VEHICLE CONDITION AND EQUIPMENT 
 
Sec. 90-541. - Glass and mirrors. 
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a condition that the operator does not have a clear vision of all parts of the roadway essential to the safe operation of the vehicle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-247) 
State Law reference— Glass, mirrors and windshields, 625 ILCS 5/12-501 et seq.  
Sec. 90-542. - Nonskid devices. 
It shall be unlawful to operate upon any street any motor vehicle equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or nonflexible portion thereof comes into contact with the pavement, or roadway. 
(Code 1980, § 17-253)  
Sec. 90-543. - Driving unsafe vehicles prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any highway any vehicle or combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person or property, or which is not in conformance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 17-259)  
Sec. 90-544. - Unnecessary noise. 
It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise. 
(Code 1980, § 17-260)  
Secs. 90-545—90-580. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - VEHICLE LICENSE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Vehicle licenses, ILCS 5/8-11-4. 
 
Sec. 90-581. - Motor vehicle defined. 
As used in this article, the term "motor vehicle" shall mean every self-propelled device, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power. 
(Code 1980, § 17-272; Ord. of 10-25-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 90-582. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the city, or for any firm, association or corporation having its principal office or place of business in the city, to use, or to cause or permit any of his, her, their or its agents or employees to use, any motor vehicle in the transportation of persons or property or the conveyance of loads upon the street, avenues, or alleys of the city unless such motor vehicle is licensed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 17-273; Ord. of 10-25-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 90-583. - Application. 
Any person desiring a license for any motor vehicle as described in this article shall file an application therefor with the city clerk upon a form provided by him, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the description of the motor vehicle, and the state license number thereof, and such information as may be prescribed. Such license shall be issued upon the payment by the applicant of the required license fee hereinafter to the city clerk, and shall authorize the use of such motor vehicle within the city until the expiration of such license. 
(Code 1980, § 17-274; Ord. of 10-25-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 90-584. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee for each motor vehicle to be paid annually to the city clerk for the license required by this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  For all passenger motor vehicles, motor scooters, motor tricycles, motor bicycle vehicles, or motorcycles, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  For all senior citizens sixty-five (65) years of age or older on or before May 1, one (1) passenger vehicle per household, free of charge, provided, however, that said sticker is applied for and issued on or before May 31. Thereafter, the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be charged as a late [fee]. For the second vehicle, the fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be charged provided that the eligible senior citizen applies for and is issued said sticker on or before May 31. Thereafter the late fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) is charged. Any senior citizen purchasing a third sticker, or any subsequent stickers, shall be charged the regular fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) as found in section 90-584. Any stickers not purchased on or before May 31 shall be charged a late fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to the sticker fee. Proof of senior citizen status (sixty-five (65) years), as well as auto registration on which the complimentary sticker shall be utilized, may be required by the city clerk's office and the applicant shall provide such proof upon request. Said registration must be to a Calumet City address. 
(3)  For all motor trucks as follows:

(4)  For any transfer or duplicate of a vehicle license previously issued, the sum of three dollars ($3.00), provided that a portion of the old sticker indicating the number and old receipt is presented. 
(b)  Any person who is a disabled veteran and who is issued a "V" license plate registration for the State of Illinois for the current year and shall furnish the proper documentation to the city clerk of the issuance of said license plate, shall not pay a license fee for any passenger motor vehicle, motor scooter, motor tricycle, or motor bicycle, for which said "V" license plate has been issued; provided further that not more than one (1) such vehicle license may be issued to occupants of the same household. 
(c)  Any person who was in the Armed Forces of the United States of America and is a former prisoner of war and has been issued an AGO Form or DD-214 Form verifying their status as an ex-prisoner of war shall not pay a license fee for any passenger motor vehicle, motor scooter, motor tricycle, or motor bicycle vehicle; provided further that no more than one (1) such vehicle license may be issued to said person. 
(d)  An owner of an antique motor vehicle registered in the city shall not pay a license fee. Proof of ownership of an antique motor vehicle and proof that said vehicle has a state antique vehicle license plate must accompany the license fee application. The term "antique motor vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle or other vehicle twenty-five (25) years of age or older that the owner has obtained an antique vehicle license plate for from the State of Illinois. 
(e)  Any person who was in the Armed Forces of the United States of America, was honorably discharged, and has been issued a DD-214 Form verifying their status as an honorably discharged veteran, shall be entitled to a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) discount to be subtracted from the license fee charged for any passenger vehicle, motor scooter, motor tricycle, or motor bicycle vehicle. The twenty-five dollar ($25.00) discount will be allowed for only one (1) such vehicle license to be issued to said person. 
(Code 1980, § 17-275; Ord. of 10-25-1973, § 1; Ord. of 12-12-1974, § 1, Ord. No. 78-37, 9-28-1978; Ord. No. 80-26, § 1, 9-25-1980; Ord. No. 82-4, § 1, 3-11-1982; Ord. No. 84-22, § 1, 6-28-1984; Ord. No. 87-24, § 1, 11-12-1987; Ord. No. 92-15, § 1, 3-12-1992; Ord. No. 98-14, §§ 1—3, 4-9-1998; Ord. No. 05-52, § 1, 7-28-2005; Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 1-12-2006; Ord. No. 07-76, § 1, 7-12-2007; Ord. 12-6, § 2, 2-9-2012; Ord. No. 18-34, § 2, 7-12-2018)  
Sec. 90-585. - Time of payment; license year; proration of fee; schools using vehicle for certain educational purposes exempted. 
All licenses issued under this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  After April 30, 1992, the license period shall commence May 1 and end April 30. The license fee effective May 1, 1992, shall be due and payable in advance on or before May 31 of each fiscal year thereafter; provided that when such license is issued for less than six (6) months, such license fee shall be reduced fifty (50) percent if the vehicle was purchased on or after November 1 of the said year. 
(2)  All licenses issued hereunder shall be purchased on or before May 31 of said year, and if not paid by said date shall be subject to a late fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to the sticker fee, except as provided in section 90-584(a)(2). 
(3)  Provided, however, that any public, private or parochial schools for educational purposes, park districts or churches, shall be exempt from payment of a license fee for any motor vehicle, other than a passenger vehicle used for said school, park district or church purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 17-276; Ord. No. 78-38, § 1, 9-28-1978; Ord. No. 81-18, §§ 1, 2, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 81-39, § 1, 11-24-1981; Ord. No. 92-14, § 1, 3-12-1992; Ord. No. 98-14, § 4, 4-9-1998)  
Sec. 90-586. - Refund of fee. 
No refund for any license fee paid pursuant to this article shall be made except under the following conditions: 
(a)  Evidence satisfactory to the city council that a duplicate purchase of a license was made for the same motor vehicle; 
(b)  A request is made for refund on or before sixty (60) days of the due date of said license. 
(Code 1980, § 17-277; Ord. of 8-22-1974, § 1; Ord. of 4-10-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 79-21, § 1, 5-24-1979; Ord. No. 81-39, § 2, 11-24-1981)  
Sec. 90-587. - Tag. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of a license as provided under this article, the city clerk shall deliver to the applicant a gummed tag or sticker upon which shall be shown the name of the class to which the motor vehicle belongs and the year for which the license is issued. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the applicant to affix such gummed tag or sticker upon the windshield of the motor vehicle in the lower right hand corner thereof, or if there is no windshield, then in a conspicuous place upon the motor vehicle, where it can readily be seen. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle which is required to be licensed by the provisions of this article, to be used upon the streets, avenues, or alleys of the city unless such tag or sticker is attached thereto, within forty-five (45) days of the due date. Any person having paid a valid license fee and received a gummed tag or sticker pursuant to this article, shall be entitled to a reissuance of such gummed tag or sticker upon satisfactory evidence being submitted to the city clerk and payment of a one-dollar ($1.00) reissuance fee. 
(Code 1980, § 17-278; Ord. of 8-22-1974, § 2; Ord. No. 81-39, § 3, 11-24-1981)  
Secs. 90-588—90-599. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - RESIDENTIAL PERMIT PARKING 
 
Sec. 90-600. - Designation of residential permit parking zone. 
(a)  The city council may on its own initiative, or upon presentation of a petition in support of a residential permit parking zone signed by residents representing no less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the dwelling units within a proposed zone, designate certain streets where residential permit parking is authorized. 
(b)  Upon the designation of a residential permit parking zone, residential permit parking shall be in effect every day during the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-600.1. - Designation of residential permit parking school zone. 
(a)  The city council may on its own initiative, or upon presentation of a petition in support of a residential permit parking school zone signed by residents representing no less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the dwelling units within a proposed school zone, designate certain streets where residential permit parking is authorized. 
(b)  Upon the designation of a residential permit parking school zone, residential permit parking shall be in effect every day during the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
(c)  All regulations found throughout article IX shall also apply to residential permit parking school zones. References in this article to residential permit parking shall also apply to residential permit parking school zone. 
(Ord. No. 10-47, § 2, 9-22-2010)  
Sec. 90-601. - Residential permit parking sticker. 
(a)  The city clerk shall issue an annual "residential permit parking sticker" to every resident that resides in a residential permit parking zone whose vehicle displays a current city vehicle sticker and holds a valid state vehicle registration. 
(b)  Every residential permit parking sticker shall be affixed, in accordance with the instructions printed thereon and without the use of supplemental adhesives, at the lower right-hand corner of the inside of the glass portion of the windshield of a vehicle, directly above the city vehicle sticker. 
(c)  The residential permit parking sticker shall not guarantee or reserve any parking space, nor shall it exempt the holder from the observance of any traffic or parking regulation. 
(d)  The annual period for every residential permit parking sticker shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-602. - Visitor permit parking pass. 
(a)  The city shall issue one (1) "visitor permit parking pass" to every dwelling unit within a residential permit parking zone that qualifies for a residential permit parking sticker. A visitor permit parking pass is limited to the time that the person driving the visiting vehicle is actually in the dwelling unit or on the property being visited. 
(b)  The visitor permit parking pass shall be placed on the rearview mirror of the vehicle so the face of the pass may be seen through the windshield of the vehicle. 
(c)  The visitor permit parking pass shall not guarantee or reserve any parking space, nor shall it exempt the holder from the observance of any traffic or parking regulation. 
(d)  The annual period for every visitor permit parking pass shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-603. - One-day permit parking pass. 
(a)  A "one-day permit parking pass" may be issued to any resident within a residential permit parking zone for the use of nonresidents who are temporary visitors. A one-day permit parking pass may be purchased only in a group of ten (10) one-day permit parking passes. Any resident in a residential permit parking zone shall be limited to the purchase of one (1) group of ten (10) one-day permit parking passes per month. A one-day permit parking pass is limited to the time that a person driving the visiting vehicle is actually in the dwelling unit or on the property being visited. 
(b)  A one-day permit parking pass shall be placed on the rearview mirror of the vehicle so the face of the pass may be seen through the windshield of the vehicle. Before use of a one-day permit parking pass, it must be validated by printing the date and time of day legibly on its face in the space provided therein. 
(c)  A one-day permit parking pass shall not guarantee or reserve any parking space, nor shall it exempt the holder from the observance of any traffic or parking regulation. 
(d)  A one-day permit parking pass is defined as twenty-four (24) hours from the date and time indicated on the pass. An undated pass or a pass that fails to indicate a time of day will be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-604. - Zone designations—Residential permit parking zones. 
(a)  The following areas are hereby designated as residential permit parking zones and appropriate signs shall be posted clearly indicating such zones: 
Luella Avenue from Dolton Road to Harbor Avenue: Zone 1 
Superior Avenue from Stewart Avenue to Sibley Boulevard: Zone 3 
Madison Avenue from State Street to Stewart Avenue: Zone 4 
Freeland Avenue from Garfield Avenue to Sibley Boulevard: Zone 5 
Williams Street to 160th Place (from Arthur to Balmoral Avenue: Zone 6 
159th Street on the north side of the street from 32 159th Street westbound to Legion Drive. 
All of Forestdale Park. 
Legion Drive on both sides of the street northbound from Michigan City Road to Detroit Street. 
Michigan City Road on the north side of the street from Legion Drive to Wentworth Avenue. 
(b)  A residential permit parking zone shall be clearly indicated on every residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass and one-day permit parking pass. 
(c)  Parking in a residential permit parking zone shall be limited to vehicles displaying a valid permit parking sticker or pass displayed in the manner described in section 90-601, 90-602 and 90-603 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008; Ord. No. 08-53, § 2, 8-14-2008; Ord. No. 08-65, § 2, 9-22-2008; Ord. No. 10-47, § 3, 9-22-2010; Ord. No. 15-39, § 2, 9-10-2015)  
Sec. 90-604.1. - Zone designations—Residential permit parking school zone. 
(a)  The following areas are hereby designated as residential permit parking school zones and appropriate signs shall be posted clearly indicating such zones: 
Superior Avenue, Buffalo Avenue, Mackinaw Avenue and Greenbay Avenue from Pulaski Road to 153rd Street: Zone 1S 
Superior Avenue, Buffalo Avenue and Newell Avenue from 155th Street to 156th Street: Zone 2S 
(b)  A residential permit parking school zone shall be clearly indicated on every residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass and one-day permit parking pass. 
(c)  Parking in a residential permit parking school zone shall be limited to vehicles displaying a valid permit parking sticker or pass displayed in the manner described in sections 90-601, 90-602 and 90-603 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-47, § 4, 9-22-2010; Ord. No. 11-69, § 2, 12-8-2011)  
Sec. 90-605. - Signage. 
The city shall erect signs in every residential permit parking zone, which shall substantially read as follows: 
"Residential Permit Parking Only between the hours of 7:00 p.m.—6:00 a.m. Violators are subject to fine and towing fees." 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-606. - Fees. 
(a)  There is no fee for a residential permit parking sticker. 
(b)  There is no fee for a visitor permit parking pass. 
(c)  One-day permit parking passes shall be issued in groups of ten (10) for ten dollars ($10.00). 
(d)  If a residential permit parking zone is in effect at the dwelling unit of an owner with a disability who is using a restricted parking space created pursuant to section 90-317 of this Code, such owner shall be exempt from any fee set forth in paragraph (a) or (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-607. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to any service or delivery vehicle when used to provide services or to make deliveries to a dwelling unit within a residential parking permit zone, provided that the parking of such vehicle does not exceed the time the services or deliveries are being made. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-608. - Replacement. 
(a)  Replacement of residential permit parking sticker will be issued without cost upon receipt of an identifiable portion of the removed sticker and a receipt for a current city vehicle sticker. 
(b)  Replacement of any residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass or one-day permit parking pass which is lost or destroyed will be made at a cost of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-609. - Unlawful use of permit parking sticker or pass. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to affix, cause to be affixed or otherwise display any residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass or one-day permit parking pass to any vehicle other than the vehicle to which the sticker or pass was intended to be affixed or displayed at the time of issuance by the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than the city to sell, offer for sale, acquire for the purpose of sale or produce any residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass or one-day permit parking pass. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase any residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass or one-day permit parking pass from any person other than the city. 
(d)  Any misuse of a residential permit parking sticker, visitor permit parking pass or one-day permit parking pass shall render the same invalid and no sticker or pass shall be issued to the person or dwelling unit which originally held the same. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Sec. 90-610. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day such a violation continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. Every vehicle shall be subject to tow, at the owner's expense, by the city or any company retained or contracted by the city to perform towing services. 
(b)  Proceedings to enforce violations of this article may be initiated and conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the Municipal Code of the city providing for administrative adjudication of code violations or by any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 08-23(B), § 2, 4-3-2008)  
Secs. 90-611—90-619. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - OVERWEIGHT RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 90-620. - Definitions of words and phrases. 
Definition of words and phrases shall mean the following words and phrases when used in this Code shall, for the purpose of this Code, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this article, except when the context otherwise requires and except where another definition set forth in another section of this Code and applicable to that section or a designated part thereof is applicable. 
Axle load shall mean the total load transmitted to the road by all wheels whose centers may be included between two (2) parallel transverse vertical planes forty (40) inches apart extending across the full width of the vehicle. 
City shall mean the City of Calumet City. 
Commercial vehicle shall mean any vehicle operated for the transportation of persons or property in the furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for-hire or not-for-hire, but not including a commuter van, a vehicle used in a ride-sharing arrangement when being used for that purpose, or a recreational vehicle not being used commercially. 
Construction vehicle shall mean any vehicle over ten thousand (10,000) pounds actual weight; registered gross weight or GVWR that is required to comply with ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, §§ 12-712 and 12-713 on identification required to be displayed. 
Gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) shall mean the value specified by the manufacturer or manufacturers as the maximum, loaded weight of a single vehicle. The GVWR, of a combination of vehicles (commonly referred to as the "gross combination weight rating" or GCWR) is the GVWR of the power unit plus the GVWR of the towed unit or units. In the absence of a value specified by the manufacturer, GCWR is determined by adding the GVWR of the power unit and the total weight of the towed unit and any load on the unit. 
Gross weight shall mean the weight of a vehicle whether operated singly or in combination without load plus the weight of the load thereon. 
Highway shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
Implement of husbandry shall mean every vehicle designed and adapted exclusively for agricultural, horticultural, or livestock raising operations, including farm wagons, wagon trailers or like vehicles used in connection therewith, or for lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry. 
Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except for vehicles moved solely by human power and motorized wheelchairs. For this Act, motor vehicles are divided into two (2) divisions: 
First division: Those motor vehicles, which are designed for the carrying of not more than ten (10) persons. 
Second division: Those motor vehicles which are designed for carrying more than ten (10) persons, those motor vehicles designed or used for living quarters, those motor vehicles which are designed for pulling or carrying freight, cargo or implements of husbandry, and those motor vehicles of the first division remodeled for use and used as motor vehicles of the second division. 
Permit route shall mean the route authorized by the issuing authority with proper jurisdiction over the roadway(s) for which permission has been granted to move a vehicle or combination of vehicles that is in itself indivisible or carrying an indivisible load that exceeds normal dimensions or weight or a combination thereof. 
Semitrailer shall mean every vehicle without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle 
Tandem axles shall mean any two (2) or more single axles whose centers are more than forty (40) inches and not more than ninety-six (96) inches apart, measured to the nearest inch between extreme axles in the series, except as provided in Section 15-111 [625 ILCS 5/15-111] for special hauling vehicles. 
Trailer shall mean every vehicle without motive power in operation, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. 
Truck tractor shall mean every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
(Ord. No. 11-43, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Sec 90-621. - Overweight and/or overdimension vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be in control of, to drive, to park, or move on, upon or across or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be parked, driven, or moved upon or across, any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the city, any vehicle or combination of vehicles exceeding the size and weight limitations stated in the ILCS ch. 625, Act 5, § 15-102 (width), ILCS ch. 625, Act, § 15-103 (height), ILCS ch. 625, Act 5, § 15407 (length), and ILCS ch. 625, Act 5, § 1.5-111 (weight). 
(b)  Size and weights limitations while operating on city streets shall not apply to fire apparatus or equipment for snow or ice removal operations owned or operated by or for any governmental body or to implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a combination in the furtherance of a farm or agricultural endeavor and to any vehicle or combination of vehicles operating under the terms of a valid oversize and/or dimension permit issued by the city under the authority of § 70.058 hereof. 
(c)  Where lower size and weight limits or other restrictions are imposed by ordinance under authority of ILCS ch. 625, Act 5, §§ 15411, 15-316 and 15-317, and signs indicating such limitations or restrictions are posted, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle or combination of vehicles in excess of such size or weight limitations or in violation of such restrictions. 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle or combination of vehicles is operated in violation of this section, the owner and/or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either or both the owner and. driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 11-43, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Sec 90-622. - Permits for overweight and/or overdimension vehicles. 
(a)  A permit shall be required for the movement of any vehicle or combination of vehicles with a nondivisible load on roadways and bridges within the jurisdiction of the city which exceeds the dimensions and weights permitted for the particular roadways to be traversed whether they be non-designated or designated roadways, 
(b)  The city with respect to any street or highway under its jurisdiction may upon application to the Calumet City Police Department on forms provided by the police department and good cause being shown therefore issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified in § 70.057. The applicant shall furnish the following information in the special permit application: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle. 
(2)  Applicant's name. 
(3)  Type of permit request whether it be for a single trip, round trip, or multiple routine. 
(4)  The description and registration (or the Illinois Department of Transportation's (IDOT) registration number or classification) of the power unit. 
(5)  Description of the object or vehicle to be moved. 
(6)  The number of axles of the vehicle or combination of vehicles. 
(7)  The maximum axle weights of all single, tandem or series axles. 
(8)  Maximum gross weight of the vehicle. 
(9)  The maximum width, length and height of the vehicle and load. 
(10)  Requested routing over city streets to and from a specific location. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  A one-way or single trip movement shall mean one (1) move from the point of origin to the point of destination. Any additional stops between the point of origin and the point of destination are expressly prohibited. Single trip permits are effective for seven (7) consecutive days from the date of issuance unless otherwise directed by the police department. 
(2)  Round trip movement shall mean two (2) trips over the same route in opposite directions. Round trip permits are effective for fourteen (14) consecutive days from the date of issuance. 
(3)  Multiple moves shall mean those in such close proximity to each other in distance or in time that the police department would consider incorporating two (2) or more permit moves within one (1) permit application. Multiple move permits when granted by the police department shall be for a period time not to exceed ninety (90) days from the date of issuance. 
(d)  The owner or his or her agent shall submit an application fee based on the below chart for a single routing which will be valid for seven (7) calendar days, round trip routing valid for fourteen (14) calendar days and multiple routings valid for a base period of three (3) months. Permits maybe issued for a maximum of four (4) consecutive permit periods (three hundred sixty-five (365) days) with the permit fee calculated in the appropriate multiples of the base three-month multiple trip permit. Permits are valid only for the date periods specified on the permit and for the specific vehicle, load and routing as established by the chief of police, or designee. No substitution of vehicle, load or routing is permitted without expressed written permission by chief of police, or his or her designee and the permit must be earned in the vehicle to which the permit applies. 
Permit Size—Width (with load) 	Fee 
	Single Trip 	Round Trip 	Multiple 
Up to 100,000 pounds 	50 	75 	150 
100,001—120,000 	75 	100 	200 
120,001—150,000 	100 	125 	— 
Over 150,000 	100* 	125* 	— 
 
*Plus necessary and appropriate administrative, engineering and road damage fees.

	Single Trip 	Round Trip 	Multiple

Note: If a vehicle requires a permit due to multiple weigh and/or dimension issues, the total fee will be based on the largest individual weight or dimension factor only 
(e)  The chief of police or designee is authorized to approve the application for approved routes. Upon approval and payment of all required fees, the police department shall issue a permit allowing passage of the oversize and/or overweight vehicles over city streets. The permit shall be specific and contain: 
(1)  Permit number. 
(2)  The dates the permit is valid. 
(3)  Whether the permit is for single, round or multiple trip routing. 
(4)  The description of object or vehicle to be moved. 
(5)  Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length and height. 
(6)  The authorized routing over city streets including the origin and termination point within the city. 
(7)  The fee paid. 
(8)  The date and signature of the chief of police or his or her designee. 
(9)  In addition, the permit will specify general conditions that the permittee must comply with that are consistent and reasonable for the protection of the general public and city streets. A copy of all permits issued will be provided to the chief of police or designee for informational purposes. 
(f)  It is the duty of the permittee to read and familiarize himself or herself with the permit provisions upon receipt. Undertaking of the permit move is deemed prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit and that: 
(1)  The permittee is in compliance with all operation requirements; 
(2)  All dimension and weight limitations specified in the permit will not be exceeded; 
(3)  All operation, registration and license requirements have been complied with; 
(4)  All financial responsibilities, obligations and other legal requirements have been met; and 
(5)  The permittee assumes all responsibility for injury or damage to persons or to public or private property, including his or her own, or to the object being transported, caused directly or indirectly by the transportation or movement of vehicles and objects authorized under the permit. He or she agrees to hold the city harmless from all suits, claims, damages, or proceedings of any kind and to indemnify the city for any claim it may be required to pay arising from the movement. 
(g)  The permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies at all times while operating on streets within the city and shall be exhibited upon demand to any law enforcement officer, police officer or authorized official of the city. 
(h)  Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a city permit whether it be by size, weight or general provisions, and either or both the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty and either or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 11-43, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Sec 90-623. - Vehicles prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  As provided under the authority of LLCS ch. 625, Act 5, § 15-111 and 15-316, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle upon any street where the operation of that vehicle is prohibited by ordinance and where signs of such prohibition are posted. Vehicles operating under the authority of ILCS ch. 625, Act 5, § 15-111 or 15-316 while utilizing city streets under "reasonable access" rules will be considered in violation of this section if they are not utilizing the most direct route to points of loading and unloading. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park a commercial motor vehicle on a residential street while said truck is running between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following day. 
(Ord. No. 11-43, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Sec 90-624. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who or which violates, disobeys, neglects, fails to comply with or resists enforcement of the provisions of this article will be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each calendar day a violation occurs. 
In addition to seeking a fine, as herein above provided, the city attorney may institute any proper action in the name of the City of Calumet City to enjoin the violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-43, § 2, 7-28-2011)  
Chapter 94 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; electrical code, § 14-131 et seq.; community development, ch. 18; environment, ch. 26; floods, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; mobile home parks, ch. 58; planning, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; municipal utility tax, § 82-431 et seq.; telecommunications, ch. 86. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 94-1. - Water and sewer facilities required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any building for habitation on any lot or parcel of land unless an improved highway, road, street, or way meeting the requirements of the city council for public service facilities improved with water mains and sanitary sewers is provided to serve said lot or parcel of land. 
(b)  No building hereinafter constructed after August 1967 shall be used for habitation unless such building is on a lot or parcel of land adjoining an improved highway, road, street or way for public service facilities improved with water mains and sanitary sewers servicing said lot or parcel of land. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued for the construction of any building for habitation unless the plans and specifications therefor comply with the provisions of this section. Provided, however, that any building which when constructed shall not exceed seventy-two (72) square feet shall only be issued a permit for construction on a building site which consists of not less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet, exclusive of any existing buildings or structures on said building site, and in accordance with applicable zoning regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 22-6; Ord. of 6-24-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 77-44, § 1, 11-10-1977)  
Sec. 94-2. - Incorporation of Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago Sewage and Waste Control Regulations. 
Any construction, operation or maintenance of a sanitary or stormwater infrastructure element must comply with the provisions set forth herein in this chapter and any ordinance relating to certain activities applicable to the construction, operation or maintenance of a sanitary or stormwater infrastructure element imposed by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, are hereby adopted, by reference, by and for the city, as if fully set forth in this chapter, including those regulations set forth in the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago Sewer Permit Ordinance, Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance and Sewage and Waste Control Ordinance, as from time to time supplemented and amended. 
(Ord. No. 06-83, § 2, 10-26-2006)  
Secs. 94-3—94-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SEWER AND WATER DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Departments, § 2-566 et seq. 
 
Sec. 94-31. - Department established. 
There is hereby established the department of sewers and water, an executive department of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-1)  
Sec. 94-32. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the sewer and water department shall be from February 1 to January 31; provided, however, that the operations of the department shall be audited for the twelve-month period, beginning May 1 and ending April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1980, § 22-1.1; Ord. of 7-24-1975, § 1)  
Sec. 94-33. - Water superintendent—Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of water superintendent, an executive office of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-2; Ord. of 7-26-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 94-34. - Same—Appointment. 
The water superintendent shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 22-3; Ord. of 7-26-1973, § 1) 
State Law reference— Appointment of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5.  
Sec. 94-35. - Same—Duties. 
The water superintendent shall supervise the city water system and all appurtenances thereto. He shall supervise all connections with the city water system and enforce the provisions of this Code relating to air conditioners and shall read or cause to be read all the water meters connected to the city water system. He shall supervise the city sewer system and all appurtenances thereto and supervise all connections with the city sewer system. He shall maintain and repair all sewer lines which are a part of the city sewer system. 
(Code 1980, § 22-4; Ord. of 7-26-1973, § 1)  
Sec. 94-36. - Same—Employees. 
All employees in the sewer and water department shall perform their duties as directed by the water superintendent. 
(Code 1980, § 22-5; Ord. of 7-26-1973, § 1)  
Secs. 94-37—94-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION OF WATER AND SEWER BILLS 
 
Sec. 94-71. - Bills; penalty for late payment; persons liable. 
Bills for water and sewer services shall be rendered monthly and shall be delinquent after the due date stated on the bill. In the event of failure to pay the bill by the due date, a late fee of ten (10) percent of the amount of the bill shall be added to the bill five (5) calendar days after said due date. Accounts not paid by the due date stated on the bills shall be designated for disconnection. When designated for disconnection, a red tag notice of disconnection will be mailed to single-family residences. When designated for disconnection, a red tag notice will be mailed to and posted upon multi-family residences and commercial properties. If water is disconnected, a fifty dollar ($50.00) turn-on fee will be assessed for reconnection. The owner will be held liable to the city, regardless of any separate private agreements that the owner may maintain with a third-party liability. 
(Code 1980, § 22-77; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 7; Ord. No. 78-36, § 1, 9-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-49, § 2, 8-6-1998; Ord. No. 07-84, § 1, 8-9-2007; Ord. No. 14-48, § 3, 10-23-2014; Ord. No. 14-68, § 2, 12-29-2014; Ord. No. 15-45, § 2, 12-29-2014; Ord. No. 17-12, § 2, 4-27-2017)  
Sec. 94-72. - Lien; notice of delinquency. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for water and sewer service remains unpaid sixty (60) days after it has been rendered the city comptroller shall file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water and sewer subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  If the consumer of water and sewer services whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the city comptroller has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the city comptroller, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of sixty (60) days after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The failure of the city comptroller to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water and sewer bills. 
(Code 1980, § 22-78; Ord. No. 98-49, § 2, 8-6-1998; Ord. No. 18-48, § 3, 8-23-2018)  
Sec. 94-73. - Foreclosure of lien. 
Property subject to a lien for unpaid water and sewer charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the city. The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the city in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the bill for water and sewer has remained unpaid sixty (60) days after it has been rendered. 
(Code 1980, § 22-79; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 8-6-1998)  
Sec. 94-74. - Nonpayment of water and sewer bills. 
(a)  Referral of certain delinquent bills to collection agency. The public utilities committee may periodically refer to the city council certain delinquent water and sewer bills with the recommendation that they be referred to a collection agency previously approved by the city council. 
(b)  Additional charge for bills referred to agency. Any delinquent water and sewer bill referred to a collection agency shall be assessed a charge of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) or ten (10) percent of the amount of the delinquent bill, whichever is greater. 
(c)  Service charge on returned checks. Any water and sewer user who tenders a check to the city in payment of a water and sewer bill, which check is returned to the city unpaid, shall be assessed a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) service charge. If satisfactory evidence is furnished to the water department that the nonpayment was due to bank error, then said service charge fee may be waived. 
(Code 1980, § 22-80; Ord. No. 81-37, § 1, 11-21-1981; Ord. No. 91-29, § 2, 7-25-1991; Ord. No. 98-49, § 2, 8-6-1998; Ord. No. 14-68, § 2, 12-29-2014; Ord. No. 15-45, § 2, 12-29-2014)  
Secs. 94-75—94-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 94-101. - Discharge of waste water into city storm sewers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to discharge sanitary and industrial waste water into any storm sewer in the city. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Code 1980, § 22-24; Ord. No. 84-42, §§ 1, 2, 12-13-1984)  
Secs. 94-102—94-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 94-121. - Use required. 
All construction begun after the effective date of this Code shall have connections with the city's sanitary sewerage system. 
(Code 1980, § 22-18)  
Sec. 94-122. - Pipe bedding. 
In connection with all sewer construction after February 11, 1971, pipe beddings shall be installed on all sewer construction, including building service sewers and house connections. 
(Code 1980, § 22-19; Ord. of 2-11-1971, § 1)  
Sec. 94-123. - Special requirements for combined sewers. 
In combined sewer areas, as designated on the Chicago Metropolitan Sanitary District maps, the following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  Separation. There shall be complete separation of sewers within the property lines. 
(2)  Detention. Detention shall be provided and/or permanent constrictions shall be built on the storm sewer system to control the flow into the existing combined system in accordance with regulations promulgated by the street and alley commissioner. 
(3)  Downspouts. All downspouts or roof drains shall discharge onto the ground or be connected to storm or combined sewer. No downspouts or roof drains shall be connected to the sanitary sewers. 
(4)  Footing drains. Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps, and discharge shall be made into storm sewers, combined sewers or drainage ditches. No footing drains or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1980, § 22-20; Ord. of 2-11-1971, § 2)  
Sec. 94-124. - Overhead sewer and sump pumps. 
(a)  All house sewers and sewers installed in any building constructed after January 1, 1965, shall be "overhead" sewers and shall be located and installed above the grade of existing adjoining main sewers; provided, however, that this restriction shall not apply to house sewers installed in buildings without basements, constructed above ground level in which all sewer installations are located above the grade of existing, adjoining main sewers. 
(b)  All buildings constructed after January 1, 1965, with basements shall be provided with a sump pump, or other device, for the removal of basement drainage. 
(Code 1980, § 22-21; Ord. of 11-12-1964, § 1)  
Sec. 94-125. - Compliance as prerequisite to permits. 
No sewer or construction permit shall be issued unless the terms and provisions of this article are complied with. 
(Code 1980, § 22-22; Ord. of 2-11-1971, § 3)  
Sec. 94-126. - Connections to property outside of city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to tap into the sewer system of the city to service any property which is not located within the city. Any person, firm or corporation not within the corporate limits of the city may be granted permission by the city council to tap into the sewer system of the city upon annexation to the city. Any person, firm or corporation tapped into the sewer lines of the city to service property not within the corporate limits of the city shall either disconnect the sewer tie-in immediately or shall pay a tap-in fee and a service user fee as set by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 22-23; Ord. No. 78-57, § 1, 12-14-1978)  
Secs. 94-127—94-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WATER SYSTEM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 94-161. - Liability of city. 
All connections and water applied for under this article and all the water used hereunder, shall be upon the expressed condition that the city shall not be liable, nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or appurtenances connected with the system, or plant, any part or portion of said plant, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery, or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals. 
(Code 1980, § 22-42; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 6)  
Sec. 94-162. - Rules and regulations. 
The following rules and regulations for the consumers of water and plumbers are hereby adopted and established: 
(1)  No water shall be furnished or supplied to any consumer for any purpose whatsoever, until such consumer shall make application therefor. Such application shall state the location of the premises to be served and the use to which the water will be put. 
(2)  No water consumer may supply water to other families or allow them to take it, except for use on the premises and for the purposes specified in the application, or after water is introduced into any building or upon any premises for alteration, repairs, extensions or attachments without a written permit therefor to be issued by the mayor and/or water superintendent. 
(3)  The city reserves the right to shut off water at any time in the mains for the purpose of repairing, cleaning, making connections with or extensions to same, or for the concentrating of water in any part of the city in case of fire; and for restricting the use of the water in case of deficiency in supply. No claim shall be made against the city by reason of the breaking of any service pipe or service cock, or damage arising from shutting off of water for repairing any part of the water system, or from failure of the water supply, or by increasing the water pressure at any time, or from concentration or restricted use of water as above. 
(Code 1980, § 22-43; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 9)  
Sec. 94-163. - Application; turning on water; fee. 
(a)  No water service shall be turned on for use on or in any premises until an application therefor in writing has been made for that purpose and filed with the water superintendent stating the purpose for which the water is to be used. 
(b)  Each applicant for connection to the water system shall pay a service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the cost of making each connection; in addition, he shall deposit with his application the following sum pertaining to the premises for which application is made: 
(1)  Residents and tenants, per account ..... $50.00 
(2)  Taverns, laundromats, car washes, restaurants, and industrial, per account ..... 100.00 
(3)  All other businesses, per account ..... 50.00 
Such deposit shall be held by the city as security for the payment of water used by the applicant and may be so applied when any default is made in the payment of a water bill; provided, however, that any single-family premises occupied by the owner thereof, shall not be required to pay a security deposit in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
Upon sale of property, the owner will be entitled to a refund of one-half (½) of the security deposit. The other one-half (½) of the security deposit will be applied to pay the administrative cost incurred by the city with respect to the sale. 
(Code 1980, § 22-34; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 2; Ord. No. 77-2, § 1, 1-27-1977; Ord. No. 78-19, § 1, 6-8-1978; Ord. No. 11-47, § 2, 8-11-2011; Ord. No. 14-68, § 2, 12-29-2014; Ord. No. 15-45, § 2, 12-29-2014)  
Sec. 94-164. - Construction uses. 
Persons desiring to use city water for building or construction purposes shall make application therefor in writing and file the same in the office of the water superintendent on a form prescribed for that purpose. Upon a permit being granted (permits shall be issued in writing and signed by the mayor and/or water superintendent), the service pipe shall be carried at the expense of the applicant to the inside of the curb line, where a service cock and meter shall be placed, with pipe leading to the surface, and a faucet placed at the end thereof above said surface. When the building or construction work is completed, the faucet and meter shall be removed and the water shut off, unless permanent connection hereunder is made. Charges for the use and connections shall be prescribed by the city council as follows: 
(1)  Sewer tap-in fee ..... $100.00 
(2)  Water tap-in fee ..... 100.00 
(3)  Construction water use ..... 100.00 
(Code 1980, § 22-35; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 8; Ord. No. 88-9, § 1, 6-10-1988; Ord. No. 91-29, § 1, 7-25-1991)  
Sec. 94-165. - Plumbing. 
No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the provisions of this Code relating thereto; provided that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 22-36)  
Sec. 94-166. - Obstructing or tampering with water system. 
(a)  No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the water system, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article within twelve (12) feet of the same, or so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department in reaching the same. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system, reservoir or plant, or any main hydrant, service pipe, shut-off box, public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the water system, or plant, or to cause, suffer or permit any of aforementioned things to be done. Any person who shall perform any act in violation of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, in addition to the penalty for violations of this Code, be liable for the actual damage done or caused. 
(Code 1980, § 22-40; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 4)  
Sec. 94-167. - Turning on by unauthorized person. 
No person not duly authorized shall turn the water on at any fire hydrant or service cock, or use water therefrom when so turned on, and the persons so using or wasting water in such unlawful manner shall be liable to pay for the same. 
(Code 1980, § 22-41; Ord. of 11-29-1965, § 5)  
Sec. 94-168. - Shutting off.
